65 cL clear bottle. Pours clear and almost golden yellow with a diminished white head. Cornish and light acidic nose. Cardboardish and mild sweetend flavoured. Ends mild sweet and cornish.

(Bottle 65 cl) Courtesy of madsberg. Pours a clear golden with a rough white head. A little aroma hops in the nose and something resembling chicory that for some reason I often detect in cheap ass Lagers. Medium body with sweet malts and not to forget loads of brewing cereal - rice I suppose. A somewhat chemical edge with some cardboard as well. Subdued bitterness. 201008

Kalyani Black Label Premium Lager Beer. Bottle. [Tasting @ Papsoe 20-10-2008] Small bubbly white head that mostly diminished. Spare display of lacework. Clear yellow color. Aroma of fresh grass, mild floral, hint of hay and corn like. Over the palate came distinctive metallic, corn and rice like in the feel. Almost chemical like. Light to medium bodied with a sparkling carbonation and mild dry texture. Light bitter and sweet flavor. Light bitter dry finish.

Bottle bought in Ooty in Tamil Nadu. Golden coloured. Clear. Dense off white head. Lots of carbonation. Hay and grains in the aroma. Quite distinct. Flavour is a bit citric and dry and has grainy notes. Hay again. Is quite thin bodied and is dry. Ends on a very light bitter note, but sweetness is the dominant factor. Hmmm. Still have to stick to my Kingfisher I guess.

SO far our favorite beer available in Delhi. Lacks the bitter aftertaste of just about every other beer available here. It�s a much better flavor for real beer drinkers than Haywards 500, a malt liquor of the worst order. It�s still kinda sad that this is the product of the same brewery that makes Newcastle. I�d kill for a Newcastle here in Delhi, but I�ll drink this for now. If you are here, look for Black Label before the other high octane liquors
A: Clear gold with a small white head N: Pale malt T: Very mild some malt and bitterness P: Thin O: Standard light lager

0,5l from can in Serengeti National Park. clear golden color, small white head. Smells tobacco, ripe fruits, bit citric, earthy. ok smell. Medium body, soft carbonation, slick mouthfeel. Tastes earthy, spices, peppery, tobacco, some molasses like notes. Finishes lightly bitter with notes of spices, earthy and peppery notes, decent overall 6, 3, 5, 2, 9

2019-01-17. Crisp body, quick head. Aroma is mild, very lightly stale cereal malt. Flavour of cereally malt. Average to light bodied palate, soft carbonation. Better than expected but quite boring. 5/3/5/3/10 Bottle shared by fiulijn at mcberko's.
Courtesy of Maureen Pale blond colour. Trying this one side to side with Kilimanjaro, and this one is actually drinkable.
375ml bottle at Matt's. Appearence: clear golden Aroma: caramel malt and lagery hops Taste: similar almost with no bitterness Overall: total watery meh

375ml bottle @ Matt's. Pours a clear light golden colour with a small white head. Nose is skunky and vegetal. Flavour is quite vegetal, light cabbage. Light bodied, mild carbonation, and a mild sweetness. Meh.
Sweet pale malts. Clear gold with a decent white head. Sweet pale malts and not much else.

375mL bottle, pours a clear pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is very skunky, with lots of skunky, herbal notes, and vegetables. Flavour is quite vegetal, with skunky cabbage, cereal, and straw. Vegetal and skunky. Shit.
Can at Zanzibar hotel. Light yellow colour with big white head, aroma of malt, taste of malt. Sweet and watery.

Bottle. Light golden, average and mostly diminishing head. Moderate, malty - some corn and lightly sweetish - sweetish aroma, light cardboard and vegetable hoppyness. Body is light, malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish - sweetish flavor, light cardboard and vegetable hoppyness, faint alcohol. Finish is short, malty - grainy and lightly sweetish, light cardboard and vegetable hoppyness, faint alcohol. Grainy and thin lager.

Name: Shenanigan Stout Date: 04/27/2006 Mode: Draft, Nitro Source: Brewpub black, thin fine brown head, big roasted malt aroma and flavor, creamy body, light roasted malt bitterness in the finish that comes across as a coffee character, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

On tap at the brewpub on 4/27/06: Pours an opaque black with a dense, pillowy nitro tan head. Lightly sweet and roasty dark chocolate aroma. Body starts with a nice dark caramel sweetness balanced with a good touch of bittering hops. Finishes drier, roasty, and dark chocolatey. A good stout.

Draft @ Bo�s: Nitro pour. Very dark brown color with a tan head and cascade. Close to opaque. Light roasty aroma with notes of chocolate and dark fruits. The flavor was sweet and roasty. Chocolate found in the flavor as well. Hop bitterness on the finish.

On tap: Nice mocha aroma with light coffee. Rather malty aroma. Dark brown, virtually black with a tan head. Nice lacing. Malty chocolate up front with roasted coffee coming in the finish. Expected the house sour taste but didn�t get one. Nice creamy mouthfeel. Best of their "everyday" beers.

Draft @ brewpub. Maybe this place doesn�t do enough volume to brew a beer like this. This stuff tasted too much like butterscoth. Maybe the lines are bad. I just hope this isn�t what it�s supposed to be. Some chocolate and coffee flavors but something is off, sour.

Hmm, looks like a little Guinness with a solid creamy head. If you put your nose real close to that head you can get a faint whiff of roasted barley, so faint that no roastiness shows up in the flavour profile. Instead you get cherries and bark (don't tell me you've never chewed on green bark?). needs some balance desperately, either from hops or roasty-bitterness.

I was last at Bo's during the fall and then the seasonal fest, their "anniversary" saison, and a fine porter rocked my world. This time I was disappointed, particularly by this seasonal which is hard and cidery as all get out with bitter hop edges that don't seem to belong.
Minimal head, light amber body. Skunky aroma, some earthy hoppiness. Taste is minimally skunky, medium body, otherwise detectable but non-descript malts and hops.

Nice amber color, generous off white head and decent lace. Nose is malt, floral tones and quite clean. Start is slightly sweet, the middle is light, nice hop presence at the finish, moderate carbonation and a touch dry and acidic, quite a drinkable beer.
Copper with medium tan head, nice lacing. Aroma is very malty, mild sweet, caramel. Taste is malty, slightly roasty, finishes moderately bitter. Dry.

Had this on tap while celebrating at the converted �Varsity Club� prior to the Fiesta Bowl in Tempe - GO BUCKS!! It was nice having access to the �Real Bar� in the back while nearly everyone else was drinking the AB canned shit in the rear; and was probably 99% of the reason I ended up totally tanked that night. Refreshing nose of warm spices and flowers. This brew is brown with a creamy off white head that is mostly diminishing. The flavor is sour and bitter with a long bitter finish and a moderate to heavy level of acidity. The medium body is dry and feels very astringent at the finish. This was the best of the Bandersnatch�s brews that I sampled.

Amber in color, nice frothy white head and sheets of lace. The aroma of hops is noticeable, but malt steals the day. Front is sweet, the top relatively light, the finish is crisp and clean with a noticeable hop presence, carbonation is moderate. Another quite quaffable beer.
Opaque black color. Full tan head. Sweet, malty aroma. With coffe notes. Flavor and mouthfeel is very creamy. Body could stand to be a bit "fuller". Overall very good.
(nitro?) Creamy tan head with solid black body. Aroma is roasty coffee, moderately sweet. Taste is very creamy, milked coffee, bitter, minimally sweet.

Deep brown to black, head is creamy chocolate brown, the lace generous. Toasted grains, caramel, coffee all swirl around in the nose. Malt sweet start, medium to full top, toasted malt finish, somewhat dry and nice hop presence also noted. Light to medium carbonation, a quite good stout.
Very dark in color, with a big head. Very much chocolate in the aroma and taste, more than in a standard Irish Stout. Very good!

A fine representation of an Irish Stout with a twist. Large almost brown head. Opaque black color. Strong roasted aroma. Choclatey flavors intermingled with a hint of coffee. The twist at the end is a pretty big blast of hops. Not usually a fan of hops, But this was acceptable, even enjoyable.
Good Irish Stout. Large head. Roasted, chocolately aroma. Nice full body. Dry finish with a slight bitterness.

Black in color, large chocolate head and sheets of lace upon the glass. Strong coffee tones and burnt grains in the nose, sweet, hints of chocolate also present. Nice malt sweet start, full top, the finish is dry, light to medium carbonation, pleasant hop finish and a all around good stout.

Golden with a slightly off-white head that disappears completely.. Grapes, elderberry, wild honey, grains, ginger ale, citrus, floral and resin tones. Very slight bitterness, light to medium sweetness, light sourness. Light body, soft carbonation, astringent dry, slightly bitter finish. For a Pils the fruity-flowery aroma is remarkable, but very lacking in all other departments unfortunately.

500ml can (Random K�penick kebaberie, Berlin) Smells like an LA with a weetabixy graininess. Light fizzy appearance, gold, big head. Palate equally fizzy, you can taste the carbonic acid. Some slightly extracty noble hop bitterbess, otherwise just a typical german pale lager. Finish has a bit of a metallic bite. Dullish, but OKish.
0,5 l Dose. Als von Raven Pilsener (Brauerei Braunschweig). Goldgelbes Bier, kaum Schaum. Etwas scharf in der Nase, vom Geschmack dann ein Standardpils mit einem leicht w�ssrigen Abgang.

500ml can (random petrol station, Berlin). Straight from the can as a street-tick in Berlin. Clear golden color (sacrifice to the drains god). Watery malty aroma. Just a simple lager with nothing nasty chemicals in it. No funky side taste. Boring and bland, but drinkable.

Dose, immer nur Dose aus der Tankstelle. Das war fr�her, ich gebs zu. Gechmacklich f�rchterlich. Ich sehe hier einige gute Bewertungen, sollte ich es also noch mal probieren? Da st�ubt sich alles in mir...

Bottle on the train from Eutin to Hamburg, 19/07/15. Clear light golden with a decent off white cap. Nose is pale malt, grain, light cereal, straw. Taste comprises pale malt, light bread, lemon tinge, straw. Medium bodied, light spritzy carbonation, semi drying close. So so pils.
50cl can from local gas station, L�beck. Pale golden color, thin white head. Citrusy, light grainy aroma. Flavor has sweetness, malt, light hints of melon. Papery. Poor stuff.
Knackig frisch und mit einer feinen herben Note gesegnet. Dahinter sch�n im Gras, etwas Heu und ebensoviel Brot. Kein Klassiker der Braukunst, daf�r aber klassisch in seinem Wesen. Nicht schlecht.

Can bought at a corner shop in Hamburg. The beer has got a clear golden colour with a steady head and medium body. Aroma of hops and malt. Taste of hops, malt, citrus fruits and grass. Refreshing and drinkable.

Bottle, 0.50l. Clear pale golden color with large frothy white head and sparkling appearance. Aroma is grassy, dusty, worty and a bit skunky. Taste starts with mild malt, follows grassy sour, mouthfeel is a bit spicy, while finish is mild bitter. Light body, thin texture and average carbonation in palate. Watery disgrace...

A pale blonde lager with a thick collapsing lacing white head. In aroma, light Rice adjunct malt with light grassy German hops, light mineral notes, so-so. In mouth, a refreshing lager with light overtones of nail polish remover.. This must be bad when it warms up. Bottle at CIP lounge at MDL.

Yellow beer with big bubbles. Minimal head. Smells grainy, maybe some sour apple. Medium body...for the world�s most feeble-bodied beer style. Grainy taste with low bitterness, but more than Myanmar Beer thank god.

660ml bottle in Bagan, Myanmar. Pours a clear amber gold with a thin white head. Aroma: Caramel malt and earthy aroma. Taste: Malts dominate. Mild caramel/brown sugar flavour from the malts. Mild corn/corn syrup flavour. Mild sweetness. Mildly bitter. Moderate carbonation. Not overly flavoursome, but pretty easy drinking. Probably was my favourite of the beers available in Myanmar.

Straight from the bottle. Typical sweetness with low hops, some corniness. You�d think there�d be a taste for bitter beers here as there�s more bitterness in the food than most cuisines... probably some law on beer bitterness to protect a general�s business interests. I do prefer this over Myanmar beer.

Tasted 30/12/2016. Bottle in Mandalay. BB 04082017. Poured a crystal clear golden amber with a 5mm bright white foamy head that diminished slowly to a very thin collar that laced poorly. Carbonation low, slow and fine. Aroma subtly of slightly sweet malt which is slightly stronger than other Myanmar lagers; no obvious hops. Taste subtly of slightly sweet malt that is slightly stronger than other Myanmar lagers; no real bitterness. Light body. Crisp and smooth with a short, slightly malty finish.
Bottle. Pours clear golden with fading white head. Aroma is light malty with bread and a bit skunky. Taste is light malty and sweet with moderate bitterness. Lightbodied and semi-sweet finish.

Draft at a beer station in Mandalay. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma of grain, light malt, light skunky and light metallic notes. Flavour is light sweet and bitter. Light bodied with moderate to high carbonation.
Backlog 2012, Bagan, bottle. Clear golden, foamy white head, corny nose, cardboard, sweet taste, watery mouthfeel, light bitter aftertaste. When hot quite refreshing...
Had this in a hotel room in Bagan. I am sorry to say this is the most horrible beer I�ve had in a while...skynku, off tastes and alcohol. Uek

I�m a touring bicyclist and inveterate beer drinker, so wherever I travel, I will drink the local brews. Occasionally, I�ll be more than happy to do so, but on the other hand it is a bit of a chore to get a few down and renew my energy after a hot sweaty day in the tropics. Mandalay proved to be such a chore. I mean, these SEAsian countries don�t grow barley OR hops, and they are often poor countries to boot... so how to produce beer from other agricultural products at a price impoverished peasants can afford? You get the idea, crap in, crap out, thus Mandalay lager.
Do you love toasted malt? You WOULD have liked this. Interesting combination of coffee/chocolate without the thickness of a stout. Unfortunate end to a brewery willing to blaze some uncommon trails.
Bottled. Very dark brown color with a big tan head. Aroma and flavor of caramel malt and a little roast. Thanks to Dogbrick for the trade.
Pours a dark black color with a thin tan head. Mild carbonation is apparent. Aroma is malty with a hint of coffee. The flavor matches with a malty, coffee and chocolate taste.
I love a good Schwarzbier and this is a decent attempt. Nice roasted flavor, not as rich as a stout, obviously, with a decent caramel undertone. Drinkable, though a bit watery.

On draught at the Geisen Haus in Canton, OH. The server was unaware that Blimp City has gone out of business. This is under the label of "house dark" but it is definitely the Black Ale. Pours a flat black color with a thin light beige head. Mild carbonation is apparent. Aroma of malt with some caramel. Flavor has a lightly fizzy feel and tastes of malt, coffee, and caramel. Finish is thin and sweet with a touch of chocolate. Not outstanding but still a shame to see it go.
The aroma was malty sweet...definite chocolate and coffee throughout. The flavor was even fuller, with sweetness all around. My only complaint is that it does seem a little thin. Great brew!
Almost opaque, faint roasted malty aroma with a light tan head. Just a little on the thin and watery side. I would like to try it on tap.
prickly carbonation. nice roasted malty finish. it is missing something though - the initial swallow is a bit thin, maybe needs more body. not bad.

Bottle. Clear dark gold with quite the white head. Belgian lacing. Aroma of apples, honey, grains, yeast and spicy hops. Taste dto plus some citrus fruits, bread and grains. Some alcoholic warmth. Moderate bitterness. Dry. Strong carbonation. Nice.
On tap. Grand Place Brussels. Clear golden amber. Lacy whitish head. Light Belgian yeast aroma. Weak taste of not much. Light bodied.
On tap. Pours amber color, white head. Aroma of malt, yeast, sugary. Taste is medium sweet, lightly bitter, malty, caramel.
07.10.2019. On tap at Le jardin de Nicolas, Brussel. Golden colour with white head. Clear. Sweet malty with white head. Light citrus and banana.

Pours orange with an off white head. The nose is predominantly yeast, apple and grain. In fact, strongly grainy to bready, with some indistinct banana/cream esters. In mouth, similar, with the typical Belgian yeasty bread flavour, but with a weak and metallic finish. Dry, mild and oily. It doesn't quite reach the spot.

Flasche 0,33l: Kr�ftiges Gold, glasklar, feinperlig, kr�ftiger stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; sehr frische + sehr fruchtige Nase, frische Hopfennoten, helle/exotische Fr�chte, malzig-fruchtige S��e, Malz, Getreide, Karamell, Honig, kr�ftige Hefearomen, gr�ne Bananen; frischer + fruchtiger K�rper, angenehme S��e, Malz, Getreide, cremig, sehr kr�ftige Kohlens�ure, dezente Hopfenaromen, leichte trockene Zitrusnoten, kr�ftige Hefearomen, leichte trockene W�rze; angenehmer w�rzig-trockener Nachgang
Light amber with a little haziness with a frothy head. Hoppy smell of bitter oranges and a rather bitter taste. Full body due to its generous carbonation. Sweet, honeylike aftertaste.

First tasted this at the Paisley Beer Festival in April 1986. Cask, handpump dispense. Black in colour with ruby highlights. Creamy white head. Strong aroma of roast grain and vinous fruit. Thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Dark malt complex gives a maltloaf base of sultanas, figs and maple syrup. Bitter hop resins add some dryness to the short aftertaste. The smooth finish is dry with hints of leather, liquorice and walnut. An excellent session porter.

Cask conditoned - gravity dispense - Peterborough BF. A black coloured porter. The aroma is slightly fudgy, and is on the sweet side with a dusting of chocolate. The taste is also a little chocolatey with some whiskey character. Also some grass late on. Quite different and quite intriguing. Good though!
Cask Handpump at Wetherspoons, Manchester 06/05/2002 Black coloured fruity and sweet with a slight roast malt finish.
Its happening all over the place and the sixties have started again. Fills the mouth with some flavour. Like a mild out of control.

Gravity, Reading Beer Festival. Black as sin and smooth as temptation. Fresh and tasty - though more in the mild style than porter. Soft coffee aroma. Soft palate with a licorice and boiled bacon and chewed plastic flavours. Not great. And not really a porter.
Standard porter appearance with a mildly hopped aroma and a burn't/fruity flavour. A good pleasant porter, bitter but not overly.
Dark almost purple in colour. This has a hot chocolate like smoothness. Flavours are earthy and quite sweet, followed by some fruitiness. Too light in character to be great.
Black hue with light brown head a very good lacing. Coffee and toasted malt aroma. Treacle, brown sugar, coffee and toasty malty flavours. A reasonable porter.
Very good porter. Definite biscuity flavour, good rounded maltiness. A good intro to the style.
Great Porter, full complex flavour very malty with a good hop balance and a good level of bitterness from the roasted barley. I love this stuff!

(Bottle 25 cl) Comes as "Derby Pils" at 5% ABV. Pale golden with a small white head. Malty body with a discreet hoppy touch and some faint metallic notes in the palate. But really no worse than the typical Belgian pilsener. 250598

Bottle, from Rythym & Booze, Brigg. Gold, thin shortlived white head and moderate condition. Very low malt with a trace of starch in the nose, quite full bodied and sweet in the mouth with some rough hop notes emerging and contributing quite a harsh bitterness in the finish

From all of the cheap beers around, i think this one of the best ones. Allthough i would never choose this over a Jupiler, it�s taste is not bad and it is VERY cheap. u can get it at Delhaize supermarket.
It's very cheap and equally bad as well!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!, however if you plan to get drunk in a cheap way this is the beer.
the best belgian beer. If you like cheap beer and you don't min't to have a headache: try this-one!

The cheapest and the WORST beer of Belgium. Looks like piss, smells like piss, tastes like piss. I brought a sixpack 0.5l cans of this at some supermarket in Bruxelles. After trying, me and my friends threw the sixpack away and had to drink lots of Bush12% to remove the extremely bad taste.

For some reason I didn't think that I would like this but I was pleasantly surprised. Chocolate dominates but not to a point were it is overpowering.Pleasant to drink and just proves that you shouldn't decide on the quality of a beer before sampling it.I did and I was wrong.

Bottled. Black-brown with hints of red. Moderate head and condition. Low chocolate powder aromas, thin bodied and weak with some chocolate notes and a finish that becomes slightly metallic. Needs more alcohol.
Most impressive is the chocolate finish. Not as moreish as Youngs Double Chocolate Stout.

Bottle from Lidl supermarket in Gorinchem, The Netherlands. The beer is amber colored with a small broken white foam. Carbonation is average. The aroma is malty, with notes sweet malts, caramel, bread, honey, light citrus hops. The taste is light to medium bodied and starts light sweet with caramel, bread and sweet malts and goes to bitter with floral hops, yeast and spices. The finish is bitter, dry and a little watery.
Clear copper appearance. Aroma is malt, sweet and toffee. Flavour is nutty, hops, sweet, citrus, bitter and toffee.

Bottle, from Morrisons. Orange gold, thin but sustained white head and gentle condition. Slightly sweet in the nose with hints of honey and caramel, and some floral hop notes, sweet and fruity in the mouth with more floral honey and red berry notes, with an emerging earthy hop bitterness providing a balance. Finish has a dominant fruity sweetness and gentle herbal hop resin bitterness.

L: -pours a clear deep golden with a small to medium,foamy,white head -medium carbonation visible S: -orange zest,biscuity,honey,mushrooms T: -spicy,zesty,clove F: -medium carbonation -light to medium body O: A pleasant, if not terribly complex English Bitter.

500ml Bottle - Had this back in the day. Not one of Ventnor's better brews, but not bad. Copper coloured with notes of malt and hints of dried fruit. Moderately bitter taste with earthy hops and dried fruit.

Bottled, 500ml donated to the cause by Pat, cheers, where was the box though mate? Reddish amber with no head. This has been stored for some time and as ever with a low alcohol UK Bottled beer there is a mustiness that develops. Malt driven, reasonably smooth after a while, some vegetable, cauliflower notes. Basic.

Bottle at Tom�s Tasting, April 2009. Amber colour. Disappearing head. Poor grainy and papery aroma. Cleaner mouthfeel but not much of note going on. Some modest bitterness on the palate. All in all, a bit dull.

A Mes rate: bottle at The Cadster�s Spotify tasting. Decent rich amber colour. Head vanished as quick as it formed. Rather raw and yeasty and seems a little underbrewed or something. Off fruity notes do it no favours either. Other than that it�s reasonable. Sorry crap rate. Better than Toms tour de force however!
Bottle thanks to Ian, had at the cads first london tasting. Alround rating: Pale malts.
Bottle at the Spotify tasting. Reddish copper colour. Bread on aroma. Bit oxidised in the mouth. OK, but not great, too oxidised.
500ml bottle from Tescos, Andover. Gold with a fast fading white head; sour and stale malt aroma; thin, watery and acidic to start then becoming thin, watery and sugary. Very poor.

500 ml bottle. Medium-sized, mostely lasting dense offwhite head. Clear, deep golden colored body. Aroma of sourish bread, earthy hops and some faint fruit notes. Taste is light malty, light sweet with a bitter-acidic twist. Body is light plus. Lively mouthfeel. Short malty-bitter ending. High drinkability, lacks some attitude.

Big offwhite fine lasting head. Amber body with light carbonation. Fruity caramelly aroma with hoppy earthy notes. Dryish roasty fruity earthy caramel taste with perfumy floral notes. Light sweetness, too. Roasted almond notes can be made out. Light palate, mid body. Dry floral wooden aftertaste with light citric notes. A very good session beer. (0.5l bottle, Centra, Oslo.)
Bottle. Dark golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is malt, caramel. flavour is caramel, malt, hint of hop. Medium body.

Aroma is a sweet malt scent. Color is a hazy gold with low carbonation and almost no head. Taste is flat and sweet. Starting with a thin body it goes down with a flat feel. Finish comes in with a sweet German malt taste then fads out bland. This is a flat, bland, disappointment of a brew. I don�t think I will ever try another one of there beers.

Blech, not a very good German lager, very lackluster in all categories. Light hazy straw yellow in color. It�s like they took an average german lager and watered it down with dirty water or something. Almost non-existant head. Take Coors Light and add a hint of German Lager and you have this beer. The bottle is pretty cool looking though (the glass for the bottle is cobalt blue) which is what made me buy this cuz it stuck out (and it�s cheap) but i�ll definitely never purchase this one again.

Bottle best by 2003 poured a hazy yellow with a small, quickly dissapateing white head. Aromas ofbread, honey and a hint of lemon. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of bread, yeast, honey and a hint of lemon with a crisp, mildly bitter finish.

Bottle best by 2003. Pours hazy, murky dark gold with minute fizzy bubbly white head. Yeast (dough, sweat) malt (meal, cookie) and citrus hop (lemon) aromas with grapes and pear notes. Watery sweaty yeast with pear flavor, malty and fizzy fruity finish that goes slightly dry. Medium bodied and thin, watery fizzy palate.

Cloudy and deep yellow with a thin, fading head. Decent nose, with notes of apples and lemons. Soft and chewy mouthfeel with a nice carbonation level. Malts were a little doughy, with a pinch of yeast mixed in. Mild lemon flavors. Hops were mild (herbs, grass) and only lightly bitter, but they dried out the mouth quite a bit. Drinkable, but not really exciting.

Cool looking blue bottle. THat is about all that is good though. Paper thin head. Pale golden, slightly hazy appearance. Aroma is slight hops and rubber. Has a bit of hops up front in the flavor, and a bit of malt, but overall it isn't that great. I would pick it over bud or genital herpes (see previous blues lager ratings).
Small head with a pale color to body. Overly hoppy taste for a standard lager.

Ick! Holy @#$&@, this beer is bad. If I had the choice between drinking this beer again and getting genital herpes, I would opt for genital herpes. Man, this is Germany''s answer to Budweiser, only I would rather drink Bud.
Quite possibly the worst beer I''ve ever had. It is dry, flavorless and smells like strange carcinogenic polymers. I won''t be trying this again. Definetly down the drain.
Maybe a smidge maltier and more flavorful than Allgauer's Bayrisch Hell, but not much. A beer brewed for a Jazz festival needn't be complex to succeed. The music lends plenty of complexity.
Smells good (spicy and sweet), but tastes almost nothing. What a shame, the amber colour is quite pleasant

column1: Sheepscot Valley Boothbay Special Bitter Pale Ale
column5: Cask at Great Lost Bear. Pours clear amber with a medium, creamy white head with long retention and good lacing. Aroma is earthy and minty hops with biscuit malt. Flavor is medium hops and bitterness with fruity esters, light malt and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

column1: Sheepscot Valley Boothbay Special Bitter Pale Ale
column5: Draft at Great Lost Bear. Clear deep golden color, thick white head, solid lacing. Aroma of tropical fruit. Taste is smooth and fruity, not too bitter.

column1: Sheepscot Valley Boothbay Special Bitter Pale Ale
column5: Pours a brassy reddish amber with a rather persistent head of fine foam. Rich fruity nose with notes of apple, pear and grape. Tart apple like taste but very well balanced. The tartness is balanced out with sweet and caramel notes atypical of a bitter. Tart and tangy finish.

column1: Sheepscot Valley Boothbay Special Bitter Pale Ale
column5: on tap @brewery-pours a white head that bubbles and hazy amber color. Aroma is orange/pine hops. Taste is orange/pine hops. Mouth feel is a bit grainy. Medium body. OK carbonation. 3.6 *090507-Sheepscot Boothbay Bitter PA @Great Lost Bear Portland-on cask-pours an off white head that laces and hazy copper color. Aroma is citrus with some bitter/herbal hops. Taste is herbal hops bite, light/medium malt-light side of medium body. Right on style for a malty English Bitter. [Not sure about Special Bitter Pale Ale] Soft carbonation. 2.8

column1: Sheepscot Valley Boothbay Special Bitter Pale Ale
column5: Cask Draught @ GLB 08�. Citrus and clean cut grass. Hop balance is well done. A bit thin in the mouth feel but the finish is decent. Good session beer is you are into bitters.

on tap-pours a white head and hazy yellow color. Aroma is light fruit, light malt/wheat/grassy, some English hops. Taste is light fruit-(apricot?), light malt/wheat, secondary spice hops that asserts itself a bit more in the finish.

(Draft) Cloudy orange-gold body served with a very minimal whitish head. Aroma of yeast, wheat malt, light bread and light floral. Mouthfeel is light and a bit thin. Decent wheaty smoothness but a bit pebbly. Flavor is quite citrusy - kind of lemon/lime but not that appealing. Mildly tart. Other than that there�s not much beer behind it. Some very light bready maltiness and sweetness and a light touch of floral hops. A bit rough around the edges.

I don�t usually review beers I have at a beerfest (it�s typically crowded, you are getting jostled, difficult to focus) but I�ll make a small exception in this case since I enjoy cream ales so much and this one does the style proud. Pours a pale hazy gold with a creamy white head. No lace evident. Smells sweet, light and creamy (I sense a trend). Tastes creamy, of course. Light bright malt flavors with very little hop flavor. Lightly sweet aftertaste. Creamy, light mouthfeel. Very very drinkable and refreshing on a warm Fall day. Must get a bottle of this and review again...
Nice floral aroma, but no other hint of hops to be found except a tad in the finish. Almost honey like sweetness. Easy drinking.
A creamy light lager. Quite enjoyable......................................

Name: Stout Date: 10/19/1997 Mode: Draft Source: Great Lost Bear, Maine black with ruby red highlights, whispy tan head, nice chocolate malt aroma, smooth character with lots of chocolate and a hint of roasted flavor, slight malt bitterness Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Draft at Sebago with Andrew, Jay and Kramer. Pours a deep brown body with thin off white lacing. Aroma is malt, bread and cocoa. Mouthfeel is soft and thin with notes of caramel, bread, malt, cocoa and nut. Not too much going on with this one.

Keg at the Portland branch. Pours clear brown with a tight, creamy tan head. The nose has lightly burnt toast and dry cocoa. Light sweet flavor with moderate earthy bitterness, some more cocoa, burnt leaves, dry toasted brown bread. Light bodied with fine to average carbonation. Light earthy bitter finish, a bit more cocoa, toast. Totally fine.

Location: Draft at Barnacle Billys in Ogunquit, 7/9/13 Aroma: The nose is malty and nutty, toast, and some caramel/toffee notes Appearance: It pours a brown color with a light brown head and some average lace Flavor: Tastes malty, similar to the nose component-wise, not overly sweet, not much bitterness Palate: The body is light-medium and it is perfectly drinkable with a fine mouthfeel to it Overall Impression: This is a fine brown, but it was nothing too memorable. If your looking for a quaffable brown you could certainly do far worse...
Pours a clear brown color with a small long lasting white head. Aroma of caramel mats and some floral hops. Taste is mostly sweet with a medium body and a nice small hop finish. Not bad at all
Bottle. Clear reddish brown pour with a thin tan head. Aroma of grainy malt, some caramel and roast. malty and grainy flavor with a bit of caramel before a dry, roasty finish.

The brown is a pretty good beer with a dark brown color and nice aroma. It has a good level of roasted malt with a nice hop finish. I have had this on draft many times and it is consistently good. If you like a little more hop, I would try the red and if you like more malt, the stout would be for you. This one falls somewhere in between.
on tap at brewpub. clear brown-reddish with a decent beige head, some retention. perfumed nuttiness, awkward caramel and minerals. moderate carbonation, light body, light herbal finish. meh.

Nearly opaque dark amber, long-lasting head cover, thick sheets of lace. Taste is semi-sweet malt with mild hops mixed in all the way through. At the finish, carbonation and a slightly warm sweetness appear, bringing things to a nice close. Simple, but good considering the abv.

On tap at the brewpub with Kramer, Andrew, and J-Dadmond in between sessions of The Festival. Pours a clear brown and a thin white to beige head. Light cocoa and malt on the nose. Soft cocoa, chocolate, roast. Soft bitterness into the finish, but not a lot else going on.

Tap. Pours clear brown with a medium, frothy off-white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma chocolate and toast malt, dats and figs with earthy hops. Flavor is malt forward with medium hops and bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Draught at the brewpub in Portland. A black creamy nitro like Guinness stout. Ok overall

On tap at the brewpub. It poured a black color with a tan head. The aroma was of malts, roast, caramel and chocolate. The taste was similar to the aroma with more malts, roast, caramel, chocolate and medium carbonation with a nice chewy aftertaste. Not bad.
Sampler at Sebago Portland. Pours black with a khaki head. Leaves a shitload of lacing. Solid roasted malt on the nose and tongue. Finished dry with a bit of pine bitterness. Not bad.
From tap. Pours pitch black with a small tan and creamy head. Aroma is dry, bitter, dark malty. Roasted. Bitter and dry. Slight herbal. Roated dark malty into the far finish.
Nice enough stout. Good use of oatmeal. Dark blackish pour. Well balanced, not too sweet, stout.
Black with a thick tan head. Light malty roast aroma. Smooth silky mouth feel. Slightly sweet and well balanced ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very dark brown pour, brown head. Aroma of espresso, dark chocolate and cocoa. flavor is thin, lactose and chocolate. Very thin.

Pours black as used motor oil, carbonation boils up and beer cascades down prettier than a well-poured Guinness leaving a thick, creamy, beige head. Lacing isn't the right word. It's more like the inside of my glass is coated with beige paint. Nose is malt and dark-roasted grain. Taste is balanced: a touch on the bitter side. Medium to full body. Moderate carbonation. Very nice! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Can had at home via beer52 bbu Feb 2020 smells a citrus flavour with cream head Taste great a orange hit followed by creamy hit

355ml can. Pours golden brown with a white head. Caramel malt and piney hop, a bit of hop spice. Medium bodied with an oily texture. Sweet with soft carbonation and some hop bitterness coming through at the finish.

Poured from 12 oz. can. Lightly hazy gold with a small off-white head and good lacing. Aroma of caramel, hints of orange, grapefruit and tropical fruit. Taste of caramel, pine, orange, mild tropical fruit and bare hints of grapefruit. Medium body and medium/low carbonation. Very strange for an IPA--malt dominates; the hops are there, but subtle. Not a bad beer, but a poor IPA.

Pours a mildly murky dull golden. Lifeless two-row malt nose with a meager hop character. �Maine�s legendary IPA is known for its unique and intense dry-hopped aroma and flavor.� This is devoid of both. I�m a little angry with how underwhelming and average this beet is given the description.

On tap at the brewpub. It poured a hazy golden color with a white head. The aroma was of hops, grapefruit and pine. The taste was similar to the aroma with more hops, grapefruit, pine and medium carbonation with a semi-bitter aftertaste. Not bad.
Tap at Thirsty Moose, Portsmouth. Color iw cloudy golden with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Fruits, some hops and malts. Sweet malty boring IPA.

Refrigerated 12 oz. aluminum can poured into a cup. Hazy light orange with small white head. Aroma is light herbal hops, medium body, lower carbonation, and some lacing. Taste is herbal hops and cardboard.

Can, Clear light amber color with a persistent head cover, and mottled sheets of lace. Taste is clean malt that grows through the palate to a long, sweet finish in which the hops show up very late and linger well past the finish. Unpretentious, but interesting and very interesting.

Taster pour at Powder Keg Beer and Chili Festival. Appearance is hazy light brown, 1/2-finger width of foamy light brown head with mild lacing. Aroma is strong, astringent lemon (like industrial cleanser), floral. Taste is strong astringent lemon, like drinking Pledge. Palate is light bodied with thin texture, average carbonation and finish as taste. Overall, this one went awry. Didn't want to finish even a taster pour amount.
Pours a dark amber. Unassuming, some pine and tropical notes. A little sweet. Good beer.

Draft @ Portland location. Nearly clear piss color. Weak nose is unknown fruit and generic hop. Taste is nearly the same. Body and texture is extremely light like it should be. Dry texture with weak bitterness. Not the worst I�ve had in this style. Somewhat drinkable.
Light ale, minimal head. hints of red. malty and minimal bitterness. getting pineapple and apricots on the nose. hoppy and bitter.
On tap at Sebago, Portland in April 2010. Pale straw colour. Slight haze. Usual clean, light, inoffensive stuff. Drinkable and easygoing. Not much body. Quite thirst quenching.

On tap at Sebago Portland , ME location. Pours out golden topped with a small white head. Aroma was of light citrus hops and a little fruit sweetness. Taste was also light sweetness crisp and refreshing.

Draught, 3.8% at the brewpub. Weak grapefruity hop aroma. Hazy yellow colour. Small white head. The flavour has a nice, refreshing grapefruity hop note. Does not taste low alcohol except for a slight breadiness. Good mouthfeel for ABV.
Can had at home from beer52 pours a reddish dark in colour large head you can smell the malts in this one pours a smooth beer followed by a malt hit not much hops in this
Malty, moderate sweet, slightly nutty, somewhat bitter with some caramel. Not bad overall.

Impressed with some of these Maine upstarts� mastery of the malt. Here�s another brown ale/doppelbock-lite type brew awash with lactic chocolate robed caramel, milky hazelnut, malt loaf. Aroma cinder toffee, crispy veggie sausage, rye bread sour streaks. Nary a hop in sight/taste. Which is how it should be sometimes. Tea coloured with a narrow beige foam. Nice.

355ml can thanks to Colin. Small off white head, a little lacing. Slightly hazy red-brown body. Sweet malt nose, toffee, red berries. Flavour is caramel, malt, biscuit, pear. Light carbonation, decent mouthfeel, dry finish. Decent amber ale.
Can from Beer52. Pours copper with a cream head. Toasty malt flavour with a bitter finish. Uninspiring.

Can from Beer52. Canned Feb 2019; BB not stated; Drank May 2019 - Clear amber red with a medium off-white head. Very malty; sweet malts, toasty, bready, caramel, toffee. Spicy. Hoppy; light hop bitterness, grassy hops. Quite dry. Sweet-bitter toasty bready malty spicy throughout. Pleasant easy drinking beer. (2019-05)
Enjoyable red ale, malty, slightly sweet and with smooth finish. Vert drinkable.
330ml can from Beer52. Deep ruby colour, with an off white head. Grassy hop and chewy malt nose. Fairly standard.
Can from beer52. Hazy amber colour with a white head. Taste malty caramel. And slightly dry. Medium body.
Filtered, Dark Amber with a slight tan head. Minimal aroma. Smooth caramel malty notes with a slight hoppy aftertaste. Very drinkable and very enjoyable!
Well, it certainly was smokey. However, the flavor combination of beer and smoked gouda just doesn''t work for me. Oh well.
Slightly smokey aroma, then bam! huge smokey flavour. Very smooth smoke though, adictive. Good thing the smokey flavour was so good, not much else going for it. Virtually no hops, hint of sweetness.
The first smoked beer I've had. It was quite enjoybale. A medium bodies ale, that has the overall smoke quality to it, which makes it very tasty.

(Bottle, Foersters Feine Biere, Steglitz, Berlin, 9 May 2019) Golden colour with frothy, white head. Malty nose with bread, grass and hay. Malty taste with notes of bread, grain, grass and a balanced grassy/herbal bitterness in the finish. Medium body, dry. Fresh and tasty. Quite nice.

L: -pours a clear straw golden with a small to medium,foamy,white head -medium carbonation visible S: -hay,sweet malt,spicy,mineral,apple T: -sweet malt,spicy,mineral -Finishes dry F: -medium carbonation -light body O: Quite different than most other Pilseners and while the Aroma is pleasant the taste is a bit on the boring side.
Clear golden. Aroma is slight malt with noble hops. Taste is bitter malt. Standard lager. Not bad but not good.
Having this one directly from a glass bottle. Aroma is malty. Taste of malts, butter, light sweet. Light bitter and sweet finish
Mindent adok: fresh, sparkling, gorgeuos b�rcsak minden itthoni pils is ilyen lenne
From tap at Cafe Bar Suedwest with HDI and RRV 27.07.17. Clear pale golden. Bright white head and lacing. Moderate aroma and fine taste of German hops and pale pilsner malt.

Tap at Zum Schneider, Montauk. I believe I�m rating the right beer here. Could also be the bitburger pils since it was kind of ambiguous on the flight. But let�s assume it�s the right beer. Pours very light yellow, white head. Aroma is light lemon, pilsner malt. Simple but decent. Flavor is the same. Not much to say about it frankly.
Flasche in der Matilda-Bar Berlin. Intensives Pils, voller K�rper, bitterer Abgang. Nicht schlecht!

330 ml bottle bought at Great Food Hall in Pacific Place, Admiralty. Pale lemon yellow colour; Half finger head and residual soapy white foam which fades in 20 seconds; Fair sticky lacing with very slight carbonation; Pungent smell of lager malt, with slightly choking floral, grains, strong molasses, thick bread, yeast, light lemon and grass; Close to medium sweet taste of lager malt, with light grains, floral, light molasses, strong bread, biscuits, yeast, strong lemon, strong bitter hops and grass; Close to light body. Thin, dry and fairly crisp palate; Mouth feel is pretty malty, more lager than a Pils, in a pretty thin and dry background. Strong floral, fairly grainy, very biscuity. Neat sweetness to balance the very lemony hops. Pretty nice!... Hoppiness is floral, lemon and grass in nose, and a lot stronger in taste. Bitterness is strong , dynamic and tasty for a lasting, fairly high astringent sweet bitter finish; Dry after taste, Crisp and quite bitter to mouth. Comments: This one feels like somewhere between a Premium Lager and a Pilsener, due to its rather light body and thin palate, but make no mistake it has a malty and rather wholesome backbone, and being topped with a lively hoppiness. A good one among the average German Pils, easy and drinkable.

Pours a clear pale yellow with a thick foamy white head...lively...nice lacing and retention. Aroma is very subdued but has mild straw and noble hoppy spice. Flavor is significantly hoppy with spice and earthy/grassy notes...mildly minerally. Mouthfeel is medium and lively...a little slick...Finish is dry and earthy/grassy/almost resinous.
On tap at the brewpub. A hazy amber beer with a mid-sized most good lasting off-white head. Aroma of clove, riped fruits, yeast. Taste of riped banana, clove, caramel okay!

Tap (?). Hazy amber-orange color with huge fluffy eggshell head. Aroma is cloves, bananas, wheat, touch of caramel, fruit esters, vanilla. Taste is fresh spicy yeasts, cloves, banana, wheat, cream, vanilla. High but soft carbonation, oily mouthfeel. Estery aftertaste, but with a touch of booze. Refreshing and nice Urweisse-like Weizen!
W�ssrig hefiger Antrunk. Hell und wenig hefig bleibend, fast neutral. Kaum herb zum Ende, monoton. Entt�uschend. 10/8/9/7//8

Light spicy nose. Cloudy orange brown, creamy offwhite head. Ryebread start, plenty of fruit mango banana oranges. Peppery spice corianderseeds. mellow mf, a little less chewy than needed to support the flavor I feel. Yeast retronasal. Flavorfull dunkelweisse.
On Tap. Nice yeasty aroma and taste. Dark brown color. Good carbonation. Ok beer.

remarkable murky shade of brown with a lasting head. big banana aroma with a little whiteboard marker in there for good measure. tastes of treacle, peach ice cream and slivovice. noticeable alcohol presence, very full in the mouth but finishes surprisingly dry with some grassy bitterness

Can @ Home. Pours clear light golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, corn, hay, dusty cardboard. Flavor is sweet, malt, corn, hay, light cardboard. Medium body, average to lively carbonation, sweet finish. 071119

Can. Light golden, small to average and mostly diminishing head. Light, malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish aroma, faint caramel and hoppyness, light metal. Body is light, malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish flavor, faint caramel and hoppyness, light metal. Finish is short, malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish, faint hoppyness, light metal. Lightly sweetish and watery lager - tastes really cheap. For the meek masses from big company (Carlsberg).
Aroma: Sweet corn. Flavour: Fruity sweet with sweet corn and slight malt. Aftertaste is sweet. Colour: Yellow with a white head. From: Can @ EuroDeli Tilst May 2019.
Clear gold. Tall frothy white head. Nose: grains, restrained lager yeast. Similar taste. No bitterness.
Golden beer, small head. Aroma is grain, malt. Taste is the same, bitter, sweet, ok.

568ml can. Pours a pale and clear orange gold with a white head. Aroma: sweet malt, grass and mild citrus notes. Not overly pleasant. Taste: sweet malt, mild honey and citrus notes, mild earthy flavour. Not a pleasant flavour balance. Thin bodied. Moderate carbonation. Mild bitterness. Easy to drink but it is not interesting... in fact, it is actually very boring.
Can from Iki. Clear pale yellow color white head. Paper and lemon aroma. Lemon and paper taste, subtle black pepper.
Wetherspoon Autumn Beer Festival 2018. Cask @ Leeds Station Wetherspoon. Copper and clear with a smooth-creamy head. It�s malty and nutty in equal lightish measure.

Cask (4%; festival ale), 1/2 pint by hand-pump from The Counting House, Glasgow on 18 Oct 2018: floral, fruity, nutty malt aroma, amber brown, good foam head, excellent film of fine lacing, caramel, nutty malt flavour, creamy, sweet malty finish.
Cask, William Wygston, Wigston. Amber brown with a firm off white head. Sweet caramel and burnt toffee with weetabix. Woody nuttiness. Leafy bitterness. Roast finish. Pretty good.

Cask-conditioned, on gravity, at the Commercial Rooms (JDW), Bristol 11/10/2018. Chestnut in colour, with a slight, off-white, head. Brown sugar, a touch red berry fruit sweetness, slightly bready malts and a gentle finish. fine.

Cask handpull at Thomas Ingoldsby JDW Canterbury Clear dark chestnut brown colour lasting beige head. Malty beer. Not much hop. Brown malts. ok brown ale. sweetish brown malt with a slightly drying finish. good temperature and condition.

Cask at the Old Manor (JDW), Bracknell. A chestnut pour with a thin cream head; grainy aroma with some tart fruit; smooth grainy body with tart gooseberry, then bready; finishing with some well roasted malts.
Cask @ The Windmill, Stansted. Clear brown with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and nutty. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. 211018
Cask @ The Windmill, Stansted Airport. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are caramel, nuts, malt, fruits and hops. Sweet caramel and bitter finish.

16th Oct 2018. 3rd of a pint in my local Wetherspoon (William Withering, Wellington Shropshire). Looked fine, red hue to the autumnal amber body, off-white topping. I found the aroma and taste a little strange, slightly bitter and 'off tasting' with a cobweb or two. A light nutty undertone maybe, but a beer not to my liking.

Deep amber with a thin off-white head. Tastes oddly old-fashioned. Nut and caramel with a restrained bitterness and some autumn leaves. A little coffee in the aftertaste. Yeah, that's about it. Ok, but leaves my socks firmly on my feet. Quite a satisfying drink though, bonus mark for that.
Can 500 ml. Blackish-brown color, good creamy foam. Aroma and taste: caramel, roasted, malty, sweet, drinkable, but nothing special.

A 500ml. can from Simplemart down the road, sold in Taiwan as 'Schwarzer Herzog Black Beer'. Aroma: roasted notes, chocolate. Appearance: cola; head rapidly dissipates to nothing. Palate: light-bodied and slick, soft carbonation, flavoursome roasted finish. Taste: medium bitter and sweet, well-balanced. Plenty of chocolate, slightly acidic. Interesting flavour, could drink another.
Black color, small foam. Caramel, patoka in aroma. Taste is sweet with bitterness. Decent black beer. Drinkable.

16oz can from Crescent Liquor, Bowie. Brown-black body. Respectable enough steady beige head. Rather straightforward dark lager, medium bodied, mellow brown chocolate tones, caramel. A little bit sugary, but that is suitable for the style. A pinch this as well, more of a cheap street drinking beer than a luscious deep example of the style, but sill a whole lot more refreshing than most US examples. OK.
Pretty good, somewhat true to style. Straddles between boring dunkel and exciting schwarzbier. A bit of sweetness, some dryness, some smoke. Not crisp enough to be a true winner.
Roasted barley, hops in aroma. Dark color without head. Roasted barley, burnt crust of bread, a bit bitter in finish. Light body, medium carbonation.

Wolter's Black Beer has a thick, beige head, a bubbly, chocolate-brown appearance, and some glass lacing. The aroma is a dull brown bread, but the flavor is of rich, sweet chocolate, some coffee, and dark brown bread crust. No apparent bitterness, here. Mouthfeel is light to medium, and Wolter's Black Beer finishes medium crisp. RJT

can - Very dark brown pour with a small tan head. The mild aroma has some chocolate malt. The flavor is on the sweet side with chocolate, somewhat bready malt and minimal hops bitterness. Thin. Rather bland. It's halfway decent but underwhelming.

aroma is chocolate.too much carbonation, thin body. taste is balanced and directly chocolate. looks meh, no head really. wish the body and carbonation was better and it'd be fine enough for a cheap beer.
500ml can as Wolters Black Bier. Pours a dark brown/black. Aroma is unsweetened brownie dough, spice, oxidized. Flavor is a touch oxidized, light roast, doughy, fruity, smooth, but not great.

On tap at the brewery pours a deep copper with some cloudy white head. Nose has a lot of dried fruit, booze, some cheap fortified wine. Flavor has cherry and raisin, malt, brown sugar, a little displaced acid, cheap red wine. Full, fruity, sweet finish.

Draft at the new Bardo. Murky brown color, thick beige head with amazing retention and solid lacing. Aroma is like snorting lines of butterscotch, very intense. Taste is really sweet and smooth butterscotch and caramel candy. Amazingly drinkable after 14 years.

Thanks to Travlr! At the (new) brewery. Grapes on the nose, but similar in smell to riesling grapes before being turned into wine. Very sweet with tiny bubbles. Great thick beige head. Alcohol is very hidden. There�s a bit if umami but not too much soy sauceness. Really tasty.

Date: 01/03/1997 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub very dark ruby red, thin fine light tan head, strong sweet estery carmel malt aroma, strong sweet malt flavor with lots of esters followed by a pleasant bitterness at the finish Aroma: 9/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.9/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
Much blacker than the typical barley wine. Nice aroma but not quite as strong as you might expect. The high-alcohol content is masked well by the hops and malt. Finish is strong and bitter.
2000 vintage. Velvety smooth aroma with a light carmel colored appearance. Very welcome mild carbonation adds to this beer's enjoyment. Very malty with a deeply bitter hop finish.
Hazed golden. Aroma has died over the years (a bit of cardboard). Dulled down sweetness, mostly malty. Notes: Bottle was ~ 6 yrs old, opened for Eric�s bottle share, Dec �16
2007 Vintage. 22oz bottle. Poured a golden color with an averaged sized head. Grains, toasted bread, some fruitiness, and some stale grass.

Nice golden color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of caramel malt, hops, some citrus, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, hops, caramel, fruit, and spice; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Good stuff.
22 ounce bottle. Thanks John! Pours a cloudy light gold with a very nice beige head. Aroma of malt, fruit, grass, and caramel. Taste is similar. Very well made, very nice to drink.
Yellow pour with a white head. The aroma has some bread notes and not too much else. The flavor is full of biscuit malt, bready malt, grass and toffee. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Bomber thanks to Phatdog1. Poured an unfiltered yellow color with a frothy white top and lacing action. Taste of sweet malts, honey, apple juice, caramel, and honey flavors. Fizzy, foamy, medium-high carbonation. All hail Smuttynose!
(22oz bomber) cloudy yellow, fine white bubbles. Nose of citrus fruit, kumquat, bit of honey, funky. Taste of burnt grain, honey, rose, raw grain, medium richness, burnt caramel.

bomber courtesy of phatdog1; thanks Craig! nice amber orange hazy pour. aroma is malt with some citrus (orange) and slight alcohol - nice combo! nice med. palate. Taste was balanced - a few things going on - malt sweetness (at times, a tad too sweet) + citrus sweetness; slight caramel; then slight drying hops at end; faintest bit of alcohol. Really like this beer and brewery - I can see why this beer is at the top of this style!

2006 Bottle. Clear gold with a fluffy white head. Aroma is strong and sweet with some slight spice notes. Honey, floral, fruity. Flavor is fruity and sweet, bready, spicy. Touches of caramel, figs, apples, honey. This has definitely been taken over by the malty side after aging for 6 years, almost no bitterness/hop presence at all.

Bottle. Pours slightly hazy orange with nice white head that thins a bit too quickly and leaves great lacing. Smells of bread, butterscotch, hay, dough, and grass. Taste is slightly sweet with a medium body, average carbonation and a short finish. Great brew!

column1: Casco Bay Salty Petes Peg Leg Ale
Casco Bay Salty Petes Peg Leg Ale
column5: Bottled. Amber-orange hue with just a hint of pink; medium frothy head. Nose sweeter and maltier than most Pales, but with some floweriness and orange as well; very nice. Flavor is very rich and full; hard to believe this comes from the same people who put out that thin, weak Pils I had last week. Not enough hops, really; tastes a little flat through the middle, but some good bitterness emerges at the end. A very nice effort on the whole.

column1: Casco Bay Salty Petes Peg Leg Ale
column5: Flavorful pale ale. It's not the best one out there, but the flavors, are complex and intriguing

column1: Casco Bay Salty Petes Peg Leg Ale
column5: Not much aroma but wow is it flavourful. Floral and malty with a beautiful hop balance.

This beer is both not that good and excellent. Not terribly interesting and some flat flavors, yet at the same time it has a nice sweetish flavor. But it is so so drinkable. It is one of those I�m not sure I like this but I love drinking it kind of beers if that makes any sense. Serving: Bottle
Bronze and clear. Pleasant aroma and slightly nutty flavour. Some bitterness with a bit of maltiness. Quite a reasonable brown ale despite being brewed by Scotish Corage.

Pours a nice clear copper/brown, about an inch of head. The head dies back to less than a quarter inch. Minimal lacing. Bready aroma is nice, but not much else going on. Sweet malty taste, a little bready, a little molasses. But mainly just sweet. A little too sweet for me. Very little hop presence. Thinner body than I expected, and a not-quite but almost medium level of carbonation.

Bottled, pasteurised, 500ml. Chestnut coloured with short lasting head. Thinnish slightly sweet beer with a medicinal, pine type background, a little like a cleaning product. The flavour turns a little nutty through warming, but nothing too pleasant. I�m never sure what the Geordies see in these Brown Ales, not for me.
Weak, thin, pallid, and altogether unimpressive. Or maybe, just maybe, Browns don�t speak my language!

(Northumbrian) "Medium" brown colored beer with an average head. Smokiness abounds: from aromas to flavor... similar to a recently-doused campfire, but tastier... and a little less dangerous. "Wet" mouthfeel with a slightly sour aftertaste. Thanks to Ben, as this was in his fridge when I was house-sitting.

Bottle (part of a Federation selection pack). Amber red. Malty aromas with banana skins and raisins. Sweet caramel but thin without complexity. Drinkable but as with other Federation products I have tried a sharp contrast between aromas and insipid taste.

nice packaging and a pretty pour the color of real maple syrup, though very clear. an aggressive decanting would produce only a svelte little head, the color of sliced banana. aroma is red plum, mars bar, almond taffy-- and also strangely like a page of glossy printing, a magazine cover perhaps. all of that is the easy part because taking a sip is about as rewarding as dropping the bottle on your bare foot. i believe i emitted an involuntary shriek or something because my dog looked up suddenly in alarm. YOW! the beer is recklessly sweet --without a license, cause or mitigating circumstance. it�s literally sugary-- cream soda, dull praline, call it what you will-- but my first �crying game� impulse was to backhand the beer for it�s deceit. even so, i drank it all-- in slightly diminishing disdain-- and to it�s credit some grapefruit tones emerged to suggest a nod of balancing hops. but too little, too late. it finished watery and still disturbingly sweet-- way too much akin to a soft drink.

"Northumbrian" in the 11.2 oz. bottle - This poured a nutty brown with reddish highlights, sporting a modest white head that soon "haloed� the glass. It�s got a mild, caramel aroma and tastes pretty much as it smells. Finishes on a slightly tart, crisp note. Not a bad brown, but not very exciting, either. Foremost Liquors, Oak Forest, IL

Dark amber/ brown in color, clear, creamy tan generous head. Aroma: metallic, piney, medicinal, with a hint of nuts and butter. Light body, thin palate, sickly twang in the finish. I guess this could stand in as an inoffensive "session ale", except that I can�t imagine why you would want more than one of these sorry bastards. It�s an 18.6oz. bottle, and I�m bored less than 1/2 way through. That�s the point, though, something to slug down in between turns at darts. At the end of the bottle, those initial off-flavors had disappeared and the beer became more mellow, the finish more pleasant, and I didn�t hate it quite as much. Didn�t like it any better, though.

12 oz bottle. Pours a clear golden color and topped by a bubbling off white head of foam that settles quickly to a thin film. The aroma shows notes of lemon citrus, crackers, toasted bread, and peppery spice to go with some floral notes of grass and straw that pairs up with the pale malts, earthy hops and lager yeast. The flavor follows and is nice and crisp with the lemon citrus, crackers, toasted bread and peppery spice up front and followed by the earthy, yeast notes, pale malts, and the grassy, floral hop bitterness on the back end. Medium bodied with ample carbonation that leads to a clean, crisp, and dry finish with some lingering hop bitterness on the backend. Really well done pilsener and another great German style beer from the master himself, Dan Carey.
Bottle, thanks to shrubber85, golden yellow in color, hazy soap ring foam, fruity nose, flavor of bubblegum, bready yeast, cocktail syrup, good finish

Poured from 12oz bottle at home. Bright yellow and clear with a tony ring of white head. Has a grassy, straw, lemon aroma. Mild hops, lemon/fruits, flowers. Very good for a blonde - one of the better of this style I�ve had
Golden yellow, transparent, with a thin white head. Complex noble hop aroma. Nice Pilsner malt on the palate with a noble hop backing. Great beer.

12 ounce bottle into lager glass, bottled on 8/12/2014. Pours fairly clear bright golden straw color with a 1 finger dense white head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass. Aromas of lemon, cracker, bread, light honey, herbal, straw, grass, light pepper, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance of pale malt and earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of lemon, cracker, bread, light honey, herbal, straw, grass, light pepper, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Light herbal/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon, cracker, bread, straw, grass, light pepper, and herbal/yeast earthiness on the finish for a short bit. Very nice balance and robustness of pale malt and earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Fairly dry finish, but not overly dry. Very clean on lager flavors with minimal yeast ester notes present. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, crisp, and slightly creamy/bready mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is well hidden with zero warming present after the finish as expected of 4.8%. Overall this is an excellent German pilsener style. All around great robustness and balance of pale malt and earthy hop flavors; and very smooth, crisp, and clean to drink. A very enjoyable offering.
3/8/15. 12oz bottle thanks to my in-laws! Golden pour with a nice off-white head, good lacing. Doughy aroma, grassy, citrus. Nice flavor, doughy pale malts, citrus, grassy. Tasty.
Bottle. Light lemon, barley malt and hay aroma. Golden yellow with giant white head. Tangy sweet lemon, barley malt and mildly bitter grass hops flavor. Nice body.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a Pilsner glass. Brew smells grassy, a little citrusy, with plenty of hop aroma present. Brew has a full, yellow color with just a little bit of haziness and rendered a white 1-inch head made up of fine bubbles--looks quite lush. Taste is grassy and citrusy at the beginning of the sip. The middle of the sip revealed that the brew has a pretty full malt profile and some floral notes! Then you�re left with that perfect bitter and crisp finish. For a Pilsner, the body of the beer is quite ample, but still very refreshing. The mouthfeel has that nice bite of carbonation that doesn�t stick with you too long so you can actually taste the beer. I�ve tasted a few really good pilsners before, but this one tops my personal list. What a great brew! "Never turn your back on your beer."
12 oz bottle pours golden with a white head. Aroma of malts, pine and grain. Taste is sweet malts and grain. Just a hint of bitterness.
Bottle: Clear gold with a tall, just-off-white head. Grains, grass, lemon-honey aroma. Taste is grassy, bitter-sweet grains...... A great example of a classic American Pils. Very good.

JINGLE ALE 12 OZ. BOTTLE. 1998--6.50% ABV. (4.5 / 5.0) Winter Ale. Deep clear brown color with hints of red. Nice nutmeg spice front balanced by rich, but not sugary, malt body. Dry finish. Sharp blend of spice and malt flavors. Sampled 11/16/1998. 2000--5.80% ABV. (4.25 / 5.0) Winter Ale. Slightly hazy nutmeg color. Light lacy white head. Spicy very coriander nutmeg front with toasted notes. Cinnamon dry sweet toasted malty body. Tapering spice end is clean dry and hot. Rich holiday brew. Sampled 12/31/2000. 2001--5.63% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Winter Ale. Spicy cinnamon front. Hazy thin bronze color. Light white sediment rain. Rich lacy head. Spiciness dominates rich light roasted body. Thin texture and light dry sweetness. Hot spicy end. Minor hops. Sampled 11/18/2001. 2002--5.63% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Winter Ale. Hazy thin dirty copper brown color. Medium lacy head. Roasted malt spice mild spruce hop floral front. Sweet malty body with tangy burnt nutmeg caramel mellow ester taste. Malt spice mild hop end. Tasty. Sampled 12/5/2002. 2003--5.63% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Winter Ale. Mild lace head. Clear bronze brown color hazes with sediment. Mildly spicy roasted mild hop front. Creamy thick sweet roasted doughy crusty caramel burnt nutmeg with yeast body. Malty mild hop end. Mild. Sampled 1/17/2004.

Bottle from x-mas 2000 and cellared since then, enjoyed on 7/25/2008. Clear garnet color with a thin head. Pumpkin pie spicy aromas with malty grainy pie crust. Medium body with light carbonation. Nice caramel toffee sweet flavors with still strong spicy pumpkin and clove same as the aroma. No trace of oxidation. After nearly eight years in a bottle this brews flavors are as strong or more so than many aged Anchor OSA�s....wow, very nice Christmas treat in July.

This one has aged a bit and the spice has stood up very strong. Pours a dark mahogany with a tall off-white head. Aroma of pure ginger bread sweet with a touch of fruitbread in the nose. Taste is very thin and light bodied with much less spice than the nose let on. A bit of an herbal hop finish with still a lot of bitterness trailing behind. I thought the bitterness might have died down a bit in the older age and it may have gained a bit of body, but i was wrong.
spicy cinnamon aroma, dark ruby, menthol with gross spiciness mostly ginger
Khaki head, hoppy fruit aroma, sour and tangy flavor right off the bat, dark amber coloring, hintes of pine needles, nice hop bitters, kind of ice tea-ish flavor, tart finish

I'm not much of a fan of this brewery but since I love winter beers I thought I'd give this a shot. I sure wish they'd have advertised this as a Ginger beer as I might have liked it better. I was caught completely off-guard with all the ginger considering I was expecting something a little more along the lines of Jubelale. I gotta be in the mood for ginger and I wasn't as I tried it. Even so, this beer is average at best. If you like ginger beer you might like this, but there's far better out there. Okay, this is an average brown beer with quite a bit of ginger and very little body.

Like ginger? Then I think you'll like this beer, since that's pretty much what's going on. I could not drink more than 12 oz of this, although the ginger and spice flavor is pretty well balanced with the rest of the beer. Interesting to say the least.

Aroma features malt, cloves and cinnamon---smells like the Holidays...Color is a rich brown with medium beige head and copious honeycomb lace...This brewery's sigature caramel malt profile is in evidence here, but in light measure...Mild hops and a sprinkling of spices buoy the top-end and linger through the lightly dry finish...Carbonation is suitably light...Body is medium-light---a little too light for a winter warmer...Flavors are spritely and pleasant, but again lack a measure of desired "oomph." Overall, a wonderful appearance and aroma highlight this offering, but the main body of work proves disappointing in comparison to the hopeful prelude.

This beer has continuously won the Xmas beer tasting at my annual holiday tasting. However, the 2002 version had very little spiciness/aroma compared to previous years. It is almost like the beer was "dumbed down" to make it more appealing to the masses. Great tastes of Cinnamon, Nutmeg and Allspice make this a holiday standard.

This was an interesting beer, decent looking amber in color but really funky flavor. Un-identifiable really. It was okay, not at all one I would get again, and I had an odd stomach ache when I got home from the brewery.

Truly shocked to see all the low scores on this beer. First time I had it, it was labelled as "Happy Viking Ale" at the apply named Happy Viking pub in Marysville, CA. As smooth an ale I�ve ever tasted, great flavor and good finish. I went on quite a search trying to find this ale again, and finally tracked it down at the Pyramid Taproom in the Oakland Airport. I was not disappointed, and it was worth the wait.

Draft at Embassy Suites, Sacramento. Billed as "Tower Bridge" Unfiltered Amber. Copper-brown with a light haze and a small ring of bubbles. Mild caramel and wheat grain nose. Taste is soured orange juice, toffee, toasted nut and bland wheat. Light-medium body has high carbonation and is fairly well balanced.
I, for one, do not get the haters of this beer. It pours brown and cloudy. Aroma of bananas, and other fruits. Flavor is cidery, but also has notes of prune and raisin in there. Finishes clean.
Cloudy red brown in color... Not very aromatic... Malty flavor with cidery tones and minimal balance... Bit a terribly impressive beer, probably had better homebrews...

Sample at Burger Bar in Las Vegas (as "Burger Bar Amber"). The beer is a murky dark orange-amber color with a minimal off-white head that disappears quickly. Spotty lacing on the glass. The aroma is fruity with notes of musty malt. Medium, smooth body with a midly tart fruit character and pale malt and lightly bitter hops flavors. The finish is clean and lightly fruity with a short tart aftertaste. Just average overall.
Served at Outback Steakhouse under the moniker "Aborigine Amber" - Thin and sweet with a heavy dose of spice and a just a bit of sour hop leaf. Whaddya expect?

On draft at Horatio�s restaurant in San Leandro, CA (12/27/07). I was told this was brewed by Horatio�s by the wait staff and didn�t think to ask more questions about it during my visit. Thanks to milo2 for clearing up the origin of this amber. Pours amber with tan head. The aroma is mild and vaguely malty and not really much else. I struggled to pull that out of the nose. The taste begins with a bite of hops and a hint of metal. It quickly turns rich and malty with roasted malts mixed with some light dark fruity esters. The hops almost vanish into the finish leaving a maltiness and faint dark fruitiness into the brief after taste.

Draught at Falling Rock. Pours hazy amber with an average, frothy, off-white, lasting head, good lacing. Aroma is average malt (bread, grain), light hops (flowers), average yeast (sweat) with notes of apple and pear. Light bodied, thin texture, average duration, and a bitter finish. Short duration, light sweetness, acidity and bitterness.

I don�t usually do this but I am rating this one from memory. Ordered this after work for a happy hour...it went under the house beer selection served at Kincaid�s Steak House. My coworker commented how his beer looked different, given that he was not used to drinking unfiltered beers before. He wasn�t going to drink it, but then after the waitress came back and explained that it was unfiltered, he ended up drinking it. What I remember is a typical amber ale flavor but some spices added. This was pretty refreshing after a long day of work.

Draft. Had this one at the Oakland airport under the name of Jet Set Amber Ale. Cloudy, opaque amber about the color of fresh squeezed apple juice. Very mild aroma - almost nothing there - faint maltiness with a bit of spice. Flavor is sweet and spicy with a little hop bite and pepper in the finish. Full body ad gentle carbonation. Not bad.

On tap (12oz) at the brewpub in Washington DC on 12-Mar-2018. Black in colour with a small tan coloured head. Full body and soft carbonation. Taste is expresso, roasted malt and chocolate. Some tobacco and wood. Sweet and thick - lots of coffee, not enough hops.
Sampler at the source in town for Scott's wedding. Thick and viscous. A little sweet and a touch of soy sauce molasses on the finish.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a deep black with a thin tan head. Big coffee, plum, cocoa, chocolate. Medium bodied, warm and boozy, cocoa, chocolate. Long and warming alcohol on the finish.

Draft sampler at Capitol Hill location on July 11, 2009. Very dark black color that�s maybe a slight bit darker than this brewery�s Prohibition Porter, intense aroma that favors the alcohol, nice rich sweet flavor with good balancing bitterness and a licorice note. This was the best of the five beer sampler flight I had.

On draft at Capitol City Brewing Co. in downtown. Pours dark black with beige head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts. Medium bodied with appropriate carbonation. Finishes with bold coffee flavors
From notes - one of first beers I rated, not a good idea to pick such a strong style, may need to revisit it.

21 nov 2013, tap at Capitol City Brewing. Black. Nose is delicious sweet coffee aroma-coffee with demarara sugar. Full body, creamy, and mildly fizzy. Really tastes of sweetened, cold black coffee. Pretty tasty. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On draft at Capitol City Brewing Co. in Virginia. The beer is dark brown, approaching black, with a finger�s width of beige head. The aroma brings coffee, chocolate, and roast, respectively. Nicely done. Coffee leads the way, though chocolate and roast notes are omnipresent. Medium bodied with appropriate carbonation. Alcohol is masked quite well by the bold coffee flavors. A solid beer. I would have this again. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 01-29-2012

On tap at brewpub. Pitch black with a short-lasting beige head. Tastes slightly roasted, coffee, milk chocolate and a touch of bourbon. Coffee bitterness and alcohol in the finish, notes of ash. Watery. Not a legendary imperial stout.

I really enjoyed this stout. A black pour with a brown head. Strong aroma of chocolate, coffee and caramel. Medium-heavy body with lots of dark fruit and chocolate upfront then coffee and alcohol. Really good.
Can. Golden in colour, with a slight, white, head and moderate carbonation. An easy drinking lager with a touch of hop, crisp malts and a solidly bitter finish. Ok.
Clear golden with a frothy but fast dissipating head. Smell of yeast and grass. Refreshing but with a rather watery taste. Medium carbonation.
clear golden colour, minimal, quickly dosappearing white head; aroma and taste of a typical malt-dominant cheap lager with cardboard, metallic and slight apple notes; nothing notable
Can. Deep gold in colour, with a slight, white, head and moderate carbonation. A sweetish lager, with a slight metallic edge and moderately bitter finish. So so.
F�r den Preis ist es gar nicht so schlecht... gut gek�hlt und dann ist es f�r den Sommee ganz ok... 4.5 ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Can in an apartment in Z�rich. Clear golden colored with a medium sized white head. Malty aroma of hay and grain. Malty flavor of grain and hops. Hoppy finish.

Can @ Home. Pours clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma of malt, corn, grass, cardboard. Flavor is sweet, malt, corn, white sugar, grass, cardboard. Thin watery body, average to lively carbonation, sweet finish. 211217
4.8% alk. Jo� jedna jeftina supermarket piva iz �vicarske. Naravno da nije ni�ta posebno, ali ,mo�e se popiti, provjereno.

Review: 50cl Can of Tell Lager: ABV: 4.8% Think it came in at about 50 to 60 cents a can, as far as I can remember, but way cheaper than more established brands. On pour I got a golden colour with a large frothy head appearing, Looks like there is a bit of sediment hanging around resulting in a darkish, not clear,golden colour. (perhaps I got a bad batch?) There is a good bit of carbonation going on, the beer has a decent sized head that surprisingly stuck around and has some decent lacing. Had a nice lagery smell and was grainy, which was faint but ok. Onto the taste, it was light enough but did manage to get some nice big mouthfuls Tastes ok, smooth and easy enough to quench, albeit had a slight sour bitter note to it. Has the expected lagery taste, with light pale malts and grains, slightly metallic. Overall not too bad, considering the price of it. For a cheap beer it can do the business, just about I might add!
can bb 23/1/18 oro limpida buonaschiuma piutyosto persistente cereale filo zolfo cosi in bocca un leggero amaro poco elegante niente aroma

500 ml can poured into a hotel water glass. The beer is a clear yellow with a fluffy head of white foam. The aroma is grains and grassy mellow hops. Taste is sweet and grainy. Lighter body and medium carbonation. Decent overall.

Bottled. Amber gold, moderate head and condition. Ginger aroma lingers but finally other notes appear, mainly malt and bruised nettles. More ginger and malt in the mouth and an initialy sweet malt finish turns dry towards the end.

column4: Les Brasseries du Cameroun - Groupe SABC (Groupe Castel)
column5: Bottle. Pours yellow. Aroma is grains, cardboard, some malt. Flavor follows the nose. Overall: not good, but i have had worse...

column4: Les Brasseries du Cameroun - Groupe SABC (Groupe Castel)
column5: 500ml bottle. Pours clear golden yellow colour. Moderate white head. Maltiness, veggies in the aroma. Malty, bit grassy taste. Vegetables. Maltiness, vegetables in the aftertaste. Quite random macrolager, which wont taste betterbten even cold.

column4: Les Brasseries du Cameroun - Groupe SABC (Groupe Castel)
column5: 500ml bottle from Afrika Market. Pours clear yellow colour, white head. Aroma is grainy, sweet, some vegetables. Taste is grainy, malty, vegetables, sweet. Light body, average carbonation. I've had worse.

column4: Les Brasseries du Cameroun - Groupe SABC (Groupe Castel)
column5: Bottle in Cotonou, Benin. Quite normal african lager, corny, grassy, not good, but good after surviving the crushing eat around here

column4: Les Brasseries du Cameroun - Groupe SABC (Groupe Castel)
column5: 1-4-1-1-5 Botella @IV cata Ratebeer Asturias. 09/11/2015. Color amarillo, aromas y sabores rancios.
Sampled cask conditioned. Amber coloured. Some grassy hop aroma. Dry, light bodied and crisp with flowery flavour. Very quaffable bitter with only slight bitterness.
