Balanced, well rounded, with some light bitterness as well. Dry earthy finish. Lightly carbonated, nice and dry. Aged rather well really. Good.

Vintage 2006. Appearance: Pours out a dark brown, near black body with a burgeoning, light beige head. Smell: An aged aroma currently embodied by a deep vinous fruitiness and staunch earthiness. Notes of darkened barley and baker�s chocolate are secondary. Taste: Roasted barley and unsweetened chocolate enveloped in an ultra thin coating of vanilla. Eventually, a modest sweetness appears. Earthy throughout. Touch of Italian almond biscotti. A strong dark fruitiness akin to over-ripened plums. Slight alcohol warmth on the sweet, malty finish. Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Medium carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel. Drinkability: While I had no trouble making my Save vs. Enrapture roll, I did still find the Dungeon Master�s Imperial Stout to be pretty good.

22oz bottle from a trade with 11026 some time ago..... not too intriguing of a pour. close to a cola black with brown edges with a thin tan head that is quick to recess.... aroma of roasted malt and chocolate..... wasn�t expecting the flavor to hold up but it did with a sweet malt bill emphasizing the chocolate, roast, and sweet caramel notes. thin mouthfeel somewhat detracts but this is still a fairly solid imperial stout that has withstood some aging. would have scored higher had it looked better and had more body to it.
Botttle,this poured a nice dark black with a small tan head and a roasty malty finished and it aged well the alcohol was well hidden.CHEERS!
22 oz. bottle - thanks to riversideak for sharing; pours jet black, roasty and thin; syrupy, thin texture; caramel, vanilla and mild roastiness; super thin, but decent overall

22. Thanks, Riverside! Jet black. Caramel highlights. Headless, laceless, still. Sharply boozy nose, even after all this time. Some vanilla showing. Watery light body (!). Sweet, sticky mid-palate. Mild finish. Shockingly underdeveloped...may be shot by the hands of time.

22 oz. bottle via trade with kp - I�m not sure how old this bottle is, but since I got it from kp, its got to be a few years old. Pours a clear brown color with a thin light tan head that faded fairly quick. No lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, light chocolate, cola, and dark esters. Suprised to not pick up much oxidation in the aroma. The flavor is quite vinous with light chocolate and roasted malt. There is a tad bit oxidation in the flavor. The flavor and alcohol lingers a bit on the palate. The palate seems a little thin. Overall an enjoyable beer to drink and glad I had the chance to try it. I bet it was really good fresh. Thanks Keith.

Bottle shared by Crosling. Poured a deep brown/black color with a thin tan head that diminished to a ring. Aroma of light chocolate, roasted malt, leather, and hints of dark fruit. The flavor was pretty similar, with a light chocolate malt leading into a roasty middle with undertones of coffee and fruit (I detected berries, but I may be crazy). Full and smooth, not much alcohol apparent. Sort of simple, a bit sweet, but overall it was a solid imperial stout that I am glad I was lucky enough to try. Thanks Nick.

Pitch black with a light brown head. Medium strong smell of mocha-chocolate malts. Smooth oily mouthfeel. Very sweet taste of dark chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Has a chalky flavor on the tongue to finish. Sweet even for an IRS. Not much depth of flavor here, but good in its own right. Alcohol is well hidden. 22406

Thanks to whoever gave me this one, been sitting in the cellar for a while. Pours out black with a tiny brown head. Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate and slight oxidation due to the age of this bottle. Flavor is complex with a nice thick mouthfeel. Chocolate, roasted malt slight dark fruits. Warming/alcohol finish. Nice

column1: Rio Salado Blizzard Bock Winter Wheat Ale
column5: Must afge in the bottle. Burnt coffee aroma. Dark ruby red color when held to light. Head was tan and was gone quickly. Flavor was of sweet and sour candy. Acidic finsh that I really didn�t care for.

column1: Rio Salado Blizzard Bock Winter Wheat Ale
column5: Thanks for the trade, TannerTavernboys! This one rubbed me the wrong way from the start for some reason. Maybe it was the seemingly random mashing of words/styles (Wheat! Bock! Winter! Applesauce!) but unfortunately this didn�t seem to gel for me. Pours dark brown with a thin light tan head and little lacing. Aroma of sour fruit and toasted malt. Medium-bodied with a sourness that permeates, making me wonder if this might have been a bad bottle. Malt, wheat and clove flavors are dominated by the sourness. The finish is dry and fruity. I�d like to try this again to determine if there are problems with the beer in general or if is what the it is supposed to be like.

column1: Rio Salado Blizzard Bock Winter Wheat Ale
column5: tap at taphouse-tempe, AZ-pours deep brown amber with no head whatsoever. big spicy, fruitcake like aroma with banana and clove in there as well. lots of spicy flavors, but the alcohol is not well hidden and becomes hot for such a low abv beer. body is very low in carbonation which could have been a problem in delivering the flavors properly. maybe this keg is really old or something. wish i had it fresh from the winter time.

column1: Rio Salado Blizzard Bock Winter Wheat Ale
column5: Pours a brilliantly clear ruby color when held up to the light, otherwise it is a deep amber color. It is topped by a thinnish, frothy light brown head. As I pour this beer I get strong notes of banana, when I go in for a better smell I get hints of higher alcohols and fusels, as well as banana and clove notes. The taste is palate filling and sweet up front, almost like a banana cream pie. The finish is sour and salty with a dry finish that actually balances the front part of this beer despite the fact that it might be a bit infected. Along with the sour finish this beer evokes thoughts of sour cherries, and oak. The finish has hints of roasted malts, but mostly the astringent notes of burnt grain husks. I am not quite sure that this beer is supposed to be as sour as it is, the sourness is only a bit here, and perhaps it is just yeast derived, but whatever I certainly like it. This beer would perhaps be a bit unbalanced without it.

column1: Rio Salado Blizzard Bock Winter Wheat Ale
column5: Draught @ the 5th Annual Strong Beer Festival in Scottsdale, Arizona. Brown with a large, dense and lasting head of foam. Moderately aromatic, with hints of banana, clove, nuts and toasted malts. The flavor is actually pretty delicious and was one of the best beers at the fesitival showing notes of big, bready, fruitcake flavors and hints of banana, clove and a certain tartness and acidity that is hard to describe.

column1: Rio Salado Blizzard Bock Winter Wheat Ale
column5: Bottle. Dark brown color with a light brown head. A sour fruit, tart and cherry flavor and aroma. Warming. Thanks to Tim for bringing this back from his road trip.

column1: Rio Salado Blizzard Bock Winter Wheat Ale
column5: Interesting aroma - typical weizen banana and clove, but there is also chocolate, malt, cherries, and a hint of molasses. Very dark mahogany brown, minimal head. Flavor is spicy and fruity, with a little chocolate and roast character. Balance is slightly sweet, pretty full bodied, warming. Overall an interesting beer, kind of like a weizen-stout-bock.

column1: Rio Salado Blizzard Bock Winter Wheat Ale
column5: Color is dark as a moonless night with a minimal head. Very malty aroma with some hints of banana. Malt definitly leads the taste but has a smooth, sweet, fruity nutty flavor. Few hints of spices. Still it warms the heart. Nice job.

column1: Rio Salado Blizzard Bock Winter Wheat Ale
column5: heady brew great bock witha nice what lick like most rio;s it has a good ehad an a strong alcohol content which is always good a nice winter beer that is is terrific for locals like us cheers

column1: Rio Salado Blizzard Bock Winter Wheat Ale
column5: Wow...this is one of the better Weizen Bock's out there. The aroma tells the story with banana and cloves just smacking you right up front...some forest scents, grapefruits, and roasty woodiness also apparent. It pours a dark brown to blackish color with a small dark brown head which dissipated quickly. The carbonation level is very active in this beer with bubbles clinging to the side of the glass. The flavor is definitely clovey and banana with a sweet hint of vanilla, raisins and lemony grapefruit in the finish. Perhaps a cranberry hint in there too...super fruity beer. Dry spicey ending..bittersweet..perfectly so. Nice mouthfeel, and a well rounded Bock...i liked it a lot. Thanks to mitch!
A dark amber color with a medium off-white head. A malt aroma and taste, fairly sweet.
a full molasses aroma - burnt pieapple and salted liquorice. thin. this style is dying in the czech republic so try it while you can

Head is initially large, frothy, rocky, off-white, mostly lasting. Body is dark orange-brown. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, toasted dark bread, nutty), lightly hoppy (herbs). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Mouthfeel is the main downer here (very watery and fairly thin). Very quaffable and clean, though, with very good flavor balance and pleasant aroma.
Better than I expected. Nice roasted malt flavor. Color is a dark amber. Very smooth and easy drinking.
A bit light for a munich dunkel, so I think that this "Garnet" beer is actually some other style (the label calls it a "Czech Amber Beer"). This is fairly bitter and unremarkable (rather thin, too).
Dark amber. Neutral aroma. Dry, oily flavour, lingering bitterness. A nice dryish polotmav� (semi-dark Czechish lager).

0,5 bottle bought in Roda supermarket. Dark brown colour with thick tanned head , aroma is dark malt , slighly roasted , taste is malty , caramel , roastiness in the finish and aftertaste, fine bitterness, medium body, soft carbonation.

Bottle. Black colour, rocky head that does not stay long. Aroma is caramel, alcohol. Medium sweetness. Watery. Boring!
0.5l bottle. Dark brown color with beige head. Aroma is caramel, chocolate and malt. Taste is sweet with chocolate and caramel with medium bitterness. Overall it's very good and balanced beer.
Brown color with small white head. Roasted malt, slightly sugary. Light bitter roasted taste. Light dry and watery.
0.5l bottle. Brown color with browny head. Aroma of malt, grain and coffee. Taste is slightly bitter and sweet, but mostly watery.
500 ml bottle at home, thanks Viktor! Copper color with beige head. Aroma is buttery, slight burnt sugar and malt. Taste is malty, buttery, slight grass, sugar and hay.
Bottle, 50 cl. Overall pleasant and well balanced. Reminding somewhat of a British bitter.

Bottle 0,50L. Courtesy of Teo. Clear golden color with a finger of creamy white head. Aroma of malt, hay and cardboard. Taste starts light sweet and malty, while finish is light to medium bitter and hoppy. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Solid and drinkable pilsner.

0.5 l bottle. Pours clear golden with medium head. A: malty T: flat, thin, waterly, low bitter,

0,5l can. Clear yellow colour with medium lasting white head. Aroma: Fresh hay and grass with flourish notes. Taste: Has a quite malty start with a decent, fresh bitter hoppy mouthfeel. Light body with fizzy carbonation. Long lasting bitter and dry finish. Straight ahead pilsner.

Firm head, fair level of bitterness, pours golden color. Strange something like a candle aftertaste.

Amertume herbeuse en final. Avis : Pilsner correcte, sans d�fauts majeurs mais dans la moyenne des Pilz que l�on trouve en masse dans le pays.
Can. Pours golden with medium white head. Aroma is malty, dry, hay, some cardboard, light vegetables. Taste is malty, bitter, some hay, light vegetables, light paper. Nice beer!

(bottle 0,5l) Aroma: Grainy, sweet malty. Appearance: Clear golden color. Medium, white head. Taste: Medium sweet, light bitter, light malty/grainy. Palate: Medium body. Creamy texture. Light bitter finish. Overall: Average.
Bottled, Cesky Brod, CZ, Malt,bread, hay and grassy aroma, Clear golden color, bigger lacing head, Sweeter taste, some bitter finish, Medium body, Average carbon, Decent beer.

aka Opat Sv�tl� speci�l 13 -- Served in an Opat mug in CZ in July 2011. Golden; clear with no visible carbonation; head is less white (more tan) than expected. Very nice and very sweet aroma of malt with a trace of hops. The flavor is more distinctive than the aroma; it has a fine bitter-sweet mix, with a nice flavorful hit of light toasted malt and hops that passes quickly leaving a lasting but mild hoppy finish. Very nice! Medium-light body; crisp. O - my first Opat is a winner. This tasted great by itself; with some trepidation, i tried it with some sweets that came to the table before i finished (vanilla ice cream; cinnamon-sour cherry-caramel parfait) with which the beer paired remarkably well! This brewery makes many flavored beers -- including pepper, cherry & apricot -- that i am now even more eager to try.
My favorite of the Czech bottled beers I brought home. A good bit of malt and the hops were still fresh. Very clean and easy to drink.

toast, grass, spruce, cereal, cheese, leaves, bubblegum, soy sauce, raisin, butterscotch, golden, sparkling, minimal head, medium sweetness, very bitter, medium sourness, umami, full body, sticky, average carbonation, bitter, long finish,

Muffiger, sehr grasiger und wirklich SEHR eigener Antrunk. Etwas herb, weiter sehr grasig, CO2-arm, komisch. Malzig werdend, woran sich die Grasigkeit anpasst. Zum Ende hin besser, da ausgeglichener. Sehr komisch! Test vom 29.10.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,5,8,6,11,6 - 6,60

Bottle at SM�F 2010. It poured a clear yellow-golden liquid with a small white head. Flavour of malt and earth. Semi-smooth mouthfeel, dry and light-medium body. Decent pilsner, didn�t look to good, but fresh and easy to drink. After having tasted a bunch of beers from this brewery I have problems seperating them, they taste very similar to each other.
on tap at klasterni pivnice at praha 7. it was awful!!! taste like CHEMICAL BANDAID.
0.5 l bottle at PBF. Golden color. Malty honeyish aroma. Dryish, malty, honeyish, biscuity, flowery, papery and slightly herbal flavor with low bitterness. Dull, not fresh.

On July 16, 2009 as "Opat Svetle Specialni Pivo" marked 5.5% ABV VV 13.06.09 Purchased at Pivni Galerie in Prague - Sampled on July 16, 2009 Hazy golden color, big white head. Sweet, malty scent. Sweet, malty, herbal taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness.
0.5 l bottle. Golden color beer with big white head. Aroma of hop, herbs, malt. Taste is soft malt, bread with hop in finish.

Bitterness below average, hop, with woody notes. In the aftertaste, maltiness fades into the background, and hop hop bitterness that is gathering ahead stretches.
Orange color, middle foam size. Good beer, aroma and taste fit into the style.

500ml bottle from beershop-bg, drunk at home on an icy December evening. Pours crystal clear with a thick pillow of multi textured head, heavy lacing and fast rising carbonation. Gold in colour. On the nose, light white bread, hay and faint floral honey. In the mouth fairly high carbonation gives a light frothy feel at first, but this is soon eclipsed by the high bitterness, flavours fairly similar to the aromas, slight sweetness, with a short, bitter finish. Overall, a very ordinary pilsner that would not stand out in a line up of supermarket lagers.

Draft pour. The beer is a clear gold with a white head of foam. The aroma has bready and grassy notes. Mildly sweet and toasty notes in the taste along with green tea and peppercorns. Lighter body and medium carbonation.

the aroma is malty and floral with shades of grain, straw and some herbs... the taste is malty and herbal with notes of grain, hay, flowers and some grasses... bitter, sweet and dry aftertaste...
Bottle. Golden colour, nice head. Aroma is mostly malt, a bit of herbal hops. Light bitterness. Solid.

500ml bottle from Edea, drunk at home on a pleasant summer afternoon. Pours clear with a finely frothy, almost mousse head that retained pretty well, heavy lacing, visible rising carbonation for a few seconds. Gold in colour. Aroma predominated by caramel and bread with floral honey. In the mouth, bitterness and alcohol presence from the first sip, medium texture, flavours consistent with the aromas, rising bitterness with a short finish but leaving some sugar in the aftertaste. Overall, a pretty standard pilsner with a good malt/hop balance, refreshing and crisp, but perhaps overly bitter.

Bottle. Pours deep golden with thin head. Nose is almost non existent, but it�s also true that the bottle is too cold. In taste it�s fairly bitter with some corny touch, but it�s just so much that it doesnt bother me in a pilsner. Not bad altogether.
Plain golden big soapy head. Malty aroma. Prickly, sweet malt forward beer with constant mild bitterness. Easy drinking lager, satisfying and not too filling.

The bottle is notable for the picture of the great Czech author, Bohumil Hrabal, who lived and grew up in the Nymburk Brewery (there is also a bust of him in the Prague pub U Zlateho Tygr where he used to hang out). The beer is named after one of his novels. It is a very drinkable, light pilsner with a fresh taste. It is lightly malty with a fairly long-lasting head - very enjoyable on a lazy summer day. It reminds me of the 11 degree Kozel, but with less bitterness

Auch auf dem Etikett dieser Flasche aus Nymburk l�chtelt Buhum�l Hrabal herab, der in der Brauerei gewohnt hat und daher so etwas wie das Maskottchen ist und seine Werke Biernamen der Brauerei sind. Es ist ein klassisches elfgr�diges Helles, das aber etwas zu viel S�ure hat. Es ist ein recht gutes Bier, aber auch kein Top-Bier; es fehlt mir etwas an S�ffigkeit.

Big, white, good retention head, gold, almost clear, aroma is malty, bit grainy, bready, caramel, taste malty, bready, decent bitterness, bit too much on the sweet side for me, medium body and carbonation, ok drinkable.

Piwo jasne zlociste ze spora piana, moze nie tak spora jak w�osy Magdy Vasaryovay, spora tez dawka chmielu na jezyku, slodowosc srednia z nutami armelowymi. Piwo dobre choc nie tak dobre jak film Postriziny Jiri'a Menzel'i, ale jako ciekawostka czemu nie

Aroma; fruit, malts, roasted notes, toffee note. Look; modest off white head, clear deep golden body. Taste; caramel, malts, fruit, soft hops, salt note, roasted note, nice tail. Feel; normal. Overall; good. [30cl 5.2% btl Pardubice CZ]
Bottle. Small white head. Clear cobber body. Sweet fruity aroma of apples and pears. Smooth and relatively sweet caramel honey flavor without much bitterness. Nice and different.
Lager aroma; not unlike Pilsner Urquell. Dark gold in color with a forthy, off-white head. Ample visible carbonation. Good lager flavor.

i�m always pleased when i find a czech pilsener that is quite different to the norm. this surprises with a roast malt aroma. weird porridge and peanut oil subsided to a good-o�s salty dryness. great stuff

In the US, this is called Pernstejn Czech Premium Lager. Darker than most lagers, with a sweet Czech malt. As it warms, the malt flavor increases. Believe it or not, I tasted sausage (in a good way, I guess).
Pale golden. Malty, salty and toffeeish with bitter finish. Tasty and unusual interpretation of the style.
Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is malt, toffee, light alcohol and fruity notes. Flavour is malt, alcohol, fruity notes, pine and light grass.
bottle from Pivni Galerie. Dark golden colour, nearly amber, small but persistent head. Malty and fruity nose. Malty and fruity flavours dominate, well-rounded by a pleasantly hoppy note.

Bottle: Deep golden coloured with a faint haze, small, but stable foamy layer, visible carbonation; malty, a bit caramelly nose, rounded ba a distinctive herbal hoppiness; moderate sweet-bitter flavour, rather light bodied; a bit fruity, herbal-malty finish. More a rural franconian brew than a Bohemian Pils...... (�eske pivo �islo 200 !)
Bottle. Noticeable alcohol amongst the sweet malt. Not much hop presence to speak of. So despite being not overly strong seems like it is.

Bottled. Golden, with a creamy white head, leaving nice lacings. Malt and grain dominates the aroma, just some hints of hops. Fruity and malty flavor, with a finish that�s mostly malty. Medium body. Quite nice lager, with a low level of hops. (060701)
Clear yellow body, fleeting white head. Fairly odorless and tastless. Some malt, herbs, hops, but very faint. Medium bodied. Slight malt flavor. Pretty mundane.
An orange beer with an off-white head. The aroma is malty with primary notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of both dust and caramel.
Bottled: golden coloured. Clear. Beige head. Light herbal and hoppy aroma. flavour is sweet and light herbal. Medium bodied. Has some sweetness and a vague bitterness.
(Bottle 50 cl) Pours a clear, fully golden with a creamy, white head. Sweetish, malty nose. Full-bodied, completely dominated by pilsener malt. Some alcohol presence and a light-bitter finish. 160206
Bottled. Golden coloured. Sweet and slightly skunky aroma. Very sweet with unpleasant cardboard notes. Thin. Not good.
Overall: Bread, nuts, red fruits. Note: Bottle 500 ml at Ingemarsgatan 7. Reviewed 2014-08-03.

Bottle 500ml. @ [ pre-TSODRBSG13 ], Ulfborg. [ As Bogesund 1788 R�de Hanen ]. ABV: 5.2%. Clear medium amber orange colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, malt extract, earthy malt, sour malt, cardboard. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average duration, sweet malt, sugary malt. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20130830]
50cl bottle thanks to omhper. Thanks per! Called "Bogesund 1788 R�de Hanen". Color is light copper to red. Head is thin. Body is thin. Taste is light bitter. Aroma is light caramel and metal.

Sampled @ RB Danish Summer Gathering 2013 day 1, Ulfborg. Bottle. Clear yellow to orange color, small white head. Smell and taste malts, very grainy, sweetish. Average body and carbonation. Don�t really like it.
Bottle as "Bogesund 1788", 5.2%. Slightly hazy amber with small white head. Aroma is malt, caramel, toasted and bread. Flavour is malt, caramel, toasted, medium sweet and bread.
Bottle @ Danish Ratebeer Summer Gathering, Ulfborg. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are caramel, malt, grass and hops.

50 cL bottle as Bogesund 1788 R�de Hanen. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is mild toasted malty and dry malty. Toasted malty, metallic and biscuit. Bitter and dry toasted finish.

Bottle @ TSODRBSG13, Ulfborg as Bogesund 1788 R�de Hanen. Hazy amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and light grainy. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. 300813
Botella 50 cl tomada en Praga marzo 2000. Fcprf 10..08....2001. (coleccion). (r06) Pocos recuerdos. Cuerpo ligero f�cil de beber. Sin mucho m�s.
Draught at Na Verandach, Praha. Pale amber coloured, small to medium white head, light caramel nose. Very watery with some weak notes of malt and caramel with grassy herbal finish. Boring.
I am a little biased, but there is nothing like drinking this beer straight out of the tap in a bar in Prague.
One of the best Czech beers. This beer has an amber colour and a pleasant taste with a bitter aftertaste. Wonderful on tap!

No doubt the best product of Prague Breweries and in my opinion surprisingly among the T10 Czech beers which is truly an achievement. Unfortunately quite difficult to come by. Best served draft (not bottled) as with most Czech beers.
Amber coloured. Grassy, citric aroma. Rather dry, medium bodied, quite bitter. An execellent fresh tasting polotmav�.

(50 cl can from Systembolaget) I think it�s the same, although in my case the beer is called "Kopparbergs The Beer". It�s ecologically marked and seems to be on the way of not being sold at Systembolaget any longer, I had to specially order mine. Clear pale yellow color, rather big white head. Acidic scent that�s not very nice, rotten grass and some malt also. Sweet sugary taste with a touch of alcohol and also malt. Metallic aftertaste. Rather unpleasant mouthfeel. Low bitterness.
Yellow colour with a white head. Malty, fruity aroma with grassy notes. Malty and sweet flavor with a light fruityness.
Can. Clear yellow coloured with a huge white head. Aroma of malts and fruits. Flavour of malts and fruits.
Can. Clear pale golden colour with a longlasting white head. Malty grassy aroma. Sweet malty grasy flavor. Dry malty slightly bitter finish.
Can. Pale yellow colour with a big white head. Carboard aroma and a sweet malty, carboard taste. Light body with a dry finish.
Canned. Pale golden coloured. Unpleasant unclean aroma. Unclean and metallic flavour. Thin. Bad.

I don�t understand the scores for the beer - as its name, this is THE beer, so it should have good scores.... A dark yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet malty with a light hoppy note, and the flavor is sweet malty with light notes of straw, leading to a dry bitter end. A very clean beer.
(on can) Metallic, pea aroma, urinyellow and and burby feeling to the tomak- Taste isen�t much; lighly grassy, since it brewed on barly, guess there�s some malt too...no, none.

Canned: Pale yellow coloured. Clear. White small head. This is not a very good beer. Some malt, some fruit and some matallic sharp herbal hops notes. Is very thin and watery and has a somewhat artificial bitterness in the end.

Canned. Golden colour, big foamy head. Horrible vegetably malts in aroma. Metallic malty flavour with some hops and cooked vegetables. Pure crap. They should keep doing their cider, which atleast is drinkable...

(Bottle 50 cl) Comes as "Gellivare Stark" - I believe it�s the same as this. Golden with a tall, handsome head. Very hoppy and aromatic, with the hops also adding quite some bitterness in the finish. Comes with an unusual tartness that somehow spoils the balance - did they forget some cider in there somewhere? 140503
Golden coloured. Fruity aroma. Vegetable aroma. Sweet, clean and medium bodied with a hint of harsh bitterness in the finish.

Cask at The Moon Under Water (JDW), Watford in 2013. Clear copper with a spotty white head. Aroma of damp malt, grassy hops and light dried fruit. Really typical cask bitter, with a malt dominated flavour.
Cask at the David Macbeth Moir. Pours copper, nose is dull toffee, taste is similar, crisp.
Nov 2012 draught Peckham - bit weak and watery. Not much in foretaste but aftertaste is OK. Drinkable, but wouldn�t have again.

Cask-conditioned at the Commercial Rooms, Bristol, November 2012. Deep copper with a moderate, off-white head. Caramel, brown sugar and a slightly roasty edge, before a lingering, bitter finish. good.

Objectively speaking: Fruity, soft rye ale. I like: The rye spiciness which I enjoy comes out, though timidly. Mostly dry palate. Interesting fruity array (peach, pear and the likes). Soft bodied. I dislike: Frankly deceivingly simple for a rye beer and really light-bodied. Not much cerealic complexity. Not very aromatic. Timid carbonation accentuates the wateriness. More hops would have been welcome.
Very pale yellow. Tangy, moderately astringent. Dry cereal finish with a bit of that rye twang. Not terribly fancy or complex, pretty easy drinking.
Pale yellow, thin head, little carbonation. Faint aroma. Very dry. Grainy, spicy, bitter. Pretty good.
Gold with hints of red. A gooey head and lace. Flat malt with hints of hops. Semi sweet. Good carbonation and medium body good mouthfeel as well. Very solid offering.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy amber with a small white head with good retention. The aroma has citrus, pineapple and something that reminds me of a locker room, yet I�m not repulsed by it. Medium body with semi-soft carbonation. The taste has the dryness of the rye, a nice form of harshness and dry grapefruits. The finish continues even drier with pine needles and pine cones. A very enjoyable IPA that I wish I could get on more than just a stopping place on a long road trip.

(Bottle, thanks moejuck) Pours hazy orange. Hoppy aroma with tones of tangerines, roses and malty/ grainy notes of toasty caramel and rye. Undertones of pine, apricot and grapefruit with a floral hint. Hoppy flavour as well with tones of grapefruit and some flowers. Some toasty caramell undertones. Light sweet and medium bitter. Some grapefruit bitterness lingers along with a touch of caramel and rye. Medium body.

12 oz, hand bottled. Cloudy apricot topped with a bit of white froth. Lovely nose of cantaloupe and spruce. Light carb, somewhat watery. Orange and honeydew with increasing pith drying. Rye in the end.
Lots of hops followed by some of the rye in the aroma.Pours a hazy orange with a medium off white head.Lots of hops in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with a bitter hop finish.

Draft at BrewHouse #1. Hazy copper pour with an average frothy white head that diminished slowly and had fair lacing. Moderate sweet citrus rye aroma. Medium bodywith a slick texture. Moderate balanced rye flavor with a medium bittersweet hop finish of moderate duration. Drinkable brew.

i have a place in my heart for rye in beer and this doesn�t disappoint. nice spicy rye aroma coupled with delicate floral and citrusy hops. both aromas carry over into the delightfully smooth beverage. great mouthfeel, coats everything with that great rye. excellent aftertaste and lingering spice finish. would had one or ten more but i was on a break from a convention across the street.

Cask - The Cottage, Norwich. Fine, bubbly, lasting white head leaving a soapy lace; clear golden body. Some earthy, yeast aromas with caramel and a delicate floral note and juicy citrus developing. Some tangy orange on the palate with a fair, easy-going toasty, citric bitterness. Light to medium body, good in the mouth, soft palate texture with a short to medium length finish.
27th October 2007 Warning! Early amateur rating! On tap at the Sun Inn, Kelvedon. Standard bitter - well balanced. Reasonable malt and hops. Just very standard bitter!
Cask conditioned at The Turf Tavern, Oxford. Brown amber with slight head. Not in great condition, toffee, dull, sweetish and a little too thin. Not great.

Cask in Bon Accord as best bitter. (3.8%?) Im thinking it was just an old pump clip. Aroma is biscuity malt grassy hops, hints of honey and citrus. Taste is similar though a bit thin and sweeter than expected. Good sessioning.
Cask, gravity dispense, at Wellington Arms BF �07, Bedford. Amber. Spicy hop aroma and taste. A bit watery, but fair late beitterness.

Cask, Cow and Plough, Stoughton. Hazy toffee coloured with an off-white head. Aromas are spicy, bitter hops with light maltiness. Flavours are hoppy, spicy and dry with a bitter finish. A decent traditional bitter.
Cask At The Ipswich Beer Festival.Another good beer from Mauldons,an easy session bitter.

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. With so many bitters in Mauldon�s lineup we had to refer to the good beer guide to sort out if this was indeed a scoop. Thankfully this wasn�t overlooked. Golden. Very strong bitter kick to it. A mule of bitter. The bitterness has tremendous length and is most rewarding for those willing to take the time between quaffs.

Sample at Barley�s Ale House #1. The beer is a lightly hazed gold color with a thin white head that burns away quickly. Spotty lacing. Wheat, malt and a bit of fruit in the nose. Light body with flavors of sweet malt, wheat and a touch of honey. The finish is short and fruity with a lingering sweetness left over. Average overall. Earlier Rating: 7/21/2002 Total Score: 3.4 Quite passable light summer ale. Honey is evident in the aroma. Light gold with thin head. Light, refreshing wheaty flavor but a little on the sweet side.

Draft sample at Barleys #1. Poured clear golden color with an average fizzy white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate apple honey and wheat aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Soft summer brew. Earlier Rating: 9/17/2009 Total Score: 3 Draft sample at Barleys #1. Poured clear golden color with an average fizzy white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate apple honey and wheat aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Soft summer brew.
Golden color with small offwhite head. Honey aroma. Flavor of honey with a little wheat and hops.

Not a fan of wheat beers. Noticeable honey aroma and taste. The wheat flavor is also apparent The two flavors are distinct rather than blending together. Light in color but cloudy as wheat beers tend to be. I can see why people would like this, it�s just not something I care for.
A good summer beer. A little light honey taste on a nice refreshing Wheat ale. Very refreshing on a hot day. A little disappointing for Barley's though. Their other brews raise the bar so high.
Light and tastey! Stong on the honey - which is fitting to the name. A very easy drink - very refreshing - great in the summer.

I was interested in trying this beer, but found it to not be as good as some of the other ones Barley's puts out. I like the color of the beer, but I find it to be a bit too light for this style of beer.

Draft at Barley�s in August 2012 from notes. Pours dark brown in color with a medium sized creamy beige head. The aroma and flavor have roasted malts, chocolate, and earthy hop character. This was a pretty straight forward porter that I would drink again.

On tap at the brewery. Pours dark brown with along lasting off- white head. Aroma is of dark fruit, toasted malt and hints of coffee. Body is medium, creamy and smooth. Toasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla, prunes fill the mouth. Very nice porter.

on tap at Barley�s Tap House 1, poured into a pint glass a: dark brown color with very small off white head s: chocolate and roasted malt t: chocolate and roastyness dominate flavor, slighlty smokey and nutty. Very nice porter example m&d: crisp mouth, medium body. Pretty decent beer.

Pint on nitro at the Smokehouse. Pours black with a creamy tan head. Roasty malt aroma with some coffee and a hint of black cherry. Full-flavored roasty coffee with a bit of chocolate and a creamy finish. Good stuff, and missing that watery character a lot of nitro brews have.

Black with white crowning head. Chocolate aroma, medium mouthfeel. Served room temperature which was appropriate. Nicely undercarbonated as almost all of the beers are, and therefore easier drinking as less bloated factor. A chocolate porter.

Sample @ Brewpub: Pours a dark caramel color with bubbly, thin white head. Aroma is heavily-roasted chocolate malts and some vanilla. Hops are blatant in this brew, as this porter is almost too crisp. Some carmel undertones. Tasty overall, but lacking of the robustness and fullness of other porters I have tried.

Firkin at the alehouse. Pours dark brown with ruby edges and almost zero head or hints of carbonation. Nice strong roasted chocolate aroma, chalky, malty - typical porter aroma but a good one. Taste is the same with a silky mouthfeel, smooth as hell, with a slightly watery and bland finish. I don�t know if the firkin covered up any faults with this but the low carbonation created a creamy and very enjoyable mouthfeel and an easy drinking brew. Good.

draft at brewpub appearance: dark caramel brown, thin ivory head....aroma: lightly roasted malt w/ little of anything else....taste: thin bodied, bitter roasted chocolate with a lightly hopped finish. way too carbonated and mouthfeel could have been more enjoyable. an average porter.

Date: 03/19/2006 Mode: Growler Source: Tasting clear brown, thin beige head, nice solid lace, rich chocolate aroma and flavor, good creamy body, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ***/4

On tap. Black with a sparse white head. Thin to medium palate. Aroma is a nice blend of cocoa and roast. The cocoa comes out really nice in the flavor, along with the roasted flavors, which linger well through the finish. One of their better offerings I had during my visit.

column1: Barley's Ol' Ron's Surly Oatmeal Stout
column5: Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a black color with a medium sized creamy beige head that left good lacing. The aroma was dryish with a strong cola notes and a bit of dark fruit. The flavor was toasty and woody with a hint of smoke and dark fruit. Medium length finish. Medium body. Meh.

column1: Barley's Ol' Ron's Surly Oatmeal Stout
column5: Draft. Dakr brown pour. Basic oatmeal sotut, slick mouthfeel, cocoa and roast notes, easy to drink.

column1: Barley's Ol' Ron's Surly Oatmeal Stout
column5: Poured on draft. Pours a darker brown with a khaki colored head of foam. Aroma is roasty and sweet with some Oreo characteristics. Semi creamy mouthfeel. Reminds me of dirt pie, the shit with oreos crumbled up in a vanilla pudding and chocolate pie crust. Nice stuff.

column1: Barley's Ol' Ron's Surly Oatmeal Stout
column5: Draft in a sampler at Barley�s #1. Pours a cloudy, dark coffee brown color with a small beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, cream, chocolate, and toasted sugar. The flavor follows the same lines closely. Medium-bodied, with a malty, roasty mouthfeel and bitterness at the end. Medium carbonation. Solid oatmeal stout.

column1: Barley's Ol' Ron's Surly Oatmeal Stout
column5: Solid, but safe, oatmeal stout. Very black pour, cocoa colored head. No real aroma to it, but a smooth malty flavor and a sharp roasty finish.

column1: Barley's Ol' Ron's Surly Oatmeal Stout
column5: Sample at the Alehouse. Darkest brown pour with a medium tan head. Coffee nose with some cream and sweet malt. Sweet malt flavor with vanilla, chocolate and a coffee finish.

column1: Barley's Ol' Ron's Surly Oatmeal Stout
column5: Draft@ Barleys Pours a deep dark brown with a decent tan head. This one laces excellently. Has a good roasted coffee aroma. Has a decent amount of carbination. The flavor was good. Has touches of chocolate and heartiness. Has a thick texture and a full body. Did not seem to be high ABV. Has a solid finish, and good aftertaste. Overall I liked this one a lot.

column1: Barley's Ol' Ron's Surly Oatmeal Stout
column5: Tap @ Alehouse: Pours a very dark brown with lighter brown highlights, ring of tan head. The aroma has a nice roastiness to it and smells a bit like burnt sugar. Flavor is scalded milk, rich chocolate malts, some dark chocolate and chicory coffee. There is a little bit of toasted caramel malt in there as well. Finishes like a dark coffee roast. A bit bitter.

column1: Barley's Ol' Ron's Surly Oatmeal Stout
column5: Objectively speaking: A brown, sweet and globally nondescript stout saying soft in every fashion. I like: Can�t blame it of being agressive. Rather large initial head, though it quickly fades. Minimal coffee roastiness. I dislike: No filling oatmeal presence, light-bodied and rather watery. Sweet, almost sugary palate never gets sufficient roastiness to be balanced. Blatant lack of depth for a beer scoring above 3.5.

column1: Barley's Ol' Ron's Surly Oatmeal Stout
column5: Dark, of course. Sweet, milky roast aroma. Sweet, a bit vacant in the middle, toasty and fruity. Fairly heavy body, but silky and watery at times. Sweet finish.

column1: Rio Salado Cold Front Kolsch Style Ale
column5: 12oz bottle(10/02)-A slightly hazy golden body with a nice hwit ehead which has an aroma of malt and hops. Taste of the same with some sweetness ocming in the back end on this light bodied brew. Not my favorite style but decent tasting.

column1: Rio Salado Cold Front Kolsch Style Ale
column5: Sweet malty aroma. Hazy yellow with medium white head, head disipated to a thin layer on top of beer. Some lacing. Flavor was bitter at first but by the middle and end sweet pear and apple flavors were present. Good belch after drinking this one so it must be a good beer.

column1: Rio Salado Cold Front Kolsch Style Ale
column5: On tap. Dark copper color with a light head and lacing. Sweet, fruity aroma with hint of banana and spice. Flavor is fruity with a touch of hops and yeast on the finish.

column1: Rio Salado Cold Front Kolsch Style Ale
column5: This beer is ever so lightly hazy, it shows a full gold color and is topped by a frothy pale white head. The aroma is yeasty with a hint of spiciness that is a combination of malt and hops, I also pick up a hint of lemon. The taste is dry up front, and actually it is fairly dry throughout. It has been served quite cold, which actually makes this even a bit more refreshing. There is a soft fruitiness that reminds me a bit of banana, though not in the way that a Hefeweizen does. The finish is spritzy from a healthy dose of carbonation and it is bitter from an ample (for a Kolsch) amount of bittering hops. Over all this is light and crisp, just like a Kolsch should be, it also has the characteristic soft fruitiness that one would expect. I do wish that the malt was more evident. This beer is nice and clean, it just needs a bit more malt to balance the carbonation and hop bitterness.

column1: Rio Salado Cold Front Kolsch Style Ale
column5: bottle- man, its too bad that this bottle of beer was very old. looking from the ratings, this bottle could be over 3 years old and its still on the shelf. When i found it, i was all excited to try it. I was let down badly. pours light orange with a small fizzy whiteh ead. spicy, citrus aroma with some sourness and actually, the aroma held up farily well. some notes of grapes come to mind in the aroma. The flavors however, were terribly oxidized to the point of overbearing sourness. From the few "good" flavors i get from this beer, i can tell that this would have been a fantastic kolsh (wlel its listed as an ale here, but this is definately a kolsh). I hope this brewery brews this beer again!

column1: Rio Salado Cold Front Kolsch Style Ale
column5: Medium gold color, medium head. Lighter bodied ale. Good malt flavor, subtle hops. Good balance. Mouthfeel is soft and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is malty, slightly sweet

column1: Rio Salado Cold Front Kolsch Style Ale
column5: I am not familiar with German style beers so I am not entirely sure how the should taste and look. Golden color, slight malty nose, sweet start, thin middle, slight hop flavor with more hop bitterness in the finish. Very drinkable when it is 105, but not something to write home about.

column1: Rio Salado Cold Front Kolsch Style Ale
column5: Pours a clear gold color, nice white head that dissipates quickly, lace is fair, the nose malt, the front is malt, and slightly sweet. Top is light, the finish has a nice hop dry bitter taste, the moderate carbonation makes it a tad acidic.
My flavour of the month right now. A golden ale with a bitter taste with a delicious peachy aftertaste. A very refreshing ale and well worth a try.

Bottle. Poured golden with an average sized off-white head. Aroma of hop, grass, flowers, peach and melon. Medium sweetness, moderate bitterness. Light body, watery texture, average to soft carbonation.

A bit of an odd one this as the peach was quite forward and it could be said by the uncharitable that it tasted artificial. It was a rich beer and that fruity sweetness started to dominate as I made my way down the glass. Perhaps it should have been chilled to within an inch of its life? Overall, not my thing because of the sweetness.
Crystal clear golden in colour. Peachy in taste. Quite refreshing, wish I had some over summer.
Bottle 500 ml. Dark golden color. Aroma: fruity esters, peach and malt. Taste: malt, peach, fruity, mild hops.
Small head with a clear golden orange colour. Lemonade notes on the nose. Good bitterness on the tongue, golden ale taste with cantaloupe and orange.

Bottle. Clear amber pour. Moderate creamy ivory-coloured head. The aroma is massively estery. Notes of peach, pear & strawberry. Additional lollipop and floral hops. Medium body. Bittersweet on taste. Biscuits, fruit pie, dry hoppy ending. Fairly bitter. Decent ale.

Butelka. Jasno��te, klarowne,z do�� trwa��, bia�� pian�. Pot�ny aromat brzoskwini, spod kt�rego niewiele wi�cej da si� wyczu�, mo�e troszk� cytrus�w. W smaku te� s�odko brzoskwiniowo. Goryczki nie do�wiadczy�em, wysycenie �rednie. Tak wyra�nie sztucznie aromatyzowanego piwa nie pi�em od czas�w Nutcrackera. Bleeee.

This stout poured a dep black colour with a smooth creamy head, tan in colour. Scents include chocolate, coffee, roasty, cream and beef gravy. First sip was smooth with a creamy mouthfeel with flavours of coffee, chocolate with a roasty finish. Palate is slightly hoppy with a charred roasty flavour lingering.

On tap at Great Wolf Lodge (?!?!). Poured a dark brown with a long lasting creamy head. Notes of coffee, some light chocolate and maybe a hint of dark fruit. Reasonably light in the mouth. Pretty good beer, but what an odd place to find it among the crying toddlers and over stimulated tweens.

341ml bottle from the brewery. Generic Amsterdam label. Appearance : Deep amber with medium foamy brown head. Aroma : Fruity yeast with raisins and light coffee. Taste : Light coffee with fruits. Light hops on finish with light chocolate, light coffee and some fruits. Body is very thin. Light butterscotch. Overall : Not bad but a bit thin. Granted it�s a dry stout but I still think it was a bit too thin. A bit too fruity also.

341 ml bottle from brewery. Pours a virtually black dark brown with modest-sized light brown head. Aroma is quite roasty with cocoa and a bit of nuttiness. Flavour is likewise rather roasty with more pronounced cocoa presence and a little nuttiness. Slightly dry in the finish; body is a little lighter than expected (though not light in absolute terms). Overall not super complex but fairly nice.
Bottle, pours dark black, I found this one a little weak but very drinkable, quite enjoyable, it had a bit of a dryness and it was very roasty, good offering
awesome aroma of roasty malts, but beyond that i didnt like it very much. very thin and weak, kind of a off sour flavour. stick to the tempest.

Pour dark brown beige head. Aroma chocolate, cocoa, roast, cereal grain, mild spices(cinnamon?), mild nuttiness. Taste roasty, chocolate powder, cocoa powder, mild hop bitterness, cereal grain, nutty, coffee. MF medium creamy body nice carb. Well done brew quite tasty happy I got a chance to try this one.

On tap at Olde Angel Inn in Niaraga on the Lake. Pours a pitch black with an beige head. Aroma is roasted malts and dry cocoa. Taste is a dry, roasted malt and faint chocolate. Some faint smoke in the aftertaste but not off putting. Good beer but very middle of the road.

341 ml bottle from the brewery. i was surprised to find this one in bottles but it was a happy surprise. AP clear dark brown with a tan head AR flabby pale malt structure, decent amount of roast, touch of peanut shell FL decently balanced dry roasty stout, not a ton going on but no real flaws PA a little to fizzy, would be nicer on nitro tap OV decent dry stout, nice to see one in ontario
On tap at brewery. Pours dark brown, cappucino coloured head. Smooth mouthfeel. Aroma of chocolately roasted malt, ditto on flavour. Pretty decent stout!
FTA. Found a picture of me drinking it. Remember it as a mass bitter. Since I love bitters - this was an ok beer.
Can BB August 2014. Pours a still amber with a thin creamy off white nitrous head. Nose is malt and hops, metal, nitrous, caramel, banana, wort, oak, spice. Bittersweet. Dry finish.
Our biggest slug slayer to date, though a very nasty drink. Why would they think this was a good idea? Reputation shot for me.

WoW. Goes from a thick cloudy beige colour, to a deep nice golden colour with a thick creamy off white head. Fruity and a mild caramel malt aroma. Creamy texture. A bit light body. Fruity and caramel malt in the flavour. [Can from a trade with tommann]

0.44l can. My god! This is a crazy pour! Milky white from the can, when it settles I see a clear beautiful warming-amber body with a big fantastic creamy head. This took me by surprise, and it looks really nice! The aroma is more subtle with some thin caramel sweetness and hints of zesty fruits. It�s as near as flat on the carbonation and it has a thin oily body. Flavors are, just like the mouthfeel, typical Guinness light roasted. Also, some thin watery caramel blended with both ripe zest, a mild nutty bitterness and not really much more. A bit dull in flavor, but shockingly beautiful in the looks. 28.07.2012
440ml can. Pours dark orange with a large, widget head. Aroma is fruity malt and spicy bread. Taste is flavourless. Watery and flat. Some caramel.
Smooth and creamy well balanced not much else going on, very typical widget type smoothflow bitter similar to Boddingtons and Caffreys
Can 0,5ltr: First Guinness i drunk thats aint opaque black, but amberbrown. Slightly dry with hints of fruit and caramel.

440ml can, as pictured. Widget-"driven" can pours a huge, monstrously creamy off-white head with good retention. Clear, nutty brown colour. Rather fain aroma of malt and caramel. No carbonation (left), very smooth, but essentially thin, mouth feel. Taste is very similar to Boddington�s and John Smith Extra Smooth, but a bit more characterfully maltish, with some caramel here, too. Mildly bitter finish and faint, but lingering malty after taste. Not bad at all. Sessionable, straightforward - just don�t expect much complexity here. Should not be drunk at too low a temperature.
Malty aroma. Mahogany, large off-white head. Flavour is malty with caramel. Very watery. Finishes bitter with slight sweetish note. Would decidedly be better if it had more body to it.
On tap at the brewpub. Translucent amber with no head. Aroma is caramel malt, medium body, low carbonation, and no lacing. Taste is rich caramel malt.

Draft in a sampler at Barley�s Alehouse. Pours a clear amber color with a small off white head. The aroma has caramel malts, toasted malt, wood, some fruitiness and light peat. The flavor is much of the same; caramel, fruit, peat, wood. Medium bodied. Decent Scotch ale.
Poured on draft. Pours a darker copper color with a white head of foam. Aroma is a little more csomplex than the Scottish ale. I get more cereal and caramel. Its almost smoky, but not quite there.

Draft in a sampler at Barley�s #1. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts, toasted sugar, wood, resin, and light peat. Flavor follows the same lines faithfully. Medium-bodied, with modest carbonation and a soft, malty mouthfeel. Simple Scotch ale. Fun to try next to the bourbon-aged version.
Sample at the Alehouse. Pours cloudy amber with a thin off-white head. Malty and boozy aroma of brandy, cherries and caramel. Caramel malt flavor with cherry and a boozy finish. Awesome scotch ale.

On cask @ Barleys Pours a light amber with a decent white head. Has a good malty aroma of caramel sweetness. Has a good mouthfeel. The blend was good and the alcohol was hidden well. Has a full body. This one had a good finish and a good aftertaste. I haven�t had a lot of cask but this was a good one to have, full flavored and darn right good. Might not be for everyone but I loved it.
On cask at the Alehouse.Poured a dark amber with no head.The nose was caramel sweet as was the flavor.There was also some slight hop presence.This finished bitter sweet
Draft at brewpub. Light amber body, malty nose, small white head. Very sweet start, cloying, honeyed notes, not smoky, finishes with bready malts.
Of a series of Scotch ales. This wee eavy is lighter, carmel, peat, orange colour and some lace. Some carmel and peat in there. A hint of the orange taste. I liked this because of the peatiness.

Sample @ the brewpub (No. 1): Pours a caramel brown with thin head. Aroma is toasted caramel malts and alcohol. Akin to their scottish ale, this is like adding half as many more malts, a tinge more sugar, and a lot more alcohol. Just mildly bitter.
Mild malziger, s��lich getreidiger Antrunk. Runde milde W�rzigkeit. Steigend, s�ffig, mittellanger s��licher Nachhall. 10/8/9/9//8
Fruity (tangerine) aroma. Hazy, amber/orange colour, white frothy head. Moderate full, fruity (grape), hoppy, light sweet. Long light sweet and hopbitter finish.
50cl bottle. Pours hazy orange brown colour with a mid-sized most good lasting beige head. Aroma of riped fruits, banana, clove, dark malt. Taste of dark fruits and malt, banana, clove, some yeast.

Bottle (purchased at the brewery): Almost clear, chestnut-amber coloured, quickly vanishing off-white head; moderate sweet-caramelly and fruity nose with a faint wheaty-clovey touch; moderate sweetish-sourish flavour, soft and almost medium bodied; caramel and sourish fruits and a tinge of wheat in the sweetish-sourish finish, followed by a molecular amount of hops in the aftertaste. Quite O.K. ....
bottle, thanks to Bochum! Cloudy brown colour, large off-white head. Fruity nose. Medium-bodied with a malty background and hints of caramel, very slightly fruity with a touch of fruity sourness.

(bottle) Hazy, dark amber colour with a big and beige, non-persistent frothy head. Sourish and mildly toasted wheaty aroma with notes of red berries and clovy spices in the background. Sour flavour, light to medium bodied with a lively carbonation. Wheat-malty and fruit-accented taste with shy toasty and clovy notes; sour and slightly tart ffruity finish. Not a gem but a refreshing brew. 25.X.09

Nice ripe banana aroma. Clear, brown, large creamy head that lasts. Sweet and banana flavors. Watery and the fullness is what I normally like about German Wheats. Long bit dusty but with good hops finish.

Der Antrunk ist flach-w�ssrig, ganz leicht w�rzig. Zum Hauptteil wird das Bier hefiger, aber auch erstaunlich herb-w�rzig. Auf der Zunge bleibt eine herb-muffige Hefenote. Komisches Bier. Dabei (f�r mich) unangenehm s��lich. --> nicht meins! Test vom 23.9.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,6,10,5,12,6 - 7,35

On Tap at Brasserie federal, sample board 10 cl- Z�rich. Golden pale color, ok foam. Medium intensity fruity aromas , very light hoppy note Medium body & complexity. Quite ok ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ein extrem bananiger Geruch st�rmt einem aus dieser Flasche entgegen. Die fruchtige Note beherrscht auch den Mittelteil, im Antrunk dominiert wie so oft die Kohlens�ure. Der Nachgeschmack ist extrem gut gelungen, lecker fruchtig s��, lang anhaltend und nur langsam schwindend. Mal ein gutes Produkt aus der Eichhofener Brauerei! Test vom 2.4.2005, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,11,8,14,11,11 - 10,80
Bottle Cloudy orange, big foamy head. Yeasty banana aroma. Bready and yeasty banana base, some unfortunate vinegary notes. Lightbodied, fizzy mouthfeel.
Light and fizzy. Not bad as far as Swiss wheats go. Nice yeasty flavor.....

Light banana aroma. Hazy, golden color, large white frothy head. Light sweet, hopbitter, light banana, very sparkling. Needs some body. Reminds of 7up somehow. Leaves a kind of nasty dry bitterness in the finish. Much unlike other Hefeweizen.

Ganz eindeutig ein dunkles Weizen (auch wenn es einige Internetportale als helles Weizen f�hren). Sehr wohlschmeckend. Eher auf der s��en Seite. Malzig. Minimal r�stig. Allerdings viel zu viel Kohlens�ure. Das passt hier nicht. Weicher w�re besser.
Bottle at home. Orange color, middle foam size. Good balanced beer. Drinkable and fits into style.

Draft at FOB, Rimini, Italy. Pours deep gold, very hazy, with fluffy and persistent white foam, medium grained. Aroma is fruity but delicate, and grainy. Body is average, with good carbonation, tickling your tongue. Taste is fairly sweet, with the banana feeling being most evident in the final.
bottle bb 19:5/19ambrata torbida buona schiuma piuttosto persistente esteri banana leggera un filo metalica una leggera crosta di pane finale chiodo garofano

Bottle 50cl. @home poured into a weizen glass. Cloudy medium amber, huge mostly lasting frothy off-white head, heavy lacing; aroma wheat malts, banana, light lemon, cloves, yeast; taste medium sweet, slightly bitter and a light acidity, yeasty; yeasty sweetbitter aftertaste, banana, lingering spicy bite; medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation; a fresh and well-balanced weizen, quite good.

Many thanks for this beer to Mariusz. Genialne chyba jedno z najlepszych, a moze i najlepsze piwo jakie pilem. Nie sposob nalac nawet delikatnie powoli by nie bylo piany, jest jej tyle co sniegu na Antarktydzie, a osadu tyle co szronu i lodu na szybach donku w polnocnej Finlandii zima. Zapach pieczonych bananow na grilu, w smaku mus bananowy z Avocado, sporo tego avocado, naprawde, troche karmelu i toffi, barwa bursztynowa, jasno brazowa z osadem, szklanica Erdingera wnet pekala od tej piany byla tak doza jak najdlozszy palec u dloni chudej modelki miezacej prawie dwa metry. Bardzo tresciwe przyrumieniona skorka razowego chleba. Pychota, kwaskowe nawet na zakonczenie
A weissbier with great body, and A very good taste. Absolutely one of my favorite beers. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle bought at the brauhaus 10.17, bbd 8 apr. 18. Cloudy livht brown with a big white head. Banana, esthers, ripe banana in the nose, green banana, fruity, a little bit bitter and esthers in the mouth. Full body, lively carbonation, long banana bread finish with some clove. Well-balanced and superb.
Definitely one of the TOP3 Wei�biere/German whit beers. It is actually quite dry for German standards. Ayinger has stronger ester note but is sweeter.

Bottle from Getr�nkefeinkost - murky dark golden color, with small head. carbonation is very high and a small minus. taste of wheaty malt, some banana, grainy, yeasty. bit metallic. Rather sweet. frish and crisp. medium dry finish. good.
Bottle from Ypres. Dark caramel with a minimal head. Aroma of honey and coriander. Flavour is dry honey malt, herb and coriander, dry sour yeast, dry bitter finish.

On tap at St. Arnoldus, Ieper, 25.8.18. Opaque dark amber with a white head. Honey, caramel, coriander and cinnamon in the nose, mildly sweet taste and alcohol that dissolves as you drink. Medium body, soft fizz, alcoholic finish.
04/02/2018 - small glass shared with tderoeck, 77ships and rubin77 @BAB, Bruges. Orange colour, big creamy head. Nose is thin sweet malts, some caramel. Taste is malts, bit orange, low bitterness.

Thanks to tderoeck, Bierridder_S & Rubin77. Sampled 250 ml. bottle @ Brugs Bier Festival 2018. Clear amber orange, creamy white head. Nose is awful, extremely metallic, dirty water, disgusting yeast. Spoiled rotting grain taste, watery, metallic, spoiled banana, rotting,� Really nasty.
Much smoother than the hefe, and downright creamy in the mouth. The flavours are subtler, especially the banana, allowing some of the mellower fruitiness room to mature in the mouth.
Bottle. Big buttery flavour and aroma. Diacetyl? Sweet and low in hopping. Pale copper colour. Pleasant enough drinking if you like butter.
Cask-conditioned at the Seven Stars, Bristol 3/5/2016. Amber with a slight, off-white, head. A very standard bitter, with a touch of citrus fruits, cereal malts and moderately bitter finish. Fine.
Bottle condition. Best before September 07. Poured a copper colour with a real fruit aroma and hops. Taste is maltywith nice hops, Dry aftertaste.
Vaguely hoppy, caramel malty and almost entirely spilt over the table in Knickersby �Spoons. Good riddance. Less than classic watery bitter.
Bottle. Still syrupy amber beer with little head. The aroma is lightly bitter and the flavour smooth, lightly dry and caramel. Overall a nice gentle beer.
Cask Stillage at the Metropolitan Cathedral Crypt, Liverpool 24/02/2001 Slightly gassy aroma. Some fruit flavours.

Bottle conditioned (4.5% abv) from Hathern Post Office. Amber coloured with a slim, somewhat scummy off-white head. Hoppy and bready aroma. Flavours are fruity, nutty and malty with a nice light hoppy bitterness. Light to medium mouthfeel with light carbonation. It�s not perfect but I like it.
Bottled. A pale golden appearance with a gentle hoppy bitterness, No cabonisation and left no lacing. Pleasant refreshing mouthfeel. An above average bitter.
Hand-pulled at Harrington Arms, Thurlston (nr Derby). Good quality and red-gold colour. Sharp and citrusy; also fairly nutty flavour which, although pleasent, is not really to my taste.
[Cask conditioned] Strong unpleasant aroma. I don�t know what it is. The flavour is ok, but slightly sourish.
A tolerable micro brew from the Cayman Islands. Nothing special. Tastes like its competitor, Stingray Beer

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Another find in the old paper. 7 or 8 years old. Described as bready, citrus, clean. Not much hop. (I didn�t really like most blonde ales, but this one seems to have been appreciated). RateBeer is a big improvement over the old messy inefficient way of keeping track of things. Odd bits of paper to little note book/pads to Excel to RateBeer. Ad zythum per aspera.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Cereal aroma with what smells like Liberty hops (slightly cheesy, funky). Crystal clear straw colored with small head. Completely neutral flavor starts with slight biscuit flavor on the finish. Thin mouthfeel. A truly unremarkable (but no real flaws) beer. Not sure I�ve ever had something that was so flavorless.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company, Ltd.--Sweet Betty Blonde Ale. 2000 12 oz. Bottle. 4.30% ABV. (3.0 / 5.0) Blonde Ale--Slightly hazy golden color. Lightly fruity ale front with a hint of hops. Smooth light ale body with good flavor. Finishes easy and refreshing, but unchallenging. Sampled 3/30/2000. Widmer Brothers Brewing Company, Ltd.--Blonde Ale--Sweet Betty Blonde Ale--2001--12 oz. Bottle. 4.30% ABV. (3.25 / 5.0) Blonde Ale--Slightly hazy bright golden color. No head. Mild crisp light floral hop front with malt hint. Smooth light caramel malt body with mild ale fruit sweetness. Easy watery end with light hop citrus note. Thin. Sampled 10/23/2001. Widmer Brothers Brewing Company, Ltd.--Blonde Ale--Session Style Golden Ale--2002--12 oz. Bottle. 4.30% ABV. (3.5 / 5.0) Blonde Ale--Clear crisp straw golden color. Very light hop front .Crisp easy light body with touch of creamy butter malt flavor and hints of caramel fruit. Clean end with touch of citrus hops. Good flavor but mild. Sampled 4/6/2002.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Date: September 22, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear gold, dense white head, solid lace Aroma: sweet malt aroma, light floral hops Flavor: sweet malt flavor, cereal character, light balancing bitterness Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.4/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: *+ /4

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Cloudy and nasty, why does Widmer have to suck so much arse? It is a lovely shade of piss yellow though, can�t beat that!

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Not a big fan of this style of beer typically, but in the summer time this one would pass for a nice daily drink.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Excellent light beer, very clean pure taste. Like all Widmer beers this beer is slightly cloudy.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Pours a light golden yellow. Aromas of grains/corn?/some hops. Flavor is crisp and dry. Has some hop bitterness.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: This was a nice beet that just needed a bit more to it. I was not impressed with this beer. I felt it just was a ber and no extremeness to it. I was at an event where we should have had beer that was odd and off the wall to try and this was just a easy beer to get anywhere.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Bottle poured a nice golden yellow with a small head and lacing. Aroma is light malt,crisp,light hops. Flavor is creamy with light hops with a a clean easy finish. Not bad at all.

column2: Prospect, Grand Cayman Island, Cayman Islands
column5: Aroma is of light caramel, nuts, roasty. Brown, clear appearance. Light sweetness, full body, creamy, average carbonation. Far superior to the Stingray Ale. Not as widely available as the regular ale on tap. On tap at Lone Star on 7 Mile Beach. Not exported.

column2: Prospect, Grand Cayman Island, Cayman Islands
column5: This the best beer I have tried in a long time. It reminded me of great home brew. Had I known it wouldn�t be available outside of the Caymans, I would have brought back a case or two.

column2: Prospect, Grand Cayman Island, Cayman Islands
column5: Hmmm... This is my first "brooding bock beer" (Do we need a third category?), so this requires some extra thought... The copper/brown body seems to be getting crushed by the Huge, fizzy off-white head. As the head subsides, an aroma of dusty caramel seeps out along with a mildly soapy yeast and some mineral water. Oddly, the effect isn�t totally unpleasant. The flavor is a soiled caramel sweetness, a drop of sour milk, a suggestion of of chocolate along with an earthy, fresh root vegetable bitterness that lasts long into the finish. I�m suprised that I�m not rating this lower but, as stated before, the effect isn�t totally unpleasant. Which causes me to brood. Thanks to my esteemed The LoSBD colleague frankenkitty.

column2: Prospect, Grand Cayman Island, Cayman Islands
column5: Here we find an immense, cream-colored head atop a slight-hazed, coppery/amber body. Aroma finds prunes & cabbage to start with dusty yeasts taking hold later. Oddly tart and malty with vegetal notes, chocolate and lemon amidst earthiness. Interesting, but it leaves an overall impression of bitter lousiness. From a forgettable duty-free liquor store on Grand Cayman

column2: Prospect, Grand Cayman Island, Cayman Islands
column5: smooth brown body and minimal white head. Some carbonation, but not too much. Had a mild caramel malt aroma mixed with some nutty notes. Taste was sweet with a mild hop presance. Really smooth but watery.

column2: Prospect, Grand Cayman Island, Cayman Islands
column5: Draft @ Bacchus (I think) on the GC Island. Poured a clear chestnut brown color with a very large light tan head. Very nice look. Nice sweet amlty aroma with a good amount of caramel, toastiness, and nutty notes. Sweet caramel malt flavor. Light fruitness and some toffee. Medium bodied. Clean finish. I liked this quite a bit although I though it was a brown ale until I went to post the rating.

column2: Prospect, Grand Cayman Island, Cayman Islands
column5: Hazy amber colour. Chewy, earthy, minerally, fizzy, malty character. The malts come across a little bit oxidized and chewy. This is no beach-sipping beer but it is also no complex, rich bock either.

column2: Prospect, Grand Cayman Island, Cayman Islands
column5: Not overly Caribbean thats for sure. A bock is a nice change from the Caribbean lagers. Reddish brown with a small head. Nose of hops and caramel. Quite smooth at first and then turns to a hoppy finish. Decent beer.

column2: Prospect, Grand Cayman Island, Cayman Islands
column5: Had this one on tap at the brewery in grand cayman. it is available there now in the bottle. Has a nice deep brown color to it and a fairly large malt presence. I dug this one as i did the other. I wouldnt drink it on the beach, but i would drink it at the bar after being at the beach all day.

column2: Prospect, Grand Cayman Island, Cayman Islands
column5: Nice dark color & a nice aroma. Malty caramel flavor in aftertaste but still a nice brew. Very good with seafood!

Side by side Babillard dark and light. Thanks Dunt and Stakem. Mahogany body with a thin khaki collar. Sweet fruit, Apple juice, alcohol, funk, basement, musty. Spicy, breads, malty. Unique and intriguing.

Back to adding reviews from Fantomefest 2014. Purchased this bottle alongside an �03 Pissenlit at a Skinner Auction. Poured into a Fantome tulip. Poured a murky brown in color with a small cocoa colored head that slowly dissipates to a ring of soapy bubbles around the glass. Nose and taste are earthy, malty, and have a slight coppery taste on the finish. Light mouthfeel with gentle carbonation and a moderate finish. Very nice dark saison, much better than I anticipated based on recent reviews of it here.

Bottle, 07/15/2013. Here we go. Pours deep mahogany, medium fuzzy off-white head fades rather quickly, very thin lacing around the glass. Aroma is tart cherries, earthy must, light chocolate, yet dominated by vinegar, nail polish remover. Taste is a slightly more manageable with tart fruity vinegar, watery cola, earthy chartreuse-like spices, dry finish with light roast. Thin body. Well, not especially pleasant at this point, hopefully there are some better bottles out there.

Here it is, a review of Saison that is likely far past it�s prime but then again seems to have taken on a far different character through the funky yeast overtones... meaning that this brew is FAR different that what is was when first released. The nose is a combination of earthy vapours, touch of dark malt sweetness and "urine" driven funky twang. (think the gutters of New Orleans Marti Gras here)... The taste is more of the complex strangeness, twangy and acidic as all get out but then there is a a chalky/ashy black patent malt character that makes this quite interesting. Not that I would say this "new" flavor profile is for everyone, but I sort of digging it has it warms. There is a LONG earthy tone upon the finish that is fully Saison in nature. Not any longer for the meek, only lovers of the style need apply to the BBB Dark Babillard. One of the most challenging brews I have had in while.

Just went to Sherlock's Home last night to catch some of this Bitter. Straight from an oak cask on the bar, this is a serious, old-school Bitter. The aroma was very clean, with a faint hint of freshly washed vegetable. The initial taste revealed celery notes with a hint of citrus. The hops here have no sharp points, rather the whole upper end of the palate is lifted upwards with pride. The only sharpness was in the aftertaste. The end of the pint revealed a half-sweet maple flavor so subtle, that merely looking into the syrup-colored remnants, I swear, made it sweeter. If you live anywhere in (or near) the Cities, go get some this month before its gone. I'm going again in a couple of days.

A nice sweetness underlies the hoppy bite of SOB or Special old Bitter. I even liked it better than their regular bitter, which was a surprise. This beer is wonderfully smooth and paired very well with the Scotch egg appetizer I had. So you know if you need something to serve with Scotch Eggs at your next dinner party, SOB is the answer.

column1: Rio Salado Lightning Bolt Pilsner Blond Lager
column5: 12oz bottle(10/02)-A yellow golden body with a huge white head and an aroma of hops, citrus(lemon), and some grass like aromas. Taste of the same with some bitterness on the back end on this fairly light beer. A decent tasting lager.

column1: Rio Salado Lightning Bolt Pilsner Blond Lager
column5: Draught @ brewery. Pours pale yellow, thin bubbly head, nothing really amazing to look at. Very fresh aroma, lemon like hop notes, just about the most appealing light grainy nose that I�ve smelled on a beer. The beer went down very easily with a fresh zesty hopy zing, very light on the tongue but very tasty. I thought it was quite outstanding for a pilsner/pale lager.

column1: Rio Salado Lightning Bolt Pilsner Blond Lager
column5: 12 oz bottle-pours pale yellow with a big sudsy white head. very agressive carbonation. spicy, grassy aroma with some funky lager character-pepper detected. flavors are very grassy, slighly sour and some spicy notes with a touch of lemon. The grainyness is slighly abrasive. A pretty straight forward lager that i thought wasn�t that bad. I didn�t get any diacytl here and if it was there, it was very slight and didnt detract from this beer. underrated!

column1: Rio Salado Lightning Bolt Pilsner Blond Lager
column5: Aroma was of just after you watered your grass. Cloudy gold with small head some lacing. Some lemon flavor but also some bitterness that left it feeling and tasting like starch. Sorry not for me.

column1: Rio Salado Lightning Bolt Pilsner Blond Lager
column5: bottle. pale golden colour with a small head. aroma is typical for a pale lager: grass, malt, and faint hops. Soapy mouthfeel. This is a typical pale lager that is marginally better than a domestic macro.

column1: Rio Salado Lightning Bolt Pilsner Blond Lager
column5: Crystal clear straw-colored body with a clean white head. Nose is hoppy with some mild funk/sulfur but not overly detracting. Flavor is crisp and very hoppy with light citrus and butter notes. Hop quality is slightly astringent and overpowering. A fair beer, though. Thanks to Brady at Il Vicino for sharing.

column1: Rio Salado Lightning Bolt Pilsner Blond Lager
column5: This, unfortunately, is the first beer I�ve tried from Rio Salado. It almost reminds me of the "High Life", which is not a compliment. Actually Id probably rather have a high life than a thunderbolt based on the sour aftertaste. Just not enjoyable overall.

column1: Rio Salado Lightning Bolt Pilsner Blond Lager
column5: Appearance: a hazy, dull orange color, including scads of traveling floaties zipping about, and the head is short, white. Aroma: hoppy, citrus, lemon, slighter suggestions of honey and flowers. On the palate, some hops up front, but gone right-quick, and very mild thereafter, mild to the point of dormancy. Light body, no surprise, and very shy texture. Hops continue to make their presence felt, and the finish is pleasant, but ordinary, and brief. Not an outstanding pilsener in any respect, but decent enough a drink. I guess.

column1: Rio Salado Lightning Bolt Pilsner Blond Lager
column5: Bottle poured a cloudy yellow gold with no head. very light hopp aroma,smelled like budweiser. Taste is bitter, not bad not great.

column1: Rio Salado Lightning Bolt Pilsner Blond Lager
column5: This is absolutely appalling! Shockingly bad! This sharp, heavily metallic lager is massively bitter. It's cloudy, too, which is usually a good thing. Truly awful and undrinkable.
Pours a lovely bronzed amber. Gorgeous nose, fruity notes, a hints of something sweet. Lovely poise between rich malt and the bitterness and a great summer thirst quencher.

(Cask) Clear, amber golden with a small, off-white head. Fruity, lightly citrusy aromas. Medium body with a soft mouthfeel and a low carbonation. Lovely notes of fruit and caramel - and again some vitamins. Dry finish with a moderate bitterness. Lovely. 070208

Tasted 23/01/2008. Draught at the brewpub. Bright. Deep gold with an airy, diminishing lacy white head. Balanced aroma shows off subtle esters, rich malt, a little minerality, fruity hops tending tropical and a wee lick of caramel. Big pale and caramel malt character in the mouth - perhaps a bit over the top for a summer quaffer - with more of those fruity hops through the middle and that classic Galbraith�s creeping bitterness in behind. Perfect temperature and carbonation. Another splendidly made Galbraith�s pale ale. This one punches well above its weight.
Hand pump at Galbraiths. Gold colour with small white head. Mild hop aroma with hint of manuka honey. Slight hop bitterness. Honey, spice mouthfeel.

I thought this was a lovely summer beer, my only thought was that it was a bit strong for session supping in the summer heat but apart from that it had a lovely flowery hoppy nose with a sweet flowery zesty flavour followed by a lovely long bitter finish, very enjoyable!

Pint pulled at the brewpub, amber with a white bubbly head. A subtle aroma with some flowery hops. A light mouthfel, plenty of fruit in the hops and juiciness in the malt. Maybe a bit too sweet and perfumed. Not quite there with this yet I do not think, could do with a cleaner palate.
Very citrusy lemon/lime aroma. Golden yellow colour. Biter start with a sweet citrus middle, and a mild finish. Light bodied. Nice and refreshing yet also falvourful.

Pint on tap at Galbraith's, Auckland. Hand pull from cask. Still clear amber beer with a thin creamy white head. Fruity malty nose, a little smoke? Good lacing. Light body, sweet taste with a bitter/sour finish. Some lingering fruit too. Very typical English bitter, very good.
440ml can Slightly Hazy amber colour with good head. Malty aroma and taste. Good Bitter.
Appealing floral aroma in an amber pour. Laid back hop forward balance with a clean malty body and finish. Pretty much what it says in the tin - and there�s nothing wrong with that.
On handpull at Galbraith�s. Pours gold. Hazelnuts, walnuts, biscuit, little white chocolate. Very malt heavy, but nice enough.

Cask ar Galbraith. Clear copper color with a small white head. The aroma is coconut and sweet malts, mild herbal hops. Slightly sweet flavor base, herbal tea, caramel. Medium light body with a casky (come on, you know what I mean) mouthfeel. Legit!

Bitter apples, plant matter, tea leaves. husky grains, stale yeast powder, wort. Very raw and unfinished, with an acidic orange jelly malt sweetness and astringent tea leaf hoppiness. An absolutely lifeless cask ale that leaves bile acidity lingering in the mouth and throat. From cask at Galbraith Brewing in Auckland.
The head is good, the body orange golden. It smells malty, decent, fruity. The taste is frutiy, aromatic, hoparomatic, less bitter. Tasty! 12/12/13/12/-/13 3.8

Cask - Galbraith�s, Auckland. A clear, golden amber in colour with a fine soapy white head. This is British bitter as it should be done. Simple, lightly hopped, lovely juicy malt body and sessionable beyond belief. Not going to knock anyone�s socks off flavour-wise but then it�s not designed to. However, in terms of precision and quaffability it�s a real winner. About as solid as you�ll get. Good grassy English hops, some earth, a bit of biscuit and yeast and pleasant mid-fruits coming through. The key here is integration and balance. Light to medium body, soft carbonation and mouthfeel with a soft intensity, modest length finish. After a slog at work, I raced here for something wet and alcoholic to neck and this slaked my thirst a good-un. It goes to show that bigger isn�t always better; as long as you�re nailing it then subtle and low-key can really hit the spot. Next time you�re in Auckland, head to Galbraith�s and the only words you�ll need are: "a pint of Bob, please."
Cask handpull at the source. Crystal clear golden color, white edge head. Aroma of subtle black pepper. Taste is pepper and straw. A classic English bitter.
Light in colour, hand pumped from beer engine, light body and very easy to drink. Low level ester profile and balanced bitterness, very sessionable.
