Pint on tap at Galbraith's. Hand pull from cask. Crystal clear golden amber beer with a small creamy head. Subdued malty hoppy nose, very English. Nice lacing. Refreshingly bitter, even a touch of nettles/resin. Finish is bitter, earthy, herbal. Nice 'best' bitter, true to style.
On handpull at Galbraith�s. Pours red orange. Strawberry, almonds, hazelnuts, cherry, little funk, touch of biscuit. Good soft carbonation. A real treat.

Cask at Galbraith. Clear copper color with a small white head. Aroma of coconut and leaves. Flavor is da bomb digg, loads of coconut, nutty malt, slightly sweet. Medium bodied and smooth with soft casky carbonation. Very impressive.

On draught at Galbraith�s. A good session beer. Has a malty sweet aroma. Pours with a nice head with a slight creamy texture soon after the pour. Brown/ copper coloured. Not as bitter as I would ideally prefer but a lovely drop!!

Cask - Galbraith�s, Auckland. Clear amber with a one finger and fading foamy off-white head. House yeast, biscuit, bread, grassy hops and mid-fruits characters abound. Light to medium body, soft mouth feel with a low to medium intensity, medium length finish. A solid ESB in true-to-style fashion.
The head is ok, the body orange brown. It smells mild, malty, creamy, fruity, ok. The taste is creamy, fruity, bit hoppy, interesting. Nice 13/11/13/12/-/12 3.7
Copper amber, rich juicy malts and more hop forward as compared to the bitter. Spicy and clean tasting, long lingering bitter finish.
Lightly fruity, med amber, soft, light caramel and toast malt, fairly light body, quite drinkable.

On tap at the brewpub. Served a copper color with a nice head that faded to traces of lacing. Aroma is a bit fruity with trace of caramel in the background. Taste mild fruit with a bit of citrus along with mild caramel sweetness. Nice bitterness and a clean finish. Medium body, a bit of crispness and quite smooth. Has a bit of character to ound it out. Enjoyable cask ale.
copper color, almost an aged Chinese liqueur nose. Woody earthy, dry , matly. A touch sour. Nice mouthfeel. Enjoyable session beer.

Pint on tap at Galbraith's. Golden bronze still beer with a thin creamy white head. Nose is caramel malt and toasted bread. There's some solid sequential lacing. Good body, smoooooooth. Taste is fruity, sweet, toffee. Finish is peppery with bitter lemon and more toffee. Amazing Bitter, one of the best I've ever had.

Enticing malty floral aroma in a tan brown pour. Hop forward balance with a dried fruit biscuit body and finish. An excellent local (NZ) example of the style (ESB) and one well worth seeking out at the source.
On handpull at Galbraith�s. Pours red brown without head. Smooth low carbonated body. Nuts, dried figs, plums, yeasty. Pretty decent.
Pint at Deacon Brodie before the tattoo 2016. Golden amber with one finger thick foamy white head. Nicely balanced toasted malt and English bitters... ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[8415-20160531] Cask. Light maple taffy malt aroma. Slightly hazy, dark orange red body with a quick foamy off-white head. Light corn and toasted malty sweet grains flavour has a noticeable black tea bag note in the finish. Medium body. Average. (6/3/6/3/13) 3.1 (@ Galbraith�s Alehouse, Auckland, NZ)

2016-05-31. Lightly hazy dark red-amber body, headless. Aroma of caramel and toffee malt, lightly fruity notes. Flavour is malty up front, lightly toasty malt has a very English impression to it. Average to light bodied palate, no carbonation. Under carbonated, not necessarily at it�s best, just okay. 5-6/3/5-6/3/12+ On cask at Galbraiths, Auckland, NZ.

Cask pours clear deep amber with a small but lasting white head. Coconut and non-coco nut aroma, good enough to make you...um...nut. Went there. Boom! Medium body with soft carbonation. Fooooking. Gooooood. Beeeeer.
The head is ok, the body darkbrown. It smells malty, chestnut, fruity, darkmalty. The taste is malty, aromatic, hoppy, bit creamy, fruity, aromatic. Tasty! 13/13/12/13/-/13

Cask - Galbraith�s Alehouse, Auckland. Poured with a fine and fading loose off-white head atop a clear chestnut brown coloured body. Lovely nutty, earthy, biscuity and gently toasty malts complemented by a choice mid-fruit character and grassy, leafy English hoppiness. Light to medium body, soft mouthfeel and a lingering almost grapefruity hoppiness in the finish. Lovely stuff and a taste of home. That soft tangerine on the nose is a joy. Yes, this is gorgeous. Simple but gorgeous. Juicy fruits in the aftertaste. Immensely drinkable. At 5.2% it�s not an ideal session bitter but I won�t let that stop me... Come all the way to NZ and sit in an English-styled pub drinking ESB? Hell yes. It�s not my favourite style for nothing and this more than justified my preference on a rainy mid-winter afternoon.
Served at room temp. Soft and flat, friendly caramel right through the palate and mild bitterness to finish. Must be off hand pump.
On handpull at Galbraith�s. Chocolate biscuits and a nice full creamy texture. Not hugely complex, but pretty good, even to a picky Englishman�s tastes.

[8419-20160531] Cask. Toasted sweet malt toffee grains aroma. Clear, cola black body with no lasting head. Boozy floral malt flavour has a sweet finish. Medium-full body is quite flat. Interesting. (6/3/7/3/13) 3.2 (@ Galbraith�s Alehouse, Auckland, NZ)

2016-05-31. Dark brown body, near headless. Aroma of light cocoa and dry dusty roast. Flavour is a bit dry overall. Some dark malt, whispers of toffee, but finishes bitter and lightly roast. Average to thin bodied palate, low to no carbonation, very thin for the style. Okay as a beer, but not great for a Porter. 6/3/6/3/12 On cask at Galbraiths, Auckland, NZ.

Cask at Galbraith. Clear (I can legit see thru it dogg!) brown with a lasting light khaki head. Smoky and roasty aroma. The flavor is intense, with heavy smoke and bitterness. Not as good as the aroma suggests, actually a bit too much. Pretty full body with light carbonation. Flavorful, but a bit smoky for my tastes.

From handpull at source, a big, black pint with a cream coloured head that disappeared in short order. A nose of licorice, anise, molasses and some faintly herbal aromas that come through well in the flavour. It had a full, rich, silky mouthfeel and was just the ticket for time and place. A pleasure to be back at Galbraith�s and a bit of a favourite beer of mine.
Near identical structure to the ESB. Coffee and dry roast is done really well but intensity is not over the top. Again super authentic in style.
very dark brown color. Very sweet hazelnut coffee nose. Like liqueur was dumped into coffee. Fairly sweet, a bit cloying. Very malty. Not really my cup of tea fr the style but not bad .

Draught at Galbraith�s Alehouse, Auckland. Very dark brown with deep Kenyan copper hue when the light can get through it, no head on mine. Nice coffee, liquorice, aniseed, just burnt wholegrain nutty toast (ie Vogels toast), mild dark fruit - prune. Mild sweetness, strong coffee bitterness. Low carbonation, medium body - lighter than other porters I have had. Finishes very coffee-ish. This was very nice, but not outstanding like I thought Renaissance Elemental Porter was, still I would gladly have it again.

Tap. Remarkable beer. Roasted aromas of chocolate, and coffee. Flavour is long-lasting, with sweet and bitter notes. Silky in the palate, with a medium body. Colour is dark brown, with a creamy white head.
Draught at Galbraith�s Alehouse, Auckland. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Roasted malt, licorice and coffee. Medium bodied with good bitterness and finishes dry.

I am a full time chef/baker and have only 2 days a week where I can chill and relax. I like to buy 3 cans of diamond white cider and clean the house. It tastes like shit but gets me drunk enough to get the cleaning done.
Had it on tap at Tommy Doyle�s in Harvard Square. Really really bad. There was a bitter, almost sour, and just downright wrong aftertaste. Otherwise pretty watery and bland.

Bottled in 2004. Dark amber, no head. Obvious yeasty, appley, oxidized defect corky aroma. Soft and medium bodied. Notes of toffee that drowns in a sea of rotting cork. This defect has ruined the beer.

Courtesy of lunaticharness. Murky, light brown, no head, appears to be completely flat. English bw, more than a belgian strong. Aroma and flavor are dominated by caramel/toffee notes, light fruit. Very one dimensional.

Casta Milenia Limited Edition Cervaza Ale--2003 25.6 oz. Corked Bottle. 8.00% ABV. (3.75 / 5.0) Abbey Ale. Hazy rich amber color. Foamy thin mild lace head. Mild Belgian floral ester fruity mild hop front. Thin body. Light toasted sweet caramel fruity body. Tangy ester citrus mild hop end. Belgian notes. Sampled 5/2/2003.
Bottle shared by Joe: This one was probably aged for too long. Smell of sour apples, plums and vinegar. Tastes tart and finishes with some astringency. Smooth mouthfeel.
Bottle shared by Joe, aged at NBD for 10 lovely, hot years. Smells a bit soupy, with prunes and heavy oxidation. Bearable, at least, bit the cardboard-like oxidation is a bit much.

Right out of the bottle, tart cherries, vinegar, fruit, caramel. The pour is a red/brown, murky, almost no carbonation, some hanging particulates. (I found this guy in a farflung place, and the botle must be 4 years old). The flavor is tart fruit, cherries, spicy, vinegar. Slightly weak flavor, but decent. The mouthfeel is medium to thick, slick. The finish is a sour and spicy flavor, like mustard, but some fruit sweetness. Not bad at all. I�m actually glad I found this, as it is no longer made.

Bottle from an old trade with hopdog. Pours mahogany with a rich off white lasting head. Smells of fresh strawberries, caramel, grapes, raisons, earthy. Tastes slightly tarte and earthy with a light peppery finish. Well balanced and enjoyable.

2005 bottle courtesy of Retorp. Pours a hazy amber color witih a thin white head. Little carbonation. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of caramel, phenol, nuts, molasses, figs, ripe dark fruit, raisins. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of mustiness, caramel, honey, cardboard, ripe fruits and some toffee. Generally medium body with a malty finish.

2005 bottle courtesy degarth. Clear amber pour, cloudy and hazy, tea-colored, no lacing. Caramel nose, brown sugar, spices, some hot fruit, dry pepper and wood. Flavor is pretty oxidized, still good, some meaty tones, chocolate, mostly Tootsie-roll and some toffee. Thin-bodied, oxidized but still tasty. Unique and would love to have tried it fresh.

2005 vintage pours headless murky copper to dirty brown. The aroma has some kick with brown sugar, dark fruity esters, lots of raisins and mustier dark fruity notes. Oh, did I forget to mention; lots of sweet raisins? The taste is pretty darn smooth with musty crusty dark fruit from ripe to near wrinkled cherries, raisins and plums moving into honey and brown sugar sweetness. It ends dry with lingering sugar sweetness and fading brown sugar and dark fruit.

A nitrokeg, The Cedars, Leicester. Took ages to pour, quality takes time. Golden with a thick head of foam. Aromas are thin malts with light creaminess. Flavours are creamy, light and inoffensive, if bland. The commercial description is correct, although I don�t believe its authentic.

Draft at the Highlander near Windsor Castle. Medium sized white creamy head. Transparent, uncarbonated and a gold orange hue. Malty aroma was all I got from this one. Malty, hoppy and somewhat bitter flavor. Palate was smooth and a little tingly. Excellent lacing.

The DM & Hotstuff�s European Honeymoon trip beer number 2. This draft brew from a small pub near Windsor Castle poured a medium sized creamy head of long lasting bubbles that left behind a golden amber body. It had a nice malt hop aroma with a thin initial mouth feel and a good smooth malty finish.
Tinned. Pale amber with nitrofizz. Thinly flavoured malty brew, not the worst I�ve had because it does deliver some flavour through the suds, but still poor.
Extremely smooth and creamy, almost invisible aroma, a bit soapy and bitter. An everyday beer.
Very nice creamy, easy drinking pint. Why 'American' Cream Ale ? ..In Scotland it states 'Premium' Cream Ale and is brewed here.
Smooth, easy drinking -even if MODERATE consumption is the order of the day.

Typical of a beer of this type. An unchallenging drink that, although quite creamy is a little lacking in flavour. Its fairly week flavour belies its strength. A good beer if high consumption is the order of the day.

Tap at a cool Kyoto beer bar! Poured a clear golden colour with a thin broken white head. The aroma is grainy malt, light gluey, light floral, light woody hop. The flavour is moderate bitter, with a crisp, malt, gluey, light sweet, light mineral, woody hop bitter palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation.
Tap. Pours clear golden melon creamy white, good lacing. Aroma is malty, grains, light grass. Flavors is light sweet, light bitter. Medium body

Suntory Malts - Finally find this on a Northwest flight, after seeing it mentioned on menu in flight magazine, but still no James Page, probably because they were slowly going out of business, kind of like Northwest Airlines, both based out of MN. This refreshes like a bathhouse in Siberia. Full enough body, full enough color, yet not that filling. Makes me wonder exactly who Malt is, and how to thank him/her for a nice refreshment. Not very aromatic, soft without being sweet. Went great with curried beef and salmon. Wish international flights served all the food you want like they do drinks.

There seems to be a divided opinion on whether this is better than the Premium Malt�s. I prefer the Premium malt�s simply because it is so different from most of the mainstream beers around. That said it is a great beer. Nose is malt and grain. Colour is standard golden lager. Body is semi thin but still decent. The flavour is not as strong or herbal as the Premium Malt�s but still malty with a decent crispness. I also get a sort of bready sweetness to it. I really like this beer and although it�s not as good as the Premium it is a better session beer. I just wish it was available in Taiwan.

Very clean beer that I had for the first time in a long time the other day. It wasn�t nearly as hoppy as I remember, but I also remember there are several versions produced in Japan using slightly different hops and malts, though it never mentions this on the can. Nice clean malt character, well brewed beer and much better than macros in the West.
Decent mid-range beer from Suntory. I�ll echo what others have said as this having more malt flavor that many beers in it�s class and light years better than Asahi dry. A solid beer with nice flavor.
Much better than the more prominent Suntory Premium Malts. With well-rounded lager taste and satisfying palate, this beer has none of the cloying sweetness many of the mass produced brews do.

350 ml can bought at YATA in Grand Century Place, Mong Kok. Clear golden yellow colour; Three-quarter finger head with crumpety white foam which fades in 40 seconds; Small sticky lacing with active carbonation; Quite fragrant aroma of full malt, with light floral, sticky molasses, thick bread, yeast, lemon, aromatic hops and light grass; Very light sweet taste of malt, with light grains, molasses notes, bread, dough, yeast, light lemon, moderate to light bitter hops and light grass; Mid to light body. Slightly slick palate; Mouth feel is full malt beer in a somewhat thin body, definitely thinner than Suntory Premium Malt�s but still above average maltyness by Premium Lager standard. Slightly grainy, sweetness is just notes, bready and doughty. Easy and nice!... Hoppiness is light floral, lemon and fragrant hop nose. Light lemon and grass in taste. Bitterness is initially low-fi but is pretty dynamic to the tongue for a neat, low astringent semi-finish; Fairly dry after taste. Quite easy and savory to mouth. Comments: I can�t help but to think this is the small brother of the rich and tasty Suntory Premium Malt�s - body and maltyness is thinner, a bit grainy palate, and slightly lesser hoppiness. Yet it still shines with fragrant floral hops, and good bready and doughty mouth feel. Given I have good access (and cheaper to buy!) to Suntory Premium Malt, this one serves as second banana. A decent lager nevertheless.

s�odki, s�odowo chmielowy zapach. da si� wyczu� lekkie cytrusy, zio�a i zielone jab�ko. kolor z�oty, przejrzysty, piana przyzwoita. w smaku p�pe�ne, s�odowe, do�� g�adkie i zbalansowane. niska goryczka zostawia jednak do�� nieprzyjemne �ci�gaj�ce uczucie w ustach.
~This review was made some time ago via another application, and thus the specific details (beyond numerical scores) are no longer available~
On tap at Harrisburg store. Pours a rich reddish amber with a thick off white head. Taste is malty with just a touch of hop balance to keep it honest. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Although this brew varies wildly from season to season (and they appear to have changed the recipe drastically recently), I am going to rate it on the Doppelbock that I often know and love. This brew is disarmingly strong in alcohol. The taste only hints at that underneath, and it is easy to get lost in the complex flavors of the malt, fig, and dark chocolate. As of late, there is a very strong coffee overtone which I do not care for. Much too similar to stouts which over-use that. This beer goes down amazingly easily. It truly is an easy-to-drink beer. Not exactly �lagerish� as the description implies, but not too far removed. When made properly, and served in a fine pint glass with regular bar staples, this is my favorite brew in the world. It�s not perfect, but that�s what I love it for.

I thought I was getting a growler of celtic rose, but it turned out to be the dopplebock. The aroma was sweet and malty with a bit of hops, the appearance was a clear dark amber with a 2-finger head. The flavor was malty, and bitter but clean. The palate was fairly thin, average. Overall its a good clean beer, but a little to bitter for me. It goes pretty well with a scoop of vanilla ice cream right in the beer.

I was surprised that this was a nine percent beer. I thought it was good. It was smooth and I could drink quite a few of these. I nice showing from Lancaster. Try this one if you get your hands on it.

Sort of a cherry wood color with light lacing,tan head. Nice piney aroma. Didn�t expect the hoppy front. Sort of like a malty pale ale. Very good, however, if you choose to eat here, they�re very proud of their mediocre food. Enjoy the beer.

Tap @ LBC - Dark amberish bronze, tan creamy head. Nose held malty notes of toasty caramel, dark fruit, and hints of smoke. Well balanced flavors with a nice touch of hops late. Full bodied, soft carbonation, malty finish. Best brew of the evening...
Darker brown with a medium tan head. Roasty, sweet aroma. Taste is malty-sweet with a medium body and a decent finish. Decent D-Bock.

On draft at the six pack store. Pours brown with a small compact tan head. Aroma of caramel, dark fruit, and alcohol. The flavor was slightly sweet, caramel, with a nice alcohol punch. Great body, good brew.

Draft. Pours medium brpown with khaki head. Aroma of heavy scotch malt, caramel, some figgy fruit. Fairly dense and complex palate, with a lot of malt flavor coupled with some figgy fruit and molasses notes. Well hidden alcohol. Nicely done.

I really did enjoy this beer, even though I only had a smaller sample of it. It was a dark brown color, almost in line with Optimator, and the malt profile was delicious. Give this one a try if you can find it.

column2: West Palm Beach, Florida, United States
column5: Golden-brown, shade darker than the Black Duke.. Rather phenolic (bubblegum) nose with that artificial candy banana. Sort of a slippery, oily texture. More candy banana with the slight toffee underneath. Simple take - it needs yeast!

column2: West Palm Beach, Florida, United States
column5: Dark amber, looks filtered. Sweet banana nose. Thin, flat palate, does not match the style. Fairly clean malt flavors with a dry finish. Not terrible, not terribly good.

column2: West Palm Beach, Florida, United States
column5: Served on tap at the Boca Raton location into a pint glass. ABV on this was 5.5% according to the bartender. Pours and opaque, light mahogany with no head, whatsoever. I�m not sure if this was a result of a piss-poor pull or the chemistry of the beer. I did try to swirl things up and with the same results... Lots of malts, a mild dose of hops, nutty, and bananas on the nose. All in character for the style. A crisp beer with lots of malty tone and banana. Finishes clean. Light mouth feel, with very low carbonation. Need to pick up the carbonation a bit to add some punch, and a head. I�ll try again to see if it was the server�s mistake. Other than that, a good representation.

column2: West Palm Beach, Florida, United States
column5: Pours murky hazy brown with meek off white head. It has a sweet full aroma of candi sugar mixed with some dark fruity esters like plums along with mild spiciness and pepper. The taste seems kind of thin in body to start where it comes across milder than the aroma had suggested. I get a watery prune and date sense along with sweet malts, mild caramel and Belgian candi sugar.

column2: West Palm Beach, Florida, United States
column5: Draft at Florida Brewers Guild Beer Fest 2008. Full rating updated as soon as I am more coherent.

column2: West Palm Beach, Florida, United States
column5: First of all I have to say that I feel right at home in a place where the first thing you notice is the brewmaster's head popping out of the top of the 650 gallon lauter tun! This beer had a nice carmel color with a slight yeasty haze. The aroma of cloves and banana is quite prevalent. Wonderfully fruitty,spicy flavor as well. I would recommend this BP to anyone visiting the Boca Raton area. Good food and above average beer.

Name: Seven Sisters WildHorse Apple Hard Cider Date: 10/12/1996 Source: Brewfest, Newport, OR light yellow, slight apple aroma, dry lingering apple flavor, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

I think this was the most over carbonated cider I have ever had out of a bottle (next to french cidres of course). This didn't leave much of a positive impression on me and in fact I'm a little disappointed I drove >50 miles to find and ended up having to by an entire case of it just to try it. Damn Pennsylvania liquor laws! Luckily the case was under $20. That should have told me something then and there.

Name: Seven Sisters WildHorse Pear Hard Cider Date: 10/12/1996 Source: Brewfest, Newport, OR very clear light yellow, headless, delicate sweet pare aroma, strong sweet pear flavor lingering through the finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
More of a D'anjou than a Bartlett flavor. Incredibly smooth without being too sweet. Low alcohol for a cider.
Not a bad cider, I prefer apple ciders and am anxious to try Seven Sisters apple, but the pear goes down smooth with a nice clean crisp pear flavor.

330 ml bottle, from a grocery store in Northern Finland. ABV is 5.3%. Crystal clear pale golden colour, moderate white head. Sweetish aroma of pilsener malts and grassy and floral hops. The flavour is slightly sweet and malty, followed by moderate herbal hops. Not too bad. Earlier Rating: 4/24/2017 Total Score: 2.4 330 ml can as Sandels Vahva ja pehme� olut (st�rkt och mjukt �l), from Alko Karigasniemi. ABV is 5.3%. Pale golden colour, white head. Sweetish "industrial" aroma of malt sugar and candy, some grassy notes too. Soft mouthfeel. Standard pale lager flavour, not offensive, but very average. Moderate hops, easy drinking.
A small taste from wiosna (tap) @ Tuoppi-Kellari. Pours pale golden with a low head. Aroma is sweet grainy malts. Flavor is sweet grainy malts with some hops. Not bad.
Sandelssin nelonen, legendaarisen everstin vahvempi ilmentym�. Toimii hyvin niin y�kerhojen hanassa kuin Gracevillen alotteluna. Herra eversti k�skee tyhjent�m��n pullon nopeasti.
Tap@Amurin Krouvi, Tampere, Finland. Strong short initial blow with slightly bitter barley. Light/medium body with medium carbonation.. Overall, almost nothing: juice. 3 2 5 3 10
Botella.Grainy aroma. Yellow colour, medium head, white. Flavour of grains and some malt, mild bitterness. Thin.
.5l on tap (or bottle I dunno) @ Veeruska. Pours clear pale yellow with low head. Aroma and malts are malts, hay, some hops. Grassy. Stingy palate

33 cl, canned (BB 01/05/16). Pours clear gold with a white head. Aroma: Mild grains, hints of grass. Taste: Medium+ sweet, mild bitterness. Starchy, mildly malty. Palate: Light body, a bit dry aftertaste, a bit watery. Noticeable carbonation.

33 cl bottle @ home, BBE 15.10.2015. Thanks Joonas! Aroma is sweetish and somewhat musty with honey, grainy malt and some starchy notes. Flavour has cardboard, honey, grainy malt and starch. Also mild grassy hops. Finishes somewhat dry. Surprisingly watery for this ABV.
Ambar clara,turbia. Aroma cereal. Sin espuma. Sin gas. Sin nada. Sabor cereal. Sin fuerza. A medio hacer.
Clear, golden. Cold, gassy, refreshing. Some sweet malt in the flavour. It�s a half decent lager.

column1: Diamond Knot Industrial India Pale Ale
column5: 22 oz bottle pours amber with an off white head. Aroma of peach, nectarine, apricot, custard, biscuit malts. Taste is a little bitter in the finish. A little watery, decent carbonation.

column1: Diamond Knot Industrial India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle at home. Doesn�t seem like a bomber type of beer. Amber pour small frothy head. Nose is caramel and pine. Tastes of caramel, brown sugar, earthy, grapefruit, pine, orange zest. Thinner but pleasant enough palate.

column1: Diamond Knot Industrial India Pale Ale
column5: Deep brown amber, minimal head and decent lacing. Slightly sweet with even bitterness throughout. Older bottle: from 6/7/17, consumed on 5/28/18 held up well.

Cask @ Monty�s, Shrewsbury. Perhaps a resurrected recipe. Re-designed pump-clip, labelled as an American Bitter if there is such a thing. Not supreme anyway, but it does tick all the boxes for a bitter. Not much else to say.

Cask at the Leinster Arms - Bayswater, London. Pours clear gold with a frothy, white head. Solid golden ale, with nice juicy tangerine character, low bitter hay and citrus rind, a bit of sweetening white bread. Light bodied with fine, massaging carbonation; good condition. Nicely balanced to finish with more citrusy hops and moderately sweet, pale bread. Good one.

Cask at The Wellington, Birmingham. Poured a poured a clear light copper with a broken bubbly white head. The aroma is grassy citrus. The flavour is medium bitter with a light malt hop bitter palate and a long bitter finish. Medium to light bodied with soft carbonation. Lacks flavour but easy to drink.

Gravity disepense at the Happy Man Spring Beer Festival, 14/03/14. Clear golden with a moderate off white head formed of bubbles. Nose is orchard fruit, toffee apple, fruitloaf, biscuit. Taste comprsies bitter orange, bready malt, apple tang, caramel. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation. So so and thoroughly whelming!

Live@Market Tavern, Atherstone. Heavily sparklered Gillette-headed gold killing all but a faint whiff of buttery pinecone. Full and slick with a flabby, orange-accented blandness. Hints of cream, pastry and pine. Maize and biscuit afters. Soporific and sadly squeezed of all but the remotest trace of US character.
A - floral citrus A - golden, with thin lasting head T - sweet with light bitter P - mid and dry O - ok
Cask.Tried at the wondrful Moat Hose at Acton Trussell Staffordshire. Golden and clear and bitter but not overpoweringly so. A pleasant bitter but like so many others.

First tasted this at the Paisley Beer Festival in March 1998. Cask, gravity dispense. Pale russet in colour with a thin loose white head. Slight flowery perfume noted in the short aroma. Thin resiny mouthfeel and poor lacing. Pale malts give a digestive biscuit base with orange peel tones to the flavour. Citric hops compliment the malt well and give a citrusy fruit note to the aftertaste. Finish is quite dry with marmalade and gingernut biscuit notes. An ok session ESB and worth trying.
Cask in the wenlock arms. Alround rating: Floral hop, some citrus bite, clean and balanced, very drinkable stuff.
Cask at Greenwich. Nice malty brew. Fruit, prunes, cherries. Nutty, dry finish. Lovely beer for a rainy day!

Very light golden, straw-like, with a very subtle haze to it. Head died out before I finished pouring. Mouthfeel was lightly carbonated, slightly watery and rather syrupy and cloying. Malt flavors were very sweet and milk-like. Almost had some nice nuances in the malts, but they were kind of hard to find and they became overpowered by the heavy sweetness and grass-like hops. Almost had a fruity thing going on. Some herbal-flavored hops, too, with just a hint of bitterness in the finish. Sweetness lingers unpleasantly into the aftertaste, without enough carbonation or hop spice/bitterness to keep it in check. Much too sweet and sticky for my buds.

Virtually no head. Body is light yellow. Aroma is lightly hoppy (flowers, herbs, lemon), lightly malty (bread, cookie), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with a light note of banana. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Smells like someone spilled a little bit of weissbier into this. It's light, no doubt, but actually kind of interesting in the aroma department.

I'm not sure if this is a lager or not but tastes like the style. White foam, light golden color (SPN 2.5 or so), slightly bready and light malt sweetness and fruitiness. Very easy drinking. Could be cleaner.

Taps clear honey with a nice beige head that leaves generous lacing. Aroma features fresh malt and sweet pomme fruit plus a caramel undertone. Flavor offers crisp malt, woody hops, sweet and tart pomme, and caramel. Mouthfeel delivers decent body and lively fizz. Do the Dead Monk!
Tap...nice aroma of fruit, candi sugar, and bittersweet hops/malt. Lots of fruity esters in the taste along with candi sugar, and yeasty funk. Tasty rendition of a Dubbel.
Draft - Brown sugar and some stone fruit. Clearish gold with a decent off white head. Stone fruit, estery yeast and sugars. Light bitterness and dry finish.

A very bubblegum and banana ester aroma. Appearence is clear gold, minor head and lace. Taste is a mildly sweet toffee, honey, banana, and some brown sugar. Palate is standard for a belgian style. Overall, very nice.
Brown pour, beige head. Flavors of dates and dried figs, some raisiny notes. Sweet caramel notes and a bit of unpleasant hop flavors.

Didn�t find too sweet, but definitely tasted alcohol with this one. Clove, Belgian yeast. Strong nose of bubble gum and banana. Darker amber pour. Good as a 1/2 pint. Followup: Honestly, probably one of the better Belgians at DM.
Red beer with no distinct aroma or flavor. The malts are barely there. Overall an okay beer.
Taste is sweet sweet sweet. Aroma is fruit and booze no carbonation. ... Wish it had more body
On tap at Dragonmead 3-13-09. Smelled and tasted just like a lighter version the dubbel. Light fruits, syrupy, and a little too sweet.

On tap at the brewery. Belgian yeast aroma of cloves and sweetness. Dark amber red pour with no head. Much of the same with the flavor, bannana�s cloves and ripe fruits. But a slight tart finish. Not bad. its very smooth as well, I liked this more than I thought I would.

This was one of the biggest treats I had on my vacation, finding a true to style doppelbock that I had not rated. And so early in the trip. Reddish, clear, clean, dark fruit unfolds. A bit of spiciness, some booze on warming. Very good for and American version.

22oz bottle thanks to Toby. Pours out copper color topped with a sand head. Nose is pit fruit notes tons of sweet malts and some spice. Tatse is more of the nice sweet malts candy sweetness wow a bit over the top.

22 oz bottle pour clear copper with moderate ecru head. Nose super sweet caramel mixed with rotten cheese. Taste tart, green apple, then butter, and caramel, toffee but all with rotting undertones. Is it possible to have multiple infections in one bottle, eck.
Looks nice and has a fun name, but this was so sweet I could hardly finish my sample. The sampler glasses are awesome but it doesn�t help this beer.
22oz bomber picked up in Cortez. Unfiltered looking amber-red body. Oliy beige head. Crucially infected...this is a sour Doppelbock. Poor quality brewing. Really weak offering. Drainpour.
Had on draft at the brewery. Huge melanoidin nose, raisin, hint of chocolate. The melanoidin character is strong in the flavor as well. Light fruity notes. Big rich beer.
Bottle. Dark brown with a thin head. Fruity malt with a warming alcohol buzz - decent.

Tap at the brewpub. Mid-brown pour, actually a little cloudy! Rich, quality cocoa aroma, a touch of musk. Flavor overwhelms with spent whiskey barrel�strange considering it gets no treatment . White sugar and sprouts. Pew.
Cask Stillage from the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 26/09/2009 Floral aroma. Amber sweet on the palate malty and strong in alcohol with a little bitterness in a nutty malt finish.

Bottle from the brewery in Cortez. Pours a very deep brown with minimal white head. Aroma of deep malty sweetness, dark fruits, and some spiciness. Taste is extremely prickly on the palate, much more like an ale than the smoothness I generally associate with lagered beers. Taste is of deep, dark cherry fruits and dark malts. Aftertaste is very dry with hints of oak....and a little pine-sol? Definitely not very to-style, but very different and interesting (tasted much different on tap as well)

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Sampled from the tap at the Railyard location. Pours a clear orangish gold with a white head that dissipates slowly and laces. Aroma has notes of both earthy and light citrus with a light grain backing. Flavor has a nice light sweet citrus with a touch of grass and a light grain backbone.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Dark golden with a fizzy white head. Dry earthy cereal grain and earthy hop flavors with a mild bitterness. Not bad.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Attractive golden body with a nice, foamy white head. Aroma of diacetyl and an interesting apple-like hop note (not acetaldehyde). Crisp piney hop flavor with a touch of butterscotch. A solid pale ale.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Pours with a fluffy head. Darker than most pale ales and a lot more floral arma. Hops hit the tongue like a good IPA. This beer has far more hops than their IPA. Got to be one of my favorite Pale Ales.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Nice aerated beer with good hop flavor. Mild aroma, good bitter aftertaste. Unfiltered.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Strong citric, herbal aroma, Big Daddyish for me, crisp and exceptional. Some tabacco-ish particulate feel. A good start...

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Light maroon without much of a thin grey white head. Aroma reminds me of a blow pop, and no, that is not a euphemism. Bitter hits me 1st. Has a grassy pine citrus that burns my tongue a bit. A burnt straw note is there too. Finish is more citrus and grass with some caramel.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Sampler at the brewery. Pours a thin head, with loads of attractive lacing, over a clear, dark amber (SRM 10-12) body.....nose is redolent of pine, grapefruit, late pineapple.....taste early is slight toffee, then grapefruit, finishing with a pine/resin bitterness....mouth feel is medium, carbonation low. Reading the prior reviews the recipe (malt, hop bills) must have changed substantially. It has been almost two years since the last review. I got no clove, minimal roasted malt in this one. This was more of an IPA variant than a Brown. It was by far the best of tasting this day.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Draught. Pours dark molasses brown with edgy off-white head. Floral fragrant hop aroma with background caramel malt and cloves. Chocolate bitter hop and medium roasted malt flavor. Medium bodied and clean palate.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Light bronze body. Rich aroma of fruit, candy malt, and perfumy hops. A medium-bodied, hoppy seasonal ale with some underlying woodiness. However, the overriding feature in this beer is a strange and off bitter flavor that's literally like you ate a fistful of flowers. Flavor is much too perfumy.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Some floral hues over the big oaty, malty brown ale-ish brew. Lots of yeasty influence, slightly tangy finish. Odd and likeable.
Draft at Lumberyard in Flagstaff. Attractive red colour with a good head. Enjoyable session beer, sweet-ish malt dominates.
Tap at Beaver Stree Brewery, Flagstaff. Colour is clear orange with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Berries, some caramel, some hops and malts. Nothing special.
#1 among locals?!!?! ;) average malty red beer - nothing bad, nothing special. toffee and very light roast, with little in the way of hops.
Pours a amber/copper color with med off white head that stays around for a short while. Aromas of mild caramel malts with flavors of mild caramel sweetness balanced with the slight hop bitterness.

The fact that Beaver St and Lumberyard share facilites and beers makes it hard to get ratings in the right place. Nonetheless, this a great strong fresh hop aroma. Looks nice. This isn�t as hoppy as the aroma but has the light flavor of an amber. Quite tasty.
Reddish pour. Aroma is big on juicy hops and caramel. Flavor follows suit with a really nice hop finish. Good.
Hoppy aroma with a light amount of malt. Clear orange-red color with a small white head. Moderate bitter beginning joined by some light malt in the middle lasting to the finish.

On tap in a flight at the brewpub. Golden with a tinge of red, low carbonation. Small dissapating white head. Surprisingly low aroma. Some crystal malts and nondescript hops. Bitter especially in the finish. Overall a nice beer maybe a bit bitter for a red/American Amber Ale.

Served in a pint glass from tap. Had this at the Brewery, which was a very nice place. Review from notes. 3.5 A: Clear orange amber color, though the lighting was low so I could be off a bit. No head. The pour was a bad one and the beer was filled almost all the way up to the top of the glass so I can�t tell you much more. 3.0 S: Other than a touch of crystal malt, there isn�t anything going on. Rather disappointing. 4.5 T: Delicious and complex. Light fruits with a healthy bitterness that balances well. Malts are grainy, but not overly so. Herbal hop flavor. Everything meshes so well to make a great tasting brew. 4.0 M: Medium body. Smooth and creamy with good carbonation. 4.5 D: Excellent brew. This beer made the trip up to Flagstaff from Sedona worth while. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 10-02-2009 05:15:57
Amber color pour with a white head. Pretty standard amber aroma of caramel malt and earthy hops. Flavor is much the same. A bit thin, but passable.

I went to my first brewery & restaurant this year on vacation with my family in Flagstaff, AZ - Beaver Street Brewery. We went for an early dinner -- I was excited and anticipation had definitely built up. To be honest, I was disappointed. The waitress was experienced, efficient, professional but really rushed us through and did not seem interested at all in working with me to recommend and try Beaver Street beers. I had their Hopshot IPA which the waitress explained was a combination of their IPA and Red Ales. I wasn�t impressed and she had rushed to convince me to order one of the larger sizes because it was on special. I wish I had taken the time to study the menu and get a flight of tasters. Not a great experience. A few days later, had a much better experience at their sister Lumberyard Brewery -- check out my review of Lumberyard Flagstaff IPA.
HopShot IPA - pleasant enough but thoroughly average. Balanced is not what I want in an IPA, or just a bitter aftertaste. Showcase the hops!!
Smooth and refreshing. Beautiful pour with a thick off white head. Aroma is hoppy and sweet.
poured in a glass @ the beaver street brewery. Nice blond colour with some shining orange colour. Smell: hoppy, citrus, just like the taste Very refreshing beer with nice body. it�s a balanced IPA!
Pours a gold color with off white head. Aromas of citrus, and perfume like with flavors of citrus, floral characters and medium bitterness on the finish.
Pint at Brewery, now called Lumberjack IPA. Pours a light amber with slight head. Big aroma of citrus and hops. Flavor is same. Nice bitter finish.
Gold pour, white head. Citrus/pine hops in the nose and follows suit in the flavor. Not overly bitte, juicy hops, light caramel. Not bad.
Moderate pine and citrus hop aroma. Clear orange color with a medium white head. Strong bitter flavor throughout with a crisp palate.

In flight at brewpub followed by a 10oz. Copper pour with a lasting off white head. Big citrus & resin aroma with some malty sweetness. Medium body and carbonation. Good sweet bitter balance in the taste with a really bitter finish.
Clear gold pour with small head. Aroma of sweet malt and piney and spicy hops. Flavor is sweetness balanced by a nice amount of hop bitterness. Good.

From old tasting notes. Translucent black brown color topped by a thick creamy tan head. Wonderful fresh malt aroma hints at cappuccino and Bakers chocolate. Bittersweet roasted malt flavor. Bitter hop finish. Very good. Very complex.

Been sitting on this bottle for years, thought it woyld be completely spoiled, surprise! Beer is at least 10-12 years old, still drinking pretty good! No oxidation or off flavors, still has good carb, only flaw is its a little thin in the back of the palatte, other than that its not extraordinary but has held up surprisingly well, nice treat. Extra point overall for how it held up.
Bright and crisp, very black, good head, some pine aroma, roasty notes. ....
Not exactly the best beer in the world - but the bottle was really cool (that's why I gave a 5 for appearance.

Malty aroma with hints of chocolate and fruit. A little metallic with some vapors. Red-brown beer with small white head. Medium thick body and medium-heavy carbonation. A bit sweet in taste, malty and a little bitter. Alcohol - like a watery bock. A decent little beer, but needs a bit more balance.

Once again, i have exhausted the supply of new beers down at my local bar upon ordering this puzzling offering known as Jeds Red. I was apprehensive at first to try a beer with a drunken cartoon dog on the label but its a local brewery so i said what the hell. The beer was good, not mind blowing good, but very good indeed. Dark reddish brown, creamy head, and lots of malt flavor with a slight tangy bitter finish. Quite impressive.
Poured yellow with no head. Aroma of corn and soap. Flavor is grass,light malt with a odd syrup like finish.

Pours a yellow color, not completely clear and has very little head with some lace. Aroma is grassy and a little citrousy. Flavor is soft and grassy with a dry hoppy and clean finish. Light and thirst quenching refreshing. This is a pretty good pilsener.

Much better than expected! Crystal clear, golden lager. Thick, creamy, white head with good retention and stratus cloud-like lacework. Soapy, grassy, white pepppery aroma. Well-balanced flavor. Medium bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Short, semi-dry, semi-sweet finish. If you like pilseners, get your hands on one of these.
Huge rocky head. Pale golden. Mildly hoppy, slightly sweet aroma. Odd earthy flavor. "Dirty" might be a better word. A unique and terrible beer from New Zealand.
Not unlike Ringnes Pilsener. Malty and slightly hopped. I like. Good citrus aroma, too.
Initial skunk turns to a grainy, lemony nose. Foamy fizzy head. Typical pils taste is highlighted with lemon undertones. Astringent finish and soapy mouth feel lost points with me.
Hoppy, moderate flower citrus aroma. Pale yellow white virtually non lacing head. Sour and oily finish, blah
No good. Skunky, rotten taste. Drain pour material here. I might have had a bad bottle, but I really dont like the style.

The unusual thing about this beer was the stickiness of the foam. It left the glass looking like someone had scraped marshmallow cream out of it. Green bottle, so-so label, screw-off cap. Garden variety lager, a trifle skunky. A tart palate.

The first New Zealand beer I had was Steinlager. It was late August 1993, at Fogg 'n Suds (which at the time was a well-respected beer bar chain in Vancouver). It was the Kitsilano location (probably the best neighbourhood on the planet), and it was the end of August, right before I went to university. That night, I had for the first time the long-departed but still missed Okanagan Old Munich (a rare dunkelweizen that I actually liked enough to buy on multiple occasions) amongst others. Anyway, they had a contest going that night involving playing Pole Position on a big screen. All these punks today with their Halo and games that have IA and everything - to hell with that I'll take the old school games that I used to play at Chuck E Cheese anyday. Give me Galaga, 1984, Pac-Man...you're damn right. Anyway, although Grand Prix was my shit, I was decent enough at Pole Position to score third place, which was a pair of Sam Adams footed pilsner glasses. I had never heard of Sam Adams at the time. Exotic shit, that was. A year late, when I got to actually try a Sam Adams I was already geared up for it, and loved it. Now, one of those glasses didn't make it to see 2002, but the other one did. And that is what I used to pour my second ever New Zealand beer, nine freakin' years later, into. Yeah, it's a grassy pseudo-pils around 22 IBUs with some honey and grain husk notes and an off-dry finish, but more importantly, the drought is over and I can get on with those Kiwi beers at the Ratebeer Summer Party next week in peace.

I really like this brown ale! Sparkling clear, deep, dark, ruby ale. Medium-sized, frothy, lightly tanned head with good retention and brussels lacing (I just like to throw around the term "Brussels lacing" every now and then). Very light, pleasant aroma. Nice notes of chocolate, vanilla and cinnamon. The flavor is decently balanced, but a hint on the sweet side. Chocolatey. Medium-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and light carbonation. The finish leaves the mouth feeling parched for quite some time. Great session beer at $.86 per bottle and 4% ABV. Unfortunately, it will be available for only a limited time in my area.

Brown bottle, 11.15 oz/330ML, with twist-off cap. Oval lable with a dragon linking motif in the background around which are the words "Naturally brewed Premium Dark Ale." It has a medal printed that states it wone a Gold Medal at the 1999 Australian International Beer Awards. Imported by Wine Mates, L.L.C. in Ellicott City, MD. Website www.abgroup.co.nz Oh yeah, the beer... Pours like a Coke with a bit of a head, but not much, and some lacing. Smells malty and rather sweet. Tastes...okay. Roasted malt is the most noticable flavor with coffee and chocolate hints. It could use more hops for balance, IMO. Funny, but it tastes a little bit like a Coke, too. There's a bit of a burnt aftertaste to it. Mouthfeel is, well, about like a Coke. It's about the same thickness and carbonation. Drinkability is pretty good. There's nothing offensive here and at only 4% ABV, it would be easy to have several of these while doing stuff around the house or whatever.
Pours a dark brown with a medium light beige head with decent lacing. Slightly fruity aroma with roasted malt.
Pretty roasty for a brown ale. Almost in light porter territory. Black like a Xingu.

I was not too sure what to expect from this one. Pours a dark if not rich brown color with a medium light beige head. Fair lacing. Aroma of roasted malt and a little fruit. Flavor is very mild which makes it both uninteresting and easy to drink. Finish is a little thin but there are some hops in it. Nothing offensive, but pretty unexciting.
Nose is a mixture between chocolate and cough medicine. Black body with a little hazelnut brown head. Taste like espresso, but has also the typcial flavor of medizine. Thin finish.
Woody and charcoal nose, dark brown color and a lovely tan head. Sharp roasted and burnt malt taste, almost like tobacco. Strong and aggressive beer.
Bottle. Dark brown and almost black with a laced brown head. Roasted malt aroma. Fairly light body with a grainy malt feel. Crisp with a carbonation bite. It leaves a pleasant and strong aftertaste.

Dark brown color, medium head. A light to medium bodied dark ale. Roasted malts, slightly hoppy. Some coffee and chocolate like flavor, slightly sweet. Mouthfeel is round, but a little thin. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Serve coolish. This is not a porter. .......................................
Earlier Rating: 11/17/2018 Total Score: 3.3 Earlier Rating: 11/17/2018 Total Score: 3.1
Rich malty flavor that remains in the form of a milder, nutty aftertaste. Great dinner or evening ale.
This is one a typical thirst quencher. Not a bad summer pilsner. A clear easy drinker.

Hazy golden colour, white head. Aroma of malts, cellar, mushroom, funk. Tart flavour, malts, hint of cheese. Malty finish, funk. Quite old but held up nicely! (from 75cL bottle @ Grand Old Lambic Tasting, Jtclockwork's place, NJ. 2004 vintage. Thanks for sharing, Nick!)

Bottle thanks to tectactoe for sharing. Not sure on vintage but it�s very old. Hazy gold pour with a small head that fades to a thin ring. Aromas are strawberry, cheddar cheese, white wine and musty basement. Tastes like a cheddar bomb. Moderate lemon and white wine in the finish too. Light lacto sourness. Not bad but not really my thing.

Bottle: Semi-clear, bright amber color with a soapy, frothy white collar outlining the edges. Best Fantome clarity I�ve ever seen. Aroma has a huge wild strawberry gummy candy note with strong hints of white wine, cork, a slight touch of horsey funk, & toasted grains. Flavor has a tart bit of lemon flesh up front, followed by white grape, mild stone fruit, faint grain, & some modest lacto-like tartness. Light bodied. Tastes much different than it smells, but I enjoy both. Finishes clean, light, semi-dry. Borderline Pinot Grigio. Really nice stuff.

The thing about Fantome is that you roll the dice on every bottle you trade for/pick up, especially when it�s an older bottle. I traded for this recently and shared it with some folks at Dark Lord Day. With all the recent reivews being generally positive, I was really excited to finally give this one a whirl. It poured a cloudy orange in color with a half fingers owrth of head into my Greenbush taster. Both the nose and the flavor displayed a significant amount of breadiness. I didnt really get any grape, apple, or pear that others picked out and despite it�s age, it wasn�t all that oxidized, it was just very plain and bready. The mouthfeel was light to moderate with good carbonation and a moderate finish. Disappointment seemed to be the consensus on this bottle which was unfortunate. A lot of people expressed how they loved this beer before but this just wasnt good. Oh well, that�s part of the allure of Fantome I guess.
Old ass bottle. IT is big time oxidized, some minitiness and cardboard, some spices.

Huge, huge thanks to Ryan for this one! Longtime want. Served in a Fantome tulip. 2004. Dry, musty basement with a bit of earth. Very light bread crust. Touch of acidity in the background. Lightly bubbly. Bit of oxidation.

2004 bottle, enjoyed on 12/19/12. Served in a Hill Farmstead stem. Pour: Murky burgundy, with a two fingers of light tan, soapy head. Leaves some solid lacing. Head hangs around for a while. Smell: Up front, big lactic tones and some molasses. Gives way to figs and dates, and some lemon juice. Light caramel, and a light balsamic vinegar. Finishes on the nose with a lemony tartness. Taste: Follows the nose with a big lactic tartness, and lots of lemon juice. Some pear skin. A big molasses comes through, with some nice caramel. A light oak (is this aged on oak for any period?). Finishes with red wine tannins and some lemon tartness. Mouthfeel: Really light for the flavors it produces, which is really quite nice. Good carb, and the tartness is just right. Overall: Time did another Fantome well. I�m very lucky to have stumbled across this bottle and have a chance to try it. Delicious!

750mL bottle, courtesy of julian, pours a cloudy dark orangey brown with a voluminous white head. Aroma is a bit oxidized with metallic notes, Belgian yeast, and stale wet cardboard. Flavour of wet cardboard, cork, and other dry, construction site notes. Lively carbonation. Too bad this isn�t a bit newer as I think this would be very enjoyable fresher, but as is now, this is past its prime. Not s good.

Huge thanks to Umberto for opening this during our epic night of drinking at the Goblin Pub in Pavullo nel Frignano, Italy. Pours a very cloudy, bright golden orange color with tangerine edges and a half finger off-white head that quickly settles into a thin ring that soon dissapears. Not much in the way of lacing. This beer has a very complex aroma with lambic, farmhouse and wheat beer notes bouncing off of each other. Lots of earthy funk with hints of barrel, wet hay and cobweb along with zesty autumnal spice, bready yeast, citrus and light fruit notes. Slight herbal/vegetal presence with lemon peel, pepper, bread and apple. Really odd combination but the nose is pretty inviting. Medium bodied and again, very complex with hints of lambic, saison, vegetable/spiced beer and wheat notes playing off of one another. Slightly tart and puckering with a decent amount of earthy funk followed by zesty spice, bread, sweet malt, light fruit and citrus. A decent amount of sourness but not harsh or acidic. More funk than anyhing else with grass, straw, hey and wood flavor. There�s also peppery spice with coriander, cinnamon and clove followed by caramel malt, apple, pear and bread. A truly unique beer. I don�t really know what to make of it because it�s so weird but it�s very complex and quite flavorful.

Bottle purchased today at Bottleworks. 2004 vintage. Color is clear coppery color with a bit of haze. Lots of carbonation, leaves a nice snowy white creamy layer of head upon the first pour. Aroma is of cork, cardboard, raw brocolli. Possibly oxidized over the course of 8 years. Mouthfeel is smooth with good carbonation. Taste consists of wood/cork, green apples, flowery hops, and on the finish an odd (yet not completely odd for a Fantome) leathery/tobacco quality. I wish I could have tried this fresh. Not my favorite Fantome in its current vintage. If you have this, I say drink it now.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Gold pour, no head. Nose is non descript malt. Middle is sweet grain, not much else. Finish is a a little sweet. Once was enough.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Draught, smallish clear pale yellow color, aroma of corn, malt and some slightly medicinal, sweetish corn flavor with some fruitiness, light bitterness. Easy to drink but quite simple.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Tap at brewery in NW Austin. Clear, looks like apple juice. Mild citrus aroma. Taste is mellow, light grass, not much going on. No body, like water. Highly carbonated. Ehhh.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: A yellow-clear beer with almost no flavor, no body, and no finish. It�s more flavorful than water but that�s it.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Clearand mostly scentless. Some light grassy and citrus hops but a pretty boring lager. Of course this is a great crowd pleaser beer i bet.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: on tap-pours a dissipating white head and brite pale yellow color. Aroma is sweet light fruit, light malt. Taste is sweet light fruit/earthy hops, light malt. OK effervescence.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: On tap at the brewpub. The beer pours a yellow color with a white head. It looks like you would expect from a light lager. The aroma is mix of grain, wheat and some grassy hops. The flavor is more of the same. Very easy to drink, but not too much going on in the flavor or aroma. Thin mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: clean light beer with a little citrus and that good ol� lager funk. smooth overall and less offensive than many pale lagers.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: (Draught) clear pale yellow, very few bubbles. Nose is mellow, but some biscuit, grain, butter, and metallic notes come through. Taste of very buttery biscuit, very grainy. Nice crisp finish, good carbonation that�s abundant but soft with a fruity finish.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: On tap at brewpub. Pours a pale yellow with a thin white head. Almost unnoticeable aroma as it is a bit mild. Taste is of grass and cereal, but not very impressionable. Mouthfeel is slightly bitter. Meh.

column1: North By Northwest Py Jingo Pale Ale
column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Cloudy yellow. Medium body with a clean finish. Floral aromas and flavors with a little honey and piney hops.

column1: North By Northwest Py Jingo Pale Ale
column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Draught, small creamy head, a touch hazy pale orange color, aroma of lemon with a shrubby hint and some malt in the back, flavor of lemon and aloysia, medium herbal shrubby bitterness. Very nice and very drinkable.

column1: North By Northwest Py Jingo Pale Ale
column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Tap at brewery. Light copper pour, thin white head. Aroma is light citrus, a bit of grass. Taste is light citrus, toast, light caramel malts. Light body, medium carbonation. Decent.

column1: North By Northwest Py Jingo Pale Ale
column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: tap at brewpub pours bright orange hue with a small sudsy white head. nose is herbal, citric, lightly bready, cracker and some nice earthy tones. flavors are very bright citrus but very lite bitterness. body is crisp and easy to drink-very sessionable. could be pretty low abv around 5%. long herbal and slightly bitter finish of grapefruits. decent pale ale here!

column1: North By Northwest Py Jingo Pale Ale
column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: On tap at brewpub. Deep orange with big white head that sticks around. Medium pine nose with light citrus notes. Medium bitterness with light malt backbone. Medium mouth with average carbonation. Average.

column1: North By Northwest Py Jingo Pale Ale
column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Looks like miller light and tastes just as weak but doesn�t have the aftertaste of piss.

column1: North By Northwest Py Jingo Pale Ale
column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Orangeygoldenclear beer. Some citrus and pine aroma, lightly citrus and mild simcoe taste. Pretty decent apa all in all.

column1: North By Northwest Py Jingo Pale Ale
column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: on tap-pours an off white head and slightly hazy yellow color. Aroma is pineapple/lemon, some light/medium malt. Taste is sweet pineapple/lemon hops with some bite, secondary light/medium malt. Soft carbonation.

column1: North By Northwest Py Jingo Pale Ale
column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: draft at nxnw. This is a good pale ale. It pours orange with yellow tinged froth and is heavy on citrus, although there is a solid malt backbone of biscuit and toast. There are actually some ginger-like notes on the finish, nice. Medium bodied, smooth, and drinkable.

column1: North By Northwest Py Jingo Pale Ale
column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: On tap at the brewpub. The beer pours an orange yellow color with a white head. The aroma has a nice grapefruit hop note along with some biscuit malt. The flavor is more of the same. I get a lot of grapefruit and some other notes from the Cascade hops, with some biscuit malt to balance things out. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Balanced and easy to drink.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Draught, No head, clear very pale copper color, muted malty aroma with a medicinal whiff, fruity yeasty flavor with some maltiness in the back, light bitterness, much to sweet. Simple and not too interesting.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Tap at brewery. Pours Amber, little white head. Aroma is grain, mild caramel malts. Taste is semi sweet caramel malts, toast, a bit nutty. Better taste than aroma. Nothing special on the palate. Average Amber.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: An amber color with very little hazy and a white head. The aroma is of subtle spices, and the body is soft, the finish is abrupt and clean.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Not a lot of taste; more carbonation and some aftertaste. I would not try this beer again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: on tap-pours a light tan head with some lacing and dark amber color. Aroma is mild medium malt-peat/cocoa, some fruit. Taste is medium malt-caramel/peat, secondary fruity hops. Soft carbonation.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: On tap at the brewpub. The beer pours an amber color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the toffee with not too much else. The flavor is better. I get some toffee and caramel malt, as well as some light chocolate notes. There is not too much hop presence, but the malt is very nice and mixes well with the other flavors. The beer is very creamy tasting. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: pours amber with a small white head. very little aroma to speak of. smooth and creamy but overly subtle. bizzare minty aftertaste.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: (Draught) clear amber with a film and ring of fine white bubbles. Nose of fruit, pears, honey, light caramel and a touch of hops. Taste is toasty caramel, biscuity, Belgian-ish, and a touch of hops. Nice abundant carbonation with a spicy finish.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: (Draught) Pours a clear amber body with a medium white head. Aroma of caramel, grass, and florals. Flavor of caramel, light roast, and some bread.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: pours a caramel with a small white head aroma is caramel and hops. flavor is crisp carbonates water caramel malt and a kiss of hop bitterness.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Had on tap at the brewpub - pours a charcoal black with a firm khaki head and good thick lacing. Aroma is slightly nutty with a roasted nature to it. Flavor has some mild bitter chocolate notes with brief hints of coffee. Same roastiness pervades the flavor which makes this quite nice. Mouthfeel is sligthy thin, but does not ruin it. A very enjoyable brewpub stout.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Yuck. Slightly thin looking. Headless. Roasty and aromatic without any body or soul. A slightly sour finish.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Good stout, lots of roasted flavor. Bonus with the hops to help balance the flavor.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: It had a thick beige head. Flavor was typical of a brewpub stout....roasted coffee, mocha, and even some caramel. But again, this brewery is a master of hops--they rounded out this stout to make it better any other brewpub stouts I have had.
Cask Stillage at the Mill At The Pier, Wigan 09/03/2002 Golden amber coloured and sweet on the palate. Some fruit flavour. Smooth hop finish.
Samled cask conditioned. Amber coloured. Fruity, flowery aroma. Light bodied and dryish with rounded flavour of grapefruit. Low bitterness, salty finish. A light but flavourful cask ale.

Cask at the Luttrell Arms in Dunster, Exmoor. Copper colour with a white head. Biscuity malt flavour with a slight hint of caramel and mildly bitter hop taste. A little watery and thin. Not particularly memorable.

1/6/2018. Cask at the Cutter Inn, Ely. Pours amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of caramel, fruit, malt, hop and a hint of coffee. Moderate sweetness, light to moderate bitterness. Medium body, slight oily and watery texture, soft carbonation. So so.
Forever Bury Beer Festival 2018. Clear copper in colour. It's a clean smoothish bitter with a low bitterness.
Cask , not getting the malt that others have reviewed, Decent aftertaste though.

Old notes from 2002. You�d need to drink a fair bit of this to get legless. A fairly standard session bitter. The emphasis is on dry malt with some earthy hop elements. Perfectly drinkable but not too distinctive.
Sampled cask conditioned. Dark amber. Ashy aroma with a hint of hay. Light bodied, on the sweet side. Not much flavour and low bitterness. Salty finish. I expect more from a British cask ale.

Bottle from Waitrose a few years ago. Orange with a white head. After trying the very poor bottled version of Landlord, this restored my faith in the brewer. Smoothmalty base with resinous citric hops. Very morish.

Bottled. A dark copper headless beer. The aroma is sharp citrus hoppiness with some toffee jam. The taste is toffee and big hops. Fruit and late bitterness. Good chewy malts and highly bitter at the end. Tasty.
Bottle 09/08/2004 Amber golden coloured with a slightly hazy appearance. Some alcohol present. Crips slightly bitter malt finish.
Huge tight lasting head on amber body. Sweet malty aroma with strong roasted malt and bitter flavour. Some metalic influence and a short finish.
Good golden colour with a huge billowy head. The nose has a good balance of nuttiness and toffee, with the assertiveness of English Ale hops being quite apparent. Nice body and good balance.

i dug this pretty majorly. heavy neapolitan ice cream and caramel aroma with some molasses. very full and fat texture. cocoa bitterness and a bit of marshmallow. amazingly tasty for a normal strength beer. beats the landlord for mine
Golden Amber beer with thinnish head. Toffee nose then nicley balanced spicy hops with caramel rich malts quite yeasty, bread. Good strength which shows through in the flavour.

not nearly as amazing as landlord on cask, but still a very tasty straightforward pale ale. lacks any british fruitiness. strong caramelly malt and spicy aroma. initially i thought it was spiced, then i realised it was styrian hops. the spicy, floral taste builds and builds and then coats your entire mouth in bitterness - and the great thing is the powerful, biscuitty malt is still right there with it all the way in the finish. could really kick arse on cask i'm sure. rer8: damn, this is still amazingly bitter and hoppy 6 months past best before! bumping it up a coupla points

I was a little dissapointed in this one,as Timothy Taylor`s brew superb cask ales but haven't been able to transfer their expertise to the bottle. However I may have set my hopes too high as this is not a bad pale ale.Nice golden appearance followed by a classic hoppy bitterness.Taste is pleasant but not overpowering and lasts for a reasonable amount of time.Timothy Taylor`s have a lot to live up to-this didn`t quite make the grade you expect from them but only just.

Nose of fresh bread, yeast, chalk, some (English) hops. Coulour: light orange, lacy head. Taste: quite (English) hopbitter - GOOD - hops becoming more and more outspoken till very bitter; there is however very definitely underlying malt and even caramel for balance. Quite chewy and savoury mouthfeel, amazing for such a light beer; English ale at its best. No new aftertaste, bitterness fades ever so slowly away. Worthy of the Landlord people, Britains'' all-time best cask. I love this beer, and am amazed at some of the other comments.
jasny bursztyn, przejzysty kolor. pianke zrobili nieiwielka ale sie osadza na kuflu. troche chlebowy zapach, srednie cialo i dlugi gorzki finish

Vintage tasting courtesy Lars, Randers Bryghus. Creamy white good mostly deminishing head. Dark yellow colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter ESBish flavor. Average light bitter ok finish. Oily palate. Tasted a little old but was still nice.
A combination of dry malty flavor and light hops. Very low alcohol content, but the flavor is still solid. I really like this brewery - and their packaging is beautiful.

They say that beer rots the brain cells: I didn't realise when I bought this that the 2.5 of the title referred to the alcohol content. However, it is a quite pleasant little drink for those who wish to stay sober and yet enjoy a beer. Hoppy and bitter enough to pass itself off as something stronger. A traditional British ale, just lacking a bit in substance with a feel of tin around the mouth.

Bottled. Less carbonated than Live Organic, which is sampled before this � slightly smaller head. Sweet, slightly hoppy aroma. As mentioned before this does taste rather thin and watery, though there is some pleasant, underlying bitterness. For a lower alcohol brew it is good, but I see little benefit in a low alcohol beer unless it is totally alcohol free.

The good thing about drinking bland beers like Bud is that after three or four the alcohol kicks in and you stop worrying about the lack of taste. The bad thing about drinking this bland beer is that you need seven or eight before you forget how thin and tasteless it is. I can accept alcohol free beers simply because I dont drink them. This just seems a waste of a fermenter.

Bottled, pasterised, 500ml, ring pull cap. Clear Amber with white bubbly head. The Ruddles part of the GK brand is going the hedgerow, organic route to protect the name, but this is still a poorly brewed beer. Adjuncty flavours in the malt, almost like rice and a boiled veg note on the finish, brewed tea. Not good.
Could be more than it is. too flat and too little bitter to be named as one. anyway an enjoyable beer.
Tried this a few times a while back, there was usually a bit of a haze to it, some bottles worse than others, head retention poor as well. Those problems aside, it�s pretty much bog standrd stuff.
(Bottle 50 cl) Very pretty, clear amber with a small head. Vague nutty, malty notes and a marked bitter finish. Not that much going on here... 090601
From the bottle this is another below average bitter going around,but this time it�s organic,a pity.
Amber, ok head. Not much aroma, mostly something flowerish, faint. Flavor mainly bitter, only a little hint of sweetness.

This is OK, but it's still a filtered and pasteurised bottled ale. Organic credentials could be better emphasised by producing a live bottle-conditioned beer. However, even non bottled-conditioned beers can be more interesting in organic form because none of the standard UK hop varities are grown organically, which means that some more interesting hops, in this case Hallertau, have to be used. This has produced a vaguely spicy, but not very bitter beer and the underlying malty tones are consequently not entirely in balance. Mediocre. Bottled, May 2003

Bottled. Pasteurised quality and some light fizz. A good tannic tea flavour envelopes the mouth along with some nutty notes. Tastes deeper and darker than regular Ruddles, though there is a Ruddles feel about the whole thing. Acceptable.
An amber beer with no head. The aroma is slightly sweet and fruity. The flavor is of a good malt sweetness but a little flat. An OK ale.
Bottled. Reddish amber, average head. Nutty aroma. Dry and medium bodied. Fresh, soft and fruity with salty, really bitter finish. Not complex, but plain and very enjoyable.

column1: Rio Salado Hurricane Hefeweizen Wheat Ale
column5: 12oz bottle(10/02)- A cloudy yellow with an aroma of banana, clove, and some lemon. Taste was the same with the typical hefe flavors. A pretty decent hefe from ann american brewer.

column1: Rio Salado Hurricane Hefeweizen Wheat Ale
column5: Hazy straw color. Great citrus aroma. A nice refreshing hefe with a little tartness at the end.

column1: Rio Salado Hurricane Hefeweizen Wheat Ale
column5: Bold banana aroma along with vanilla. Cloudy yellow body with small white head that disipated quickly. Flavor had banana and lemon at first. Toward the middle beer got a sour pear flavor with the bubble gum at the end. Good refreshing beer.

column1: Rio Salado Hurricane Hefeweizen Wheat Ale
column5: tap at taphouse-downtown Tempe, AZ-pours a cloudy yellow hue with a beautiful white head and AWESOME lacing. bigtime banana, lemon and clove aroma with notes of orange peal and pear. flavors were not as robust as the aroma, but were light banana and spice mostly. Even though the flavors were more subdued, i still think this is a great hefe that i guess is�nt as good in the bottle. also, some bubblegum flavors came out as the beer warmed. Lite carbonation fit this very nicely! Very under-rated and a must try on tap!

column1: Rio Salado Hurricane Hefeweizen Wheat Ale
column5: I liked this wheat beer. It was slightly tart, true to style and appealing in both flavor and aroma. Hints of banana, nutmeg, cornbread, butter toffee and vanilla are present in the aroma. Tastes of cloves mainly, but also nutmeg and vanilla. I really liked the mouthfeel as well. This stuff is quite good.

column1: Rio Salado Hurricane Hefeweizen Wheat Ale
column5: Had this during one of the hurricanes that cam through the Philly area. Florida man, I feel sorry for you guys. Well this beer wasn�t that good and my future sister-in law got is for me. This was overly cloved for me. Way to tart and sweet is the best way to describe it.

column1: Rio Salado Hurricane Hefeweizen Wheat Ale
column5: Appearance: bright, golden yellow, hazy at the top, clearer at the bottom, with a short white head that�s quick to close. Aroma: large, sweet citrus, sugar, spice, so much that it reminded me of a tripel, which is most unexpected in a hefe weizen. Oooo!! The sweet�n�citrusy sour character right up on the palate was a bit much, and not appreciated. I need my weizens on the mellower side, not so harsh with the citric acid! Grainy wheat texture appears, plays with the tongue for a spell, then vanishes. Finish is short, body on the small side. Unfortunately, this was not a hefe weizen that went down smooth with me. I hope that it was just an off-bottle, and I thank Good Sir Gusler for sending the sample!

column1: Rio Salado Hurricane Hefeweizen Wheat Ale
column5: this sucked,,,no head no lace sour bitter,,,lokked like beer had been sitting in glass for a week,,,bad bottle??? THIS WENT DOWN THE DRAIN!

column1: Rio Salado Hurricane Hefeweizen Wheat Ale
column5: Pours a very light yellow color with a very small fizzy head. Aroma is unlike that of any Hefe I've tasted to date. Absolutely zero banana or clove-spice of any kind. Detected unexpected sourness in the flavor. Watery body. Maybe this was past its prime because the other raters of this beer seemed to have very different take.

column1: Rio Salado Hurricane Hefeweizen Wheat Ale
column5: Mine tastes about halfway to a lambic. It's plenty yeasty and cloudy, but the flavor just has too much sourness. Sad. I can tell this had potential when fresh.
Reddish looks, fruity malt nose. Appley light oakiness and a little dryness run throughout. Firm maltiness. Pretty robust and hearty but just lacking a little depth for the style.

On tap at the source in Austria. Caramel dark pour, ivory foam with drafts while lowering. Nose: caramel hints with milled coffee, roast. Mouth: again caramel mild feel, roast prominent character, round, elegant.
Helder, koperkleurig. Licht beige kraag. Ruikt wat naar nat stro of urine. Moutig. Licht zoet en licht bitter. Waterig, weinig bijzonder.
On tap. Dark reddish liquid with small tan soft tan. Medium body and carbonation. Medium sweetness. Medium sourness. Some caramel in taste. Drinkable. Nice one.

Dark reddish brown color, small tan head. Lots of lacing. Medium body, average to high carbonation. Aroma is roasted malt, caramel, dark fruits. Taste is medium sweet, light bitter. Not bad, but Hirter Morchl is much better. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone

20100609 tap at Bierstube in Moline, IL. Medium brown color with creamy, even beige head that leaves good lace. Aroma is slightly metallic around rich brown bread and mild pepper. Soft palate up front, easy eff across back, full. Stark but bready, quite dry at finish which was very refreshing. Beer felt almost juicy.
Draught: Poured a reddish brown off white head. The aroma was light caramel malt. Taste was sweet malt with sugary caramel tints.
Sampled draught at Pivnica 10, Zagreb, Croatia. -nice dunkel with fine aroma and good taste
Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer Beer ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured into a snifter. Burnt amber color with good clarity. White head that drops rather quickly. Aroma reminds me of sauerkraut. Biscuity, cabbage, some soy, which is odd. Cabbagey flavors reminds me of St. Patrick�s Day dinner, corned beef and cabbage. Dry mouthfeel with a mild carbonation level. It is drinkable, but the cabbage feels weird on my palate. Would be great with some bratwursts. Could it be a tainted bottle? DMS I assume.

12oz bottle. Pours a light copper color with an off white head that has decent retention. Smells of grainy malts and light caramel with a slight hint of alcohol. Smooth, mild malty taste, with a mild bitterness. Not much flavor from the hops. Medium to light bodied.

Bottle poured a clear amber with a lingering ring of ivory foam. Aromas of carmel,earthiness and a hint of fruittiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of carmel and earthiness with a smooth dry malty finish.
Yellow straw pour with nice white head. Hops and malt. Better than mass produced pale ales, but average micro. I tend not to like this style very much. Rated 3/19/03
Pours a murky golden orange color. Aromas of citrus hops, caramel malts. Flavor is bitter and hoppy with a touch of pepper/grapefruit with sweet malt.

This was a pretty good straight up pale ale. It has all the typical malts and hops. I remember having this straight off the taps at the brewery itself. It taste so much better there. Too bad they decided to change their ways and retire this one.
