Orange amber in color, the egg shell white head dies out within a minute, leaving a thin layer of minute bubbles. Some nice lace on the glass. The aroma is malty (crystal?) with surprisingly little hop. That missing hop really comes through in the flavor and the aftertaste. Thick, almost chewy with a light effervescence. A decent brew...

12 oz bottle from trade. Poured copper in color with a large frothy beige head. Aroma of grass, hay, light hops and wet grains. Tastes of very mild hops, lightly sweet, earthy, bland and not really that good.

draft at brewery.....purely transparent medium brown pour with a thick,frothy off white head..... aroma of earthy grassy hops which make it hard to distinguish between the pils and some of the others..... flavors of mild grassy hops with a good supporting malt backbone.
Bottle 33cl @ Cerveceria Internacional, Seville, Spain. A: Golden. T: Grain, sweet.
Botella 33 cl de la antigua internacional Oviedo. Lote 08. hasta 17-02-2002. (r30). Tomada en 2001. sin mucho que decir, salvo que lo �nico que merece la pena es la etiqueta.

One of John Martin�s aromatized cheap lagers with a trendy look in a transparent longneck bottle - a particular style I can only meet with deep distrust. Which proved justified in this case: this was a clear, orangey blonde beer with thin, snow white head and off-putting aroma and taste of sugar, brown rhum, some grainy sourishness and a finish dominated by artificial rhum extract, in a chemical way, as well as cloying sweetness. Must have been one of the first tastes I had of this type of lager and like very good beers, very bad ones leave a lasting impression just as well...

Bier mit Rum auf kubanisch gestylt...aus Belgien. Man riecht den Rum derartig deutlich raus, das ich meine Zweifel hab, ob noch Bier dabei ist. Der Geschmack h�lt sich jedoch wider jeglicher Bedenken zur�ck, am Anfang zwar eindeutig auszumachen verfl�chtigt sich der Rumgeschmack im Laufe des Trinkprozesses immer mehr und macht einem leicht herben Mittelteil Platz, der in einen sehr w�ssrigen Nachgeschmack mit lasch fruchtigem Aroma �bergeht. Die leckere, vom Rum stammende S��e und Fruchtigkeit k�nnten hier ruhig noch einmal zur Geltung kommen. F�r die Masse gebraut bekommt man nach einer gewissen Zeit ein wonniges warmes Gef�hl im Bauch, leider kommt mit dem Gef�hl auch ein letztes mal ein Nachgeschmack auf, der mich an Erbrochenes erinnert. Nun... vom guten Anfang wirds immer schlechter - schad. Ach ja: Die Flasche ist nat�rlich durchsichtig, passt irgendwie zu dem Bier. Test vom 7.11.2005, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,11,12,5,8,9 - 9,00
Deep golden colour, only slight fuzz for a head. Smells sweet, fusel, slight smoke and cane sugar. Flavour is unbalanced sweet and rum fusel. Rather pretty bottle, not good beer. (From 33cL bottle)

Bottled. Clear deep golden. Aroma of cigerette smoke from yesterday. Sweetish up front, then just empty. Though vacuum with day-old cigarette smoke may sound pretty bad this shit actually tastes worse than that. Absolute horror.
Bottle: Poured a golden color with a froathy white head. Aroma is sour grain and rum. Taste is sweet with rum and a weak grainy finish. Drain pour material!
Appearance: Clear golden. Lots of white head. Aroma: Artificial, no beer aroma. Glue? Taste: No beer flavour, artificial. Why oh why? Info: 330ml bottle, 10/2-2009

Bottled 33cl. 5 ABV. As soon as I opened the bottle I almost had to throw up. As soon as tasted the beer I was even closer to throwing up. After that, I decided to throw it away. I like rum, but this beer is disgusting. Very faintly interesting, different.
Exotic aroma (with rum notes). Dark golden colour with soft white foam. Strong bitter flavor with strong rum alcoholic notes in palate. To drink once, notice it is original and forget it.

Pour from a 12 oz bottle. Nut brown hazy brew with small disappearing head. Aroma of brown sugar, caramel and a little toast. Taste is light, sweet malts, caramel, a little toast and very faint butterscotch. Faint grass towards the end keeps it from being too sweet. Overall pleasant and enjoyable.

"Bottle label states Koza Brada Bock, a tamed down version of their Aviator. Brown sugar aroma with raisin and toffee. Burnt sienna in color, thin tan head and spotty lacing. Medium bodied, nicely balanced and very clean. Light toast with figs and molasses to boot. Could be more robust, but all in all a solid bock."

bottle from citywide. just sittin here drinkin this beer on my couch. Seems nice enough. Aroma is a dough bready cinnomon toast crunch with some wet dog brown sugar. flavor follows suit. flavorful and doughy.

Bottle: This has a clear light amber body with a huge crusty head. No lacing. There�s an odd floral aroma over some faint generic malt scents. Thin but well carbonated. It has a malty sweetness, but there�s and off tartness near the finish. Maybe some earthy hops, too. Bock? Koza Brada may mean "I�m not really a -". Party Pak Liquors, Indianapolis, IN

Name: Koza Brada Bock Date: 07/18/2007 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, Cellar Party dark orange, creamy off white head, drops of lace, strong aroma of chemicals with sweetness on the backend, creamy body, sweet malt flavor followed by a sharp tartness, Aroma: 2/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.7/5.0 Drinkability: 5/10 Score: */4
Pours a hazy light amber color with a white head. Aroma is light malt, some tartness, and a hint of sour apple. Flavor is sour fruit, and a tart finish.

Koza Brada Bock. Moderate malty aroma. Light chocolate aroma. Moderate floral hop aroma. Amber color, clear. Light off-white head low head retention and light lacing. Sour, acidic initial flavor dominates the low malt backgound. Hop bitterness struggles against the sour signs of an infection that hopefully, has not run rampant throughout the brew house. Light body, smooth mouthfeel. Sour finish.

Koza Brada Bock: Pours a hazy copper bronze with clingy, thin off-white head. Aroma of sweet crystal malt with some tart notes. Starts with a fizzy acidity and a touch of sweetness, but an obvious infection. Would be nice to try a non-infected bottle.

Bottle, Koza Brada Bock. Strong spicy aroma took me by surprise. A good deal of sweet malt there mixing strangely with grass. Clear orange-amber body with a large soapy eggshell head. Sour, lightly acidic beginning, floral fruits at the front of the wave with faint bitterness and caramel toward the end. Doesn�t quite veer to metallic. Medium-thin body. Some work to be done here.

On tap only, Koza Brada: A 2nd running from the batch of doublebock then dry hopped: A clean amber hue with a small frothy head and good lace. The aroma hints of grassy and floral hops, light caramel and toasted malts, touch of fruit(apple and plum), bready and zesty yeast esters. The taste is refreshing and balanced. Bitter with a nice background of sweet chocolate malts. The finish has a metallic and malty nature. The mouthfeel is lively and clean.

330ml capped plastic bottle. Clear bright yellow beer with a medium disappearing white head. Sweet corn malts, wet cardboard and somewhat soapy aromas on the nose. Flavour is sweet with a low hop bitterness and abrupt finish. Light-medium bodied with a watery texture. Like your average Mexican-style pale lager - absolutely nothing "Belgian" about this beer.

Small head gold pour medium carbonation aromas mild grain grass assparagras like the flavours wheaty like grain asparagras chalky dull it is drinkable but not good no real good aftertastes at best a refresher

330ml bottle. This pours very pale amber with a thin layer of sudsy looking white foam. Looks quite dreadful. The aroma is almost non existent except for some hay like aromas. He flavour fares no better as it is thin in the mouth and leaves nothing on the palate. Not sure if the plastic bottle had any impact on this beer but it is quite horrid.

Big sudsy mess of white atop a bright, medium gold body with irregular, soda-pop carbonation. Drabs a thick film of white down the glass as it empties. Very grainy, rich and sweet malt nose with hints of chaff and dried mown grass. Quite sweet again in the mouth, backbone of toasted malts, a light coloured nutty praline note comes in there as is an odd hint of bacon and light, zingy herbs. Quite light on, oily in mouthfeel with light carbonation. Finishes slightly soapy and very short with a dash of shy hoping. Not much bitterness but at least it has hops, suppose. Overall, an average offering from a non-existent brewery. (33cL, 4.7% ABV, BB 23/05/12, Dan Murphy�s Bunbury)
Flat pale lager with a malty dry aroma and a quite strongly dry flavour. Overall a poorish lager.
maybe it was just the name but it tasted a little metallic. lifeless. ......
golden colour, few head, paperboard-like aroma, tart and oily with an unpleasant dry finish - it shows everything you can do wrong with a lager ...
Back log rating so no not s in aroma , appearance etc . Just the saved rating from an old book

Faint plum-molasses nose. Some apple notes with hints of pineapple and apricot as it warms up and breathes. Medium-light body, but with no wateriness. Flavor sweet with an overlay of bitterness. Fantastic mild with excellent flavor for a 3.5% beer.

Can from B&M, Team Valley, Gateshead. Dark amber-copper coloured with a thick white head. It has a malty and slight burnt toffee flavour with slight almond notes on the creamy finish. Not bad for the low ABV.
Hadn�t had this for years then came across it as a guest beer, nice surprise.
Very easy drinking colour rust small head toffee caramel taste hint of dark fruit ok bottle at home

Can shared by Theydon Bois at the RBWG Fart Dungeon - thanks again, Colin! Pours a clear dark orange tea color with no head. Kind of sugary and earthy, with leaves and wet toast. But mostly just dull and watered down. Light-bodied, with medium carbonation and a dry, toasty, sugary, watery mouthfeel. Snooze.

[1/29/16] Can sample at a hotel room bottle share during RBWG 2016 in Santa Rosa. Thanks everyone who shared bottles! Amber. Aroma of DMS, malt, caramel. Sweet flavor with caramel, DMS, malt, drier finish. Light-bodied.
Can at fart dungeon tasting. Clear copper pour with thin white head. Aroma is vegetal, metallic, caramel, light toast. Taste is very metallic, light cooked veggie. Palate is light bodied, watery.
Can. Pours copper with small white head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is fruity malt and toast. Medium mouth, bready malt, bitter, decent.
Can - Toasty malts and caramel. Clear copper with a decent beige head. Toffee, light grains and a light finish. Simple and decent.

On tap at the pub. Pours very little head and has a pale golden appearance. Weak lacing. Moderate carbonation. Aromas of maple are fairly noticeable, some sweet malt, herbs. Flavours are quite sweet, some notes of maple. Dry finish.
Light body with a subtle aroma of maple. Light texture, heavy on maple taste but not much else to it. Nothing spectacular but not bad.

Draft @ the Brew Pub. Amber color in a mug. Nose is only hints of light Maple. Taste is lager yeast and watery maple syrup. Thin body. It�s like drinking watered down maple sugar water. Sticky texture. MEH.
660ml bottle from Booths. Standard stuff, prefer Moretti or the red Peroni if I'm honest.
330ml can on Lago di Garda, Italy. Aroma is light malt. Appearance is clear golden with a small white foam. Taste is light to medium bitter. Light sweetness. Slightly dry. Ok Lager.
just about drinkable had pint from tap while in venice crap beer terrible tasste

Dec �14. On tap at the brewpub. Finally managed to get there, thanks Ruza! Beer was dark brown bodied, seemed maybe slightly hazy, with small brownish head. Caramel and sugar aroma, some toffee. Flavor was, accordingly, sweet, without bitterness of any kind. Caramel and sugar were dominating, simple as that. Lightly acidic, too. Medium to thin body with very smooth palate and shorter, sweetish finish. Utterly simple, but not bad, clean, easy going and without any faults. Okay.

Dark brown color, medium sized off-white head. Caramel aroma, taste is also caramel with some nuts. Thin to medium body, nice creamy texture, soft carbonation. Sweet finish. Actually, pretty decent dunkel. Thanks to Marko for sharing it at 2nd beer conference in Magic Beer Room.

Enormous thanks to Davor �., Matija & Fran I think for bringing some of this handbottled to Zagreb, and Dinko for bringing another. So, first rate in 12 years, wow! Hotel Golf is, obviously, a hotel with a brewery, located by the Drava river in the Me�imurje region, a bit out of the way, but known, kinda, for being one of those rare few places anywhere where gold panning is still done. So, yeah. They only do this beer, and it was available in the bigger towns relatively close to D.V. at first (Koprivnica, Vara�din), but 10 years ago or so they stopped that and it�s, as far as I know, only available at the hotel. From what I�ve heard, the brewer uses crazy amounts of gypsum (?!) and has a "less hops used = better" policy. So what does that give us? The beer actually looks damn good. Very dark brown/black, with a lasting, medium sized creamy off white head. Mild caramelly aroma, quite creamy, mild caramelly taste, quite creamy, very, very soft, with, unsurprisingly, no hops to be detected. No aftertaste. So, kinda catering to the lowest common denominators, but they wouldn�t survive this long as a brewery if they hadn�t. I�d honestly expected worse - and allegedly it often is. Still damn thrilled to have had it. Shared it with several more raters that day - so the number of ratings should rise a little.
Sampled draught at Pastuh Pub, Varazdin, Croatia. -good munich dunkel, nice aroma, this beer can be drinked lot
Pours amber with a thick white head. Aroma of malt and grass. Taste has caramel malt with fruity resin. Palate has grassy fruit notes, melon and yeast. Good. Hoppy but drinkable.
Draft at Nationals, NYC. Ordered while waiting for other folks to arrive. Fairly tasty and easy drinking.

Bottle at a JFK Airport Bar, New York. Malty aroma with resinous hops, caramel, soft floral notes, some grapefruit. Fairly sweet, medium bitter. Body is medium. Resinous and malty, bittersweet, not bad but I don't get the relatively high rating.

Hazy golden-amber, compact off-white head. The aroma is rich creamy firuty caramel malts, candied citrus. Same with the taste - savoury jammy malts. The pungent somewhat harsh hop bitterness has some green grassy notes, but the malts are just too good at the rounding such errors. Nice.

A bit of orange and mango on the nose. A little sweet at the start like malt and honey then the bitterness comes thru. Nice smooth mouthfeel. Light carbonation makes it feel a bit flat in the long rub.
Fruchtig in der Nase und im Trunk, hopfig, mittig leicht bitter, nach hinten st�rker werdend. Passt.
Not too heavy or hoppy but loses a little taste and lasting power. Easy drinking and didn't leave a big hangover ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Can. Pours a clear pale gold hue with an off-white head. Citrus, tropical fruit, peach, mango notes. Good stuff.

Can pour with a barely cloudy yellow gold color. Aromas of pineapple and pine needles. Soft mouthy feel up front with a prominent bitterness that overtakes the hop aromas. A burnt charcoal note comes through. A hint of alcohol vapors as well.
Bottle at Dia:Beacon. Super lovely juicy hop bomb, sweet and bitter well balanced (it's still quite bitter though). Went down so fast with a delicious black bean burger.
It's a bad sign when the beer comes with an orange slice. Faint wheat and spice aroma. The flavor was better with pronounced cloves.

Hazed yellow pour with a creamy white head and lace. Aroma is wheat and a hinot clove. I get no banana at all. Wheaty flavor, some clove, and a bit of the dry tinge at the end. Thin and watery not very special.

From draft sampler at Two Rows in Allen, Texas (suburban Dallas) on July 24, 2011. Very cloudy yellow hue, spicy aroma heavy on the clove, sour/sweet flavor with some bitterness, light body, would be better if it was a little less watery.
On tap at the restaurant. Hazy yellow pour with a white head. Aroma is citrus, banana, and grain. Taste is lemon, banana, banana, wheat, and a little clove.

On tap at the Allen location. Served with a slice of lemon. The beer pours a hazy straw color with a white head. The aroma is very strong banana, but I also get a little bit of clove. The flavor is overwhelmingly banana and is very sweet and syrupy. This tastes like a wheat beer with some banana extract poured in. Medium, creamy mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Nothing to seek out.
(draught) opaque golden color. Nose of wheat, mild clove and banana. Taste if spicy clove and cinnamon, bubblegum with a spicy somewhat refreshing finish.
(Draught) Pours a cloudy golden body with a moderate white head. Aroma of vanilla, grain, wheat, and spoiled veggies. Flavor of wheat, spoiled veggies, close, and some off fruitness.
Cloudy pour from tap at Two Rows in Allen, TX. Pillowy head. Banana, clove and yeast taste. Smooth as silk finish. Solid hefe, one I would drink again.

Pours a cloudy yellow with white head. Aroma of some banana and is grainy. Flavor is much the same with some nice wheatly malt notes. Mouth feel is light body with medium carbonation. Overall, a tasty little heff.
draft at the brewpub. murky yellow with a white head. oranges and light coriander for the aromas. smooth like water on the palate with a big nutmeg/spice flavor and a light orange finish.
Not bad at all. Roasted malt and decent palate from the oats. Hints of chocolate.

On tap at the Allen location. The beer pours a dark brown to black color with a tan head. The aroma is reminiscent of cocoa and not too much else. Overall, it is a little faint and the beer doesn�t really smell like much. The flavor has a lot of heavily roasted malt, as well as some cocoa and some oats. Creamy mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Brown black pour with a frothy tan head and lace. Roasted malt aroma with a hinto coffee. Flavor is sweet toasted malt, coffee, and cough syrup. A fizzy beer with a good malt bitter. Not bad but not a big fan.

On tap at Two Rows in Allen. Pours black with tan head. Aroma of dark roasted malts, coffee, and faint dark fruit, well balanced. Flavor is nice, semi sweet baking chocolate and coffee, raison, nothing over powering, nice fresh taste. Mouth feel wasn�t what I expected though, the only downside was that it seemed slightly watery, but easy drinking, with medium carbonation. This beer was pretty good!

Tap. Weak black coffee color with some roasted malts on the nose. Flavor is oddly carbonated (like the Dunkel I had just before)...like a soda and has little flavor...some mild sweetness, but the body is all wrong.
Legitimate oatmeal stout. Fairly simple flavor; mostly oatmeal and malt. Watery mouthfeel.

Tap at brewery. Pours thin brown-black with an aroma of rotten garbage and spoiled cabbage. The flavor follows suit, containing bit of rotten sugar-sweetened vegetables. Watery mouthfeel at best. This is liquid barf.

One of the best Two Rows had to offer (which isn�t saying much). There was certainly an oatmealy flavor and aroma that dominated the beer. It might have been a little on the weak side of things for a true stoutie, but I�m a session/pale ale kind of guy so I rather enjoyed this. One of the best Two Rows offered, but like all of its brews, its Houston location, it left a little to be desired and was bland.
Looks like an ok stout. Has no aroma. The flavor is very very watered with a hint of cherry in the finish. Who knew a stout could be so far off the mark?

This poured a very dark brown body, nearly black, with a slender tan head. The aroma is a strange blending of buttered toast and coffee. Fairly thin for a stout, it had a flavor of roasted malts, coffee, and a bit of milk chocolate. Fairly watery finish. Two Rows Brewery, Dallas, TX

Right now I am pulling something out of my ass for this one. I remember having it but fail to remember what it tasted like. It was most likely good, but none of the Two Rows beers really stick out in my mind.

The story on this was that the Houston Aeros (hockey team) requested a beer by this name. Get it...penalty bock. Yeah, really funny. Anyway, it was a standard American dark lager that claims to be a bock. A little caramel, some maltiness, nothing outstanding.

Dude said that this beer is comparable to shiner bock....quite the contrary. This beer was more of a bock than shiner, but by no means a benchmark for a good bock. It was typical....smooth, sweet, caramel tasting....nothing special here.
One of the better beers in the flight I had. Aromas and flavors of pine and resin. Golden-copper color.
On tap, and cast conditioned (?). A very average ipa, with floral hop and citrus notes. Big malt backbone in this one.

On tap at two rows in roce village. Pours a cloudy copper with a medium creamy white head that leaves good sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is very hoppy with grapefruit and caramel. Medium mouthfeel with a hoppy pine flavor. Easy to drink a good IPA from Two Rows.

Name: India Pale Ale Date: February 15, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear copper, fine off white head, streaks of lace Aroma: sweet crystal malt aroma with lots of citrus hops for the definitave sugar grapefruit character Flavor: sweet and bitter flavor, lots of sweet crystal malt balanced with a growing and lingering bitterness, just a touch of hop flavor in the middle Overall: needs more hop flavor to match the wonderful aroma Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4

Had this on tap at the Rice Village, Houston location. Poured a golden copper color with a medium off white head. Smelled of light grapefruit and tangy hops. Tasted of slightly sweet citrus followed by hops and ending slightly bitter. Clean mouthfeel, with little aftertaste. Dried my tongue out nicely. Good, but unremarkable.
At least it had hops. This makes it one of the better Two Rows brews I tried. It too was on the watery, thin, and bland side of things. But it was passable.
Draft in Houston. Floral and citrus aroma. Similar flavor, nice bitter finish but nothing too interesting.

Draft at Brewpub. Poured a golden color with alot of carbonation. Aroma of grapefruit is exciting. Taste is sweet start with a hoppy finish. Earlier Rating: 3/18/2007 Total Score: 2.6 Draft at brewpub. Poured a red and brownish color. Aroma of citrus and floral hops. Taste is not as strong as the Cask IPA but still good.
I am surprised by some of the ratings as this is not a very good US IPA I found it bland and not particulary crisp
this was pretty good even though ipas aren�t my favourites anymore...Very good and full, rust colour...good lacing..bitter and clean..well made, nice sticking around flavour factor.

Bottle at an Ethiopian restaurant. Clear straw in color with an average white head. Aroma is floral hops, and mild lemon. Slightly spicy as well. Taste is tangy hops, grains, and bread. Average and a bit skunky.

33cl can. Crystal clear straw body topped by minimal white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, bread, light honey, spicy. Taste is moderately sweet, bread, honey, light spicy. Light-medium body, light sticky.

DWG; Bottle received as a gift. Thank you. Can 330 ML. Pours clear golden with a large frothy, lacing, moderate lasting white head. Aroma is malt, caramel, hay, honey, light vegetable and spice.Taste is moderate to heavy sweet and light bitter with a moderate lasting, honey finish. Body is medium, texture is oily to sticky, carbonation is soft.

6/X/14 - 33cl can @ home - BB: 4/XII/14, canned: 5/XII/13 (2014-1182) Thanks to Annemie for the can! Clear blond beer, creamy irregular white head, little stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: sweet, pretty fruity, bit hoppy even, sugary touch. MF: ok carbon, light body. Taste: little bitter, some citrus, bit sugary, sweet. Aftertaste: slightly bitter, sweet and sugary, some banana.

Clear golden colour, white head. Aroma of malts, straw and hops. Malty flavour, sweet, light bitterness, wheat-like grainy touch. Malty finish, light bitter, light sweet. Not bad, not bad at all. (From 33cL can @ the �tick countries & enjoy some good beers� tasting. 5% ABV. Thanks for sharing, Tim!)
Cloudy, very opaque. Smells and looks like a nice wheat beer. Taste is malty, with honey and toasted notes. Very good with spicy fare, as Ethiopian food usually is or can be.
Bottle. Creamy White good mostly lasting head. yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Light bitter finish. Watery palate.

330 ml bottle in Sudan. Pours a pale yellow with short head. Aroma has some heavy spices in it that are hard to place, but pleasant. Taste is unlike the aroma and has a slight cardboard taste. Palate ends with some sourness.
Bottle in Dembi Dollo, Ethiopia. Hoppy aroma, pale yellow colour. Resin hop flavour with bitter aftertaste. Mediocre lager.
25-Oct-2006 - Sweet and low hop aroma. Hazy yellow light amber colour, very low head and poor suds lacing. Sweet plain and hopless flavour. Flat hop plain and bubblegum finish.
(drought at City Steam in Hartford CT, 5%, AKA City Steam Ale) medium body and ^drinkable, predominantly rich-chclt-malts.

In short: Basic thin and watery fruity dark ale. How: Tap at brewpub The look: Dark mahogany body topped by a little ring of foam In long: Watery toffee and breakfast jam. Roastiness kept to a minimum. Nutty notes totally absent in this so-called brown ale. Malt economy mode in action. To call it thin is an understatement. Barely any hops. Carbonation appropriately soft. We drove through Hartford, the weather was shitty, we went to the City Steam, I drank their Dark Ale. Then I started to have spasms and convulsions. Boredom overdose.

Light brown, off white fizzy head. Nose held soft milk chocolate tones that lay on lighter wafts of earthy sweet caramel malt. Balanced flavor begins with more chocolate and touches of watery coffee that round out to a slight hoppy bitterness. Light bodied, light carbonation, drying chocolate finish. Nothing special here�

I thought it was a stout at first b/c it was rather sweet and heavy, but being a brown ale, it has other flavors in it as well which make it fairly complex. As it gets warmer, it gets alittle syrupy and flat, but it was great starting off....

A brown ale with no nuts and some tofee caramel in the base. A very small touch of burnt coffee or chocolate was noticeable in the flavor and aroma. This one was most impressive in appearance with a brown-red darkness that beckoned to be consumed. Not nearly as good in flavor as in appearance.
Pours with a small whitish head. Smells earthy. Tastes malty with some sweetness. Watery finish.
on tap-pours without a head. Color is dark brown with red tint and effervescence. Aroma is dark malt. Taste is very dark malt, medium bodied. Minimum carbonation.

Poured with little head with tap from City Steam Brewery in Hartford. Sweet, but not overwelming with cheeseburger. With little carbonation, I thought the ale would turn syrupy after my long meal, but it held up nicely to the end.

On draught at brewery 8/11/05 with Clarkvv: Caramel colored brown, mostly clear but not totally translucent, with a small beige head that quickly recedes and then dies. The aroma is caramel, chocolate, mild roasted malt, and a hint of coffee (barely). The taste is caramel, toffee, coffee, grain, earthy/grassy hops, with hints of deep roasted malt flavors and diacetyl (mild, well below levels representing a problem). Light-medium bodied, mild carbonation, very easy to either sip slowly or down in quantity.

Came a dark brown, with a finger of thick dark tan head. Aroma was sweet, chocolaty and caramel. Flavor started with sweet caramel and chocolate with hints of sweetened grain, then turned lightly roasty, and a bit smoky. Finishes full with hints of grassy hops, but not enough to overpower the sweetness and roastiness of this beer. Not a bad beer, but I don�t think this will ever be the best beer on tap at City Steam.

Dark, dark opaque brown with a foamy tan head that dissipates. Roasted aroma. Nice body, for a dry stout. Medium thick with loads of chocolate malts and roasted aspects and some black malt tang. Heavier than most dry stouts, which is nice. Much better than last years drier, bitter, sourish version.

Tap. Tons of citrusy orange tangerine aromas. A small amount of marijuana is present as well. Transparent dark-copper color with an off-white/light tan head. Lots of citrus, orangey hops to start, turning quite bitter and harsh in the middle. Mild dry maltiness in the finish that renders this quite drinkable. Very reminiscent of some of the SoCal IPAs that I had in San Diego.

Clear copper. Thin white head. Light carbonation. Medium body loaded with citric and piney hops. Sticky aftertaste. Alcohol taste increases as you drink but is not bothersome. Crystal malt balance. Hops are fresh and tasty and resinous. Finishes bitter, strong, hefty and with a surge of spicy alcohol. Nice job.

Pours a darker gold with an off white head. Smells spicy with some anise hints and some citrussy splashes. Tastes grassy and perfumy with some sweet notes and a peppery splash on the finish. Great example of the style.

Hazy yellow with a minimal head. Steady carbonation. Honeyed, toasted corn aroma? Wheaty and thick and corn syrup flavored. Medium-heavy body. Toasted malts, but loaded with corn syrup sweetness and popcorn toastedness. Cloying as well. Spicy alcohol taste is redeeming but this is bad. What happened with this one? Not the same as last years recipe, which was..uh..good.

Pour on tap at the brewery, clar yellow with white head, aroma brought notes of grass, biscuit, bread, hints of grain, some mild honey as well. Taste is a mix of grass, biscuit, bread, hints of yeast, honey, finishing clean. Eh.
Light yellow color, very see through. Has a light wheat taste. Not terrible, but not great.
draft... bmc appeasor beer not worth trying, very light and ugly beer to boot

Sample at the brewpub. The beer is a clear pale golden color with a thin and fizzy white head that evaporates quickly to an outer ring. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of grainy malt and hops. Light and clean body with flavors of grassy hops and sweet malt, plus a bit of fruit. The finish is mildly hoppy with a lingering light bitterness. Decent introductory beer overall.

On tap @ the brew pub: Pours a clear gold with a white head. Aroma, light malts, yeasty, grassy. Flavor, crisp light fruits, some yeasty notes, grassy, light bready malts. This was better than I was expecting.
Not too inspired. Another stand by beer that is always on the chalkboard. Out of boredom, I may lean towards this one.
On tap. Yellow and with brilliant clarity, this beer was refreshing. Slight hints of fruitness in the aroma. Good clean lawn mower beer.
On tap at the Royal Oak Brew Pub. Poured a medium and clear yellow color with a small sized white head. Aromas of grain and corn. Tastes of grain, lightly bready and some grass.
Tap: golden yellow with little head. Aroma has nothing to speak of. Flavor has a little citrus with a grassy finish.

Tap. Golden yellow colored, clear. White head with a bit of lacing. Absolutely unchallenging in any aspect. Fairly light, clean and unintrusive. Per style this is ok. Lacking a bit on the hop side of the house. I am sure this is the money maker beer for these fine folks.
On tap at the pub. Thin coffee aroma. Black body with a decent head. Creamy palate has a medium mouthfeel. Creamy taste with sweet chocolates and a coffee finish. Not bad.

On tap at the Royal Oak Brew Pub. Listed on the board as "Shilcelagh Stout" @ 7% abv. Poured a dark brown (almost black) color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of roast, some chocolate, and a little earthy and dirty. Tastes of roast and light coffee. Thinner body.

Poured from a growler. Thick dark black with a thin tan head that diminishes rapidly, appears to be very little carbonation present. Large nose of burnt popcorn, smoke, roasted malts, stale coffee and dark chocolate. Flavors of smoke, stale coffee with a very dry burnt malt finish. Far to smokey which really does smother any other lasting flavors.
Pours dark brown/black with a tan head. Smells of chocolate, hints of coffee. Taste is mostly chocolate with some coffee within. Too thin and watery for a stout.

On tap: Moderate roasted coffee aroma. Some light chocolate Dark brown with red hilights. Not as dark as a stout should be. Tan head. Looks more like a porter. Chocolate up front with a roasted coffee finish. Cafe mocha aftertaste. Not thin, but thin for a stout.

on tap at the brewery. poured a dark brown to black with small tan head. aroma all weak, chocolate roasted malts, tried to get something else but I couldn�t. flavor just like the aroma weak roasted malts, and chocolate. not impressed with this one I have a lot better stouts than this one. this would be the beer the bud drinks could say that they like dark beers and make them feel worldly.

The head on this beer was nothing too special, however, it looked very nice, but then again, most beers do. Aroma was good, with some chocolate hints in there. Nothing too special about the taste either, an average stout that can be found in almost any microbrew bar.

Definitely not the best brew found at the ROB. Although this is labeled an Irish Stout, it is way too sweet to really exemplify that style. Some thing about mouthfeel of this stout just isn't correct. It feels too thin on the palate, even though it packs a lot of malt flavor. I would go for the porter rather than the stout at the ROB any day.
This is your average micropub beer. You can get similar stouts nearly everywhere.
The only other beer at Royal Oak with enough redeeming qualities that I'd try it again. It's long and dry and roasty, though without much substance.
Lots of citrus, especially lemon. Variety of bread flavors. Undertones of banana and hints of caramel. A bit too acidic but overall not bad.
Dark yellow. Has a mix of light wheat and a sweet fruity flavor. The banana is subtle, and this gives the beer a nice refreshing feel without being overpowering on the fruit.
Nice little wheat beer. It is light and refreshing but there are no real complexities to it.
On tap at Royal Oak Brewpub. Active milky yellow with a thin white head. Aroma of wheat, grains, lemon and toasted malt. Taste of lemon, wheat, grains and mild bubblegum.
Cloudy yellow pour that smells of bananas. The taste is loaded with wheat and has notes of banana as well. It was quite nice but it could have been better.
On tap at R.O.B. Slightly hazy yellow body. Low head retention. Too flavorless to be a Hefeweizen. Decent wheat beer but needs more banana / clove for style.
Tap: yellow with little head. Yeasty banana aroma with lots of spice. Flavor is very bland with a little banana in the finish. Rather thin body.

Tap. Yellow colored with a slight haze. Bits of clove and bananna but ever so slightly. Fair white soda pop head fades quickly. Light bodied to the point of being a fault. Lacking in flavor and body to be a decent German Hefe.

Cloudy yellow, one of the few unfiltered beers on tap here. On draft, presented with a champagne like pure white head that fizzled away rapidly. Not much lacing, which I have come to expect from thicker wheats. Definite wheat and malts in the aroma, some citrus as well, the usual lemons, oranges common to the style. Flavor was dominated by the smooth malts, light citrus, however this wasn�t as thick as I thought it would be based upon looks. Finished strong, a nice wet hop finish with slight spiciness. Good effort, but there are better examples of the style out there in Michigan alone.

On tap: Real light citrus and banana aroma. Hazey and an extra pale yellow with a white head. Light up front. Banana and real light citrus with a light clove finish with some bitterness. A little more malty than your average wit.
Draft. Pours an orange amber color. Light frothy head. Very hoppy as expected with orange citrus flavors. Leaves a bit of aspirin taste on the finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Always a good solid well balanced IPA from the people at Royal Oak Thye have perfected the art of brewing and their Pleazures is a first class ale. Consistently smooth in its malt finish with a slight degree of fruit. Excellent
Not bad I suppose. Cascade hops, not much of a head, and once again kind of thin. Not the worst beer.

On tap. Light citrus and faint grassy hops. Light golden brown body with a medium head. Thin and watery palate really detracts from this one. Thin hop and malt profile. Balanced, but weak overall. Definite grassy hop aftertaste.

On tap @ the brew pub: Pours a clear copper color with an off white head. Aroma, citrus and caramel notes, with some pale malts. Flavor, citrus, pine, some spices, with some pale malts in the background.
Draught at pub. Reddish with small head. An attempt at one of these famous very hoppy beers. Not up to any of the famous ones but very hoppy and grapefruity.
My go to ROB beer. Basic IPA. Hops ok. Decent flavors. Goes well with a burger or fish n chips.
Citrus, orange hops on the nose. Pours amber with decent lacing. Very bitter hoppy taste with a creamy malt smoothness at the tail end.
Orangy amber with nice white head. Aroma is hoppy with undertones of malt, some spiciness. Decidedly hoppy, but flavor rather muddled. A decent offering, but not special.

MBG 06. Skunky pils like aroma - wtf??? Hoppy taste but again, this thing reminded me of a pils??? I had an Imperial pils at the fest, I had an India Pale Lager (??), but this was just supposed to be an IPA damn it! Some citrus hops do come through after a while in taste and it settles down, but man, I found this experience almost unsettling...
Pours a dark amber with a thin white head. Aroma is caramel and earthy hops. Flavor is caramel, earthy hops, and finishes with nut. The flavors and aromas are very subtle. Nothing memorable.

I have a cold, please take my rating with a grain of salt. An extremely mild aroma of cereal. Appears a very dark reddish-purple brown, thicker than average head, some lace. Tastes of malty sweetness with a touch of bitter charred marshmallow. Palate is fizzy and nice. Overall, a nice red.
Tap. Super dark ruby. Lingering few milimeters of head. Slightly sweet malty nose. Some caramel malt presence without being too sweet. Tastes German.

Pour on tap at the brewery, dark red, hazy with off white head, aroma brought notes of caramel, toffee, hints of nuts, sweet red fruits with cherry, slight nutty note as well. Taste is a mix of grass, caramel, toffee, hints of grain, red fruit, touch of spice, finishing slightly sweet, dry.
Haylike nuttiness of malt in the nose. Very bland brew. Maybe an early recipe that they never bothered to improve.
draft... really boring amber, mostly generic caramel... the bartender told us she mixes it with the ipa, enough said
From the Jug at the GABF Colorado Convention Center, Denver 10/10/2008 Fruity aroma. Amber mid brown coloured and a little rich on the palate with a crisp and slightly dry malt finish.

I had a pint of this on tap at the brewpub today while out to dinner with my friend BeerBaron617. It was a nice pretty ruby amber color with a light head. It had a sweet aroma with a tiny hint of hops. It was sort of sweet to the taste, not remarkable though. A bit malty, and a tad hoppy. Overall a decent refreshing beer.
A very good red with a rather dark pour. A somewhat light with a not too subtle finish but refreshing nonetheless.

column1: Royal Oak Pappy's Porch Sippin' Porter
column5: Served on tap at Royal Oak Brewing. Dark black color with a brown head. Malt coffee aroma. Malt choc bitter. Basic porter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Royal Oak Pappy's Porch Sippin' Porter
column5: Aroma is a bit burnt, sweet cocoa with noticeable bitterness. Flavors of heavily roasted coffee, semisweet chocolate and burnt grains. Has a bitter bite toward the end which I like. Decent feel. A bit oily is my only compliant.

column1: Royal Oak Pappy's Porch Sippin' Porter
column5: Draft. Deep black, thin head. Chocolate and roasted aroma, medium body, very strong bitter sharp finish.

column1: Royal Oak Pappy's Porch Sippin' Porter
column5: Very decent porter, on tap at the brewpub. Very dark brown, lace sheet.Lots of burnt edges, but drinkable.

column1: Royal Oak Pappy's Porch Sippin' Porter
column5: Dark brown beer with a foamy light brown head. Has a coffee flavor at the head with hints of chocolate at the finish.

column1: Royal Oak Pappy's Porch Sippin' Porter
column5: Growler thanks to Mike! Pours a clear chestnut and a brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of roasted malts with a bit of supporting dark chocolate. Flavor starts with dark grains and grows to have roasted malts as well as a bit of bitter chocolate in the finish.

column1: Royal Oak Pappy's Porch Sippin' Porter
column5: draft... really light porter, ugly watery body, the taste is watery coffee... pass

column1: Royal Oak Pappy's Porch Sippin' Porter
column5: Sample at the brewpub. Dark brown pour with a medium thin and creamy tan head that diminishes steadily. Stringy lacing. Aroma of roasted coffee and malt. Medium, somewhat dry body with flavors of roasted malt, coffee and touches of hops and chocolate. The finish is roasty with a short coffee aftertaste. Decent overall.

column1: Royal Oak Pappy's Porch Sippin' Porter
column5: Kind of thin, and too sour. Not the best porter I�ve had. The yeast didn�t seem right for the style either....a little too fruity. But what do know?

column1: Royal Oak Pappy's Porch Sippin' Porter
column5: Pours dark brown, smells like roasted coffee. It has a roasted flavor but it is sweeter then the aroma. Smooth toffee finish that was too sweet for me.

On tap in Cambridge, MA. I have to say that i'm not a big honey fan to begin with, so i wasn't surprised when i didn't care for it that much. It was smooth and kinda refreshing, but with a hefty honey-ee taste to it.
You can definitely taste the honey tones in this brew, nice gold-type color, very smooth
Pretty traditional bock style of beer, nice dark gold color, very smooth ..
Nice black color, kept a nice foamy head, coffee type undertones, very rich, a little lighter body than most stouts

On tap at brew house. Poured a medium copper with a half finger foamy white head. A sweet roasted malt and grain aroma, with a hint of nuttiness. The taste upfront was sweet and grainy malts accompanied by a moderate earthy hops. Light and smooth body with a clean refreshing finish.

TAP NY 08. Light amber in color with a small off white head. Aroma of light toasted malt, a trace of caramel and perhaps a touch of butter. Taste is pretty weak in flavor, not too much going on- some light toasted malts, caramel sweetness, and light butterscotch. Very watery and quite bland.

Tap at Lake Grove location. pale amber ber, no head. Nice light malty aroma, some light toastiness. A soft herbal hop character. Nice sweetish flavour with good balance. Toasted lightly bready malts. Herbal and floral finish. Nicely balanced beer.

Sampled on draft at the Monroeville PA location this beer poured a vibrant bright red-bronze color with a small white head. The aroma was light malts and floral hops. The flavor was a somewhat bland but smooth mix of light malts and crisp floral hops.

Clear, pink rusty with no head. Honey cereal malt aroma. Woody, light malt mustiness. Medium-light sweetness, but it comes off dray. Medium body. Nicely done. Did well with the fish and chips and malt vinegar. Pittsburgh.

As �Southwest Vienna Lager� on draught at Monroeville. Light bitter astringent aroma, low on sweetness or malt character. Clean dull amber brown body with thin lacing head. Light bodied with soft carbonation. Starts subtle and smooth. Light malt sweetness. Toasted grain and subtle floral hops notes. Orange rind bitterness and some toffee. Finish is medium bitter with light carbonic acidity. After is dry and nutty with a bitter bite.
Not a whole lot to say. I liked it. No fruit undertones. I�m not that good. But the "average guy" would find this one quite quaffable.

(DC) Clear copper body with off-white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, toasty, some lemon. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, grassy, some bread, finishes with some lemon. Light-medium body with some creaminess, finishing with moderate acidity.
Nice brew pub in downtown DC. Amber color with a sweet malty flavor. A nice crisp finish. Drank several and enjoyed each one.

On draught at the Framingham location, March 2005. Light brownish-auburn color, with some light tan tinges throughout and a small beige head. Mostly clear with a big shot of crystally malts and cream. Not much lager apparency in the nose. I�m not getting the banana esters everyone else mentions, which is fine with me. Flavor begins sweet and well-malted, with light fruit (cherry, strawberry, apple) notes. Quite attenuated, but I don�t mind the wateriness as it makes it that much more refreshing. Dry, but not very flavorful hops bite at the end. A bit of dusty yeast.

Light raspberry aroma with bit of citrusy hops. Light cloudy amber-tan with small lacing off-white head. Light carb and medium watery body. Sweet and berry notes. Not big raspberry taste, but a light tartness with bitter finish and after. Decent, but I've had better raspberry beers.
Not so much into these types of fruity beers but thought I'd give it try anyway, too bubbly & carbonated, too strong of a berry taste almost overpowering

Sampled on draft at the Monroeville PA location this beer poured a black color with a medium sized brown head. The aroma was roasty malts and a hint of coffee. The flavor was sweet chocolate, cream and light toasted malt with a long silky chocolate finish. The mouthfeel was silky smooth.
This was a knockout. Served huge head. Taste roasted and choc aromas .... delivered creamy. After taste a bit bitter but choc lingered. Nice consistency.

At the JH in Lake Grove NY. This was the "Augustus Gloop" Porter at this location; clever name is the best thing going, unfortunately. VERY sweet & chocolaty, just some hints of roastiness, very simple, just too much, and I'm a sugar-holic with dark beers. Oh well.

MMMM, this one is really yummy. A huge frothy head, and immediately you taste a very chocolate malt flavor. This is a great desert beer. Not something I could really sit down and drink more than one of. But do not get me wrong this one is extremely yummy, right down to the smoothest finish, I have had in a long time.
Nice black color, kept a great creamy & foamy head, you can definitely taste the chocolate tones in the beer, very very smooth

column4: Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake - Molson Coors)
column5: Reviewed from notes: Pours a very nice clear golden amber color with white head. Caramel malt, some barley notes, and a little pine and citrus on the nose; follows onto the palate.

column4: Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake - Molson Coors)
column5: Surprisingly nice beer. Had on tap in Kansas City at some pizza place. Drinkable lawnmower beer.

column4: Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake - Molson Coors)
column5: This was my least favorite of the summer sampler. The malts are noticeable with a slight hop finish.

column4: Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake - Molson Coors)
column5: Had this several years ago and I remember that it was among the best light beers I�ve had. No adjuncts in flavor and smooth in taste, I don�t know why Leinenkugel stopped making it.

column4: Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake - Molson Coors)
column5: Pale amber. Aroma of caramel malts and mild hoppiness. Flavor is thin with mostly caramel malts and hop water.

column4: Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake - Molson Coors)
column5: Vintage 2002 (135th anniversary bottle) 12 ounce bottle. Pours a nice, cloudy, light brown with a persistent, thin, foamy, white head. Taste is of caramel, fruit, grass, citrus, yeast, apple and malt. Similar aroma. Very palatable. The body is rather thin, but that is forgiven since it is a light beer and is seven years old. Easy to drink, is rather refreshing and is a nice treat. Has held up nicely for being seven years old. For a pale lager it is rather dark and flavorful. I wish they still made it and a little dissapointed that they don�t. I might have to find another bottle and age it further.

column4: Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake - Molson Coors)
column5: Bottle. Pours pale amber with fizzy head that deminshes quickly. Smells lightly malted, kind of corn-like. Tastes a little sweet, light, bread grains, with a hint of hops. Pretty good light beer.

column4: Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake - Molson Coors)
column5: Compared to other light beers, this Amber is one of the best. Pours with a light red color, and goes down smooth with a nice light taste.

column4: Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake - Molson Coors)
column5: one of the worst beer i have ever tried, undrinkable, flavor is horriffic, still sends chills down spine when i flash-back to the waste of time trying this shit.

column4: Jacob Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake - Molson Coors)
column5: This was a nice alternative to other light beers, and I�d put it in competition with Sam Adams Light or Amstel Light. Great color, but (not surprisingly) a watery taste. If only it tasted as good as it looked and smelled...

This was killer, one of the best that I have tried from Hawks. Deep rich brown color, aroma is nutty and full of rich milk chocolate. Flavor has alot of cocoa, medium bodied and rich with some nice hoppy bitterness and just barely keeps this one being too astrigent. Almost off balance but has just the right amount of flavor for what I was looking for.
Medium dark brown. Sweet nose of chocolate and mild wheat. Flavor is a weak, thin roasted malt offering. A very weak porter, according to my notes. Strong scotch finish is enjoyed, though.

Bottle @ RBSG 04� Grand TastingRuby colored with light tan head & lacing. The aroma is very herbal with some balanced hops & a moderate amount of alcohol & dark malts. The flavor is sweet & astringent, lots of nicely balanced dark malts. Good!

(RBSG04) Beige head atop copper body. Taste is moderately sweet, wall of chococoffee, molasses. Taste is moderately sweet, roasty, chococoffee, some anise, cherry. Light-medium body. An all-around nice beer, though the palate is too light for the flavors.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is dark brown to black, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (chocolate, caramel, cookie), moderately hoppy (flowers). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, creamy/velvety texture, lively carbonation. What can I say? Another beautifully made Hawks brew...very much British style like everything else they make, and impossible to stop drinking. Rich rich rich.

Amber with ruby hues, tannish creamy head and spotty lacing. Alcohol and chocolate in the nose. Bitter roast along with floral hops. Chocolate and roast come back for the flavor. Bitter hops accompany some fruit. Bitter palate with a roasty finish.

Ok purchases from the local Organic food place in town. Comes in the plain brown bomber..simple screen printed label. Very good looking beer poured into my dimpled Imperial pint mug, mahogany brown with reddish accents..a great thick creamy tan coloured head..very well done. Nice aroma of burnt malts,,milky..fresh. Nice taste too..starts nice and creamy smooth malty....then a big burnt oat falvour followed by a good noticable bitterness..very good. Very nice on the palte smooth at first then 'adventurous". A nice drinkable porter..nice for the winter months.

Dark black color. Medium white foamy head. Aroma is chocolate. A medium bodied porter. Malts are choclately, with hints of vanilla and dark fruit. Touch of hop spiciness. Flavors are mainly the chocolate and roasted malts. Very smooth. Nicely balanced. Nice porter. Etched/painted bottle. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
Excellent Porter. Slight head, malty sweet aroma. Flavor is mostly chocolate, but some coffee and slight burnt flavors. Almost no acidicity. Creamy warm mouthfeel. Good Porter, thanks Beerguy101!
Translucent dark amber-brown. Huge off white head. Sticky sweet aroma of roast, yeat, twang, light coffee, mostly burnt. Semi sweet with a sour-smokey burnt finish. Very solid porter.

Amber bodied with an off-white head, this has a light,fruity malt aroma (cherries & apples)with a suggestion of holiday spices. The ale�s a bit thin, but in the flavor the fruitiness continues, the spices fade from view, and there�s a faint earthy bitterness. Not sure what they intended to do here. Two Rows Brewery, Dallas, TX
Draught at the brewpub, Dallas Amber color. The aroma is lightly fruity, I�m hoping... but the flavor is deceiving, weak and just some caramel.

A Two Rows "Winter Ale"--having been four years since we have record of this beer, it�s hard to say that this is the same recipe. It probably isn�t, though there is nothing in the ratings to suggest it is much different in effect. Amber/red with standard carbonation and a head tending to white in color. Malty, a hint of cherry, musty basement, a little paper mulch, and barely any spice character. More of a cross between a Scotch ale and an English bitter--moderate sweetness, lots of malts, etc. Somewhat sticky, but not hugely sweet. Vegetal in the finish, lacking robustness of flavor. (on tap, Greenville Ave., Dallas location)
I love this stuff. Tastes like gingerbread. This is the perfect Christmas beer.
This beer was probably the best I had at Tworows. The aroma was raspberry oatmeal. Taste was fruit, nutmeg. Decent finish, drinkable.
Average brewpub run. Medium hoppy beginning, somewhat bland taste..........
Clear golden appearance. Aroma is corn and malt. Flavour is bitter, malt and sweet. Not good!!
Clear gold in color, white head, average lace. Nose is light malt, front is malt the top thin, the finish, lightly hopped and weak, not my style of beer.
On tap @ Dr. Hops. Pours a nice amber color. Aromas of roast malts, hops, an a touch of fruit. Flavor is a light roasty malt taste with a mild hop finish.
musty aroma with some hops, bla, this is so basic. light crystal malt sweetness with a slight hop taste, pretty much as boaring as it gets
Where is the real amber lager and what have you done with it. Blah, boring and watered down, murky, stale and piss poor.
Musky hops and stale malt flavor. For the beginning to the end of this bottle it went for "eh, average amber, nothing special" to "eh, discusting average amber, nothing good".

apricot golden hazy. bathwater bubbles yield quickly. honey malt is inviting, but there is some damp lawn bag too, like composting tea bags. bought in jackson, wyo., so i guessed was fresh, alas... biscuity and apple peel flavor, but it's out of balance somehow, and surprisingly watery for such good color and opacity. it's a new brewpub, so perhaps some "slack" should be given, next time out west i'll try it again.

Name: Winter Date: 05/05/2002 Mode: Bottle Source: Brewpub Vintage: 2001 clear dark amber, frothy off-white head, toasted malt aroma, rich dry malt flavor, a touch of grainy bitterness in the finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Courtesy of kramer17801, Bottle Dec06, 2002: Beer pours cloudy amber with a totally dissipating off white colored head. Aroma is straightforwardly malty. Flavor is heavily oxidized, sour and card boardy. Would have like to try this fresh.

Bottled 12/6/2002- Pours thick amber tinged brown with off white head. It has a barley wine aroma. A sense of full thick malts fills the nostrels. It is toasted and sweet. The aroma has a nice presence. The feel is thinner than expected from the aroma. Sweet malt is the most noticable. A little fruityness. Dissapointed of the flavor following the plesant aroma, maybe it�s past it�s time.

Pours a dark copper with a tall light tan head. Aroma is faintly sweet and malty, a bit toast, very lightly earthy. This brew had a bit too much bitter hops in the finish for my taste in a winter brew. Needed a bit more toasted malts to warm it up a bit and balance out the hop finish a bit more.

Lovely, bright cherry red color...head is large at first, simmers down quickly... Aroma: Mmmmm....complex! A mix of fruit, spices, alcohol, and...what, you want more, isn�t that plenty? Quite a rich and invigorating aroma, I postpone consumption to prolong my time drinking it deep into the nose...really nice! A hot little hop invasion at first, that dips back, and afterward the flavor is dominated by juicy malt and fruity, but not bitter, hops. A ringing, canyish finish, like cinnamon JollyRanchers... Bottled in November 2002, could it have expired by this point, I wonder? Has some of the character of a dubbel, if that stylistic designation is to be trusted, but not enough to really make it worth caling it a "dubbel." Hmmm, I get it now, it is tasting more and more like a dubbel as we drink it down. But a lesser dubbel...fruitiness persists throughout, tossing further suggestions every time (cherry, melon, peach, mango, berry, grape), overall rich and tasty! Nice, tasty brew from Dominion! I would put it in my regular rotation, if I could!
Bottled on Dec. 06, 2002. Malts and cherry in the aroma. Reddish-brown with very little head. Strong cherry flavor, hint of hops in the aftertaste. Finishes nicely.
No aroma at all. Well balanced, easy drinking, with nice slight hop finish. Good dark color.

Dark Brown appearance with a good sized head and generous lacing from a very fresh keg. Aroma was a little nutty and a little spicy with some hints of nutmeg. Texture was dry and the initial flavor had a light bitterness to it (lcs).

I look forward to this one every year. It is a very malty brew. Malt nose and taste are dominant. More yeasty than some of their other brews. As is typical of winter ales there are hints of various spices. Just the right amount of stickiness is left after you swallow it.

Dark brown, very large head. Aroma full of coffee. An unusual roasted side. . . A nice plateau forms from the head, flavours of smokey chipotle, wood, did south western monks brew this? Some chocolate and good malts.
Kolor coli bez piany. S�odka wi�nia w zapachu, mo�e ciut melanoidyn. W smaku s�odkie, lekko colowe, lekko chlebowe. Nijakie.

Bottle from Edeka Hamburg - dark clear brown color, bit transparent. small beige head. dark malts, cane syrup sweetness. medium carbonation. not my favorite, but okay. way better than the flavored versions.
piana �adna, drobna, aromat karmelowy, pusty, w smaku jeszcze gorzej, cukier i karmel. Dramat. Bardzo wodniste

L�beck 16/4 2019. 50 cl bottle from Rewe, Sandstrasse, L�beck. Black label with a mysterious red dot and two hard working fellows carrying a barrel of beer (Porter I presume). Pours clear, dark Maroon with a small white head. Settles as patchy layer of foam unable to cover the surface of the beer. Very moderate Lacing. Aroma is fairly sweet with a medium strong, citric sourness lurking in the background. Caramel and brown sugar partly balanced by lemonade-ish citrus. Light carbonation. Quite thin, oily, almost flat texture. Flavor has strong sweetness bordering on being sugary. Followed by a more moderate, medium strong sour bitterness. Lingers for surprisingly short while. Very sweet but lacks some depth and density. A little odd but strangely refreshing citric edge.

Flasche im Supermarkt. Dunkles klares Bier mit viel Schaum. Aroma: Hopfig, Malz rieche ich erst mal nicht . Beim zweiten etwas zu finden, aber sehr versteckt und nicht identifizierbar. Sonst nichts. Geschmack: Mit viel Wasser verd�nntes Malzbier. Metallisch. Etwas Ahornsirup.

Sampled from 0.5 l bottle, best before June 2019. Clear, deep ruby with a thin, frothy, almost stable, off-white head. Very faint, sweetish-malty aroma of caramel. Quite sweet, malty, moderately bitter taste of mainly caramel with some burnt sugar and traces of licorice, followed by a short, moderately bitter, a little metallic finish. Thin to medium body, slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Pretty bland but drinkable.

Bottle - Darkish brown with initial thick slightly pink head. Sweet berries aroma. Ok mouthfeel. Very berry tasting but not as sweet as initial aroma. Not a porter at all - a fruit beer all round - sweet but drinkable.

Sorry, but this so-called porter is a joke, right? I could excuse the fact that you can actually see through it - but the aroma is just flat malt, and the taste is water, sugar and the faintest ghost of something that might have been bitter when it was alive.

Geruch muffig, leicht s��lich fruchtig. Antrunk malzig, sehr s��. Die Schaumkrone f�llt sehr schnell ein. Man schmeckt ein bisschen den Hopfenextrakt raus. Leicht muffiges Aroma, leicht bitterer Abgang. Die Caramellnoten sind unverkennbar, ebenso das Sauerkischaroma. Es ist vielleicht nicht jedermanns Geschmack - und sicherlich spielt es auch nicht in der Liga der Top Biere, allerdings finde ich hier so manche Bewertung einfach nur unprofessionell und unn�tig. Den Porter w�rde ich pers�nlich als ein Malzbier f�r Erwachsene beschreiben und ihn - �hnlich wie bspw ein Honigbier - als kleine Leckerei f�r ab und zu mal einsortieren.
Porter ist das sicher nicht. Schon eher ein Malzbier. EInfach nur ein s��es S�ftchen.

Bottle. Dark brown with a beige/grey head. Aroma of roasted malts and liquorice. Taste is malts, bitter chocolate, some coffee, liquorice, bread and roasted malts. Medium bitterness. Medium carbonation. Nice one. The wife likes it a lot.
Bottle from Trinkgut, M�nster, NRW! Pours deep black with a nice beige head. Aroma has nuts and roasted malts. Taste is bitter roasty, coffee and some burnt notes. Thin body...

bottle, kindly donated by pivnizub. Clear brown with a rather tall, fluffy beige head. Roasty aroma. Really light-bodied, shy malty background with some doasty, chocolatey flavours, some coffee. Shy bitter hops tune in and lead to a dry finish. Light and mild, but still quite nice.
Bottle. Brown color with amber highlight and a small grey head. Aroma is sugary, roasted malts. Taste is rusty nail, iron, cardboard, chalk. Fine-bubbled carbonation. Not my cup of tea.
Bottle. Black, low grey lace. Light bodied mellow mouth feel. Light licorice roast, sugary, iron, dirt. Watery. Not great.

Bottle: Clear, ruby-amber coloured, small but lacy off-white head; sweetish nose of burnt malt with a touch of vegetables; mild sweet-bitter flavour, very light bodied, but at least soft; burnt malt and vegetables, again, in the sweetish finish, sticky MF in the aftertaste. Not good�
From tap at De Paas. Very dark brown spicy roasted with cocoa malts and bitter finish. Backlog from 2014/04/29.
* Old rating. 0,33l, best before 25.01.02. Malzig-s�ffiges Bier, nicht zu tief, leichte R�stmalzankl�nge, nette passende Herbe. Insgesamt etwas flach.

Draft at De Paas. Pours dark brown with a thick tan head. Aroma of caramel, malt and some dark fruit. Flavour is light moderate sweet and bitter. Light medium bodied with light carbonation. A bit dull.

Tap. Very dark brown with small greyish head. Light spicy and light malts up front, then goes into nice roasted notes with some cocoa and coffee. Light roasted bitter and very dry finish. Medium to light bodied with slight watery feel. Nice stuff
Pite z kranu w Marynka, Wroc�aw. Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnie� z degustacji.

Draft @ Nordpol, Bielefeld. Cloudy milky gold with a white frothy head. Aroma of yeast, protein and a dash of lemons. Taste is bread, dough, yeast, grains and lemons. Mild hoppy bitterness. Medium carbonation. To use one of my all-time favourite words of the German language: S�ffig.

One of the best beers I ever had. Hazy golden body with a foamy persistent white head. Bread and malty aroma. Taste is decent hoppy, bready again, grainy. Nice herb finish. Medium body, texture is oily, carbonation is soft
Draft @ Caf� Jos. Opaque golden yellow, white lacing foam head. Fresh hoppy aroma and decent taste, NIce beer. (Nijmegen 201606)

1000ml bottle. Hazy, orangey golden colour with average to huge, thick, creamy, fairly lasting, moderately lacing, white head. Weak, husky, slightly grainy, minimally doughy aroma, a spicy touch of hay. Taste is minimally sweet pale malty, husky, minimally doughy, a spicy touch of hay, a lemon dash, soft palate, gentle carbonation Very mild, harmonious, highly drinkable.
Draft at Cafe Jos. Golden fuzzy pour. Aroma of fresh grain and some malt mostly. Fresh taste of grain, malt , some sweet caramel-ish note and a bittersweet finish. Solid.

Ein-Liter-B�gelverschlu�flasche: Pale-golden, hazy, big and stable besten-egg-white-like head with a good lace; mineralic-grainy nose, presence of yeast plus a touch of peppery hops in the background; mild to moderate sweetish-bitter flavour, light bodied and. Soft; fruity-yeasty finish with a slight acidity, grains detectable and an illusion of peppery hops. Quite good, presumably a fresh bottle�
7 Dec 2015, tap. hazy yellow. nose is sweet and yeasty. med body and mildly fizzy. slightly sweet, cereal malt and slightly bitter dried grass hops.
Tap 0.5 l, Kontynuacja, Wroc�aw, Poland. Z�ote, m�tne piwo o puszystej ale niezbyt obfitej pianie oraz lekko le�nym aromacie. W smaku pe�ne , ziemiste, z �agodn� goryczk� na finiszu.

(Hohenfelder Kellerbier) Big glass from the tap at Cafe Samson. Bright yellow colour on a hazy body, tall white head with good retention. Grainy aroma, malts, lemon zest, earth. Taste also of grains and unfermented malt, lemon zest. Medium thin body, soft carbonation. Simple but highly drinkable.

* Old rating, 0,33l bottle, 5,2%, best before 23.04.04. Malzig-caramellfarbenes Bier, leicht s��lich-malziger Antrunk. Nicht sonderlich herb, malzig mit leicht s��licher Note, ausgewogen. Malzig-leicht s��licher Nachgeschmack mit einer moderaten Herbe. Lecker!
Thin foam over a copper color ale. Some hop aroma and a fruity hop taste. Realy fresh summer beer with a thin body that enables you to drink large amounts of this beer.

[Cask at Sweeney & Todd�s Pie Shop, Reading] Amber with a small white head. Slight carbonation. Smells like a farmyard (so it�s a true Waddy�s, then!). A spicy hop tingle at first with biscuity overtones. This is soon ovetaken by more farmyard, before sweet malt and autumn fruit arrives. There�s some sweetness in there, but nicely balanced against a robust bitterness in the finish. Not a bad ale, and certainly far better than the insipid bottled version.

Cask-conditioned at the Rising Sun, Frampton Cotterell, S Gloucs 17/2/08. Deep copper coloured with next to no head. Malty caramel aroma with a touch of earthy hop. Flavour of red berries and more sweet malt with a bitter finish. Good.

Cask at Duke of Ellington, Southampton. Nut brown. Syrup and minerals up front. Sweet and rather malty. Some grain ans salty sweat. Fairly soft with somewhat soapy mouthfeel, Medium bitterness. Not bad - if a bit unrefined.
Handpump at The Square Peg, Birmingham. Copper colour with a small head. Malty scent. In the mouth, there are lots of summer berry fruits, with some hoppiness. Perhaps a bit too sweet.

Cask, The Gateway, Leicester. Amber/red with an off-white head. Aromas are sweet caramel malts with spices. Fruity with lots of citrus, especially. Fairly sweet. Flavours are sweet candy and sugar with toffee maltiness. Some floral and fruity aspects. Pretty dry with a fruity finish.

Cask handpump at the Trigger Pond, Bucknall, Oxfordshire, 16-04-06. Dark amber, decent white head, great maltyiness and very chewy beer, very flavoursome not had this for a very long time really enjoyed this beer.

Half pint pulled at The Turf Tavern, a clear darkish amber witha think white frothy head. The aroma is malty while a good combination of malt and hops produces flowery flavours. Smooth mouthfeel at the front with a sweetish tart finish.
Cask Handpump at the Richard Hopkins, Newton Abbot (JDW) 10/03/2003 Amber golden coloured with a malt aroma. Some sour fruit flavour. Slightly dry finish.
Cask hand pull, Wetherspoons Ashford, Kent. Reddish brown colour, with red fruit malt flavour and dry hop finish. Better than I expected

nice dark brown color, beige heads that quickly fad es. aroma of espresso, chocolate and orasted malt. taste lives up to the aroms with cofee, chocolate and mat flavors coming through. there is also an unusual taste that may come from grain adjuncts perhaps rye. the beer disappoints in its mouthfeel. for an otherwise robust drink, it is thin and over carbonated.

12/7/2019. Bottle from Cotswold Vintners, Chipping Sodbury. Pours pale amber with a large foamy off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, hops, fruit and light brown sugar. Moderate sweetness and bitterness. Moderate body, watery and slightly oily texture, soft carbonation. Disappointing.
Bottle from Cotswold Vintners. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are grain, malt, bread, hops and has a sweet malty finish.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Appearance - golden amber with a nicely proportioned head. Nose - grass, lemon and chewy toffee. Taste - more toffee, sweet bread (maybe rye bread). Palate - light bodied and creamy. Rich but dry finish. Overall - decent.
Amber colour with white head. Sweet malt, bready, watery orange, orange candy, watery. Pretty solid for abv.
grassy, earthy, copper coloured bottle at home from ocado run of the mill bitter.

From Jun 2008 Purchased at Wilburs Total Beverage in Ft Collins Colorado. I was looking for some low alcohol English Bitter brews and this one was the first that caught my eye. No indication of its age on the bottle but it pours a clear light gold with a 1 finger head of foam. Very good head retention and there's some good lacing. Smell wise, it fits the style very well. Some sweet malty tones and a more than adequate nose of fruit. Seems promising. The taste is nice. I get big flavours of biscuit up front followed by some fruit and some lemony hops that comprise most of the finish. Good medium mouthfeel for the style and the carbonation is light. Hmmm....this is pretty tasty however "old" it is and I find it very drinkable. Still, I doubt that the bottle I'm drinking from would be found to be impressive by my cousins from across the pond. It just doesn't have that "freshness" factor that I look for in all the brews I try. Oh well, a 3.6%abv brew *is* very delicate, to say the least, and the fact that I enjoyed it probably says how good it must taste when sampled fresh. It's a good one, for sure.
Aus der Flasche getrunken (H�ndlerlieferung). Sch�nes Amber mit feiner Schaumkrone. F�r ein Schankbier ziemlich bitter, leichte Fruchtnoten fehlen mir.
Bottle. Deep golden color, white head. Metallic aroma. Fairly clean, malty flavor with some floral hops and a bready finish. Medium-light body, medium-light carbonation. Not bad for the ABV.
Bottle in Oxford at Andrew and Rachel�s wedding. Copper amber pour, fair head. Cardboard and light bitter grain. Mediocre and boring flavor. Easy drink but nothing unique. Fair.

L: -pours a clear golden-orange with a medium,frothy,white head -medium carbonation visible S: -honey,toffee,grapefruit,spicy,grainy T: -Follows the nose + a toasty finish -medium bitterniss for the style F: -medium carbonation -light body O: A pretty solid English Bitter.

column1: Hook Norton Double Stout (Pasteurised Bottle & Keg)
column5: Bottle at home. Black color, middle foam size. Coffee in aroma, good stout taste. Good beer.

column1: Hook Norton Double Stout (Pasteurised Bottle & Keg)
column5: 500ml bottle [courtesy of Grumbo - cheers!]. Jet black colour with small, thick, creamy, moerately lasting, minimally lacing, beige head. Minimally sweet-ish, roasty, dark malty aroma, hints of coffee, dark chocolate, fruity overtones with a touch of blueberry. Taste is roasty dark malty and slightly fruity hoppy, hints of coffee, dark chocolate, some blueberry, a touch of bramble; smooth, soft, silky palate.

column1: Hook Norton Double Stout (Pasteurised Bottle & Keg)
column5: Excellent stout with bitter notes and full mouthfeel. It's a slow sipper, but you could have quite a few.

column1: Hook Norton Double Stout (Pasteurised Bottle & Keg)
column5: Bottle from ocado nice easy going stout. Espresso chocolate crema quite a dry finish.

column1: Hook Norton Double Stout (Pasteurised Bottle & Keg)
column5: Bottle from Beers of Europe. Appearance - deep brown to black and opaque. Nicely proportioned off white head. Nose - sweet malt, caramel and dark chocolate. Taste - light smoke and molasses. Edge of liquorice. Palate - medium bodied and crunchy texture. Dry crunchy finish. Overall - good.

column1: Hook Norton Double Stout (Pasteurised Bottle & Keg)
column5: Bottle, from Waitrose Oxford. Pour a jet black with a beige head. Aroma: roasted malt, cocoa, dark chocolate, toasted grain notes. Taste: roasted malt, cocoa, chocolate, grain, mild lactose, creamy flavours. Medium bodied. Fairly creamy mouthfeel. Smooth. Easy to drink without being exceptional.

column1: Hook Norton Double Stout (Pasteurised Bottle & Keg)
column5: 500ml bottle. Black colour with light tan head. Dark roasted malts, dark chocolate, Americano, coffee beans, toffee, cocoa powder, light dark fruits, light tobacco, burnt toast, light liquorice, light grassy hop finish. Good complexity for abv, super drinkable, nice.

column1: Hook Norton Double Stout (Pasteurised Bottle & Keg)
column5: The aroma includes roasty notes, coffee, dark chocolate and malt whiskey - with a faint burnt edge (nice). You get medium intensity on the tongue: somewhat single-mindedly (but not overpoweringly) bitter... leading up to a dry finish. Enjoyable and juicey, but not terribly complex.

column1: Hook Norton Double Stout (Pasteurised Bottle & Keg)
column5: Bottle - solid dark with thick tan head, creamy finish. Strong dry coffee aroma. Good mouthfeel. Good stout tasting - coffee with dry finish. Maintains head throughout - excellent beer.

column1: Hook Norton Double Stout (Pasteurised Bottle & Keg)
column5: 500ml bottle from Waitrose. Pours dark brown/red almost black with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, milk chocolate some dark fruits and a hint of orange peel. Very smooth and fairly light mouthfeel. Taste is roasted malt, milk chocolate, dark chocolate, prunes and some citrus peel. Medium roasted malt bitterness and some hop bitterness on the finish too. Very tasty and easy to drink !
The best cider ever perfect aftertaste not too sweet.....was pissed when they stopped selling in Ontario.
(Bottle) Nice friut crispness with a fairly dry finish. A nice quencher a tad sweet but still a clean example of it�s style.
TFOB 2001. Dark amber colour. Sweeter and darker than Strongbow. Crisp drink, strongly of apple. Pretty enjoyable.
(Bottle) Limited availability at Vineyards in Ottawa; this B.C. cider had a nice stong MacIntosh nose. Potent apple taste. As mentioned, little detection of alcohol. Very good.
Strong apple scent. Deep clear amber. Tastes just like apple juice, alcohol is undetectable. Crisp after taste. Pretty good. Thanks Anna.

On tap. A golden colour with no head. Rice aroma. Flavour has hops, plum, wheat and rice. Plenty of malt, caramel and citrus in the finish. I was expecting another macro brewed lager but this was actually pretty good.
From old tasting notes. Bright yellow color. Light malt aroma. Mild tart malt flavor. Brief dry hop finish. Brief listless aftertaste.
Draught at Lymm Lounge Chinese Restaurant. Pours a pale golden colour. Tastes very much a standard lager, better than I expected and better than the other Chinese beers I�ve had
Clear golden color, minimal head. Very light malty aroma. Taste like any other typical lager, maybe a bit bitter.
On draught in Cantonese resteraunt rice in the body sweet and syrupynot unpleasant not good, but drinkable
Yet another pale lager tasted in a restaurant to see if it is at all different from the others. Apart from a faint hint of the rice, it isn�t.

Foam is short-lived, leaving thin foam. It smells fine hops and the taste is also fine hoppy with light notes of flower. The finish is a little water and the stand only slightly from the usual industrial lagers by its slightly sweet floral expression. It is easy to drink and thirst quenching, but it is also shown the only positive.
Bottle. Clear light golden color. Aroma: light malt and a little grassy hop. Taste: malt, a little fruity, refreshing.
Bottle. Clear golden colour with small white foam. Weak aroma of hops. Tastes watery, light and a bit metallic. Some malts and hoppy bitterness, a bit sweet.

Kolor - jasnoz�ocisty, ��ty, klarowny Piana - drobna, wysoka, �redniotrwa�a Zapach - wyra�ny s�odowy + aromat "zielonej butelki" Smak - wyra�ny s�odowy, nutka ry�owa, �rednio s�odkie, lekki chmiel, lekka goryczka Zaliczone, powt�rka nie wskazana

New Years Eve in my Father�s kitchen (again) Pours a pale golden color with a small but well retained head. The aroma is sweet & malty with some weird cidery stuff happening. The flavor is rather weird very sweet without hardly any bitterness. Lots of apple flavor... maybe some creamed corn . It is washing down this spicy Indian goat dish jyst fine.

Bottle 330ml. [ As Royal Challenge Premium Lager ]. Clear light yellow color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, cereal, pale malt, vegetables. Flavor is light to moderate sweet with a average duration, sweet malt, sugary. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20160625]
330 ml bottle at Ulfborg. Clear pale yellow color with white to off white head. Malty aroma, grain, caramel. Sweet and light bitter taste. Light thin body with soft carbonation.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and corn. Flavor is medium. Sweet finish. Watery. 250616
Bottle - pours yellow white head- nose and taste of bread mold, skunk and corn - light watery body
Aroma: very sweet corn and fruits. Flavour: sweet corn and bubblegum. Colour: pale yellow with a white head. From: Spirit Zone Bangalore Apr. 2016.

Bottle from Drops 100 Feet Road, Bangalore. Poured a crystal clear straw colour with a frothy broken white head and a little broken lace. The aroma is malt, more malt and a little yeast. The flavour is moderate sweet with a smooth, dry, mineral malt, light bitter hop palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Not great, but not undrinkable. I won�t be buying a crate though or even a second bottle for that matter!

Bottle from Bangalore courtesy of Nav, drank at The New Penguin, week 11. Pours lazing gold with a fleeting white tuft fast becoming a halo. Something of a mineral, phosphorus-laden aroma in the regional English ballpark accompanied by weak lemon sherbet and bags of lovely glue-like glycerine.
