Decent weak lemony flavour at first moving swiftly into stale hay, envelope, licked stamp, Disprin and matchbox. The stale cardboard and pea-like meaty vegetable flavour is pretty hideous as it warms. It�s not going to trouble my top 5000 but a perfectly serviceable adjunct-laden drab global lager if drunk sufficiently chilled.

Bottle @ home, thanks to MacBoost for sending. Pours a clear yellow appearance with a white head. The aroma is dusty, full of lemon, stale grains, some rice, and a bit of bread. Thin mouth feel. Twangy, bland flavor. Kind of bready and herbal. A little chewy. Not all that good.

Tasted on 2/8/14 from a bottle at the late night tasting after the RBWG Grand Tasting. Pours clear golden with an average white head that disappears after some time. The nose is corny malt with a hint of green hops. The flavor is the same light pilsener malt, some corny sweetness, and just a bit of lightly bitter green hops on the back of the palate. The body is light with average, fizzy carbonation, and a short, corny, very lightly bitter finish.

it contains all of the necessary components that have satisfactory sent man in search of better beer trough the ages. and i suppose in that respect we should be grateful. hey, folks gotta make a living.
Very pale lager, almost water. Nose and taste is hay and light malts. Very sub standard drain pour. Rated 5/13/04

Bottle bought in Kerala. Light golden coloured. Clear. Quickly diminishing white head. Chemical and light fruity in the aroma. Flavour is totally watery and has no significant notable signatures. Very thin body and no aftertaste at all. This is a sorry excuse for a beer imo, and fortunately I have only seen it in Kerala till now. No need to find it otherwhere, apart from being able to provide my rating brothers in Denmark with yet another bland pale lager rating.

Bottled, acquired and drunk on location, Samudra, Karrela, India. Golden fizzy larger. Large course bubbles rise rapidly but fail to form a head. Another forgettable beer, perhaps less offensive then the others. [Glycerol included]

Like with Cornfield, a bottle from Foremost Liquors, Oak Forest. "Mfg: 3/2001� and smells it: skunky taste pours out. Thin, clingy head stays in. Still a little darker than the usual American piss, but not by much. Smell settles, not surprisingly, to the sherry notes of oxidation. Taste is hard to describe, because there�s no little of it there. Thin and watery, even the bubbles in it don�t perk it up much. I think it�s mostly grain, but they�re so indistinct, they might as well be corn squeezin�s. Are we surprised there�s no hops? And I poured this into a glass which just held some Delerium Tremens, in hopes of taking the edge off. Now the odd thing is, I�m sure this store only started carrying Indian beers a year or two ago. So how they�d get such an old stock of bottles. Well, you can see why I�m not saving this for Rating #2000.

Looks like a sick man�s urine with some bubbles on top. The thankfully faint aroma has some grainy malts to it, but is mostly sugar and tin. Thin. Tastes watery and grassy and sweet and metallic. Odd. The 5000 was so drinkable. Foremost Liquors, Oak Forest, IL

[bottle - 650 ml] Clear and pale yellow. No head. Looks like apple juice. Slightly sour and bitter smell with some hints of grain and grass. Slight taste of apple peels, apple cores, grass, hay and some malt. Not much hops present. Lots of grain. Very watery.
Smells funky and looks like a lager. Oh, this is not a good beer. It tastes like the worst of a lager mixed with the worst of a hefe.

looks like carbonated apple juice w/ a small white ok lacing head. smells of light rotten apples some malt.. and just not good. Palate is ok coating some body and a little bit of carbonation.. flavor is lightly malty some wheat a touch of tart bitter in the finish. Pretty blah but also pretty unoffensive.
Light gold. Nose grassy, some adjuncts. Flavor very sweet, a few hops. Standard lager, nothing offensive, just boring.

All these other reviewers breaking it down, completely missing the point of this beer. This beer is a punch in your face. You drink 1 can and you will be knocked out from the inside. This beer is MADE to go with some spicy, tasty non vegetarian food (think BBQ, Indian, Chinese) and it is MADE to knock you off your feet in 1 can! You are not supposed to savour this beer, you are supposed to enjoy it as a token of good times, where it perfectly complements the taste of food.
M�rkt gyllengul �l med vitt skum. Doft och smak av s�d, malt och alkohols�tma. Inte v�rre �n andra av typen.

660 ml bomber at beer bar restaurant. A mid golden coloured pour with a lasting G white froth. Aroma is sweet tangy apple, solvent,. Flavour is composed of semi sweet malts, apple, weird waxy crayon thing, dusty malts. Palate is semi sweet, light solvent, lowish carbonation. Pretty bad.

Bottle at some dive bar in Udaipur. Clear deep golden liquid with medium egg shell white head. Aroma of grain, booze, sugar, plastic, green apples and dms. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes of booze, grain and green apple. Medium bodied with low to medium carbonation. Decent likka but sweet.
Amber with little head Sweet syrupy aroma Flava is syrupy sweet with hints of malty grains and tobacco Feels medium and silky with lively fizz Finishes tangy malty mildly sweet

Barwy jasnej, z�otej, klarowne. Piana bia�a, drobna, delikatnie oblepia szk�o. Aromat s�odowy, troch� s�odki, s�aba intensywno��. W smaku s�odowe, troch� s�odkie, goryczka niska. Nie czu� mocy tego piwa. Dosy� przyjemnie si� pije.

Bottle. Poured clear golden color with a large white frothy head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate sweet grass aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Sweet malt beer.

330ml bottle @ Taj Agra, Canberra. Sweet malt nose, crystal clear golden beer with thin film of suds on top. Slight zing. Quickly goes from sparkly fun to liquorice cardboard alcohol blast! Much more interesting than I thought it would be.
330ml bottle from Elephant Corridor, Melbourne. Pale straw/no head. Had the typical Indian beer grainy/corn aroma. Grainy taste with usual malt liquor ABV palate/finish. Ho hum.

Golden beer, poured into a pilsner glass from a pint bottle. Barely any aroma, mainly malt. Taste is too sweet corn, finish is nasty harsh sweet malt. Imagine people drinking 10 million cases of this.

Cask at the Town Crier, Coventry on 25th October 2019. Clear copper with lasting off-white foam and spot lacing. Caramel malt aroma. Sweet maltiness in-mouth with light berry fruits. Sweet fruitiness on biscuit malt in the finish. Light of body and mouthfeel.
Sample at the Rhinoceros JDW Rotherham. Thin creamy white head. Hazy golden pour. Light bitterness.
Cask @ Old Post Office, Shrewsbury, as Old Post Office Post Craft Ale, its house beer. Clear golden with a creamy head. It's hoppy and mildly berry-sweet, coming across as a clean session ale.
Cask at the Old House in Dorking. Fairly light, malty, with fruity hints. Decent session beer.

Cask (3.8%; as Marston's Saddle Tank), 1/2 pint, hand-pulled at Guildford Arms, Edinburgh on 10 Oct 2017: malty aroma with a bit of resin, amber brown with a thin off-white head, toffee, some resin, creamy, sweet malty finish.

Cask at the Running Hare, Ewloe. Thick creamflow head. Slight vanilla. Hard to detect much bitterness through the cream and coldness. In line with expectations. Gave up halfway through and poured a half lemonade into it, which improved it.
Tried at the Horse & Jockey, Mini Beer Festival. Amber colour with a thick white head. Aroma malty light fruit and caramel Taste light bitter sweet. Medium body.

Cask. Pours amber with gold lights. Thin white top. The taste is what is known as balanced. One detects bitter hops and toasted malts. Aroma is ever so slightly malt rather than hop. Palate is soft with light carbonation. A session bitter. For a long time I foolishly assumed that this was a sister pub to the Trent Navigation and hence a Navigation pub that had Pedigree et al. as a safety tap for the old guard. But no it�s Marston�s. With a liking for Jennings and Brakspear. Great location and some good live music but the latter eclipse the beer in these craft times. Anyway the bitter is cheap and sessionable.

Cask at The Cattle Market, Leek (Marstons) A clear amber colour with a thin white head. Aroma of caramel, fruits, slight biscuit and some earthy, grassy hops. Taste is similar of caramel, fruits, slight biscuit, subtle mineral and some earthy, grassy hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A soft, dry, earthy hop bitterness in the finish. A extremely simple, bland bitter. It�s ok for a session beer.
Cask at the chanter. Pours copper amber, nose is malty, toffee, biscuit, the taste is similar.
Spicy And herbal aroma. Gold, clear. Malty, herbal. Unimpressiv german Pilsner. 0,5l, draught, pub, Berlin.

2016 09 02 Butelka 0,5 l. Piana bia�� obfita, �rednio g�sta, nietrwa�a. Kolor jasnoz�oty, ocieraj�cy si� o s�omkowy, klarowne. Aromat niezbyt intensywny, nuty zio�owe i trawiaste od chmielu i s�odowe biszkoptowe. W smaku na pierwszym planie wyra�na zio�owo��, opr�cz niej nuty s�odowe. Pe�nia niska, wysycenie �rednie w kierunku �rednio wysokiego, goryczka �rednio niska w kierunku �redniej, lekko �odygowa, wyra�nie zaznaczona. Przyzwoity, ale nie powalaj�cy niemiecki pilzner.
330ml can Clear bright gold pour with white head. Grainy aroma. Crisp taste with slight metallic aftertaste.

,33L bottle at The Neuses Museum in Berlin The pils poured a clear gold color with a white foamy head and no lacing. You detect a grassy aroma and hints of yeast. The beer does have some hop bitterness. The pils has a medium body with a fizzy carbonation. The hop bitterness was appreciated in the land of lagers.
Oct 2019. 330ml can from BeerWulf. This is a tasty pale lager. Quite fruity and refreshing. Easy drinking. Inoffensive. Not quite bland. Yeah, you can drink this. Anyone can drink this.
golden beer with huge white head. Aroma hoppy. Taste hoppy and dry. A good pilsner.

(500ml can, 0.79EUR, Berlin) AROMA: very light nose, maybe some grain, maybe some wet cardboard, hard to say APPEARANCE: clear pale straw yellow, quite light, but an inch think airy foam head which died down to a dirty layer. TASTE: pale malt, grain, some noble hops, hint of sweetness and dairy, toast, coffee grounds. easy bitterness PALATE: light, smooth, ok fizz, nice balance between soft/light flavors, easy to drink, minimal harshness OVERALL: this may be one of the most drinkable german Pils I have had this week. nose is quite weak and the beer is pretty pale ... but it gave a bit more head than usual and even though the tastes are muted, it is well-balanced and non-imposing. far from a robust Pils but if you want a smooth drinkable pils/lager that does have hints of flavor, this could be a more than occasional friend.

Can gratis from Beer Ritz. It pours clear yellow with a decent white head. The aroma is sweet doughy white bread, biscuit, cereal, gooseberry, grass and spice. The taste is crisp, firmly dry, lick of bitterness, biscuit, grassy, slightly herbal, earthy, gooseberry crumble, citrus peel and spice with a drying finish. Average body and moderate carbonation. Pretty decent tbh. Quenching in this damn summer heat.

Appearance is golden, fairly clear, a small pure white head. Aroma- caramel, wheat, cereal malt, lemon meringue hints, some more malt. Taste- malty cereal, bitter hop hints, a bit creamy, trace of caramel, some sherbet lemon. Solid pilsner.

While in Berlin have a Berlin beer, especially if it is named Berliner. Purchased at a department store (?) and brought back to sample. I�m putting one of the glasses provided in the room to use, not exactly a Pilsner glass. A firm pour gives a heavy head of pure white foam on top of a lemon-yellow body. The nose is no surprise, grain and lightly citrus. More of the same with the taste. Straw, water, hops and a fair bitterness. What more to say? It�s a Pilsner.

column1: Milwaukee Brewing Old No. 7 Whiskey Bock
column5: Wonderful malt aroma, reddish hue, a hint of whiskey along with a pleasant roasted malt flavor. Nice finish.
330 ml bottle. Pouring golden color with white foam. The aroma of herbs and malt notes. The taste is slightly malt, hemp with a slight bitterness.
Ocena wystawiona w ramach czeskiego panelu degustacyjnego browaru papi w czerwiecu 2019

column1: Jarre Creek Ranch Heffer Wizzen Golden Ale
column5: Had this beer on 3/27/2001. Aroma is a sweet malt scent. Color a slightly hazy gold with good carbonation and head. Taste smooth and sweet. Starting with a medium body it goes down smooth with a sweet feel. Finish is a dry malt flavor.

column1: Jarre Creek Ranch Heffer Wizzen Golden Ale
column5: Jarre Creek Ranch Brewing is in my own backyard and I never knew it until my grandfather passed a bottle of this along to me. It took awhile to get past the idea that this beer was coming out of a cow�s urinary tract thanks to the handy graphic printed on the label. I now understand why I never really paid any attention to the fact that a brewer had snuck up on me in the last few years. If their publicity is muted, so is their beer�s flavor. Their Heffer Wizzen ale pours with absolutely no head, save for a few white, fizzy lily pads of carbonation. The golden ale is darker than gold, more of a well ripened pumpkin orange, and well clouded, suggesting a deeply flavored beer within. A tinge of honey wafts from the glass, along with sweet blood orange and hops, which is then acutely polished by a heavy alcohol vapor. A stinging smell of cleaning chemicals also tags along, ruining the synchronization the other aromas so carefully built and leaving me a bit more hesitant to give it a drink. My caution is affirmed when the taste mirrors the smell. The very slight honey flavor returns, this time paired with corn syrup and bustling carbonation. The vigorous bubbles might be a little overwhelming, but they at least contribute to the suppression of the cleaner agent taste which has nearly disappeared, leaving this Golden Ale a very simple, very light and very boring ale, but not as repugnant as I had expected. Still, too bare for my tastes, but could be a good teaching tool to a Hefeweizen neophyte. Now if only they could get a new label artist.

column1: Jarre Creek Ranch Heffer Wizzen Golden Ale
column5: Bottle. Pours lightly cloudy deep gold with a small foamy white head and some lined lacing, some retention. Aroma is malt (hay, straw), yeast (dough, grass, earth) and light flowers, sour fruit nose. Mildly sweet malt and yeast flavor, flowers and fruity, mild acidity with no bitterness. Light bodied, creamy palate, very refreshing light ale.

column1: Jarre Creek Ranch Heffer Wizzen Golden Ale
column5: Bottle. Pours a somewhat darker yellow without much head. Nose is lightly scented with, yeast. Flavor is thin, sweet with some malt. Not great, but not offensive. Got this one from Artic Liquors and didn�t realize it had been retired till I got here. Anyway, no loss on this retirement.

column1: Jarre Creek Ranch Heffer Wizzen Golden Ale
column5: Why is this not a hefe, but the name suggests it is? Yellow. Overly sweet taste, with some funky earthiness. Finish is sweet and bitter.

column1: Jarre Creek Ranch Heffer Wizzen Golden Ale
column5: Clear, still and maize-colored. Tart and sharp with a good malt character and slight bittering. Good light ale.

column1: Jarre Creek Ranch Heffer Wizzen Golden Ale
column5: Draught. Body is medium yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (grain), lightly hoppy (herbs). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

column1: Jarre Creek Ranch Heffer Wizzen Golden Ale
column5: easy drinking beer...malt and slightly fruity flavors come through..decent beer

Served in a tulip from a 500ml bottle. Pours very dark clear garnet-brown with a medium beige head. Aroma is malts, molasses, caramel, liquorice, red fruit, coffee. Taste is slightly smoky, malts, caramel, toffee, liquorice, red fruit and coffee, bitter-sweet with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Medium creamy body with medium carbonation. Very pleasant and smooth porter, invites you to put your cosy gown on, sit back and chill with this brew in one hand and a good book in the other.

Bottle from Alesbymail. Hazy dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is dry, roasted malt, dark chocolate and nutty. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted moderate bitter finish. 231016

500ml bottle (Ales by Mail) Sweet caramelly aroma, some black tea. Nice dark mahogany, small tight head. Kinda watery palate, carbonation a bit high for me. Pleasant dry bitter malts in the taste, and leaves not much apart from black tea tannins. Doesn�t hook me.

Bottle from Sidmouth Wines, Sidmouth. Clear, extremely dark red ale with no head. It�s a steady porter that�s easy-sipping without a stated character. It�s pleasant with extremely tight roasted malts in both aroma and taste, hints of liquorice that provide a small sweetness and a small smoothness for its texture.

Gravity at The Roebuck, Leek (Titanic) A deep brown colour with a medium beige head. Aroma of coffee, earth, some chocolate, slight liquorice and subtle nuts. Taste is similar of coffee, earth, some chocolate, slight liquorice, a little dark fruits and subtle nuts. Medium bodied and soft carbonation. A dryish, earthy bitterness in the finish. A lot more earthy than I thought it would be, but it sure is an old fashioned porter. Got to like it.
Cask, 1/2 pint, hand-pulled, Bon Accord, Glasgow (28 Mar 2016), musty malty aroma, dark brown near black with a bubbly beige head and good lacing, earthy, chocolate, oily, malty aftertaste.

Bottle at home in London - sourced from Ales by Males. Pours mostly clear, rich brown with a monstrous, frothy khaki head. The nose holds toasted malts, light caramel, hints of earth and dried berries. Light-medium sweet flavour, subtle touches of oxidation, dusty caramel, dried out milk chocolate, leathery berries, toasted leaves, earth. Light bodied with lively carbonation and massaging texture. Pretty well balanced, with faint peppery burnt wood, more mellow cocoa, bitter earth, dried fruits. An easygoing, low-octane porter.
500ml bottle from Tuckers Maltings. Pours clear ruby brown with a thin cream-coloured head. Light chocolate aromas, malty toffee. Taste is light roast, sweet finish.

Bottle, Beers of Europe. Reddish brown colour. Unusual one this. Some slightly thin toasty malts and an earthy ashy bitterness. But the whole dominated by a slightly sour flavour - I see other reviewers refer to salty and licorice as well. I can�t believe this was deliberate - it was a bit weird for sure and not that nice.
Lovely chocolate coffee porter. Dark mahogany, minimal head. Easy to drink, sweet not bitter.

9/2/2019. Bottle from Beer Dock, Crewe. Pours pale amber with a bubbly off-white head. Aroma of hops, citrus, malt, toffee and a slight metallic edge. Moderate sweetness and medium bitterness. Light body, watery texture, average to soft carbonation.
Bottle from Beer Dock, Crewe. Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and light dusty. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 090219

Bottle from Connoly�s Wines, Solihull. Poured a clear copper colour with a thin broken white head. The aroma is metallic hop. The flavour is moderate bitter with a light citrus, watery hop bitter palate. Light bodied with soft carbonation.
At Jim/John is back tasting. Bottle courtesy of john. Clear amber, white head. Caramel malt, distant orangepeel, tea, dusty. Mild bitter. Medium body. Dry leaves.

Bottle shared at the John/Jim tasting. Hazy orange with a small off white head. Aroma is herbal with caramel and veggy notes. Flavour is light to moderate sweet and bitter. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle at John is back tasting. Clear dark golden with white head. Cardboard, some English hops, soft lime, toffee, soft earthy notes. Light sweet and under medium bitter. Under medium bodied with soft carbonation. Meh.
50cl bottle shared at the Jim/John is back tasting thin white head. Hazy amber pour. Slight bitterness

Bottle: Pours hazy, dark gold-amber with a frothy, off-white head. Toffee, slightly leafy aroma. Taste is toffee malt with a nice, subdued, leafy bittering. Mild and light, but with a fairlyrobust, malty flavour. Pretty nice.

Bottle. Toffee malt and herbal vegetal aroma. Golden yellow with large off-white head. Golden yellow with large light tan head. Lightly sweet toffee malt and mildly bitter herbal flavor. Body on the lighter side. Pleasant easy drinking beer.
Bottle - clear Darkish amber with thick foamy off white head. Nice on tongue and in mouth. Decent hoppy aroma. Malty bitter finish - enjoyed.

6/4/2019. Bottle from Rebellion Brewery Shop, Marlow Bottom. Pours dark amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of light toffee, malt, fruit, caramel and sugar water. Medium sweetness with light bitterness. Moderate body, water texture, average to fine carbonation. Bit disappointing.

"Bright" bottle, bought at the brewery. Rebellion is an absolutely great brewery - very popular and highly expert in the craft. However, I wasn't really impressed with this one, which is one of its core selection, other than in its truly "red" appearance. Nothing wrong with it overall, but nothing really great, either. The Cascade hops aroma is so well "balanced" out with the Goldings, that you can't really smell or taste anything subtle within it. It's a bit mass-market, a bit too sweet and pudding-like. It goes down easily, but for a craft ale I think it really needs an edge and a bit of spice to give it some much-needed character, and shouldn't be this smooth.

500ml bottle. Poured a clear copper colour with a frothy white head. The aroma is toffee caramel malt, red berry fruits, light woody hop. The flavour is moderate sweet light bitter with a sweet caramel malt, fruity, light pepper spice, dry woody hop bitter palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
500ml ml from Waitrose. Pours dark ruby with a small tan head, Aroma slightly spiced malt and a touch of hops: fruit. Taste sweet slightly caramel a little bitter,

Bottle at home in Hackney - picked up from Ocado. Pours clear red with a frothy, khaki head. Toasted brown bread in the nose, faint piney and floral hops. Medium sweet flavour with a good dose of creamy caramel, toasted grains, low bitterness, accents of ripe berries. Light bodied with fine to average carbonation. Sweet finish with slight earthy bitterness, more toasted grains and brown bread, ripened berries, plums, caramel. Not bad.
50cl. I had this beer before and liked it. Unfortunately this is a bad bottle. Butter, corn are a bit overwhelming. Bleh.

Cask at the Polecat. Brilliant clear reddish amber, really quite red, white foam. Probably the best Rebellion beer I�ve had, some sweet crystal malts and more of a bitter finish than I expected. Slightly fruity. Hint of astringency. A pleasant pint.
Bottle from the brewery. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are wheat malt, yeast, fruits, coriander and hops. Sweet yeasty banana finish.
330ml bottle from the brewery. Clear golden with a small white head. Light fruity aroma, flavour is citrus, cloves, very refreshing

1Jul2018 Sweet grain and cereal malts, yeast, wheat, dusty straw. Clear gold, medium, creamy, white head. Light bitter. Bitter grain and cereal malts, straw, bit of grass, medium carbonation, medium bodied. Boring. Bottle from the brewery, Marlow.

Bottle 500ml. @ Chris and Ruth�s place in London. [ As Rebellion White ]. [ BBF 2005/10 ].Unclear matt medium orange yellow color with a large, frothy, fair lacing, mostly to fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, wheat, oxidide, citrus, moderate yeasty. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, sweet malt, wheat, sweet fruit - citrus, oxidide. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20150809] 4-3-5-3-8
Rating from bottle collection/historic scores. Bottle purchased from Waitrose when in the area some time back. Nice citrus aroma but that aside wasn�t so keen.
Bottle at Chris and Ruth�s place in London. Hazy golden beer with an offwhite head. Grassy, hay, hoppy spicy perfume aroma. Hoppy perfume citrus, grapefruit,grassy flavour.

Bottle at Chris and Ruth�s place in London. Hazy golden beer with a rich offwhite head. Perfume aroma, grassy, hay, spicy notes, grapefruit notes. Hoppy perfume flavor, citrus, grapefruit, some lemongrass.. Decent.
50 cl bottle. Pours hazy yellow to orange ith a small white head. Aroma is dry, herbal, citrusy and light fruity. Smooth fruity, dry and solid hoppy. Bitter and herbal dry finish.

Bottle from Waitrose, Berkhamsted. Colour is cloudy murky amber. Nose is delightful when first poured. Sweet lemon, apple, caramel, clove, yeast and some sweet sugary sherbet. Taste is not as powerful as aroma. It�s caramel, sweet lemon and clove, but not such a zingy citrous kick. It�s more subdued.

The wife is out with friends, so I�m having a random, weird beer tasting evening: first up an English brewed Witbier! This brown 330ml bottle (5%ABV) was best before 10 Mar 2011, drank and reviewed 28 Jan 2011. Poured into my Westmalle chalice. Good looks, pale orange, cloudy and headless after ten seconds, just like a regular Witbier. Strong clove aroma, with a bag of mixed spices thrown in too, impressive smell. I�m not a huge fan of this style, but this tastes and feels as good as the much loved Hoegaaarden in my eyes. It has that coriander/orangey edge to it as well, different and pleasing. A good start to my evening, hope the Armenian Lager is as good!
Bottle at Anchored in Worthing. Nice chocolate notes in aroma, quite dry for a porter. Decent beer.

Cask at the Harp - Covent Garden, London. Pours clear brown with a frothy tan head. The nose holds well toasted bread, light smoke and hints of chocolate. Light to medium sweet flavor with rich smoke and bacon, light chocolate, some earthy bitterness. Light to medium bodied with fine carbonation. Great condition. Dynamic finish, pleasant smoked malts and bacon, burnt toast, light cocoa, charred wood, a bit of scorched earth. Solid porter. Good depth for 5%.

Tiefschwarz mit kaum Kohlens�ure. Der Antrunk ist sehr mild-weich, angenehme herb-r�stmalzige T�ne, der HT ist vollmundig, s�ffig, tolle R�stmalzt�ne, leicht herbe Note, der Ng ist r�stmalzig mild, mittellang und leicht herb. --> sehr s�ffig-leckeres Bier. Ganz leicht w�ssrig, aber trotzdem toll! --> 13/12/12/13

50cl bottle from Waitrose, Tenterden. Deep mahogany with a chestnut gleam and a ring of cream head; the aroma has rich caramel and some nutty malts; rather thin in the mouth with treacle toffee flavour; and a gently bitter finish.

Cask, handpump at The Hop Pole, Aylesbury, Bucks, 29-02-10 Pours conker brown with some ruby glints, creamy off white head. Dark sugars on the nose and some malt. Soft and creamy in the mouth, some bitter toffee, touch on the warm side, tangy, its fine. A6 A4 F7 P3 Ov13 3.3

Cask - White Cliffs Beer Festival. Black in appearance with a foamy beige head. Smoky, barbeque aromas with some roast coffee notes. Burnt malt flavours mixed with a dark chocolate bitterness, more coffee tones and a dry bitterness on the finish. Average body but given the % this is surprisingly diverse.

Cask at the Eastbourne Beer Festival, 9th Oct 2008. Near black with berries and alcohol on the nose. Dark chocolate, malt, red fruits. Ok finish but a bit sweet and full bodied. Not as good as the sum of its parts.

Bottle. Black with a large beige foam. Aromas are oily with roast coffee. Some chocolate and liqourice with a light smokiness. Flavours are earthy, oily roast malts with a good amount of dark chocolate bitterness. Biter and dry hops on the finish. Very tasty.

500ml bottle @ Cardinal. Dark red/brown body, close to black with a small beige head. Roasted malt and licorices aroma. Flavor is mild and soft burnt malt, some coffee and licorices, fruity. Balanced and impressing flavorful porter at only 5% ABV.

Huge brown head. Deep dark brown body, barely translucent, with a strange, slow carbonation. Acidic coal-and-chocolate aroma with smoky, earthy notes. Dry smoky, earthy, burnt taste with watery chocolatey notes. Slightly one-dimensional. Dry smoky coarseish earthy aftertaste. Good, but could use more body. (0.5l bottle at Cardinal, Stavanger.)

Gravicask at Spa Valley 9th Beer & Cider Festival. Shared with Finn. Almost copper brown in the glass. Dotted spots from a low beige head. Toffee-fruity smell and a caramel fruity taste, hints of leafy hop bitterness to a semi-dry ending. Pretty alright. (Tunbridge Wells 18.10.2019).

Half-pint, guest ale on cask at Glue Pot, shared with Finn. Patchy white head, clear mahogany coloured body. Moderate aromas of bread and dark fruits. Creamy malts and nuts to the taste buds added by some impact of dark fruits. Mid-sweet malt-driven finish. Pleasing to a certain degree. (Swindon 26.10.2019).

Cask@The Lord Moon Of The Mall, Trafalgar Square, London. A pretty dull bitter it has to be said, not really an old ale, didn�t pick up too much different about it. Thin, grainy, some hop bitterness, watery, not much happening.
Cask Handpump at the Waterhouse, Manchester (JDW) 06/02/2004 Mid brown smooth on the palate. Some sour fruit flavour. Pleasant malt finish.

Cask at Ye Olde Trip To Jerusalem, Nottingham. Chestnut brown body, very thin white head. Musty hedgerow aroma with some sweaty sweetness. Flavour of bubblegum fruits held in check by malty cream, slightly sour in the finish.

Cask Conditioned at The Old Trip to Jerusalem, Nottingham. Chestnut brown with a slight head. Malty sweet, yeasy beer, with a powdery dryness. Develops a sharp bitterness in the finish with a sulphery nose.
A dark red-brown beer with a small off white head. Aromas are sweet and malty. This is almost alt-like in its dryness and bitterness. Licourice notes complete this unusual bitter.
Cask conditioned version sampled. Redbrown. Nose with coffee and roasted tones. Coffee and nuts in the flavor, good bitterness.
Sampled cask conditioned. Chestnut brown. Very fruity, medium bodied, mild. Some apple aroma. A rather uneventful, but flawless cask ale.
500ml Flasche. Kupferfarbenes Bier mit flachem cremigem Schaum. Herb malziger Duft. Cremiger bitterer Geschmack.
Malzig-fruchtig, etwas grasig, Karamell. Typische Bitter-Aromen. Leicht herb - angenehm. Recht tief im Aroma - Lecker.
Bottle from the local Co-op. Copper colour with a beige head. Malt and fruit aroma. Caramel, malt and fruit flavour. Soft malt finish. Quite nice.
Pours a dark brown colour and has a grassy malty aroma. In the taste its malty and hoppy a pretty good bitter.
Crisp, hopped, grassy flavours, but with some underlying malt character. Decent, not great.
Original badger beer not much depth of flavour but ok once in a while if u like beers like this heavy enough tastering i suppose
Drinkable, quite a full flavour, fairly decently hopped, but just misses the boat somewhere.
Some caramel came through. Malt present. Standard and dependable fare. Nice bitter ale.
Bottled. Pours a real amber colour with a soft head. The beer is smooth with a hoppy favour with a soft malt substructure. Pleasant but not a stand out.

Dark amber, nice head. The aroma is both hoppy and malty. The flavour is quite full and smooth with brief sweetness and a refreshing bitterness. It has notes of roasted malt and the brew has a nice balance and is quite charming.

(Draught) rich amber, effervescent with fine white bubbles. Nose of raw grain, honey, light fruit. Taste of persimmon, raw grain, honey, lightly bitter, complex, grain mash. Well carbonated and a bit dry on the palate finish.
Orange pour with creamy white head. Caramel malt and perfumy hops. Light caramel malt with floral hop bitter. Thin and watery. a pretty nice beer.
(Draught) Pours a clear orange body with a small white head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, bread, grass, and florals. Flavor of orange, earth, caramel, grain, and grass.
On tap at Draught House Clear light amber with a small off-white head and some lacing. Floral, grainy and malty. OK.
On tap at the Draught House. Light pour with a white head. Nice, grainy, malty aroma and taste.
2/25/12. On tap at the brewery during RBWG 2012. Plain biscuit/malty aroma with a similar grainy/malty flavor and a touch of butterscotch. Meh.
On tap at Draught House. Pours a cloudy orange with small white head leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is honey malt. Thin mouthfeel with sweet malt and dry finish.
Smells like citronella candles. Bitter orange peel. Orange blossoms and just a bit rough.

On tap at the Draught House 42nd Anniversary Party. The beer pours an amber color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the caramel and bready malt. The flavor is a mix of grassy and earthy hops with some bready and caramel/toffee malts. Low bitterness. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
on tap. deep amber with a cream head. fruity,bready malts with a slight toastiness and some chocolate. nice on the palate wiht a flavor of roasted malts, chocolate and light smoke.
Listed as a cream stout on the board. Pours black with a tan lace of head. Nice sweet aroma, but not strong. Thin body. Really delicious. I think it�s their best beer.

Sampled on tap at the brewpub in early May 2010. The beer pours a black color with a tan head. The aroma is roasted malt with some vanilla. As the beer warms you get more mint and chocolate notes. The flavor is strong vanilla, chocolate and roasted malt. Medium-thick mouthfeel and low carbonation.

(draught) jet black pour, some light tan carb but low. Nose of vanilla extract, chocolate syrup. Taste of chocolate syrup, vanilla extract (too much), and more vanilla. Undercarb. If this was bottle conditioned it might rule.

On tap. This was labeled as simply "vanilla porter" and wasn�t nitro, so not sure if this was a different beer. Black pour with a small head. Aroma is brown sugar, vanilla and coffee. Flavor is ash, coffee and earth. Slight sweetness on the back end.

Dark black, small light tan head, excellent lacing. Smells like coffee, and vanilla, imagine that? Also smells like dark roasted malt. Has a strong vanilla taste, but it�s good, unlike the Breckenridge attempt where it was just kinda weird. Other flavors include oak or pecan. Mouthfeel is heavy, slightly creamy, and develops a dull bite on the finish. Coffee lingers in the aftertaste.
Seventy five characters eh? How about Yuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuum!!

2-10-08 tap Black brown in color - a bit thin looking - with decent head. Smoky vanilla roasted smell. Flavor is similar just toned down - vanilla is there and the roasted malt hints are in there too, but just masked a little more. Palate is a bit thin and watery but drinkable nonetheless.

Pours a deep, rich black color with a light but short lived beige head. Smell is strongly of vanilla and astringent coffee. Taste is very influenced by the vanilla to begin with with strong coffee in the finish that lingers for a bit. Pretty nice beer with a bold flavor. (not served on nitro)

Pour is black with a thin brown head...smell is sweet vanilla...taste is sweet vanilla...mouthfeel was thick and chewy...finish is vanilla with maybe a touch of alcohol...while you may not think that this rating is descriptive, I have to say that everything I wrote about this beer is 100% accurate...true story...like getting the shit kicked out of you by a vanilla bean is sort of how I feel about this one...no longer served on nitro.

Great for those that like vanilla, not subtle for those that don�t. Great color, head retension, alhtough coudl be a bit more balanced at times. Great beer overall with no off-flavors when I have had it.
I like that. Chalky brown. Dense brown head. Light roasted malt and chocolate aroma. Flavor istarts medium roasted barley and cocoa and finishes with a mild bitterness. Quite good.

This is an excellently subtle brew. What a stout. Very interesting rich chocolate in color. Head looks like milk chocolate smoothie. Smells dry, fruity and slightly chemically. Apricots really come through in the nose. It is overwhelming. However there is a slight chemically bouquet on the nose. Brew itself tastes very apricoty. Deep rich dark malts, nitrogen and dried apricots and cherries. Exquisite. G-rat

I'm alway's taken by surprise with brewpubs. Something with the name HammerHead just sounds like an attempt to cover a bad taste with a cool name.....BUT...I loved it! Fruity, Dark, and Smooth. starts off realy fruity, then gets more rounded towards the bottom. A good change of pace.
Unremarkable stout, very typical. Not a whole lot of flavor. .............
Not bad, but nothing special. Picture a Guiness with less gravity..........

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: From a 650 ml bomber. A dark brown beer with plenty of whitish head and a sweet malted nose. Sweet, with ample malts in the foreground - reminiscent of dried fruits and brown sugar. No hop bitterness detected. Not too bad! 3.5

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Bottle. Strong and sweet caramel/toffee aroma. Pours dark amber in colour with very little head and light carbonation. Caramel and brown sugar flavour with some notes of roasted coffee. Medium body. Sweet finish.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Bottle. Amber in colour with moderate carbonation. Strong caramel and apricot aromas. Flavors are of pale malt, cooked sugar, vague pit fruit, and a hint of toasted nut. Heavy and sweet on the palate. Decent for the style, but not really my jam.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Brought a bottle at the brewery on a trip and tried it out. Drinking from the bottle. Aroma of malts and caramel, taste is pretty much the same. Enjoying it!

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 650ml brown bottle. 2013 release. Reddish brown in colour, clear looking, off white foam on top. Average lacing and short head retention. Nose is malty with some nutty notes and caramel/toffee. Taste has caramel and toffee malts. Toasty finish with lingering toffee and mild bitterness. Medium bodied, average mouthfeel and carbonation. Some nice malt flavours here, overall a nice beer. Probably would have been a bit more enjoyable in the winter months.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: caramel, toast, earthy, smoke, red, brown, clear, minimal head, tan foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, soft carbonation, bitter Brown pour with some reddish highlights. Subtle aroma from minimal tan foam of sweet malt, smoke, and toasty earthiness. Taste is lightly sweet with a more pronounced hop bitterness. Hint of diacytal butter as well. Very thin bodied with a watery effect on the tongue. Alcohol heat apparent and finishes on the dry side. Lingering bitterness in the aftertaste. More reminiscent of a dry stout then the expected cloying sweetness of a scotch ale.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Pouring a dark burnished brown with burgundian highlights in the body and a light beige coloured head. The head albeit shortlived gives a few intriguing lacing rings to the glass. The initial aroma is a bit intense up front with noticeable roasted and peated malts and a slight smoky ash scent. An overall malty aroma lacks an overall balance with a big blend of robust dark malts. The flavour profile has mild sweetness with toffee malts and rich creamy pudding flavours. The peat and smoke is lacking in the flavour despite the mild presence in the aroma. A bit of spritzy carbonation towards the finish with moderately hop bitterness rounds out the flavour rather well. A nice lightly smoked brew with rich malts throughout and a good balance. Overall, a nice solid brew.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 650 ml bottle. Pours a dark mahogany/red with little head. Aromas of biscuit and toasted malt. Flavors of malts, light caramel, light vegetable, and toast, plus a little butter and nuttiness. Not bad, but not impressive.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 650ml bottle pours brown in color with a finger of creamy white head that retains well and leaves a few spots of lacing on the glass. Aroma is quite mild for the style with some caramel and very little peat or smoke aromas. Taste is mellow but pleasant with some caramel and light bitterness and hints of smoke. Light to medium body with mild carbonation. A very subtle Scottish ale, which is easy to drink, makes a good session ale.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: A - Caramel and Molassis A - Copper brown T -Mellow sweet and bitter M - Medium body and soft O - Nicely Scottish ale

Mild sweet grainy malts and herbal hops in the nose. Clear golden body with low but lasting white head. Cooked cabbage, grainy, sweet flavour with light bitterness. Light body with strong carbonation. Bottle. Entered from notes.
There really isn't anything special about this. I will admit it had an odd taste. But nothing that will make me jump up and say hey I want that beer again. I'll save turtles another way thank you.
Thirst quenching pils but not as good as Unibroue U. This company brings tears to my eyes that they are trying to save the environment but their labels are creepy after drinking two...

I was very disapionted because I thought I was buying the Ale which was really good. This is a limpid labatt/molson wannabe. The colour is very pale - almost watery. Nose of corn and light-light hops. Flavour of corn and slight malt and very little bitterness. Give this to your mother when she asks for a beer and you know she hates your micros. I cannot believe that this is the **** that Cheval Blanc chooses to send Ontarians at the LCBO. It's the only beer they make that I've ever seen outside of Qu�bec and is their worst by far.
I don't have much more to add. Not a terrible brew though, drinkable.......
Malty aroma, dark orange appearance, and a head that disspeared quick. Malt in the palate, the middle is full with some lemon or citrus. It finishes long and unpleasant. NOt my type of brew!
generic. Very generic. Sweet and generic. .................................
Light; vaguely hoppy; pils-like, a decent int'l lager. That said, I feel sorry for the turtle, because I don't know that they'll be selling enough to save the poor guy.
Hops greet the nose. Typical pilsner golden. Taste is almost bitter, I think its flat. Unpleasant palate, bad.
Light bronze in colour. Aromas are gooseberry and sweet malts. Flavours are initially sweet and watery but then the gooseberry flavours comes to the fore. Improves by the mouthfull!

Bottled, pasturised. Light coloured, decent head. Light tasting premium bitter, pleasantly balanced with hops and malt. Citric (Grapefruit?) notes come through, a little fizzy from the bottle, would be better on draught but good enough.

Bottled. Copper coloured, good head and condition. Typical English bitter aromas of fruity citrus (orange) malt and low hop. Mainly fruity malt in the mouth with a lingering dry hop bitterness appearing in the finish
Mediumly bitter bitter that is a pleasant drink. It has slight hints of fruit in the aroma and bubble gum in the flavour. Not overly spectacular in an category but a good all-rounder.
Not much bitterness or flavour in general. Even at its relatively low 4.8% the alcohol stands out, but not unpleasantly so. Very good beer.

Bottled. Thanks to oh6gdx for this one. It�s a foamy experience with a pale yellow color. It has a bubbly head and lacings.The aroma is artificially malty. The flavor is malty, dry and it has a dry aftertaste.

Date: July 11, 2009 Mode: Bottle Source: RBSG 2009 Appearance: hazy yellow, fine white head, drippy lace Aroma: light floral malt aroma Overall: light cereal aroma, floral hops, light bitterness Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 7/20 Rating: 2.1/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: *+/4

06-Mar-08 (12 oz bottle) While this is a very flavorful pilsener, it�s extremely sweet. Additionally, the sweetness of the bready malts is enhanced by the strong, floral character of the hops. While the malt does have that rich, malt character of Czech pilseners, the sweetness is the overriding factor. The palate is medium-bodied and lacks the clean and crisp mouthfeel that pilseners are known for. Sweet and very floral fragrance in the nose with a lightly hoppy background aroma. Pale golden in color and slightly hazy. Small, white head dissipates fairly rapidly. Second attempt with this beer, and I�m still not too fond of this offering. 09-Sep-04 (12 oz bottle) I�ve yet to taste a floral Czech beer, and this one is so floral and yeasty, it doesn�t even seem remotely to emulate a Czech style pilsener. I�m not sure I�d even consider this a pilsener at all as it doesn�t really fit into any of the classic pilsener styles. It�s flavorful, lightly malty, quite sweet, and moderately bitter, but I�m so overwhelmed by the sweet, floral, yeasty nature of this beer, everything else seems way in the background. The palate is medium bodied and the antithesis of clean and crisp. Extremely floral fragrance in the nose with a lightly hoppy background aroma isn�t unpleasant, but certainly not to style. Pale golden in color and very slightly hazy. Large white head has excellent retention and leaves plenty of thick, dense lacing on the glass, so at least this is an attractive beer. (6, 4, 4, 3, 9 = 2.6)
Golden, smooth, citrus, bready, slight sweet malts, and a little bit of hops. Clean and crisp.

To start with, I am not a pilsner fan, but it was hot, and Pete�s Brass Rail didn�t have too much that sounded good to me at the time, so I got a sample of this and a few others. I ordered a pint of this one after tasting it. Pours typical Pilsner pale gold with tight bubbles creating the same type of head. The nose was a bit toasty and biscuity, as was the smooth, clean flavor. Highly drinkable and deserving of a higher score.

~Pours a very light yellow colour, almost white when held to light, many bubbles and huge white fluffy head. Head is too large! ~Scent of sour wheat, very tart. Lemony ~Can taste light hops and citrus. ~Light and dry. Citrusy aftertaste. ~This is an enjoyable beer. Great when hot out. Its 100 degrees out right now. The scent is a little candy like and taste is a bit tart, but its pretty good.

Bottled Pale yellow color, cloudy dishwater head. Fresh lemony nose. Very lemony-flowery hoppy flavor - this is very fruity American pils and certainly close to original European ones. Tickling hoppy and fruity flavor.

Bottled (thanks omhper!). Hazy yellow colour, mediumsized white fluffy white head. Aroma is fruity hops, salt water, malts and hops. Flavour is fruity hops, some malts and mild spicing. Wellbalanced. Long citrus frutiy aftertaste.

I got this beer as a gift in a sampler pack. It is a very light golden color with a little haze and a strong head. There is a classic pilsner aroma and a fairly crisp taste on the tongue before getting a hint of sweetness. All in all, it�s pretty average, although it would probably be more enjoyable on a warm day.

Bottled (6.1%). Clear golden, small firm head. Grassy nose. dry with dense, powerful, rounded mouthfeel. Lots of grassy hops. An oversized pilsener packed with flavour. One of the better American pilseners.

draft. clear yellow color with a slight white head that leves heavy lacing. Bready aroma with some slight fruit notes. Crisp and slightly fruity flavor with heavy malt notes. Bread somes accros a bit in the flavor as well. Clean finish.
Very clean Lager some biscuits and hay note. Good mouthfeel No defects. Some mild vanilla and citrus. clean finish. Basic lager.

Draft. Pale golden color (darker than most lagers) with no head. Very little aroma. Flavor was of malts, biscuits, and a slight fruit - overall richer than most lagers. Little bitterness. Clean and crisp. There�s nothing here to offend. The beer does have more flavor than most lagers, but otherwise is just a drinkable beer. I�m not a real lager fan, but this isn�t a bad option.

Draft @ Barclays, Oakland, CA. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty aroma with some hoppy citrus hints. Sweetish malty fruity caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a sweetish malty fruity hoppy finish.

On tap @ the brewpub. Pours clear gold with thin copper core and micro thin off white head. The mild aroma is crisp citrus hops mixing with a slightly roasted and sweet malt component. The taste has a very brief pulse of sweet malts before citrus hops plunge in. The hops begin with tasty late addition hop flavor and finish increasingly bitter. It ends dry with lingering citrus hop bitterness into the after taste. Solid tasting Pale Ale where the hops remain restrained and not really moving out of style IMO.

courtesy of Per - hazy golden-amber colour with a robust and creamy pale beige head, nice lace; charming fruity hoppiness with notes of apricot and grapefruit, very soft and creamy mouthfeel, quite low carbonation, sweet with a moderate bitterness; long fruity finish (peach comes to mind) - velvety and balanced

Bottled. Clear amber,firm head. Rich citric aroma of tropical fruits (pineapple and lychee?). Sweet and caramelly with tounded mouthfeel. A quite bold and full sized pale ale. Long resiny bitter finish. More powerful than thirst quenching.

Clear amber orange, HUGE HUGE head, didn�t see this one coming. Gentile pour had some overflow. Aroma is fairly unique for the style, sorta like a blond ale. Herbal, grassy hops with a lighter fruit bouquet. Ligher malts than typical, got some bread and caramel. Medium to light body, moderate to low bitterness, somewhat watery. Interesting take, but just didn�t click with me.

Draught at Falling Rock. The beer is clear, light/medium caramel with a small. frothy, white, mostly lasting, quickly diminishing head. Clingy lacing.Delicate and floral for a PA. The aroma is malty with a light note of biscuit; Hoppy with a light note of lemon and orange zest, light honeysuckle floral; Trace of yeasty basement.The flavor is light/moderately sweet, trace acidic with a long, lightly bitter, lightly sweet finish.The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

Draught, Falling Rock. Head is mostly diminishing. Body is dark yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly to moderately hoppy (flowers, herbs, grapefruit), with a note of ginger. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. A fairly solid little brew, actually. Nice hop character and some unusual gingery spice notes as well. Nice balance that isn�t the usual crude high-alpha attack on one�s mouth. Enjoyable.

12 oz. bottle- color dark amber , with a decent tanish quickly departing head - nose of sweet roasted malts , apricots , and slight hops � taste of sweet red fruit , spruce , bitter hops , slight grains , and malt - body is medium to light , semi bitter , and with mild carbonation � light aftertaste of resin , hops , and malt
Bottle poured a clear gold with a minimal white head. Aromas of fruitiness, bread and light carmel. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of carmel, orange and straw with a crisp sweet finish.

12oz bottle acquired in trade with DarkElf (thanks!). Poured a deeper and cloudy amber color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, oranges, citrus and lemon peels. Tastes of caramel, juicy oranges, and citrus. On the sweeter side. This was actually not that bad of an APA and wouldn�t make that bad of a session beer.
You can achieve a similar beer at home by tossing apple concentrate into a standard ale.

Auch ein Apfelbier kannte ich bis zu diesem Bier hin nicht. Es wirkt ordentlich nach Apfelringen mit deutlicher S�ure. Aber das hefige Hintergrundbier bleibt doch erhalten. Ich finde es nicht so �bel -aber ich esse auch gerne Apfelringe.

15-Dec-13 (330-ml bottle: Purchased 09-Feb-08 for $4.99 at Ledger's Liquors in Berkeley, CA) This apple beer pours a hazy, golden body with half an inch of white head that settles to a bubbly ring, leaving a few rings of lacing on the glass. The nose is pretty much just spiced apple pie and yeah, that's it. Taking a sip, it tastes like spiced apple pie too, with a background flavor that tastes like the bottom crust. It's fairly sweet and somewhat sugary, but there's a touch of tartness to at least help provide some contrast, but in the end, this is just drinking apple sauce. The beer is medium bodied, though sugar certainly adds to the perception of weight, and carbonation is medium. Overall, this is very simple and one-dimensional, but I suppose it's fun for what it is.
Bottle sample at a tasting at Max's place. Thanks Tom L. Golden, tiny bit of foam. Cheap lemonade, sweet, sugary, faint graininess, light-bodied.

0,25 l bottle. Pours crystal clear golden with small almost immediately dissipating white head. Aroma is artificially fruity, lemonade and some corn. Taste is medium to heavy sweet. Body is watery, texture thin and carbonation average. Finish is short and sweet, some light fruitiness.
At Max Place, pours yellow with a small head, aroma of lemon, sprite, flavor of sprite, sweet, light bodied

Bottle, 0.25l. Clear yellow pour, instantly vanishing soapy white head. Nose is artificial lemonade with slight herbal notes. Thin and watery, soft carbonation. Sugary sweet taste with slight lemon tart. Aroma pretty much same as the nose - carbonated lemonade with subtle herbal touch. Something in the aroma reminds me of Desperados, but it's quite faint. Sticky mouthfeel, quite sugary. Overall, somewhat refreshing lemonade. But even so, quite artificial and mediocre. Not even a trace of beer in this one. Meh.

Enjoyed: Poured from a bottle into shaker glass. Appearance: Deep golden colour with no head. Aroma: Corn, something sweet. Palate: Watery body, soft to medium carbonation, Taste: Sweet, corn, hint of lemon. Overall impression: Not so good, too sweet. If it has something with beer, it is cheap beer.

Bottle 25cl from Cora. A clear yellow beer with low head. Nose is on barley sugar with lemon notes. Aroma on lemon and kind of sweet biscuits, so sweet body, low carbonation. Bit strange for a radler but pleasant.

Bottle 0,25L. Adding this one just to add radler/shandy to my style list. Looks like blended tea with some carbonation. Aroma also reminds me of tea, some herbs and lemon here. Flavor is very sweet with some lemon and orange. There is no trace of a beer, if you ask me. One of the worst drinks I ever had.

Pours a clear light yellow color, topped with a very small white head that immediately disappears. Fruity aroma of artificial lemon. Taste is sweet and sugary (but not to excessively), citric. Drinkable and refreshing, but doesn�t really have much to do with beer.
Bottle from Interspar (Ljubljana). Clear liquid. Light body, medium carbonation. Very sweet. Taste like artificial lemon aroma with some beer and sparkling water.
Clear yellow color, no head. Sugary sweetness. Thin body, average carbonation. Apple and lemon aroma. Good, for a lemonade. (InterSpar Ljubljana 0,25l bottle)

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: From a 12 oz. can. Pours a clear dark mahogany with a tan head. Aromas are nutty with some molasses. Flavor is moderately sweet dark brown sugar.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Can from Dennis. Decent carb. Earthy bitterness, some artichoke and field flowers. Ok

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Light nutty aroma. Thin flavour with a bit of nut and syrup. Very thin finish. Not bad, but not really good either.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Nothing offensive, but nothing remarkable. Rather light taste for a brown ale

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Draft pour into a pint glass. The beer is a hazy copper with a velvety head of beige foam. Sweet and roasty taste. Very sweet. Medium body and medium carbonation.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Verrrrry chain brewpub like with this one... Aroma is stale caramel and nuts, as is the taste... Medium carb. Nothing complex or distinguishing about it.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: 12 oz bottle. (Susan�s Fine Wine & Spirits) Santa Fe, NM. Dark mahogany color with a tiny off-white head. Mild sweet brown sugary malty aroma. The flavor is dry wood, peanut skins, brown sugar and sweet malt. The kind of brown ale I don�t like.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Starts of well with a nutty aroma but the taste is unbalanced and the hops can�t really enhance the weak body. I had higher expectations.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Longneck. Clean label. Aroma is at first a bit yeasty and sweaty from the bottle. From the glass, it�s malt, cereal and lagery. Light molasses and straw notes, alt-like, lightly sweet, lightly bittered. Medium body. Cherry pits and straw on the backend. Not going to set the world on fire, but very drinkable and sessionable. Thanks to PorterPounder.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Amarillo, Tx - Party Stop Liquors - 12 oz bottle. Pours a medium brown with a quickly fading light off-white head. Aroma is pleasant, slight nuttiness, a hint of chocolate. Flavor has some slight nutty accents, a touch of molasses, some brown sugar. Mouthfeel is thick enough.

column1: Peak To Peak Apex Mountain Amber Ale
column5: Had this beer on 9/29/1999. Aroma is a sweet malty scent. Color is a pale brown with light carbonation and head. Taste is rich and malty. Stating with a smooth medium body that goes down with a malty feel. Finish is a full malt flavor with a light bitterness and mild hop flavor. It�s very well balanced brew

column1: Peak To Peak Apex Mountain Amber Ale
column5: Head is initially small, fizzy, off-white, fully diminishing. Body is hazy medium amber, moderate density of tiny particles. Aroma is lightly hoppy (grass, flowers, citrus - orange), lightly malty (light bread, caramel). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Pretty lightweight and a bit too sweet, but inoffensive.

Moderate pineapple aroma. Hazy, amber/orange color, off-white frothy head, good lacing. Sweet, moderate full, very fruity (pineapple). Long sweet sparkling finish. If you like sweet triples this one is very good.
Pours quite black. Very malty flavour with little subtlety. Sweet malt finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

330ml bottle into glass. Very active head, a real gusher. Nose is milk chocolate. Massive soapy tan head slowly recedes. Great deep red colour with champagne carbonation. Fizzy in the mouth, good body. Finish is smoky, a little chocolate, then sour fruit. Quite similar to Tooheys Old. Tasty.
Bottle to glass. Nutty, malty aromas. Looks fairly average. Sweet milk choc and bitter burnt toffee in the same mouthful. Little bit on the gassy side. An interesting little blend. Maybe again.
Excellent balance of sweetness and bitterness, with great aromatics. Unfortunately the specimen I had was way over carbonated, which was a real shame. Other than that I thoroughly enjoyed this guy.
Nice gentle malt aroma. Black cloudy colour with good head. Strong on hops with coffee tones. Heavy body with medium carbonation.

From a 330ml bottle on 5/5/2011. Pours a very dark amber with a modest head. Smells mainly of sweet caramel malt. Has an interesting flavour, beginning with sweet chocolate, caramel and toffee, which is quickly followed by an intense and long roasty bitterness. The carbonation is fine and the body is relatively light. A good beer, and a little harshly treated on here.

Pours very dark brown with ruby highlights and a large lasting head. Nose shows caramel, milk chocolate and roasted malt. Quite sweet smelling. Some nutty hints also show. Flavours are dominated by roasted malt with little of the complexity shown in the aroma. Some sweet caramel comes through towards the finish. Carbonation is much too high and the body feels watery.

Bottle. Darkish brown with a light beige head. Aroma of toffee, cocoa, roasted malt and grass. Taste has plenty of toffee but the roasted malt is not lost. Nice distinct bitterness comes into a finish that�s still quite malty but not very sweet. Pretty tasty blend of Gippsland Gold and Hatlifter.
bottle. great beer. Lovely head. some bitterness and caramel. deep brown, not overly carbonated.

Bottle 330ml. Nice beer. Aromas of apple, liquorice, milk, and a hint of chocolate. Taste is sweet, with bitter notes, and average duration. Palate is velvety, with a thin-to-medium body. Black, with a frothy white head.
A - Honey A - Amber with lasting creamy head T - Sweet with slight bitter finish P - Full bodied with medium carbonation O - This is a beer I have always enjoyed...
Draught @ Milestone�s in the Vancouver airport. Pale yellow, faint grainy aroma. Sweet grainy palate, rather bland.
Draught @ Milestone�s as Palomino Honey Red - Nice color but lacked head, too sweet for its own good. Pleasant enough to drink, but only recommended for beer newbies or my wife.

Amber-orange with no head or lace. Lots of honey and caramel in the nose, but that�s it. Taste is muddled by too much honey. Watery with some malt flavour. Has a syrupy mouthfeel that resembles old cola...flat and unflattering in every way.

Draught at Milestone�s. As �Palomino Honey Lager�. Pours a clear bubbly orange with an average size diminishing white head. Aroma�s mild and dull with sugar, light hops, somewhat fake honey and a hint of grain. Watery flavour of fake honey, grain, malt and only a hint of hops. Light to average bodied. I�ve had worse Canadian �Honey� beers, that�s for sure, but this is still pretty mediocre stuff.

I�m pretty sure this one isn�t retired completely, I had it at the rum runners pub last night in Kitchener. And it wasn�t all that horrible. Nice aroma with honey being very evident. The taste had sort of an unpleasant skunkiness to it, but other than that it was enjoyable.
not very good. very very sweet, way too sweet. it was like taking a macro pale lager and dumping in whack of sugar water. very thin, not enjoyable at all.
Bronzey-red with white lace highlights. Smooth and malty flavour with a touch of hops. With food, this one went ineluctably down the gullet no questions asked.

Unfortunately, not in keeping with what I�ve come to expect from Brick. It does carry forth the Brick-typical absentee head, but this one also carries a somewhat unpleasing smell and far too much carbonation. I�ll go out on a limb and assume perhaps the place I tried it on tap - Big Daddy�s - had allowed it to age and become somewhat stale, but that�s not going to convince me to try it a second time. Flavour is mostly just carbonation, but you�ll find a bit of corn and grains alongside a tinge of honey. Sadly, I�ll recommend a pass.

Tap at Moxie�s in London, Ont- It�s not really red first of all, but more of a light amber, almost dark yellow. A medium sized with froth sits a top. Mildly hoppy aroma with soapy and caramel aspects to it. Sweet corn and caramel flavours are teamed up with grains and a mild bitterness. About as expected.

Taster at the brewery. Pours a golden with a white head. Aroma is flowery, fruity, and somewhat similar to Belgian Saison. Similar taste that is again very close to Belgian Saison with hoppy bitterness, moderate sweetness and some honey notes. It is decent, but fairly hard to drink even the full taster.
Bottle, shared with Parksy and others. Medium golden, average white head with decent retention. Sweet and boozy with strong yeast esters; precisely the profile of this style that I dislike.
Draft - Sweet fruity yeasts and stone fruit. Clear gold with a decent white head. As it smells, fruit Belgian esters, touch of perfume and not much else. OK.

Pours a clear golden, with a quickly dissipating tiny white head. Aroma of sweet lemon candies, subtle tropical fruit, and strong boozy yeast. Incredibly thin mouthfeel, almost no carb. Very sweet finish, slightly vegetal. This was rough.
Hazy gold with a small head. Moderately spicy and slightly dry finish. Fairly light bodied with no alcohol burn, I would drink it again.

Sold as "Steamworks Blitzen Belgian Tripel". Smell of yeast, some hops. Lemon yellow colour, small white head. Aroma of honey, overripe mango, yeast. Finishes with white wine / champagne. Sweet to begin with, slightly sour in the end. Flat carbon, semi-oily texture. Heavy body.
Yeasty concoction. Not super drinkable unless you share with at least 3 people. LCBO months after xmas.

2015-04-05. Dark yellow body with a nice white head. 3+ Aroma of sweet pale malt and dryish alcohol. Flavour is similar with a sweet pale malt core, dryish lightly bitter finish. Moderate alcohol character. Smooth average plus bodied palate. Decent, relatively mild for the style but enjoyable. Bottle from the LCBO, Toronto.

Now called "Blitzen Belgian Tripel". Pours a light golden colour with tiny clear particles that float around, but the overall brew is clear. White head with decent retention and some light creamy lacing. Good spiciness in the taste with the Belgian Ale and fruity-grainy malts. Alcohol is well-hidden with just a slight warmth. Grainy aromas with hints of grass and spices. A real easy-drinking Belgian Tripel that I would have again. Wish I could try this just a little less filtered.
650 ml bottle from LCBO. Pours a clear golden colour with medium white head. Aroma is fruity, grainy malts. Taste is same. Pretty good.

On tap in the Winnipeg Airport. Has a brownish body with copper notes and okay foam on top. Smells of a very macro lager with sweet fake malt hints, cardboard sugar, that kind of smell you smelled from the couch at your drunken uncle's house when you visited him as a kid in 1983 to watch the Jets in the playoffs. Flavour is smooth fake amber malt and nothing else. Full on the mouth and completely uninteresting, but approachable for those who live in fear of craft beer.
Bottle. Amber color, creamy off-white head. Smooth, malty flavor with some floral hops. Medium body, medium carbonation. Not bad.
Don't know why this doesn't have a higher rating. Has everything I'm looking for in a beer. Good flavour, not to much aftertaste, and goes down very well ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle at a bar in Winnipeg. Golden, light head, malts and grass? Not a great choice.

Solid take on Fort Garry's popular Pale Ale beer with a zest of bitter hops added to it. Amber in colour, medium amount of bitter hops to give it a mellow pine and citrus aroma. Moderately bitter tasting, very grassy and hint of lemon zest. Very easy to drink. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

My hopes weren�t high for this. But it was decent. Pours a dark golden with lots of white head. Aromas of grains, tropical fruit. Flavours are sweet and juicy. Tropical fruit mostly. The hops used really elavate an otherwise average beer. Earlier Rating: 12/25/2011 Total Score: 1.6 This is unspectacular in almost every way. crisp, and easy drinking are some of the better things i can say about this beer. As far as Manitoba brewed pale ale�s go, stick with half pints st.james pale ale.
Growler sample shared with northropfrye. Faint aroma of musty clean straw. Clear golden colour. Disappating head. Taste of musty straw with a slight hint of a floral element. I like it.

Light pale orange body foamy white head and some lacing. Slight pine, citrus and perfume aroma. Taste is sweet malts and a touch of perfumy hops. Not bad, but could be much hoppier. Earlier Rating: 8/8/2011 Total Score: 2.6 Bottle. Nothing special here. A nice quality pale ale with nothing noteworthy in the flavour.

On tap at the Winnipeg airport. Has foamy beige head but rather fast disappearing and a reasonably dark brown body. Smells of very sweet lager barley, all smooth and sugary, no rough edges, like a ball bearing sinking in water. Flavour is a kind of weak earthy barley with vegetable notes. Wet on the mouth, no crispness, and that vegetable character lingers. This is an awkward mess, wonky would be the best word to describe it.

This was back before the Craft Beer Explosion. Now that there's so many great options, fort Garry has kinda been forgotten. Decent dark ale with no overbearing notes. Subtle hints of coffee and nuts. Syrupy texture. If a restaurant's 'local craft' selection includes bud light and this, I'll choose this every day. You know what restaurant I'm talking about.
Dark, low hops flavour, good tasting, good aroma, would purchase again, available in cans

Kamloops 23/7 2018. 47,3 cl can bought on Via Rails the Canadian. Dark and golden can telling me this is a Dark English Mild Ale. Pours dark deep brown with small white head. Settles as thin, almost transparent, patchy layer of foam. No lacing. Aroma is intense and dark. Sweet caramel, dark chocolate, Tanned leather, tart, sour and sharp notes. Soft carbonation. Creamy, velvety, thick texture. Flavor has medium sweetness followed by somewhat stronger tart bitterness. Aftertaste is sour, tart berries. I would�nt exactly call it mild. A suprisingly tart dark beer which works good with lunch on a Train.
Cleanly made brown, it's at the very high end of the roastiness for the style and relatively dark. I think this is also underrated on ratebeer. Can from LB. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A winnipeg produced dark beer. I have higher expectation for the dark ales but this one was ok.
Dark brown color, aroma is rather bland. Taste is a little chocolate, caramel and coffee but nothing really stands out. Mediocre dark ale

Aroma is roasted malts, caramel, molasses and fig. Some light coffee beans. Taste is roasted malts, caramel and coffee. Finished somewhat watered down yet a bit creamy. Appearance is a clear amber with a thin pearl head that retains quite well.
Easy to drink dark. Light roast and some caramel. A hint of dark chocolate. Black pour with ok head. Thick consistency. Bittersweet finish. Tap.

341ml bottle. I can�t comment on the pour - it was from the bottle at a wedding. The aroma is a mix of nutty and chocolate malt notes, with a little spice in there. Light spice hops up front lead into a nice, malty body, with milk chocolate and nut flavours. The finish is a little on the sweet side, and lasts pretty well. All in all, quite an enjoyable brown ale.
Straw and some paper, but no weird chemicals usually present in these kinds of beers. Golden pour. Light crisp finish. Boring. Bottle.
Light straw color - lots of foamy white head. Almost no nose - maybe a bit of dough. Watered down flavor on the palate. No thanks.
Bottle. A light beer - what do you expect. About as good as it can get for a light pale lager. Watery.

[3688-20110416] 473mL can. Sweet honey bread grains aroma. Slightly hazy, light yellow body with a quick foamy white head. Initial wet grains flavour follows up with cooked corn. Light-medium body. Not great. (4/3/4/2+/9) 2.2 Overheard: "I enjoy a good can of swill every now and then." (w/ jerc, JoeMcPhee, RadekKliber)
Very pale golden pour - chill hazed with a bit of light ethanol. Crackery and industrial malts. Meh.

Can 473 ml Aroma: strong fruity character. Hints of honey grains. Quiet sweet.3+ Appearance: slight haze on gold. Medium top that reduced to minimal fizz in few seconds. 2-. Palate / Taste: Soapy front. Thin bodied. Empty character with slight feel of malts. Not very clean ,not easy going , wont quench you thirst either. Meh.

2011-04-17. Crisp yellow body with a tiny white head. Grainy, sweet floral aroma. Flavour is similar, grainy undercurrent, floral notes. Average palate. Meh, pretty inoffensive for the most part, it actually has some hop character, though its not a hop character I personally like. More flavour than many light beers. A mainstream lightly flavoured brew. Bottle from MLCC, Winnipeg
Not the worst replacement for a macro beer that I have had. Poor yellow coloured body, with a little light head. Minimal taste but not harsh, a light malt.

341ml brown bottle. Yellow colour with a noisy white head which dies quickly. Nose is grainy, light bread. Tasty is also quite grainy, some hay notes, mineral water, faint lemon. Dry finish. Thin body, high carbonation. Basic lawnmower beer, better than most macro "lite" beers.
33 cl bottle, Winnipeg, MB, Canada. Slightly hazy, noticeably carbonated. Very minimal head. Primarily straw aroma, sweet taste with a mild pepperiness on the finish. Okay for a light beer.

341ml bottle pours a pale golden color with a small white head that does leave a little lacing. Aroma is slightly grainy with some grassy notes as well. Taste is a light malty sweetness with a mild hop bitterness that finishes quite harsh. Overall, just another mediocre lager style brew that is nothing special.

Bottle from trade. Pours a pale gold spritzy lager with a smallish cap in the glass. Cap retention not great but does lace the glass. Faint nose on this some boiled grains not much else. Tastes pretty much like it smells, kind of bland, thin malts clean hops show in the finish, clean but bland, not what I look for in a pilsner.

Cloudy gold color. Smelled malty and sweet. Flavor was not as bitter as you would expect for a "pilsener" but in the end this was very drinkable. Tasted more like a German lager than a pilsner, but is was very quaffable.

Hazy beige/dull dark straw sort of colour. Grainy, creamed corn aroma with doughy overtones. The flavour is doughy, lightly sweaty, with more creamed corn and a bit of footiness. Low carbonation. Poor attempt - misses at being a mainstream lager and misses at being a craft beer.

Bottle (thanks to piscator34 for the trade). Corn/barley malt aroma. Medium golden color with small head. Corn malt flavor with light hops. This seems more like a pale lager than a pilsner to me - not bad but nothing special.
Lots o� carbonation, but not too flavourful. Good beer to have with a meal though. Could become a standard in the fridge.

Medium gold in colour with lots of carbonation. Some sulfur aromas mixed in with a bit of malt. The dominant flavor is the Fort Garry house malt, which has a cookie dough quality to it. There�s a strange somewhat bittering green quality as well, which doesn�t really seem like hops. Except for the colour, this beer is not even close to what a pilsner should be. Would it kill these guys to use some aroma hops?

Sampled at the Matheson open house last night. Standard pils pour....very light translucent gold color...small whitish head. Light grassy aroma, flavor is more of the same but maybe with a light malt/hop mix in there. Hard to say. Bitter finish arrives quickly as I chug the rest to move on to something better.

Kind of waterey & thin for a pilsener. Almost instantly headless with lazy carbonation, this golden drink has a soft, sweet grassy aroma. The flavor is a mild malt sweetness and a dusting of hop bitterness. The finish is, well... wet. Bridgeview Liquors, Bridgeview, IL
Light clear gold colour with thin white head. Pretty much no aroma. Flavour-wise a little bit of a surprise. Lite sweetness and a little hop finish. Overall pretty thin, but clean.

Draft at Earl's of the Rockies. Pours clear bright amber with a bubbly off white head. Tastes like toffee malt, dark toast, light corn, and faint citrus hops. Light body and medium carbonation. Smells like toffee malt, toast, and faint citrus hops.
Draft - Light malts and a touch of wood. Clear gold with a small head. Sweet caramel and woody.

On tap at Earl�s Surrey. Clear medium copper under a small short lived off white head. Nose is caramel and light floral notes. Light sweet with a similar grassy bitterness. Mouth is medium with average carbonation. OK.
Pours a nice light amber. Aromas of citrus and caramel. Nice caramel notes on the tongue with pine too. Quite nice.
Pours dark amber with a white fizzy head. Aroma is malty. Tastes of malts, copper and yeast. On tap at Earl�s. A nice, easy to drink beer.

Aroma is of light pale malts with some floral hop esthers. Pours a clear orangish copper with a big thick head that dissipates quickly. Taste is faint sweet pale malts with floral hops and a nice crisp bitterness throughout. Overall it�s easy drinking.

Pint on tap at the Earl�s Tin Palace location in Edmonton pours a pale amber color with a small white head that leaves very little lacing behind. Aroma is cereal grains and grass with a hint of light fruits. Taste is a light grainy and fruity sweetness with a light hop bitterness. Light bodied with decent carbonation. Nothing compared to the Albino Rhino.

A copper amber ale with a thin off white head. In aroma, mix of caramel malt with light veggie notes. In mouth, a grainy caramel malt with light herbal an vegetal notes, boring. On tap at Winnipeg location, Nov. 2 2012.

Draught at Earl�s in Yaletown, Vancouver Amber color; medium sized head. Light sugary aroma, a bit papery. Same for the flavor, with light residual sweetness and a light astringency; ordinary bitterness. Quite boring.
On draft at Earls in Burlington Ontario. Pours a copper colour with a white head and some spidery lacing. Smells malty and a tiny bit of hop. Taste is also rather malty and a touch of hop too.
I believe this is from TWSP. It's been in the fridge awhile. Golden. Aroma is honey, a little funkiness. Flavor is honey - not overly sweet, and almost an apple-like flavor. Simple, but drinkable.
Bottle from Total Wine and More in Reston, VA Aroma: honey, grapes, floral Appearance: clear golden, no head Taste: medium sweetness Mouthfeel: still, oily feel, medium body, long finish Tasty

Chaucer's is one of your lower end meads. Chaucer's is not a bad mead, but it doesn't compare to the quality of mead you get elsewhere. A common complaint I hear with Chaucer's mead is that it is not viscous enough, it's less of a honey taste and more the taste of a thin wine. The bottle design is simplistic. It it a good beginner's mead, to introduce someone who is used to wine into the world of meads.
Sample from a bottle at Hy-Vee Oktoberfest. Poured clear straw, no head. Aroma of honey, herbal, flowers. Taste was medium sweet, honey, sugar.

Bottle. Clear golden yellow. Smells of honey and spice. Minty. We did not add the spice bags in. Some alcohol warmth on the nose. Flavor is similar to apple juice, honey, sweet for sure. Warmth is present after the finish.

Light golden color. Aromas big honey. Flavors big honey. Highly sweet but delicious. Pretty mono-toned but tasty. Tried with the spiced packet it came with, which made it even better. (consisted of cinnamon, spices, orange peel and clove). Drank at reunion 7/22/16.

750 ml. bottle with mulling spices packet attached. Threw away the packet and drank at room temperature. Look is clear golden and still. Nose is white grape and mildly earthy honey.
