Bottle pour into tulip glass from Redstone Liquors, Stoneham. Appearance is opaque black with nice sparkle at the edges of the glass, fleeting 1/2-finger width light brown head. Aroma is rich roasted malt, blueberry. Taste is equally sweet and earthy bitter roasted malt, chocolate notes with blueberry floating in the background. Palate is light-to-medium bodied with smooth texture, soft-to-average carbonation and finish as taste. Overall, not complex by any means, a little light bodied and the blueberry could be a little stronger but good.
Matige neus, redelijk vol mondgevoel, vrij korte afdronk. De bessen komen mooi terug in de smaak even als een beetje koffie en chocola.
Zwart bier met weinig schuim. Smaak is bitterzoet met iets van koffie, donkere chocolade en een vleugje fruit.

Color negro con capa de espuma marr�n de dos dedos de grosor y buena retenci�n. Carbonatacion inexistente. Textura oleosa, casi acuosa. Me gustar�a con algo m�s de cremosidad pero tampoco soy de poner excesivas pegas en estos asuntos. Aroma a ar�ndano por un tubo, malta torrefacta, chocolate y algo quemado de fondo que capto en algunos olfateos y en otros no, quiz� ahumado. Sabor a ar�ndanos, muy potente, con ligera acidez, perfectamente calibrada, malta torrefacta, cacao, chocolate, recuerdos muy lejanos de caf� al final del trago. Final que no considero licoroso, aun bebiendola caliente, alcohol perfectamente integrado. Toques torrefactos y ligeramente quemados en postgusto, junto con ar�ndano. Interesante ser�a decir poco.

Aus der Flasche (2015) im 2018-05 getrunken. In der Nase ist eine ganze leichte Blaubeernote wahrnehmbar, doch am Gaumen bleibt davon nichts. Hier wird dieses doch sehr s�ffige Stout von einem kalten Kaffeearoma beherrscht.
Aromas of blueberry,roasted malt,cocoa.Taste of blueberry,bitter chocolate, roasted malt and sour blueberry. Hiddes well the alcohol,the aftertaste is a bit artificial..
Called "Cerveza Nacional" (not Andes). Popular known as "media jarra" (half jar). It was a very cheap and watery beer. If it was cold, it was drinkable. Low quality beer.
0.5 l bottle. Golden colour beer with white head. Aroma of caramel, malt. Taste is sweet, fruit, grain.

100cl PET bottle from Jannseni kaubamaja, Tallinn. Pours clear, deep golden to amber with a small, rather fast dissipating, white head. Sweet, grainy and malty with caramel and hints of cooked vegetables and hay. Better than expected, not impressive, but still drinkable. Fair enough.
Botella 0,5l Color dorada con espuma blanca,moderada,poco resistente.Aroma malta,cereales,herbal.Sabor malta,cereales,herbal,dulzor suave combinado con ligero amargor
v Ruskom obchode NEO Markt. Vona medovo sladova, jantarova farba, pena takmer ziadna. Chut medova, sladova. Na konci ostava.

Draft sample at brewpub from notes in fall 2002. Poured a clear amber color with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Medium hop and sweet malt aroma. Medium body with a soft texture and soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Another smooth session brew.
A light gold color and a small white head. An aroma of hops and caramel. A flavor of hops, malt and lightly of caramel and grain. Light finish. Wasn't terribly impressed
This is what I call a good beer. It has a good taste, however not hopped enough. Overall this is a good heavy beer.
eh not BAD persay but wasn't worth getting my fake id taken the first time I tried to sample it

Yep, serious caramel malts alright, and unfortunately pretty weakly hopped. But the worst thing (and on balance this was quite drinkable) was the corny, super grainy way it warmed up. Hmmm. Not too crisp and clean.

Great mouth feel but really not very flavorful. Sean was reaching hard to find those sesame tones. I also feel he spent an inordinate amount of time studying the label in order to give you all a "proper" description ...

You really can't comment on this brew without mentioning the titillating label on the bottled version. I hear the brewer's wife modeled for it, but I suspect they augmented her natural endowments somewhat. If not for her well placed suspender straps, this thing would be soft porn brew. Before you fall all over yourselves trying to get a bottle, though, here is what it drinks like: rounded, toasted sesame malt flavour in a decent body - not as substantial as the label might suggest, but a decent body, to be sure.
Probably the best beer they have. If you are a fan of heavy beer, this is their best.

Good amber beer. One of the more pleasant one's from my perspective. I have had both this and their Salt City Slugger and have thought both are excellent. Haven't had the Broken Putter yet. Strong flavor from an amber.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub on Hilton Head. Called "Reggie" there - although this may be a slightly different batch, am still lumping together. Lightly fruity. Citrus. Some biscuity malt. Decent. 13

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: At the brewery. Actually called "the folly" And it's a doubleipa. Pours murky yellow. In your face citrus and pine hops. Mellows out after a few sips. ---Rated via Beer Buddy

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Part of the sampler in my recent visit. This was the worst of the bunch (perhaps tied with the Pale Ale, but I am too lazy to add the beer). Possible infection does not help the case for this brew. Light grain/cereal with some notes of light butter and mild hops. All in all the would have been a drain pour had it not been for the only 2 ounces I received in the flight. Based on other reviews I apparently had a bad batch of a already mediocre beer. Which makes me kind of upset that they sold me the beer.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours a hazy golden color with a medium sized white head. The aroma and flavor have some sweet citrus, floral notes, dry toastedmalt with mmoderate bitterness to the finish. This just seemed to be lacking compared to other local IPAs on the island.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Narrow pils glass sample, approximately 3 oz, draft at the brewpub in Hilton Head Island, South Carolina. The pour is a light haze orange golden with a white head and a bunch of thick lacing. The aroma is soft floral and citrus orange hops. The taste is bitter, dusty grain, then the orange citrus fruit sweetness. The palate is medium to light bodied with soft carbonation and a dry mineral bitter finish. Just an OK IPA, didn�t use or manage the dry Bitterness that well.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draft - pours deep gold with white head and good lacing. Flavor is grassy, floral and a tad piny. Bitter in moderate fashion.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: On tap. 6.3% ABV. Hazy golden pour with a fluffy white top. Scent is citrus and grainy. Taste is citrus with a piney bitter finish.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draft sampler at the brewpub. Nice hoppy/grapefruit/malt aroma, small white head that slowly left with good lacing, clear golden hue, light body, satisfactory hoppy taste with fair malt balance. Tasted on July 8, 2012.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Enjoyed on-tap @ the Hilton Head Brewing Co in Hilton Head Island, SC for $5. Tapped from the non-labeled silver tap handle into a 16oz Pint Glass. Aroma- American hops are first to hit the nose and then has a very sweet and malty background. An average IPA aroma is found here. Appearance- Received with a .5 finger head that dies very quickly. Has a clear, golden body with some copper included. Leaves good lacing behind. Flavor- A faint dry hopped flavor is the first thing I notice. Malts are stronger than the hops coming in very sweet. Light-Medium bitterness. Mouthfeel- Light-Medium Bodied, Medium-High Carbonation, sweet, and tons of wheat on the finish... Not sure I can appreciate this. Watered down as well. Overall Impression- The aroma and appearance are well done but then the American IPA taste and mouthfeel just isn�t there. You can be cheap on the crystal malts while brewing the beer but not the hops when it comes to this style... Definitely reminds me of Schlafly�s Yakima Wheat which isn�t close to the style.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: The aroma has hops, but fairly indistinguishable hops. The appearance is nice - copper colored with a fluffy white head. The flavor is of more indistinguishable hops ... grassy? It also lacks the malt to balance it. Not a fan ...

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Coppery, a little thin. Wheat�s aren�t my favorite and this did nothing to win me over either. But it wasn�t really objectionable either. Just not much there to speak for it. Weak tasting.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: Has a light copper appearance, just a litle bit of a wispy white head. No real aroma detected. Has a muted banana-like flavor with a little bit of bubble gum action going on as well. Rather bland overall.

column2: Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, United States
column5: American style wheat beer. Not very complex, and looks a little watery. Decent thirst quencher, though the aftertaste is a bit chalky.

column1: Foxburg Inn Silver Fox Red Amber
column5: Sampled on draft at the Allegheny Grille (formerly Foxburg Inn) this beer poured a dark brown color with orange highlights and only a touch of a tan head that faded quickly. The aroma was light fruit and cola. The flavor was cherry, cola, tangy sour nut and a bit of wood. The finish was medium length tangy nut, fruit and wood. Medium body. Decent.

column1: Foxburg Inn Silver Fox Red Amber
column5: Draught. I had to recheck with the waitress to make sure I was drinking the original Silver Fox Red Amber that I had heard so much about. My wife�s iced tea had more head. Minimal aroma from virtually no carbonation. Taste wasn�t bad, something like caramel malts, with hardly any hop bitterness. The waitress said all the beers served were headless! I was extremely disappointed.

column1: Foxburg Inn Silver Fox Red Amber
column5: Draght. Great color once again as it poured a light ruby with not much carbonation and a diminishing head. A little malt sweetness coupled with slight taste of hops, but not much. Finished OK with a smoothness that forced me to try another. Not bad stuff. Great place to overlook the Allegheny River here in Western PA.

column1: Foxburg Inn Silver Fox Red Amber
column5: Nice red/amber color. Limited head retention. Slightly sweet and malty. Not highly hopped. Smooth carbonation. Weak but clean aftertaste.
Light everything. Almost no taste, aroma, malt presence, or hop presence. Generic in every way.
Light aroma with an equally light flavor. Pretty ordinary pale lager but lacks the weird fruity flavor some cheaper pale lagers pocess.

Smelled like cake batter. Had some dryness to it, fruit, grain, and bakery. Looked no different than any macro. A little unusual flavor but nothing offensive. Slight watery mouth feel. Extremely quick finish. The flavor disappears immediately upon swallowing.

Bottle: The aroma is light and consists of grain, mustiness, and a touch of straw. It pours a pale yellow with a half inch white head that lasts a minute or so. The flavor starts lightly sweet with a touch of corn. The finish has some faint grain and grass notes. Pretty bland and pretty close to tasteless. Light bodied with lightly fizzy carbonation. Nothing offensive, so I suppose it could be an okay thirst quencher on a hot day.
Corn aroma. Pale yellow, headless. Light lemony tartness, weak malty finish. Weak.

Pillowy white head. Sweep hoppy aroma. Almost tastless aside a slightly sour fermented backdrop that is just enough to let you know you�re not drinking a club soda. A snap of tasty hops jump out towards the end of each sip, but it�s brief...very brief. Would be great for a college kid to throw in the line up somewhere between the 3rd or 4th Bud Light.

From bottle. Stale metallic aroma, with some corny notes and oxidized hops. Light sweet pale corn-malt notes. Pale yellow clear, dull, with thin white foamy dissipating head. Medium-light watery body with medium-high carbonation. Starts a bit sweet, with corn and mild pilsner malt. Light carbonic acidity and mild fruity hops to it. Finish is lightly sweet, fairly clean, with a mild bitterness. Mostly dull. Reminds me a lot of the pale lagers of Europe. Cold is better for these.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Trader Joes (Short Pump), 12/14/09 Aroma: Aroma has some stale grain, crackers, some floral Appearance: Pours a clear, pale yellow color with a wispy white head Flavor: Taste is weak, some sweet macro-like flavor, very mild hops Palate: The body if this one is very light, almost non-existant Overall Impression: I didn�t realize when it said "ordinary" on the bottle they were making an attempt to compliment their beer, but ordinary would certainly be a compliment to this weak attempt at a beer. It will remind most of your standard macro swill. Don�t bother...

Very mediocre. "Ordinary" is hardly something to shoot for among beers, but this didn�t even stand equal to most "ordinary" beers I�ve tasted. Thin, watery, and more reminiscent of a BMC beer than something you�d expect to find amidst a decent selection.
Bottle. 12 oz. Honestly, one of the worst beers I have ever tasted. Pure garbage. Aroma smelled like straight urine. I had to pour it out. Avoid at all costs.

Pale golden color,small white head that gave a pathetic shot at hanging around but failed.The aroma was weak,fruity and mild hops with a slight thin feeling aroma for the style.A bit of a lemony citrus taste mild malt at best with a mild hop presence.Over all this is a weak version of the style.It was a poor attempt but worth atleast trying once and little else,don't go out of your way to find this brew but for me this was a decently priced brew from the beergeek.FREE,due to screw up on my order.
Pale colden color with white head and some lacing. Slightly cloudy. Nice aroma with a touch of fruitiness. Taste is well balanced, noticable hops and a bit of fruit in the finish.

5/1/03: bottle. slightly cloudy body with a golden yellow coloration. stinky hop aroma-very distinctive. sticky lemon-honey tasting with a lingering hop flavor. there is a touch of bitterness in the finish.
Yucky yellow pour, semi-thick head. More of a lager feel to this. Not a good APA.

Another below-average Trader Joe''s beer. I am glad these were available as 77 cent singles. This is easily the uglist APA I have ever seen. It pours a dark yellow with a medium thick off-white head. Some effervescence but the strange coloring really threw me. Aroma is lightly hopped not unlike a regular Lager. Flavor is really bland and uninspired. Chicago deserves a better tribute beer.

You can always count on Trader Joe's to stock a fine selection of boring beer. "Extra" pale? Should be "incredibly" pale. Looks like a lager, light gold. Nasty scent, smells a bit skunky, like a bad pilsner. First taste is like a cheap lager, bit tart and sour. Finish actually gets some expected pale ale hoppiness, though not much. Really tastes like someone tossed a few hops into a bucket full of Stella Artois. Blech.
It's a funny combination of hoppy and watery. Not bad for a cheap(ish) local brew.

column1: Rio Salado Tornado Helles Bock Pale Lager
column5: 12oz bottle(10/02)-A golden body with a decent head and an aroma of malts. Taste the same with some sweetness. The alcohol was hidden very well. Nice tasting brew.

column1: Rio Salado Tornado Helles Bock Pale Lager
column5: Courtesy of Boackyhorsey. Huge sourdough bread aroma. Cloudy orange with a big two ginger head that stays firm as you drink it. Sour fore with some sweetness in the middle, orange citrus, and a crisp abrupt finish. Alcohol is well hidden as it does not feel at all like 8%

column1: Rio Salado Tornado Helles Bock Pale Lager
column5: Bottle. Had an almost stale malty aroma. Gold color with decent head that dimmished to a thin layer on top of beer. With thin dimmishing heads on beer seems to bring a lot of lacing, this one didn�t. Sweet hop flavor that went down good on the palate. Decent beer.

column1: Rio Salado Tornado Helles Bock Pale Lager
column5: tap at taphouse-tempe, AZ-pours a light apricot hue with a nice foamy white head. big diacytl aroma and lager characteristics (german hops and malts). man, thats buttery. flavors are mostly diacytl and some lager notes as well. man, this is bad!

column1: Rio Salado Tornado Helles Bock Pale Lager
column5: Mine poured a big thick head,,NICE! light malt aroma,cloudy golden darker amber color,,lingering after taste,,good beer.

column1: Rio Salado Tornado Helles Bock Pale Lager
column5: Bottle. Pours a cloudy (barely but noticeable) neon-yellow/golden color with a medium head that fell to a nice layer of lace. A few bubbles continually floated to the top, but it did not look to be over carbonated. Initial aroma is very fresh, very light and subtle sweet malt, with ever so slight hints of fruit, and wet hay. The alcohol is masked very well for having 8%. Flavor is quite sweet; good hop (flower buds) flavor, strong malt base, and a yeasty tangy finish. It all works very well, and is quite refreshing to drink. Body is medium, and the carbonation dances on your tongue, it might swallow a little chalky, but still a very solid beer. Would Buy Again.

column1: Rio Salado Tornado Helles Bock Pale Lager
column5: Clear golden color. Sweet fruity-malty aroma. Sweet initial taste almost cherry-like. A little bitter on the palate, semi smooth on the mouthfeel. Interesting character. The aftertaste lingers. Different yet somewhat appealing.

column1: Rio Salado Tornado Helles Bock Pale Lager
column5: clear crisp and strong with a nice hoppy bite a and a dry clean finish that really makes u think why would one come out with a srping ale in a state with only 2 seasons

column1: Rio Salado Tornado Helles Bock Pale Lager
column5: bottle: clear yellow w/ a frothy head. Malty on the tongue w/ some sweetness. Nice

column1: Rio Salado Tornado Helles Bock Pale Lager
column5: Draft. A nice looking beer. Pale, clear yellow. Smallish head. Slightly sweet aroma. And a sweet start that quickly became, alternatingly, Hay, horseblanket, and a fresh barnyard. Not one I'd seek out again.
One of the better Draught House beers. Not great but above average for a brown ale. Goes down very smooth.
Not at all bad, but nothing special. I would drink this before a newcastle for sure. Pleaseantly sweet malt taste with slight notes of caramel. Easy finish.

Ohh man I get sooo excited when I know they�ve got his bad boy on tap. Its an IPA on nitrogen. Weird right!. Probablydisgusting right? Not a chance. Pours a lovely pale straw color with a giant massive foamy head. Nose is of lavender, rose, saffron and even a bit of hops just ever so slightly bitter on the nose. In the mouth it is exquisite. Malt dominates at first. Vanilla character followed by a nice robust straw flavor. This fades into a slightly bitter hop that is really more floral than anything else. Excellent brew grat
One of the best beers to come out of this place. Floral hops finish this beer with a nice transition from the malty beginning.

Perhaps the best appearance of any beer ever. Huge head that had a multi-colored thing going on, It was white on top, then tan, then the beer was amber. The tan part faded in about a minute but it was still cool. Unfortunately the appearance was the only remarkable part of this beer. The mouthfeel was almost slimy like their century ale, and the hops were floral but weak in both the aroma and the flavor.
Very good IPA. Had a slightly malty start, then the hops came out. The hops were grassy and floral but werent overpowering....they had a nice flavor. Finish wasnt overly bitter too.
A very malty, dark stout. Full head, very easy drinking and a nice finish. Another quality beer made in Milwaukee!

On tap at the pub. Clear straw color, small diminishing head. Pleasant sweetish grainy aroma; flavor has more hop accent than malt, though there is significant sweetness upfront. At the end it turns fairly bitter for a lager; it is altogether average or slightly below throughout, and should be avoided by those who do not wear backwards baseball caps and do not think of drinking simply as "get hammered" time.

"L�bzer Bock", Flasche von REWE, Forst. - Kupferrot, blank. - In der Nase kr�ftige karamellige Herbe, Malzbonbons, bittere Nu� und schale, leicht chlorige Hopfenherbe. - Antrunk gut malzbitter mit Malzkaffee, Karamel, gebranntem Zucker, Lakritz, ein wenig Trockenobst. Dezent s��, zart s�uerlich. Aromenarme, schwach ranzige Hopfenextraktherbe. Gut rezent, f�r einen Bock schlank; der Alkohol kommt recht deutlich durch. Im Abgang trocken malzbitter und nur bla� hopfenherb. - Ganz auf Malzbittere setzender, bla� gehopfter Industrie-Bock; eher billig gemacht. F�r Wirkungstrinker. (30.10.2019.)
Red wine type aroma, good fruit overtones. Deep red hue and nice foam. Nice strong and complex flavor. Happy aftertaste.
A scottish ale flavor, little hops, slightly sweetened malt. Decent........
A classic dark beer taste. Nothing too special. Nice coffee bean aftertaste.
Worth every shilling! Very smooth and malty with a roasted coffee flavor that pops up here and there. Dark color and thin head, this is a great Scottish Ale.
On draft at Rowley's a week and a half ago. Tasty Irish Red. Went great with the poutine and pierogies.
Bottle. Sweet, malty, full-bodied ale. It�s missing an interesting finish. Reminds me of ales before so many of the offerings went to the hoppy, cities spectrum. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pint at Winking Lizard Peninsula Ohio, Draft. Malty aromas Thin white head, some film on glass. Very smooth and malty. Could drink a lot of this one at one setting. Light brown, reddish in color. Very nice offering from the Dog. Cheers!
red color; bready, malty aroma; bready malt flavor with caramel notes; fairly light bodied

Bottle. Nose a little vegetal, a little weedy (not the kind with THC). Pour deep and hazy blend of reddish amber and brown, abundant carbonation and a large but airy and foamy beige head. Taste lightly sweet, lightly dry, medium bitterness starts slow but sneaks up on you, harsh dark caramel with interesting scored notes, and the sweetness transcends fruit into hard candy. So a lot of aggressive caramel malt, which works well here, but a little herbal-grassy clash. Full body picks up cloy with volume. Not a disaster, but it�s a hard pass. [2016.08.03: 2.6]

12 ounce bottle - $2.49 at Total Wine & More in Greenville, South Carolina. Appearance: Pours a clear, dark reddish-copper body with a reluctant, stray, off-white head. Smell: Fairly neutral aroma, small touches of toast, brown sugar and a thin measure of earthiness. Taste: A thinned taste of toast with a little grain backing. Lightly sweet with some hints of dry brown sugar. A mixed, vaguely berryish fruitiness. Very minor hops, softly earthy and just a bit spicy with near nil bitterness imparted. Fairly relaxed, mild finish that�s a wee bit drying. Mouthfeel: Light-bodied. Medium carbonation. Overall: A refreshing, easy-going, harmless red.
Toasty sweet hop note on a copper body. Quite drinkable, floral hop finish.

Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. This beer has a roasted malt aroma that matches nicely with the reddish / amber color of the beer. The head is a medium sized tan colored head. The flavor is full of malt and some hops in the background. I found this to be a thoroughly refreshing brew. I am glad I tried it and I will drink it again.

Pours a light color with very little foam on the head. Has a light caramel malt taste and doesn�t have a very dry aftertaste. Aroma is light and has a regular beer smell to it. Overall it�s good and I recommend giving it a try.

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, no bottle dating. Pours slightly hazy deep orange/copper color with a 1-2 finger dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of caramel, toast, biscuit, brown sugar, light nuttiness, light pear/apple, herbal, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready malt, earthy hops, and light fruity yeast notes; with good strength. Taste of big caramel, toast, biscuit, brown sugar, light nuttiness, light pear/apple, herbal, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Light herbal bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, toast, biscuit, brown sugar, light nuttiness, herbal, and yeast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice robustness, complexity, and balance of dark/bready malt, earthy hops, and light fruity yeast flavors; with a good malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Nicely clean with well restrained yeast ester notes in the aroma and flavors. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth and moderately creamy/bready mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent Irish red ale style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, earthy hops, and light fruity yeast flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink for the ABV. A very enjoyable offering.

This draft brew from the brewery poured a medium sized head of finely sized mostly diminishing white colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing. The body contained unnoted carbonation, was unnoted and unnoted in color. Its aroma contained notes of very mild malt hop . Its mouth feel is initially tingly mild bubbly with a lingering slightly tingly mellow palate and a fading aftertaste. Its flavor contained mild malt hop notes. Good for a light lager.
Dayton draft. Amber color with a small white head. Light aroma with a sweet tone. Flavor was medium with a short sweet finish. Better than the airship light but still to light for me.
(Dayton) Pale straw body with white head. Aroma is mild, medium sweet, bread. Taste is medium sweet, bread, no bitterness. Light body.

Rated at TDBC. Small white head that completely diminished, fine sized bubbles, good lacing, uncarbonated, transparent, and a yellow hue. Malty, sweet aroma. Sweet, malty and smooth flavor. Smooth mouthfeel. Light body.
Very light and refreshing with a touch of sweetness. This beer went down smooth and is a good beer for drinking on a hot day
Bright yellow color is not appealing from the start. Surprising touch of hops towards the end. Weak and thin. This is a swilling beer for a masses.
this reminded me of everything that is bad about american lagers. It was vile, evil and tasteless...
Too light for my taste. Not realy bad just realy bland......................
Very much on the light side with a subtle malty sweetness to it. Not the runt of the litter, but not much better.
Man's best friend, is unfortunately, a fluffy little yipping pup with a medium/thin body, sweet malts and short finish. little or no aroma.

This draft brew from the brewery poured a medium sized head of fine to medium sized mostly lasting off-white colored bubbles that left behind a good lacing. The body contained soft carbonation, was transparent and caramel brown in color. Its aroma contained notes of mild nutty brown malt with some mild roasted chocolaty notes . Its mouth feel is with a palate and a aftertaste. Its flavor contained nice nutty malty notes and was tasty. An above average brew.

Had this on draft at the Thirsy Dog in Dayton. The beer is a deep reddish brown with a light brown head. There was a malty aroma with a nut like hint. A medium body wich starts off with a nutty like taste and finishes with a bit of malty sweetness.
Dayton draft. Color was reddish brown with a medium tan head. Complex medium aroma of malt. Medium flavor and body that produce a medium sweet finish. Good match to style.
(Dayton) Crystal clear copper with off-white head. Aroma is medium sweet, biscuit. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, nutty, milk chocolate. Light-medium body. Tasted too sweet to me.

Rated at TDBC. Small off-white head that mostly diminished, sparse lacing, transparent, and a brown hue. Malty, caramel and a little sweaty sock aroma. Sweet, malty and caramel flavor. Fairly smooth mouthfeel. Light-medium body.
Pretty decent sweet malty flavor. I�ve had better versions of this style, but I sure wouldn�t turn down another one of these if offered. Had this on tap in Canton also.
Pretty uneventful beer - harmless and acessible to the masses. Weak nose, pale brown color, sticky head. Roasted malt taste burried deep in a thin body. Candy-like sweetness in the finish.
very nutty. Iffy on the ale part, but at least they tried. I could drink this because i like the style, but the beer itself did not impress
Sweet nutty flavor, some carmel, the sweetness almost taste fruity, moderate body. Oily mouthfeel. I thought this was Okay, but not one that I go out of my way to have again.
Slightly watery version of the clasic brown ale. Still decent with slightly sweet malts coming in. Faint nose.
Solid beer! Very dark and toasty. Very full flavor without being syrupy or overly thick. Nice.

Pours a dark brown. Almost opaque. Light to medium body. Notes of chocolate and coffee. Very sweet but that is nicely balanced by a lingering light bitter finish. A solid example of the style though not a stand out. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On draft at J.B. Quimby's. Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. Taste is mildly sweet with a bitter finish

From Aug 2007 Yet another sample I got in trade with Wasatch. Thanks, John! It pours from the 12oz bottle a very dark brown with some reddish hues and a tiny head of foam that dissipated quickly. There's just some spotting and a little bit of lacing. The smell has a nice roasted and caramel malt nose to it. The taste starts off with a good chocolate malt flavour and it's pretty sweet but then the roasted malt moves in and cuts down on the sweetness a bit and that improves the taste and drinkability for me. I pulled this straight out of the fridge, not my usual modus operendi, so I'm going to take small sips and see what happens when it gets closer to room temp. It's now warmed up some and nothing's really changed. I'd have to say that this is a pretty good sample of the style, not overly complex yet a solid interpretation and I'd gladly drink it again if I was offered one.

Light, sweet chocolate coffee aroma, pours dark brown, medium mouthfeel, bitter malts on the back of your throat, mild toffee sweetness throughout, more like a health bar followed with some coffee. bottle.
A solid porter. Faint aromas of dark chocolate. Flavors of water coffee, some mild dark chocolate, earth, and woody notes. Earthy, dry finish is semi-sweet. Oily mouth feel. Enjoyable.
Dark brown color. Thin, beige head. Milk chocolate and roasted malt in aroma. Sweet ,malty taste with roasted bitterness at the end. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Deep brown, basically black with a cream head. Rich chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts. Smooth palate, heavy roasted malts up front, light chocolate, coffee in the finish.

Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head which disappears quickly.....aroma is chocolate, sweet malt, slight coffee.....taste follows the aroma with a medium thin body and slight bittering on the back end.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle. Brown, moderately heady pour with reddish hues. The aroma has a kind of cherry fruitiness at first along with the roasted sweet malts and a low hop profile. The body is light to medium and smooth. The taste also has a sweet cherry-like character with a slightly fruity short lasting bitterness to end.
Smells like raspberry tea...taste is milky and smooth...great mouthfeel...sweet flavor with good complexity..very malty with grape flavor...no bitterness...quite good!

If you like fruit beers then this is you. Pours up a crystal clear golden color with a red hue. Large white head. Super fresh raspberry aroma. Taste has lots of raspberry. Not overly sweet. Mild funk. Truly awesome beer.
A killer fruit beer. Beautiful burnished striking golden pour with a creamy rocky head. Fresh raspberry jam aroma jumps from the glass. Bright and juicy. No fake fruit flavors.
Draft at the brewery. Poured a clear golden yellow color with a small fizzy white head. Aroma was a lot of raspberries. Sweet malts, some grassy notes. Flavor was raspberry, light sweetness.

Bottle. Pours light gold with flakes of sediment and a thin white head. Medium to high carbonation. Aroma of raspberries and bread. Flavors are raspberry, sweet malt, bread, dry grass, and a subtle metallic taste. Mild bitterness. Lively mouthfeel. Not bad, but not terribly exceptional.

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, no bottle dating. Pours slightly hazy/cloudy pale golden/straw/light pinkish color with a 1-2 finger dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of juicy/lightly tart raspberries, fruit seeds, peach, pear, apple, wheat, cracker, lightly toasted bread, light honey, herbal, grass, and yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance of raspberries, pale malt, and light fruity yeast/earthy hop notes; with solid strength. Taste of big juicy/lightly tart raspberries, fruit seeds, peach, pear, apple, wheat, cracker, lightly toasted bread, light honey, herbal, grass, and yeast earthiness. Slight herbal bitterness and fruit tartness on the finish. Lingering notes of raspberries, fruit seeds, peach, pear, apple, wheat, cracker, lightly toasted bread, light honey, herbal, grass, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice robustness and balance of raspberries, pale malt, and light fruity yeast/earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitter/tartness balance; and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light dryness from bitter/tartness as well. Medium carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth, fairly creamy/grainy, and slightly acidic/sticky balanced mouthfeel that is nice. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 3.9%. Overall this is a very nice fruit beer. All around nice robustness and balance of raspberries, pale malt, and light fruity yeast/earthy hop flavors; very smooth and refreshing to drink. Very flavorful for the low ABV, and never watery feeling. A very enjoyable offering.

12 ounce bottle at home. Love the aroma. Strong scent of raspberries. Watching the light carbonation bubble in the glass upward this medium straw like color beer is refreshing. You can taste the raspberries in this easy drinking beer. Overall this is a nice beer and would be great at a summer picnic. Lightly malted, lightly hopped.

Pours a clear pale pinkish yellow with a thin white head. Very nice sweet and tart raspberry aroma. Thin body. Taste is light and not as good as the smell. Raspberry falls flat. Not as good as I expected.

This draft brew from the brewery poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized long lasting off-white colored bubbles that left behind an excellent lacing. The body contained average carbonation, was transparent and light yello brown in color. Its aroma contained notes of mild hops. Its mouth feel is initially smooth asnd was very smooth for an IPA but came on strong in the finish Its flavor contained caramel hoppy notes. A very average brew.

IThere is something about the flavor of their beers that I just don�t like. that being said I feel as though this is the best of a buch of mediocre brews. It has decent flavor with mild hoppiness and a slightly dry finish. Overall-OK.
Dayton draft. Aroma was hoppy in style with IPA with a sweet tone. Flavor was complex hops, malt and a medium sweet finish. Medium in body and was a very pleasing brew.

On tap at Dayton location. Piney, fruity, and grassy hop aroma. Very hazy orange-amber color, off-white head. Nice hop flavor, piney and citrusy, moderately fruity, caramel malt comes through, solid bitterness. Medium-full body, smooth. Not a bad IPA.

(Dayton) Hazy amber body with off-white head, nice lacing. Aroma is moderately sweet, floral, caramel. Taste is moderately sweet, floral, chocolate, caramel. Watery light-medium body. For some reason, the body and taste seem at odds with one another.

Rated at TDBC. Medium sized ivory head that mostly diminished, fine-medium sized bubbles, good lacing, uncarbonated, and cloudy. Malty, hoppy, sweet aroma. The flavor was sweet, caramel, malty and hoppy. Tingly, hoppy mouthfeel. Light body.
Underrated - a classic English fruitiness (Fuggle?) and toasty malt - of course this is not a regular IPA - an appealing and well-put together, minerally version.

On tap at the Dayton location. So this is an IPA, and Hoppus Maximus is an English Pale Ale? Something seems screwy. In any event, this beer lacked character IMO. Looked just like Hoppus Maximus in the glass, with a clear copper body and a medium light tan head. In contrast to Hoppus, the aroma here is subtle, with earthy hops and caramel. The flavor is actually malt-dominated, with classic Thirsty Dog caramels and light fruit interplaying with the rather subdued English hops, which left an earthy, slightly bitter aftertaste. Although quaffable this is not a very distinctive brew.
Stinging hoppiness in the middle of the taste profile from an odd blend of hops. No wonder the hop aroma comes out in the nose. Not a good IPA at all - just not convincing.
Not much of an aroma. Tasted more like a Pale Ale to me. The bitterness was light even for an English IPA. Some acidy on the finish

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Anvilhead Unfiltered Ale--Spring Selection--2001 12 oz. Bottle. 5.60% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) ESB? Clear rich amber color. Light sediment. Amarillo hops. Earthy sweet unique floral hop front. Rich semi sweet caramel malt body with light earthy notes. Mild citrus hop spice end and lingering doughy malt. Sampled 4/4/2001. Anvilhead Unfiltered Ale--Spring Seasonal--2002 12 oz. Bottle. 5.60% ABV. (4.25 / 5.0) Amber Ale? Slightly hazy rich amber color. Malty toasted floral Amarillo hop front. Sweet thick toasted biscuit caramel fruit body with rich unfiltered texture. Lacy head. Malty balanced mild hop end. Sampled 9/8/2002.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Had this beer in 12/5/2001. Aroma is a fresh hoppy scent. Color is a nice golden brown with good carbonation and a nice head. Taste is hoppy, mild and smooth. Starting with a easy medium body it goes down smooth with a nice hop flavor coming out. Finish is mild with a creamy malt flavor with fresh hops and a slight bitterness. Overall I feel it is a good drinking beer but just not fresh and crisp enough for a Spring brew.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: From a 12 oz. stubby brown bottle with a blurb about the ale on the back label and no freshness date. Made a good appearance, poured a semi-hazy amberish copper with a foamy off-white goldenish head that reduced to a thin, bubbly lacing. Had a caramel malty aroma with whiffs of citrus/fruity hops and a bready yeastiness. Good carbonation and a slick light to medium bodied mouth feel, good drinkability. Had a big citrus fruity hop taste, a mellow bitterness, with a underlining sweet bready maltiness and a crisp soft sour finish. A decent Amber Ale from Grant�s, not their best hop-upped ale, but very drinkable.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Bottle: Aroma is bready with moderate cookie maltiness and a touch of flowery hops. Pours a transparent amber with a yellowish off-white head that diminishes quickly. Toffee flavors up front are instantly dominated by a sour and nutty hop finish Not what I was expecting in an APA.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: got this in a trade and cannot remember who sent it. thanks any way. from the bottle , poured a copper ambe with off white head. aroma malts and hops, caramel, hints of grapefruit. flavor, malts, caramel, some toffee, floral hops, a little on the watery side but not to bad.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Not really sure what this one�s trying to be, but it does not possess the qualities of an amber ale; not that that is a bad thing. Pours an almost brown color with a decent heda. Smells citrussy with some grapefruit undertones. Finishes floral with some wildflower like qualities and some tastes I cannot quite place.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Started a beautiful cauldron or rusty orange, fomenting into a solid overcast of head. Interesting aroma, almost pepperoni-like. Quite metallic tone on the palate (is the anvil IN the beer?), a sweet and sour hop-malt balance and a spicy little finish. Pretty good ...

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: An excelent head on this one, with a nice amber color. Good hop nose and taste. Caramel malts and barley come into play wuickly. There is a playoff between the sweetness of the caramel and the sour of the hops, which makes for a very good beer.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Cloudy amber... beige head... sweet aroma.. light body... light creamy palate almost watery.... nothing to redeaming about this beer.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: pours amber, big white head. toasted bready malt and caramel in the aroma and flavour with a bit of fruity/spicy hops. flavour is fruity with some nutty hints and a bit of roast. not bad.

Coarse foam that quickly flares out to small foam islets. Aroma is malt and dark caramel, but in a slightly synthetic manner. The taste is caramel, a little light bread and again a synthetic malt. The hops bitterness is flat and moderate and adds no rescue to this too sweet beer. The overall impression is discount and bad raw materials. Not a beer I would recommend.

Marielyst 21/10 2017. 33 cl bottle from Meny. Black label with the mandatory mug of beer and a handful of medals. Pours clear light amber with small white head. Settles as thin layer of foam barely covering the surface of the beer. Moderate Lacing, Aroma is quite generic and exactly what I would expect from a cheap Vienna which usually goes under the description "Classic" in Denmark. Grainy and sweetish with caramel and brown sugar. Sourish notes. Medium carbonation and thin watery palate. Flavor is medium sweet with only very light bitterness for balance. Aftertaste is sweet caramel. What could be expected from a cheap Danish Vienna. Not too bad when you drink it cold.

Been there done that. Clear golden color with a decent white head. Moderate intensity in the aroma. Medium body and an ok carbonation. Tad sweet and a moderate bitterness. Some sweet Danish fruits (corn), kind of bready and grassy flavor. [Bottle from a local grocery store in Copenhagen, Denmark]

Having to rate this from memory as it is now retired. So I will simply say that I had this at the brewery whilst on holidays and liked it so much, that upon returning to the mainland, I ordered a case as soon as it was available. Great beer, reminiscent of an IPA but not as potent. Hops, fresh hops and more hops.
On tap at kilsyth club bad micro aroma deep amber in colour white head taste is ok simlar to fat yak but for an annual release a little too boring
Meh, not that great, not that bad. I won�t be buying it again in a hurry, but if I had to drink it I wouldn�t cry.
Light amber, faint crackery hop. A bit of toasty character but with not much hop. Ok macro amber but that�s below my expectations.
Pours a clear amber colour with a white head. Aroma is malt, some light fruit and mild hops. Taste is light sweet with a light bitter finish. OK.
Sparkling amber,fast fading beige head.Salty stale beer nose,malty hints.Lightly skunked start,mild metallic hop finish I know this bottle is several months old, so this may not be a fair rating

First rating Draught at Belgian Beer Cafe Eureka, Southbank - Melbourne, on July 30, 2013. Clear copper color, big white head. Malty, hoppy, bitter taste. Medium mouthfeel, high bitterness. Resin aftertaste. Sweet, malty, hoppy scent. 7/4/8/3/15=3.7 Rerate Draught at Cascade Visitor Centre, South Hobart. As part of a tasting paddle after the brewery tour. Sampled on August 8, 2013. Info that it was made May 15th, 2013. Clear deep golden color, white head. Hoppy, fruity, bitter taste. Bitter, fruity aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness. Sweet, malty, a bit fruity sent. 7/4/7/3/13=3.4

2013 batch on tap at the brewery. Made with fresh hops, which is reflected by taste. A strong hoppy aftertaste released strong citrus flavours and hop bitterness. Some lemon and grapefruit. Dark yellow in colour, light bodied with medium carbonation. A better effort for a large brewery like Cascade.

2013 Limited Release. Poured a clear dark amber colour with a two-finger light beige coloured foamy head that collapsed slowly and provided soap suds like lacing. Medium carbonation as seen by lots of small to medium bubbles forming trails. Aroma of slightly sourish malt. Taste initially of malt sweetness followed by a mild hops bitterness, much like many other macro-brewery lagers. Light body, bordering on watery. Long mildly bitter finish. Worth trying once.

2013 Vintage. On tap. Pours a dark amber with a good deal of foamy white head. Nose is grapefruit hops and some floral notes. Taste is lemon, grapefruit, some residual malty sugar and a crisp biscuit finish. Body is watery and thin. The aroma is passable but the taste is just boring and generic. Honestly, I�m not sure who they�re targeting with this beer. It�s the sort of thing that has potential, but after trying it once I now know to never have it again. They could have built a sort of cult following with this one, but instead they put in their standard level of effort ie. none.

oude rating, toen van tap in Uitwellingerga, proeverij, verder niet te veel van opgeschreven toendertijd, was ook niet zo bijzonder dus. maar heb toen de hele serie wel geproefd, noteer ze dan nu ook maar als zijnde �gedronken� ga op �t gemiddelde zitten om de boel niet te verstoren
Bottle in Schierminnekoog. Probably my favourite of the three Waddenbiers I tried there but not great either. Buttery and yeasty. This beers have a medicinal feel to them. Bitterness in the finish.
Beer gushes heavily out of the bottle. Buttery aroma. Thick and oily beer. Malty taste, bit tart, with liquorice and coffee. Slight bitter and porto finish.
Pitcher from the brewery. Big but semi lasting white head. Cloudy yellow color. A bit wicked aroma and taste. Still a interesting and enyoable beer with a big maltiness and a firm bitterness.
Orange amber with white fluff head. Light nose with some malts and a refreshing summery taste. Light and easy drinking. Well brewed but not a sensation. The experience at Brauberger is though.
Yellow light beer without bitterness. Get one if you can. Nice and cozy atmosphere in a cellar like room.
Growler from Palle. Cloudy yellow with a lasting white head. Aroma of malt and herbal hops, with a lot of sulphur. Sweet malty and fruity flavour.
Its a great beer. Go drink it if youre in Lubeck. Its a good beer to drink alot of!
Literfles van de Brouwerij. Troebel donkergeel, kraag verdwijnt snel. Ruikt moutig, maar ook zurig. Smaak is lichtmoutig, beetje zoet en ook wat zurig. Misschien niet vers genoeg gedronken.

Pours a cloudy golden amber color with a white head.Floral, caramel and biscuit aroma. Caramel, toffee, light floral hop and biscuit flavors. Medium light body and carbonation. Biscuit and caramel finish. On tap at the brewery.
On tap. Pours a hazy deep yellow color. Malty nose. Medium-bodied with a malty background.
On tap at the brewpub. Tr�bes dunkel goldenes Bier mit einer mittelgro�en wei�en schaumkrone. Geruch sehr getreidig, etwa Obst. Geschmack s�� malzig, sehr getreidig, wenig hopfig bitter.

25.07.2015. On tap at Braberger in L�beck. Amber pale brown colour with white head. Unclear. Aromas of malt. Not so fresh. Malty with moderate to low bitterness. Aftertaste is a littlemorebitter. Leaves a dry malty tounge. Ok.

Originally rated August 2006. Pours a golden-amber colour with a big off-white foamy head. This one stays a while and leaves decent lace all-around. Big alcohol nose, which is weird for not so high on the ABV chart. At least, the alcohol does not show in the taste. But then again, not much is there. Mild sweet malt, mild grain malt and mild corn in the aftertaste. Acceptable for swill, but trying to much to be fancy Bavarian-style and overpriced.
damn i forgot i had this, kinda yellowish thin head nose is a little grassy, kinda musty. Flavor is kinda malty, kinda boring
Pours a clear gold colour with a thin bubbly head. Grainy malt aroma. Slightly sweet malt taste but no great "world renown european hops" flavour jumps out at me. Lingering oiliness on the tongue.
Slightly fuller lager than usual. Mainly malt oriented .Light aftertaste. Medium bodied beer.

Slightly pale golden hue with a off white head. Very small scent of malt, mostly hops. The taste starts off surprizingly smooth with a somewhat balanced flavour of malt and hops but ends quick to a watery, cleaning solution, generic, commercial beer. Definately not the worst beer I have ever tasted. Sure as hell not the best.

Bright golden coloured brew with good carbonation. Head is thick to start but dissipates pretty quickly. Aroma is overpowered by alcohol content. Yes, 5.9% isn't that strong, but it's enough to kill this bouquet. Pretty hard to make out the reported Bavarian Hersbrucker hops in the flavour as well. Doppelgold is not one of Dave's better beers. (Is it that tough for a North American brewery to come up with a decent German lager or pils??) Check out Dave's Honey Brown instead... much, much better. (341ml bottle)

A nice, tight, off-white head sits atop a dark golden beverage. The grainy nose displays a sinus-clearing show of alcohol, with hints of malt and lemon straining out of the glass. Texture seems a little flat and thin on the tongue, while the flavour profile is thick with alcohol and not much else. Considering Doppelgold is only 5.9% alc./vol. � not overwhelmingly high when you think about it � there is a dizzying amount of sweet, heavy alcohol dominating the entire experience. Built for indiscriminate guzzlers looking for quick, cheap buzz.
dave get out of the beer business and get back to the grocery store, ur beer is shit

My favourite of the Dave beer family but that is like saying the best of the Lada automobiles. It really doesn''t quite cut it; who is this Dave that is taking my money? They should have a reimbursement policy for unsatisfied customers. They can call this Doppel-whatever but all it is is your standard boring beer. Fine to drink if you run out of something else at a party...
Bottled. Deep golden. Light apple aroma. Sweet and clean. medium bodied with low bitterness. Unremarkable...
Dave's is a peice of shit. How could molson try to market this crappy product.
I really wish Dave would go back to bagging groceries at the supermarket. Dave has lived his 15 minutes of fame...
There is nothing belgian about this at all. Pretty weak try at this one guys.
Sure beats me what is belgian about this beer. Maybe they used a little bit of belgian two rowe malt - wow! whatever. This is a simple light pale ale that is using the word belgian to shore up sales.
May be fuller and fruitier than a regular blond, but does not bear any resemblance to a true Belgian-style product
Very dark in colour, but only a lightly toasted flavour. More sweet than bitter. Very smooth. Quite drinkable if served ice cold.
Well, it's dark. That's about all this beer has going for it. Sweet and harsh. I guess that's where the "massive" comes in.
this is dave's worst beer product, even though his other one's are very shitty as well. People dont drink daves. Only bums drink Daves beer.
Absolutely horrible. Wanted to puke halfway through drinking it it tasted so bad...massively horrible is more like it.
All the massive irishmen I have met in my life would be sickened by this beer... Dave, get out of the business!
I agree with dhurtubise on this one... ouch Dark... Irish I don't know about that
Nice try dave. Typical of this guy to make a cheap beer and sell it cheap under the pretense that it is a premium product. Dark, sweet, lightly hopped. I wouldn't have it again.
dark colour, fine lace coffee aroma, toasted, smooth........................
Mild-tasting, but with a pleasing dark malt palate. I'm not sure that 'massive' is the operative word.
341ml brown bottle. Golden colour, somehwat frothy white head. Grainy aroma, corn? Fizzy, highly carbonated, gassy. Some grainy malt flavours, bland, no hops. Not that enjoyable, and not IPA.
First beer I ever had. All I remember is that I hated it. I almost never drank another beer because of this one, it deserves ones across the board, simply because of that.

Boo! Everyone is right, this is worse than keith�s. And that is tough to do. What was Dave thinking when he gave this stuff the green light? Almost no taste of hops, and the slightest aroma possible. Rough!
Old rating: Comparable to mainstream beers like Keith�s. A bit more fruity malts.
Where all those hops go? That golden lager, ahmm pale ale was strikingly similar to all those pale lagers I had that night.
It's an IPA like Alexnader Keith's is...in name only. No real hop flavour or aroma to speak of, just a pale bland beer with no aftertaste.

Okay swill,but kind of sweet. Decent enough on a hot day. I took a chance at this stuff since the last Dave's product I bought had a spider floating in it. That was the Cream Ale. This has a mild alcoholic taste to it... not a long lasting head. Sweet aroma just copy of Keiths thats all I can say. Competition.
with daves face on the bottle, to pale ale. this beer is calling for me to throw-up.

I think Dave wants me to puke! This is really a half-arsed effort; I want my money back! It isn''t Pale Ale but a blonde... and a terrible beer to boot! Overcarbonated, weak and finishes like a sweaty-sock.
this beer sucks, dave made it. good news is their taking daves product out of the beer stores.
Middle of the road, but not bad from Molson. I would buy it again...........
transparent red-amber colour, big head, aroma almost not distinctive, flat taste - boark ...

I was impressed with the lovely reddish-brown colour of this beer. This all-malt beer also contains some peated malt, perhaps just enough to give it a woody dryness. Crystal malts also make an appearance and the beer does, to its credit, transcend the typical "mainstream lager with slight modifications" character of so many big brewery attempts at craft beers
Nice color and taste, high graduation without really tasting it, to be industrial is a good choice
I tried the asian edition. Quite a good simple beer. Blurry thick. Simple but not bad.

Puszka. Aromat ledwie wyczuwalny. W smaku to, czego si� spodziewa�em - eurolager. W sumie nie jest nawet jako� specjalnie paskudny, ale czu� nieprzyjemne elementy, m.in. �elazo. Wypi� si� da, tylko po co?
0,33l can from Spain, enjoyed @ Uotila. Pours clear golden with a medium head. Aroma is malts. Flavor is clean malts with some hops. Decent.
Ich habe mir eins aus Spanien mitbringen lassen. Geschmacklich so lala. F�r ein Spanien Urlaub ok f�r mehr aber auch nicht. Farbe Gold mit kurzweiligen Schaum. Geschmacklich komisch s��
there�s nothing wrong with this beer. Clean crisp and quenching for a hot day, and better than North American versions of the style. Konsum dresden
Takie klasyczne piwko, pij� przy 30 stopniach a to zawsze dodaje do oceny. Poza tym to jest piwko kt�re cz�sto pije na wakacjach wi�c jest sentyment
Klasyczny eurolager, ca�kiem zno�ny, zimny bardzo dobrze orze�wia. Ma�a piana, w smaku wyczuwalna lekka goryczka i kukurydza, w zapachu delikatnie wybija si� trawa. Sza�u nie ma, ale da si� pi�.
Classic spanish lager, balanced aromas with a nice low carbonation, little caramel malty sweetness good from the 0.3 bottle Always a good choice
33 cl Kupljeno u omanjem ducanu u Anconi.. Dosta dobro lager pivo, ugodnog i finog okusa..svidja mi se..

Color amarillo oscuro, transparente. Espuma blanca, medianamente cremosa, de dos dedos de espesor y buena retenci�n. Aroma y sabor escaso, a cereal, notas met�licas, final corto ligeramente dulce, alcohol imperceptible. Textura acuosa. Carbonataci�n media.
It's very refreshing with a mild flavor and carbonation. Good beer to go with seafood
Bright and slightly pale yellow. Creamy head. Aroma is grass and pepper. Taste is pretty spicy and hoppy
Puszka. Badziewie pic tylko zimne albo jak najebany. Nie mia�em dost�pu do ktaftu a chcia�em odhaczyc ten kraj na RB i kupi�em to dziadostwo
Can from supermarket. Golden color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, malts, a bit of toast and grass. Bitter finish with citrus, malts, toast and grass. Basic bulk lager.
Ein weiteres Lagerbier, das sich in den Strom der einfachen Hellen mischt. Man macht nix falsch, bekommt aber auch nix au�ergew�hnliches.

Aroma: Cereals. Appearance: Gold color with clear sparkling liquid and white head. Taste: Light bitterness with light sweet notes. Palate: Light body with thin texture and average carbonation. Short sweet finish. Overall: Refreshing. Very soft features and easy to drink. Average beer but not metallic or alcoholid memories.

Pours clear, pale golden, with a full, white head. Aroma is corn syrup and straw. Taste is corn syrup, moving to light clove and a hop overtone. Finish is oddly hoppy. Not a beer I'd look to drink again.
Pale golden with a white head - Malt aroma - malt body with just hints of hops to balance - Malts in the finish with just hints of hops - This was just ok
14-04-18 // bottle from kiosk45 Frankfurt. Country tick beer. Classic pale lager, better than many i had before. Doesnt taste to watery dull. Quite nice.

0,33l can at a hostel in Bar�, Colombia. Yellow clear color, small white head. Smells earthy, tobacco, malty sweet, peppery. Below Average smell. Light body, soft carbonation. Tastes earthy, malty sweet, peppery, tobacco, bit earthy. Finishes lightly bitter with notes of tobacco, sweet malts and peppery notes. Not that great 4,3,4, 2,7

Color amarillo p�lido, transparente. Espuma blanca de dos dedos de espesor y corta retenci�n. Aroma escaso a cereal y notas c�tricas, lima. Sabor en esa l�nea, final corto de ligero amargor herbal y levemente met�lico. Textura acuosa. Carbonataci�n media alta.

On draught at the micro-brewery tavern/campground near Unity, Wisconsin. Pours a clear copper amber brew with a thick off-white head that slowly dissipates and leaves behind some spotty lacing and off-white ring. Aroma of caramel malt, some roasted nuts, flowery hops and a touch of toffee. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonated with flavors of caramel malt, fruity apples/pear, some flowery hops and a touch of mild spice. Finish has a good balance of malt and flowery hop aftertaste that quickly turns to a crisp and clean cut finish. The crisp finish from the brewery�s new location water is a major improvement from the past batches.

Dark copper color with no head. Muddled aroma that seems to be some grains, but nothing stands out. Taste is earthy, actually pretty spot on to being a wet pile of leaves. Cardboard starting to creap in.

(12 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with hopdog, thanks Steve!) Amber waves of grain and corn are the feature of this mediocre red ale. It�s lightly sweet and caramely, somewhat toasty, and I don�t think there are any hops in this beer whatsoever. The nose is all cheap smelling corn. Light-medium body, but this beer gets watery in a hurry. Medium amber body is a bit hazy, but I can clearly see that there are no carbonation bubbles rising through the beer. Barely a filmy layer of head forms during the pour, and that quickly fades to a tiny ring. Frankly, this is one of the worst red ales I�ve ever tasted. It�s like drinking a golden ale with food coloring.

A thin-bodied amber brew with a filmy off-white head, this has a sweet caramel aroma with rotting apples thrown in for snicks. The taste is a weak caramel malt with the slightest hint of a non-hop bitterness. With selling points like that, it�s no wonder there�sno commercial description. Thanks & a tip o� the pint to El_Borracho and RAYBOY01.
Poured a medium and cloudy amber with virtually no head. Kinda of a skunky cabbage aroma. Tastes like water with a slice of lemon in it. Very thin. I�m on my way to dump this one out...
Watery texture, underwhelming on all levels...flavor was weak, forgettable, caramel hints, no hops detectable at all. Will not try it again.

Light amber with a small head. Not much in the way of aroma. I tried this right after the lager they make and other than color there is not much difference. Possibly good for pounding when out on the boat catching walleye, eh der!

Dark orange, almost amber colored body. The aroma is sweet apples with cheap tobacco and some earthy dirt. The taste is light toffee and oak with some roasted and salted peanuts. The body is a little thin for an amber. However, this is a very accessible beer that is still interesting. This would be ok as a lawn mower beer.

Copper color ale with an off-white head of thick bubbles. Aroma is mild and malty. Flavor is somewhat flat but still fresh and ok; bitter, coppery and oaty. Finish is unpleasantly flat; in retrospect I can see cardboard in there like some other ratings.

Bottle - pours a nice off white, thin head over a deep red brown beer. Aroma of sweet malt and some roasted character. Nice roasted flavor, even a bit of a burnt bite. I like this beer. Did they use some lightly smoked grain. It seems like it. A little thin on the end, but really malty and warming.

"Cask conditioned. Poued a nice dark copper color. Smalled creamy head which left good lacing. Not sure if it was cause it was cask conditioned but almost no carbonation. Mouthfeel was smooth, kind of coated the tounge. Aroma was of sweet malts and yeast. Flavor was of hops and sweet malts. Had kind of a sweet bready aftertaste. Awsome beer. "

Very dark for a scotch ale. Almost black with a thick head. Looked more like a porter or a stout, but when I tasted it, there was definitly the character of a scotch. Lots of malty sweetness. Very different from what I am used to in a scotch, but I liked it.
Draft at the brewpub during the Eagles victory over the Giants. A bit dry and hoppy for a scottish ale, lots of roasted barley more in line with a porter. Overall a bit off balance.
Pitch black with a thin tan head. Slight lingering hop bitterness on the palate. Not as malty as I would expect from a scotch ale and I would liken this more to a porter.

Rich creamy head, kept that great head throughout the entire pint, blackish color, had a very distinct sweetness on the nose & at the start of the taste, a malty-type of aftertaste, I'm not usually one for Scotch ales but this was great

Draught at "Altes Tramdepot Brewpub" - Bern. Deep brown color, good fizzy aspect, elegant and solid head, little nut color. Fresh malty notes with rumors of roast wood and cereals. Refreshing and little bitterish taste, good alcoholic balanced and pleasant malty final.

very dark brwon colour, small brown tainted head, malty, caramel nose, slightly sweet with a late bitterness, short dry caramel finish; a modest roastiness shows up while the beer is getting warmer - not much character
very dark brown colour, fine creamy head, nice lace, very hoppy, deep floral aroma, notes of gingerbread, very smooth, full with a late bitter kick, long bready finish

Amber ale, misty, nice head. Very nice hop aroma, lightly floreal; some caramel too. In the mouth, the first impression is the hop, strong but not aggressive, aromatic; then some malt with light caramel, completely overwhelmed; finally the hop strikes back, aggressive, bitter. The palate is aromatic, strong and long, maybe too much bitter, but with an interesting hint of nuts and bitter orange. Beers of Switzerland
pale reddish colour, few head, nice lace, pineapple, floral and caramel aroma, very creamy and smooth, full with a decent bitterness, long dry hop aftertaste
cloudy orange colour, big creamy head, corn and floral aroma, full, sweet and bitter, long dry floral finish
pale orange colour, almost no head, deep spicy nose, fruity, perfumy, full with a bitter fruity finish - quite free interpretation of a pils ...
jest to bardzo przeci�tne piwo, piana szybko znika ,w smaku s�odowo kwaskowe z lekk� nut� s�abo wyczuwalnej goryczki mo�na si� raczy� w upalne dni do woli .
This beer has a golden body - hue apperance and a white scum collar. I have drunk the beer from the bottle and no carbonic acid. The initial flavor tast was zweet.
Bottled(500ml). -not so good like Amstel and Amstel Gold....................

Soft coppery body and okay foam, very vague hops on the nose. Flavour is mostly malt and a hint of hops. Full enough on the mouth. Way too malty even for an old school IPA, and actually really hard to differentiate from their ESB. When it's a total crapshoot and even the waitress can't tell (and even brings over an extra sample of the ESB so you can make sure), well.....

On tap at Sailor Hagar�s, pours an opaque dark orange with a medium beige head. Nose brings out medium strength hops, some metallic notes, and crisp biscuity malt. Flavour is quite astringent, with a very harsh hop bitterness dominating everything. Nothing refined or pleasant about this. A little abrasive.

On tap at Sailor Hagars. Pours a solid amber with creamy white head that lasts to the bottom of the glass. Aroma has pine and grapefruit/citrus hop notes. Flavour is also very hoppy but with enough toffee malt character to balance it out. Lingering bitterness. Decent but a tad underwhelming.

Draught at Sailor Hagar�s Golden color; creamy head. The aroma is lightly fruity, at least this one has some aroma, from Sailor Hagar�s. The mouthfeel is quite dry, but there is a good toffee flavor, a very strong bitterness, with a good share of hop oils and resins, and bitter orange peel. Solid.
650ml Bottle purchased at Sailor Hagar�s. Beer has good body and hop bitterness. Pronounced grapefruit flavour. Overall, this is an enjoyable IPA and more than worth trying.

The Sailor Hagar�s IPA was undoubtedly better when it was brewed on premises in North Vancouver. However, it remains one of the finest BC IPAs. Reddish-orange color. Strong nose with distinct hops and grapefruit notes. Citrusy throughout the bouquet and the taste too.

(Draught) I found that they were sold all out of the bottled version so I was lucky to find this on tap. Pours a thin, beige head with an orange-amber body. Nose and flavour of sweet English malts and bitter PNW hoppiness. By far the best beer at the Hagar. Too bad the bar is SO unimpressive...

Was one of my fave�s when it was made by Gary Lohin. It was BCs best IPA. I still like it but the recipe has been tweaked by Fab & Franco at Howe Sound. Here�s a secret - all the contract brews at Sailor Hagar�s are exactly what�s on tap at Howe Sound - just a different name. Compare the ratings! That said, it�s served with a creamy head, great lace, hops now less citrusy than before, thinner in the mouth.
An orange beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet hoppy with hints of caramel. The flavor is nicely hoppy, and the alcohol burns slightly on the tongue.

Very light orange, off-white head. Floral and piney nose, sweaty average floral hops hide most of the maltiness. Barky, lasting oily hops bitterness, woody and annoying. Light bodied feels mysteriously sticky. Average..
Fine, not bitter, one of the best from Ragutis. Only in cans................
Yellow color. Fizzy, little hops, slightly bitter..........................
Medium gold, hop touch, slight fruitiness...pretty bland. Pass on it.......

Hazy unfiltered peach. Pine sap aroma, incredibly intense. Medium bodied, loaded with hops. I mean, holy crap this is like drinking hop juice. Bitter Chinook hops and light citric notes. An IPA lovers dream, although terribly unbalanced. Who cares. If you need a hop fix Willimantic is the place to hit for primo IPA's.

This beer is an Imperial Stout by style, brewed with eight different malts and barley, and coming in at a mighty 8.8% abv. Imperial Stouts are big, robust, roasty, high octane brews that were brewed by British brewers in the 19th Century to be drank as a winter warmer in the brutally cold conditions of the Baltics and Russia. They are rich, decadent brews with intense aromas, flavors, and alcohol punch. Main Sack Stout is a stellar domestic example of this style, and one that would please even Ivan the Terrible. Mail Stack Stout is served in a 10oz brandy snifter and pours to an ink black color with a thick, dense, cinnamon colored head, with a soft carbonation. The nose on this beer is amazingly complex with a multitude of aromas. Dark chocolate, espresso coffee, piney hop aromas, licorice, and peppery waves of alcohol heat flood the nostrils. The palate is rich and decadent, with layers of complex malty and estery flavors. Dark chocolate, sweet malt, burnt currants, fig, licorice, espresso, and treacle flavors all lay heavy on the tongue. The consistancy of this beer is oily and viscous on the tongue as it slowly glides down. Mail Sack Stout finishes with more big complex flavors up front, then ends with a roasty, hoppy, soothing, warming burn that lingers. Once again, Willimantic Brewing has stunned me with one of the most impressive Imperial Stouts I have ever tasted.

column4: Lion Breweries - NZ (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Amber orange colour. Citrusy hop aroma. Spicy, slightly citrusy mild hop flavour with a solid malt backbone. A little too solid, I would like the hops to come to the forefront a bit more.

column1: Harrington's The First of the Summer Ale
column5: Bottle, pours a hazy light gold with a large white foamy head. Strong aroma of ginger and cordial. Spicy, but thin palate. Ginger, lemon, apple and raisin flavours, but with cardboard malt in the finish. Not for me - do others really like it that much?

column1: Harrington's The First of the Summer Ale
column5: (Bottle 50 cl) Cloudy, pale golden with a small, white head. Aroma of honey, ginger and oranges. Medium body with rather sweet fruits and honey and also some ginger. Ends fairly dry. Actually quite balanced and refreshing - and very summery. 040208

column1: Harrington's The First of the Summer Ale
column5: Golden, slightly green very hazy body with a small head. Fruity aroma with ginger. Citrus and ginger in the taste. Small and plenty of boubles. Citrus and ginger aftertaste makes a very light feeling.

column1: Harrington's The First of the Summer Ale
column5: 500ml bottle. A rocky white head sits atop a clear pale straw yellow brew. Large fresh almost ginger ale type fragrance with contrasting flavours. Biting dryness, spices and definately the Elderflowers though I would have almost said dandylions. It�s an eclectic, different pick-n-mix type brew - I�ll go out on a limb and suggest that while many won�t, I think it�s not too bad...

column1: Harrington's The First of the Summer Ale
column5: Perhaps a bit harsh in my comments but this is a fairly pedestrian golden ale style. Well constructed nevertheless. Light malts, faint honey, and a nice elegant spice finish. Not miles away from Coopers Pale and Sparkling, at least to my tastes.

column1: Harrington's The First of the Summer Ale
column5: The colour was pale amber gold, and there was a light head. The aroma was strong fruit and ginger coriander. The taste had strong spicy ginger, and there was a crisp light hoppy finish. This was a quite fresh beer with strong fruit, and it was quite crisp.

column1: Harrington's The First of the Summer Ale
column5: Very floral with strong corriander aroma. Tangelo hits first in the flavor with corriander finishing. Little vanilla or elderflower presence.

column1: Harrington's The First of the Summer Ale
column5: Nice golden-orange colour. Vanilla is apparent in the aroma. Interesting flavour: citrusy (but not like a witbier, you can really taste the tangelo), and pretty sweet, not much hop balance at all.
Roast malt sweet aroma with spice. Clear red Amber colour fair head and lacing. Sweet malt flavour. Smooth palate.

500ml bottle BB 9/3/2017 Aroma is all sweet spicy fruit cake. Poured dark red/brown with decent head. A mild bitterness is followed by a delicious smooth mellow rounded finish with warming sherry/brandy barrel overtones. The best from this brewer.
Rzadko spotykany u nas styl, s? nawet dodatki toffee i wanilii. Nieco zbyt s?odkie, ale ci??kie, oleiste i warte wypr�bowania. Mimo wszystko dost?pne u nas whiskey stouty moim zdaniem s? lepsze.

I think that is is a bit good. Clearly the brewer is in some kind of rebuild rebadge reimagine, but this has many of things that you might look for in a beer, inviting and welcome about of bitter, fantastic amount of roasted chocolate dark malts and a lovely sweet over-note, which not being a bourbon drinker I�ll make it hat. The finish is soft and lands well. I�m really enjoying this and it is possibly the brewers best.
A pleasantly surprising brew that is full bodied and well balanced but add a subtle hint of hard liquor to keep you guessing. One of my favourite beers from this brewer.

I saw a description a few minutes ago that describe a beer as looking like Coca-Cola. This applies here except that it has been poured over a significant amount of rum to account for the thick latte coloured head. Smells of cocoa, dates, dusty carob dark sugar and molasses. Flavours similar with cola coming through now that the idea has been planted in my head. Some bitterness arising reminiscent of dark chocolate. A lengthy, pleasing finish. Another look a few years after the first trial sees me think this is quite a bit better. Quite a bit better.

500ml bottle purchased and consumed in Christchurch, NZ. Pours clear and dark reddish-brown with a very good beige head. Feel: Medium-full body and nicely smooth; medium and rather lively carbonation. Aroma: appealing and fruity, with raisins, dates and dark roasted grains plus a hint of smoke. Flavor: similar to the aroma with plenty of dark fruits and a hint of smoke, but with some hops showing in the finish and aftertaste and a hint of bourbon. Very good balance. O: Excellent. One of the better NZ dark beers . A big dark ale without real high ABV. Recommended.

Bottle. Pours a dark red colour with a thin white head, malty aroma with the bourbon in the background, the taste is sweet with malt but the bourbon does not come through in the taste, with a dry finish.

weird, i had this only two days ago but it was obviously nothing special (either great or terrible) because i can hardly remember anything about it. malt and alcohol are the two things i remember. it was good, anyway.

Bottle. Had this sitting in the fridge for a while now. Pours a deep bronze with reddish tinges down the side of the glass. Small light tan coloured head. Falls away pretty quickly. Looks a little lifeless in the glass. Aromas are not too bad. Some dark stone fruits, a little sweet caramel, hints of vanilla and some alcohol surprisingly given abv. Not too bad. Taste is dominated by nutty grain and more of that alcohol. Somewhat sweet. Thin mouthfeel.
Hazy dark orange appearance. Very sweet malty aroma, malt carries throung into the palate and ends slightly bitter.
Aromatic maltiness, flowery, earthy, full flavour...........................
RateBeer Summer (Toronto) '02: Murky ruby color. Something about this beer bothered me. It would have been better if I wrote it down.
Clear light brown. Sweet malty rich coffee aroma. Much richer taste, fruity, and alcohol comes through slightly. Good body, goes downsweet with a bit of alcohol.
Nice choco-coffee aroma (like ice mocha). Coffee, coffee, coffee. Good aftertaste, nice roast.

Yep, not super complex as Kaya said. But its god damn tasty, buttery toffee and milky, roasted coffee in there aswell, and very smooth. Very nice spicy finish and quite malty, i kind of dig it. Thanks beer_ledgend!!!!!

Light brown, amlmost reddish hue. Wonderful milk chocolate aroma with flavour to match. Light to medium bodied. Not super complex, but an incredibly balanced rich, chocolatey Scotch Ale with a wonderful silky smooth mouthfeel. This goes down very easily despite its strength. Damn good!

At first I thought this must be the same thing as the Alt; but upon tasting, then going back and looking at my rating for the other, I must conclude this is a different beer and one of the better offerings from this pub. A smooth brown semi-translucent color is topped by a reasonable and lasting head; aroma is not strong in the smoky bar, but caramel and earthy malt notes do come through. Very well balanced in flavor and on the palate, quite sweet (caramel caramel) and somewhat fruity but with plenty of hoppy zing and a big kick on the back end. Good body. A pleasure.

cloudy blond with a fine head, nice lace, fruity (apricot) and hoppy nose, slightly nutty, full and tart, decent bitterness, dry hop finish with notes of apricot - this beer needs to get warmer to let the aroma coming out properly
dark amber colour, fine creamy head, nice lace, aroma, of blood, quite flat and slightly tart, metallic finish - something went wrong with this beer and it has no analogies with a dunkelweizen

Bottle courtesy of Greg Koch at our stop at the Stone Brewing World Bistro & Gardens on 08/03/2008 on day three of RBSG 2008. Dark caramel body with a small off-white head. Big malty caramel aroma. Dry caramel and some dry floral earthy hops. Medium full body with low carbonation.

RBSG �08: Provided by Greg Koch while drinking in the garden Note: I thought this said Y2K but from what I could find the abv is exact as this and other attendees seemed to have put their ratings here. Poured chunky but a clear amber color with no head. The aroma was of apples and brown sugar. Sweet smell with alcohol fumes running up the nose. The flavor was sweet and malty. Sugary with a full body and sticky mouthfeel. Warming in the throat.

Sampled at the 2008 RBSG from a bottle from Greg Koch Cellar. This Eisbock pours a medium brown color from a 12oz bottle. Small sized white foamy head. The aroma is caramel, fruity and sweet. The hops are earthy. It�s kind of a bit past its prime and the oxidation is evident, but it seems to work here, it makes the sweetness much more evident. Carbonation was good. Very smooth tasting. Hides the 12.5% very well. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
12oz bottle at Stone during RBSG. Dark brown. Thick. Nice buttery malty aroma. Very nice. Sweet. Delicious.
