Or y2k with a bottle @ Stone today from Greg Koch�s cellar for us to taste during RBSG. Pours copper orange. Taste is big and big sweet caramel. and overall sweet. Taste is sweet caramel and overall kicking and kick ass. Love it.
sweet malt and fruit nose. with some hop presence, weird for style. warming brndy and madeira notes almost portlike at the finish.

Murky brown color with smallish head. Aroma of light roasted malt and mellow hops but thats all thats mellow about this magic elixar. Why would they possibly discontinue something this good? Tastes of over ripe oranges, brown sugar and espresso round it out. Magic on the lips.
Brown sugar gone wild. Very sticky palate. Clingy, long-lasting head. Citrus/caramel notes.
Dark pour with decent head (on tap). Cocoa molasses with a little sour grapefruit. Good flavor. Refined taste for amount of complex flavors.

Mahogany color. Impressive head for this much alcohol. Some apricot aroma and flavor. Stong caramel flavor. Slightly sweet. Brown sugar? Full body. Quite bitter. A friend I was with saw 1.070 and 12.5% ABV on the label and thought there had to be a typo. I didn't realize this was an Eisbock when I drank it. It all makes sense now...
Pours amber with aroma of honey, florals, malt. Tastes very malty, with hops, caramel, fruit, and honey at the finish.

pleasing amber. caramel gold colour, fizzy head. sweet and spicy nose. malt sugar taste with lots of caramel and some zesty and bitter flavours from the hops. finish is surprisingly hoppy and peppery. alcohol taste is strong for a medium strenght beer.

The foam stability is ok, the body gold. The aroma is malty, a bit bitter. The taste is Malty,maltsirup, a bit bitter. The alcoholic taste is for 8,8% soomewhat integrated. Otherwise pretty close to a lot of dutch high percentish beers.
Bottle in Polonnaruwa, Sri Lanka. Pours a pale straw gold. Sweet malt, grain, boozy notes. Grain, sweet malt, mild caramel, mild cotrus flavours. Unbalanced and a bit hard to drink.
323ml can. Pours gold and fizzy. Peach, apple juice, vodka, real funky apple juice. My first malt liquor experience and I do not care for it.

Tasted 10/1/2017. Bottle, People�s Park Complex, Chinatown, Singapore; $S7.50. BB 15 DEC 2017. Poured a crystal clear amber with a one-finger bright white foamy head that diminished slowly to a collar that laced poorly. Carbonation moderate (high for Asian beers), slow and fine. Aroma is of slight malt and sweet honey; alcohol well hidden. Taste is quite sweet with hints of honey and alcohol burn; alcohol burn increases as it warms and over-powers everything. Light to medium body. Smooth with an alcohol burn on the finish. Not nice.

0,5l can at Hotel room in Sigiriya, Sri Lanka. BB 04/2017. 8.8% ABV. Amber clear color, small pink head. smells nutty, marzipan, ripe fruits, tobacco, caramel. actually quite decent smell. Full Body, Licht carbonation, slick mouthfeel. tastes nutty, marzipan, ripe fruits, molasses, honey, light caramel, some boozy notes. finishes lightly sweet with notes of booze and nutty notes. okish, but a bit on the boozy side.

Cardboard, wet paper, grain malts, light metallic. Clear gold, medium, creamy, white head. Light sweet. Sweet grain malts, more molasses, lively carbonation, medium bodied, some bitterness in the finish. Not very nice Malt Liquor, weird Aroma and taste, spend your calorie budget on better stuff. Sri Lankan brewed can from Food City, Kandy.

[ bottle ][ 1.5oz ][ @Tasting ][ $? ][ mini snifter ][ 05.01.16 ] effervescent gold, thin white head, decent lacing. Stingingly sweet, cloying corn nose, lightly metallic. Foamy front palate, sticky sweet, fizzy gum notes, burnt and bright competing. Clinging sweetness eats at enamel.
Can. Pours golden, clear, small head. Aroma of sparkling wine, grain, citrus, metal. Taste of caramel, yeast, grain, fruitiness, alcohol.
Can pour at the May 1st DC Tasting. Poured a pale, sad looking golden color with a fizzy white head. Aroma was corn, malts. So sweet, malts are awful. Third world hangover.
12oz can I brought back from Colombo pours a clear dark gold with no head. Nose has adjuncts, corn, metal, honey. Flavor is super sweet, metal, corn, honey. Sweet finish. Bad.

On cask at Sailor Hagar�s, pours a clear amber with a medium bubbly beige head. Aroma is quite medicinally sweet, with artificial sweetness and cough syrup. Flavour is thankfully better, but still bringing out some medicinal notes, sour toffee, and some English malt. Is tho how it�s supposed to taste? Not good at all.
Sample at brewpub. Pours a dark brown colour with thin ring of off white foam. Aroma has some prominent malt but lacks a nuttiness. Taste is reasonably malty but again the nutiness is lacking. Okay.

Hand-pump at Sailor Hagar�s Brown color, creamy head. Light caramel and very light butterscotch aroma. The body is weaker than expected, there is caramel flavor, low bitterness. The hand-pump allows for lower carbonation, which is better for me. Simple but easy to drink

Re-rate 10 years later at the source. It's dark brown with good creamy head, okay biscuit on the nose though it does come across as watery. The flavour is more sweet biscuit with a big watery streak. Medium finish but not fulfilling. Simple and simplified, needs more attention to its style but probably works for the coughing 75 year old next to me whose tastebuds are shot from several decades of heavy smoking. September 2009 - Bought as a bottle quite awhile ago. Lives up to its name quite well, lots of nutty flavour in this one, some malts, but really too nutty a flavour for my tastes. Comes across as a little artificial, and low alcohol content doesn�t help me to get tipsy to enjoy it more either. Still okay, just not great.
Decent nut brown: not sweet as some can be, but then again it�s not got any distinctive flavors either. Quaffable and pretty good.

(650ml bottle) Purchased at the Sailor Hagar�s Off-Sale for ~$5. Lasting foamy almond-coloured head with a ruby body. Pleasant roasteed malt and slight coffee flavours. This is a good contender. I like the solid beers made by Howe Sound.

Very dark porterish colour with ruby and mahogany notes. Has a thin light brown head. Sweet blackstrap molasses and treacle aroma. A vineous sherry-like aroma. Cherry and black current fruitiness with port-like notes as well. Not like any other brown ale that I�ve had. Tends to become cloying, but is still a well-crafted beer. Based on the description I�m reading I think this is a totally different beast from what others were drinking when it was still brewed at Sailor Hagars.
Dark brown body with little head. Flavour is nice and nutty but a little thin. Finish is dry.
Deep amber colour. Dry nutty flavour. Medium bodied. Unimpressive. .....
Brown with off white head.Faint malt nose. Light malt faintly nutty flavor with short dry finish

Taster, many thanks to Werckmeister! Golden-orange, clear body, with a medium, fluffy, yellowish head. Aroma of cheesy funk, basement, some horse blanket, lemon, apple, wood. Tastes similar, with some more ripe stone fruits. Medium, slightly creamy mouthfeel, with a moderate carbonation. Finishes dry, musty, wooden, moderate citric, with some green apple, some basement. Really tasty! Not the most complex Geuze I've had, but so balanced, with a great, rustic character. Lovely, diverse funk notes, which are my highlight here, while also interesting fruit notes. Score: 8 / 4 / 8 / 4 / 17
Barwa z�ota, piana du�a. Aromat owocowy, cytrusowy, dziki. W smaku mocno wytrawny, kwa�ny, sporo winogron, siano, nuty dzikie. Fajne pifko.

Yellow, muddy beer with good persistent foam. The aroma of fruit, citrus, a little lemon, barnyard. The taste is quite balanced, fruity, small pleasant bitterness in the aftertaste. The body of beer is oily, carbonation is very high.
Refrigerated 75 cL bottle poured into a glass. Clear golden with white head. Aroma is funky, medium body, low carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is funky and dry.

(750ml 2016 bottle from boxbeers, I think) Pours nearly clear pale orange with a big head of fine eggshell foam that piles high and lingers with lace. Aroma is musty and funky but has a bright fruity core, with notes of oranges and pit fruit, citrus peels, ample wood, dried leaves, blue cheese, some barnyard, nice spike of lactic tartness. Flavour is smooth and less tart than the nose implies, notes of mandarin, sweet apple and yellow plum (or some other pit fruit?), soft lemony lactic acidity, minerals, dry grass, just a little wood giving a leathery drydown. Lingering notes of oranges and pit fruit. Medium bodied with rather high effervescent carbonation. A rather soft geuze, especially on the tongue where the funk is less present, but the surprisingly bright fruit character was a treat.

0.75 bottle in Craft Room. Lovely tangerine and sourness in aroma, wine barrel, wild yeast, mold. Bit hazy amber color with medium sized white head. Barrel, mold and sourness. Medium body, completely flat. Long sour aftertaste. Nice!

Original Rating 08. Dec 2018: 0,75l from bottle at De Heeren. BB 2040. Dark yellow clear color, small white head. Smells lightly sweet, earthy, light funk, some wood. Nice smell, very subtle. Medium body, soft carbonation, slick mouthfeel. Tastes citric, earthy, spices, funky, peppery, wood. Finishes lightly dry and lightly sour with notes of citrus, earthy and light funky notes. Quite nice one, not super complex or super drinkable, maybe a bit young 7, 4, 7, 3, 15 Rerate 20.06.2019: 0,75l bottle at home (bought in Belgium). Has a Bottling Sticker of 04/2014. BB 2034. opens with a loud blob, yellow rather hazy color, huge head. smells earthy, grassy, musty, wood, some stone fruits. nice smell. full body, strong carbonation. tastes earthy, grassy, bit cheesy, musty, spices, peppery, light stone fruits. finishes bubbly, lightly dry and lightly sour with notes of stone fruits, earthy and some woody notes. nice one, finishes is almost too light though, taste just trails away, might be also related to the strong carbonation. 7, 4, 8, 3, 16
Bottle at Cotteridge Wines tasting room; hazy amber pour with a bubbly off white head, aroma has funk and a hint of cheese, taste has light funk a hint of pineapple ok

Handpull cask at the Vernon Arms, Liverpool. Golden brown. Clear with a tight off-white head. Aroma of raisins, caramel, browned toast. Sweet, fruity taste, very malt-led. More bitterness in the finish, with Garibaldi biscuit in the aftertaste. A passable stronger bitter.
Pours a brown colour. Taste is malty with some sour vomit like taste. An ok bitter

Picture of the late undersung national treasure Pete Postlethwaite on badge. Not a bad ale, but can�t call it an apt tribute. Quite thin, sweet, not much depth of flavour. An alright session ale however, fairly typical of coach house. Similar to Post Horn.
On cask at Wheatsheaf (JDW), Stoke. Pours amber with white head. Erm, strange bitterness with a hint of toffee. Very thin and typical of Coach House in my experience.
Cask @ Fox & Goose, Hebden Bridge. Amber with a small head and a slightly sweet aroma. Has a gentle bitterness.
Cask@lychgatetavern, wolverhampton. Amber beer with small head and good lacing. Aroma of mild hops. Taste is a little bit of hops, bready, malts and a touch nutty. Average beer.

Served on cask at the Sussex Arms, Twickenham Green into an English half pint jug (Jan �12). A little background, this beer was brewed as a tribute to the great English actor Pete Postlethwaite, who died in January 2011 born in Warrington home of the Coach House brewery. Poured to a mid golden/amber colour with a small white head that held up fairly well through drinking. A floral, hoppy, grassy aroma attacks the nose - good all round sense attack! Quite a dry and hoppy beer, less flowery in taste than aroma but still a little floral flavour in there. Also a sweet and light malted flavour. Mouthfeel is adequate, not full bodied, not thin - just right, dry and bitter in the aftertaste, perhaps more than the floral/hop aroma and taste would suggest. Overall - a decent tribute to a favourite actor of mine!
Cask at Bon Accord, Glasgow (14 Jan 12) - pours hazy golden with a slighlty hoppy aroma, very smooth and sweetish and a pleasure to drink
Cask @ 3 Judges. Clear golden colour, white head. Aroma is slightly hoppy, and slightly malty. Very subtle, but at the same time not watery. Hints of glue. Very sessionable.

Cask@Oliver Twist. Reddish-copper brown, good off-white head. Sweetish flowery hoppy nose. A bit strange hop profile, woody-grassy, a bit out of balance. Long hoppy aftertaste. Extra point to Pete Postlethwaite, cool actor!

column1: Adler Brau Bucky Brau Barley Wine
column5: Bottle that is at least two years old and found while digging through my "cellar" and cost me $1.59 at Discount Liquor in Milwaukee. Served in my Stone RIS snifter: A muddy reddish brown color with a small frothy tan head that produced moderate lace. The aroma has lots of fruity esters, caramel malting, candi sugar and some spicy hops. An inviting nose and I got interested is what would follow...then came the taste... what is that? Starts with a quick dash of sugars and malt but then a surprising winey acidic nature pops up. Lot of oxidation in the flavors as well leading me to think of this as more English Old Ale than Barleywine. The finish is sort of peppery but really more papery and blends away to nothingness. Despite the negative comment, this is not really bad, just not expected. The feel is slightly sticky and more mellow than most of the genre. In the end, this is a forgettable beer but not regrettable.

column1: Adler Brau Bucky Brau Barley Wine
column5: Slightly murky fiery red body, no head. Aroma is fruity and sugary with some cherry, apricot, and pineapple. The flavor is bizarre; lots of pineapple juice (sweetened), heavily sweet malt, and hot alcohol. Where are the hops that other raters mention? The body is full and sticky. Horribly unbalanced in my opinion. Shame.

column1: Adler Brau Bucky Brau Barley Wine
column5: Hmmm, didn't know what to make of this brew-was it supposed to be a barleywine, or an old ale, or a spice/herb/veg brew? It was like the transexual of brews in my opinion. Very fruity nose-palate was somewhat like DFH rasion d etre, but definately not as good-finish reminded me of Flying dog Horn Dog barleywine, just without the carbonation. A wierd brew-definately not my type of barleywine(SN bigfoot and Avery hog heaven are my types!!)

column1: Adler Brau Bucky Brau Barley Wine
column5: This has a very sweet, somewhat floral aroma with a hint of cherry. Very rich dark brown in color. The body is sweet, sour, syrupy and complex, but also confusing. It has good flavor but is unbalanced. Kinda tastes like a cross between a traditional barley wine and a Flanders red.

column1: Adler Brau Bucky Brau Barley Wine
column5: Year unknown. Slightly hazy dark ruby. Thin tan edge head, loaded with tiny bubbles and lasting til the end. Very light carbonation. Aroma of alcohol, strawberries, resinous hops and sugared caramel. Medium thick body, quite viscous. Hearty and filling caramel malts with a hoppy overtone of pine sap. Malt depth is thick and sweet, almost cloying and sticky. Strawberry-like fruitiness. Body thins a bit as it sits and this balances itself better than when it began. Obvious alcohol in the aroma is hidden well within the thick body. Finishes with an increase in sticky fruitiness and juicy hops. A decent Barley wine from an unheard of brewery.

column1: Adler Brau Bucky Brau Barley Wine
column5: Formerly known as "Bucky Red". A deep ruby color with minimal head - typical to style. Floral, malt and alcohol fill the aroma. Warming, fruity and estery. If any fault a bit thin in the mouthfeel. A nice barley wine.

column1: Central Waters Lac Du Bay India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle. Dark amber color. Bread dough and medium sweet, there are hops that are dry and bitter and less prominent than the sweet,brown sugar malt.

column1: Central Waters Lac Du Bay India Pale Ale
column5: Pours a cloudy, reddish-copper, with middling head. Hops, malt, and grain are all present in the aroma. Flavor is quite malty-sweet, with some hop bite in the background. Bitter finish. Well-balanced.

column1: Central Waters Lac Du Bay India Pale Ale
column5: 12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured reddish amber, with a nice abundant head and lots of lacing. Aroma of fruit, hops and spices. Tastes is consistent, fruity, malty well balanced. Very good IPA, quite enjoyable and drinkable.

column1: Central Waters Lac Du Bay India Pale Ale
column5: 12oz bottle to tulip. Pours cloudy blood orange, cream white head. Aroma of fig, caramel, alcohol, pine and citrus. Taste of the same. Lots of figs.

column1: Central Waters Lac Du Bay India Pale Ale
column5: Not a bad ipa. Definitely drinkable but nothing really stands out about it. Hoppy but lingers a bit long.

column1: Central Waters Lac Du Bay India Pale Ale
column5: Moderate grassy and earthy flavors followed by a pithy earthy hop bitterness. Not much malt character. Maybe a hint of burnt bread but has a watery and thin mouthfeel. Some burnt character. But like a burnt rubber.

column1: Central Waters Lac Du Bay India Pale Ale
column5: Nose has notes of wheat, mowed grass, chocolate and an earthiness. Pours an amber to red-brown with nearly an inch of foam that dissipates in a couple minutes. Taste is hop forward then moving to a caramel, toffee, chocolate that quickly gives way to a nice crisp hop finish. Beverage comes to the palate strong and clean, finishing crisply.

column1: Central Waters Lac Du Bay India Pale Ale
column5: draft at Blue Monk & Moor Pat, solid english styled IPA. toffee, light butterscotch, earthy hops, good fuller mouthfeel. decent

column1: Central Waters Lac Du Bay India Pale Ale
column5: Pours burnt orange with white head. Good lacing. Aroma is buttery toffee and malts. Flavor is toffee and bitter hops.

column1: Central Waters Lac Du Bay India Pale Ale
column5: Draught @ Waterfront Ale House. Reddish dark amber with medium sized creamy beige head, slight caramel aroma, low carbonation, slightly hoppy bitter caramel taste, abrupt finish with bitter aftertaste. I did not really taste the hops much, more like an ESB.

column1: Central Waters Satin Solitude Imperial Stout
column5: Botella 33 CL en el Taxman Le�n 27..06..2019 (r563). Color oscuro con espuma beige que desaparece casi por completo al poco tiempo. Sabores maltosos tostados con buena dosis de carbonizados suaves, acabando ligeramente seca y con suave amargo cafetosos. Cuerpo medio f�cil de beber, se esperaba algo m�s de densidad. Bastante sabor, bueno ese toque carbonizado. Para repetir.

column1: Central Waters Satin Solitude Imperial Stout
column5: Nice imperial stout. Roasty, light sweet and light bitter. Tastes of coffee, chocolate... soft and creamy. Nice

column1: Central Waters Satin Solitude Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle. Dark brown with bronze color, yellowish foam. Aroma: sweet, caramel, esters, roasted malt, a little dried fruit. Taste: sweetish, caramel, a little coffee and chocolate, a little dried fruit, bitter finish.

column1: Central Waters Satin Solitude Imperial Stout
column5: Flesje van Wijnhuis Blerick. Bijna zwarte kleur, kraag zakt snel weg ( wel te koud ingeschonken). Ruikt droppig, melk. Smaakindrukken van drop, peper en de traditionele stout smaken.

column1: Central Waters Satin Solitude Imperial Stout
column5: black/kaki head. Massive roasted flavors, some lactose, milk chocolate, cacao, weak texture, thin, some vanilla, old coffee, firm , decent not great

column1: Central Waters Satin Solitude Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle shared at De Gekke Geit. Pours close to black with a tan head. Like a milk stout, lactose sugar, sour yeast, old coffee.

column1: Central Waters Kosmyk Charlies Y2K Catastrophe Ale
column5: On tap at Champps in Brookfield. Tannish brown pour, very muddy. Fruit & toffee nose, very nice for style. A touch of alcohol. Some simple sugar especially in the nose. Brown sugar. Light nut. More than medium bodied with some alcohol. The blend is solid. Finishes sweetly. 13.7

column1: Central Waters Kosmyk Charlies Y2K Catastrophe Ale
column5: Pours somewhat hazy mahogany with a fairly thick light tan head. Aroma features sweet caramel and toasted malt notes. Flavor features woody, caramel and toasted malt character, while some hoppy/woody bitterness rears its head. Mouthfeel delivers thin body and so-so fizz. What a catastrophe.

column1: Central Waters Kosmyk Charlies Y2K Catastrophe Ale
column5: C-. Pours a dark brown color with khaki head. Very strong flavors. It does get a little better as it warms, but still a little too strong
Dark in colour, golden brown at the bottom...light in smell...a little noticable burnt smell. A light taste with no excessive or overwhelming flavours.
Very dark, kept a nice head, a thick malty aroma, very smooth .............
Brown colour. Chewy toffee & earth aroma with hints of molasses. Soft, chewy body with slight raisin and molasses. Malty...sweet but quite soft in the finish.
Bottled. Very dark brown. Papery roasty malt aroma. Dryish with firm but clean malt back bone, Lightly oxidized, but still with a lot of malt flavours intact. Low bitterness.
Nice dark colour, almost porter like colour. Aroma is sweet, molasses with some light spice. Malty taste, some roastiness but thins as you continue. Nice flavour but a little light.
Pours black with a ruby tint and an off-white head. Plenty of coffee in the roasty aroma, along with some notes of chocolate. The body is lighter than expected but grows into a bitter coffee finish.

Tasted 18/05/2005, retasted 16/01/2006. 330ml bottle from Regional Wines and Spirits (both times). Near-black, garnet tinted, dark ale with a thick, lasting, tan head. The chocolate malt nose jumps out at you superbly, reminding me of an unsweetened cocoa drink. There�s also hints of vanilla bean, caramel and roasted coffee in this pungent nose. Also get soft floral notes and sweet tobacco. Good flavour that balances sweet malt with a chocolatey, roasty, bitterness. More of that fsoft floral hopping. Fritha picks some minty hints from the hops (good girl, she�s getting better). Mouthfeel is right on medium body and is a little tingly from being the slightest bit overcarbonated, for me. Finish is relatively dry and the palate is slightly powdery. Lovely, delicious, worth consuming (in moderation, of course).

Nearly black in colour. Vinous aroma (similar to Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout). Winey flavour, with a slight tendency toward roast/burnt malts towards the finish. Relatively light bodied with a thinnish mouthfeel.
Clear golden with tiny white head. Very sweet aroma with lime notes. Flavor likewise with a very sweet end.
A great effort. Good uplifting fruit overtones with a pleasant mouthfeel. Finishes dry.
Orange amber in colour with fluffy head. hoppy aroma certainly nice autum drink. Nice citric aftertatse. (Autum 2002)
Quite nice, kind of a grapey aroma, light in body, slightly spicy, starts sweet and spicy and ends up slightly dry, pretty good, good to see a kiwi having a crack at a saison.
Nice golden-orange colour with a creamy white head. Spicy, fruity falvour, with nice balance, and a dryish finish.

Slightly hazy pale yellow colour with a fluffy white head that looks like molten marshmallow. It looks good enough to drink (which is reassuring). The aroma is driven by a lemon scent with faint basement yeastiness and some ground coriander. Cantabrian�s not gonna like that! The flavour is again light, dry and lemon citrussy. It faintly gains that yeasty character as it sits on the tongue and there�s a soft banana and clove that comes through in time as well. It�s a pleasant surprise this beer and I�m forming a shortlist of people to introduce it to. It does what it says on the label: clean, crisp and refreshing.
Again sold as a weiss beer. Light pineapple colour and a lasting bubbly head. Sweetish of pineapple and esters.
500ml bottle as weiss Bier. Sl cloudy, straw yellow with a good head. Light slightly cidery nose. Chalky texture, well carbonated and a little tart but quite ok

500mL Bottle - Harringtons Weiss Bier. Foggy pale "wheat colour" that gets cloudier towards the end of bottle. Average short lived white head. Aroma of wheat really. Smooth wheat dominating initial taste, with a longish bitter finish. Yeasty/banana flavours in the mix. Almost a soapy taste in mouth after drinking this but gets better the more you have.

(Bottle 33 cl) Clear golden with a dense and very white head. Aroma of citrus and a little yeast. Medium body with sweetish fruit, but also notes of yeast, sulphur and some chemical diacetyl notes. Dry finish. Quite drinkable though. 040208
Light golden clear body with normal size head. A little hops in the nose. Highly carbonated. Thin mild taste with a aftertaste dominated by hops and citrus.
Bottled. Hazy deep golden. Grainy malt aroma. Sweet and medium bodied with soft but mellow mouthfeel and notes of honey sweetened mustard. Low bitterness. Unspectacular.

ecz is right that this had little flavour besides wheat, making it taste just like breakfast cereal. but it was 10am and we'd had nothing to eat so it did seem appropriate. maybe it was my empty stomach, but the alcohol did seem particularly warming and dominated the finish

slight banana in aroma otherwise the only flavour is wheat. nothing else, it's like eating cereal, which is not without its pleasures i guess. cardboardy, stale, thin and fizzy. bit of a letdown, i thought harringtons were gunner be good for some reason.
cloudy straw colour, nice tight head. spicey mild bitter tatse..............
Had this at hop cat. Very boring. Smooth and good but boring. Cloudy orange. No head. Apricot and fruity.
On tap at Dragonmead. On Nitro. Poured a golden amber color with a small sized head. Some citrus, floral hops, and lighter toasted malts.

Poured up via nitro tap at the Dragonmead brewpub with a clear copper body, off white head and thick sludgy lacing. The aroma offers up bready and mineral notes as well as some spicy hops. The taste is smooth and pretty yummy with citrus, spicy and floral hop flavor slowly building toward hop bitterness. To about midway it picks up mineral notes.
Had on tap at Ashley�s in Ann Arbor. Lagerish flavors with strong hay and grasslike notes. Somewhat dry and lightly bitter. Not very exciting.
Poured on Nitro at Dragonmead. Pale yellow with huge frothy head. Not much going on in the taste department. Not as creamy as it looks. Mild bitterness. Kind of boring. Need more Juggernaut
Not as distinctive as their other pale. Light taste. Refreshing. Little hop taste.
very average with a bland taste to it. none of the beers here have very good aroma. this one has no aroma or taste. not very good.
On tap at the brewery. Golden amber color. Lastling frothy off white head. Wet grain sweetness with some orange peel citrus notes. The finish brought back the green hops from the nose.
Tap. Medium amber color. Scant off-white head. Light malt aroma with a little grassy hop thrown in. Nice mild malt flavor, a little bready. Slight, but pleasant, hop finish.
On tap: Weak aroma. Light citrus. Transparent orangish-gold with a small white head. Very watery flavor and texture. Waterd down citrus. Light sourness in the finish. Just not enough flavor.

On tap at the brew. I�ve had this a couple of years ago...in fact it was the only beer on tap, just like this time...but I couldn�t recall if I liked it or not. Pours a mahogany red with a good head. Nice bubbles. Nose is typical malt with a nutty, roasted quality...along with chocolate and dates. Flavor was roasted chestnuts with Fig Newtons. Was a bit thin, but has good coverage considering how slick it is. I was surprised by this beer...even if they only had one.
Clear light brown with a thin white head. Sweet caramel and slightly earthy aroma. Toffee flavor with a hint of chocolate. Clean but boring.

Awesome brew.I was hooked on pint #1. It is local only, and only on tap. It is extremely flavorful. Nice round taste with fruity, hoppy fullness. It finishes great, and no gas! lol I am not sure I have had better. It is very rich in color, dark brown, but not black. Very high head due to the tap, and is carmelly sweet, but not overdone. This is a great brew. If you are in town for Wurstfest, you need to stop in for a pint. RERATE: They had a new batch come out last week. I was very disappointed. One of the factors that has to be considered in a brew pub beer is consistency. The new batch was very bitter, and less flavorful. It still had the robustness and berry/maple feel, but the bitterness was painful. Man I was in love with that last batch! lol

Draft at the source. Clear gold in color, ample carbonation level. Aroma is weak grain and straw, nothing more. The flavor is really isn�t much different base tastes like German Pils malt with the straw and grain. Body is real light and thin. What more can I really say about a Golden ale? With this one nothing more.
Draft at the source, from notes. Hazy pale yellow color, medium white head. Aroma of peppery hay. Taste is wet straw. Light body.
Golden pour with a white head. The aroma and flavor are quite buttery with a hint of grass and biscuit malt thrown in. Something is wrong with this batch. Would like to try again.

Well... this is the only regular Faust brew that I�ve never had. Time to drink it. Light, but bright, golden yellow in color, it has a thin, almost soapy bright white head. The nose shows some nice, stiff hops and pilsener malts, leaving a great overall aroma that�s fresh, refreshing, and flavorfully light. A pilsener-like malt flavor and soft bitter finish shows up soon after it enters the mouth, with the in-mouth flavor made up mainly of a fresh grain and soft palated, sharp flavored, very distinctive hops. It�s slightly thicker than your average Texas golden ale. I like it! Tops my list of golden ales.
Clear gold pour, Aroma is light fruit and hops. Flavors of grain, light hop. Boring.
Clear and golden in color with a thin white head. Mild, slightly fruity and grainy aroma. Basic grain and slightly caramel flavor. Rather thin overall.

I am not a blond fan, and this one is not anywhere near my top list. It is bitter and very sharp. The color is very light blond. It has a high head, like the Walter's Brown, but is not flavorful or strong enough. I am prejudiced towards lighter beers, so take my words with a grain.
Definitely hoppy, but I am not a fan of the flavor. It could be that "light beer" problem I have. It is not exceptionally round in flavor, or deep in texture. I am not a fan.
(Draught) Pours an opaque black body with a small tan head. Aroma of peat, licorice, and roasted malt. Flavor of lactose, roasted malt, peat, and cocoa.

This was one of the worst beer experiences of my life. Me and the girlfriend stopped here on the way back from Dodging Duck in Boerne (a respectable brewpub). We walk in at 430 after calling to find out that the brewpub opened at 400. But, upon entry, we noticed that the lights are off and there isnt a soul in the place, not even a bartender. I go to piss and tell the gf to figure this out. When I come out, my gf was talking to a 40 some odd year old bartender woman who was obviously a heavy smoker, her face looked like a catchers mitt. So, I cautiously sit at the bar and ask which beers are available. She goes into some long story about how the place undergoing a change in management and they temporarily halted beer production...all they have is one....the stout. I agree to try this beer. The old hag pulls the tap handle and walks away. I hear air coming through the tap, see periodic sprays of foam. At this point, I shit myself. Are you serious?? The lady walked away to let the lines fill up with this crap. She finally comes back with a plastic pitcher and fills it with a steady stream of foam. I interject with, "I'll just try a sample, how about that"?....the old bag smiles with her pitcher full of foam, now with a 2 inch layer of liquid at the bottom. She takes a metal ice scooper and scoops foam out of the pitcher til most of it was gone! She pours the stout into a small glass and gives it to me. Beads of sweat had developed on my head as I looked down at this scary nectar of Fausts Brewing Company. I take a swig...blah...not bad, just an average brewpub stout. I look up and leatherface says with a thick Texas accent "It's kinda like a guiness". I give her a patronizing smirk and a nod of my head. I look down at this 4 ounce glass and decide to go all out and finish it with one gun. The girlfriend was speechless this whole time--ready to go. The only signs of life she had were the looks of fear when leatherface made random yawning grunts when in the back. I slam the glass on the table when the old bag asks if I want a pint of it. I acted as if I was seriously contemplated whether or not to get a whole pint of this garbage. I, of course, denied leatherface's offer, threw a dollar on the bar, grabbed gf's hand and left. I do not plan to ever visit Fausts again, even once they have new management, I never want to see leatherface again.
At SM�F 2011. Pale golden clear cider with ni head. Fruity with a nice sweetness. Lovley appleflavour. Really refreshing cider.
SM�F 2011. Pale golden, no head. Fruity aroma, sweetish, some apples. Apple flavor, sourish, fruity. Kinda refreshing.
Sample @ SM�F 2011. Pours clear golden with no head. Aroma is apples sweet and sourish. Flavor is sweet fruity refreshing and apples. Finishes sourish sweet fruity.
(bottle). Clear golden color. Small white head. Light apple and alcohol aroma. Light sweet apple flavor. Short duration. Dry finish. Thin/slick texture. Soft carbonation. Spare lacing.

A really good cider, better than its over-produced and excessively tarty competitors. This one maintains a level of sweetness without becoming smirnoff ice hard cider. A nice refreshing drink for any cider fan.

On tap at the monthly Dec. Boston Brewery tasting. This was my first ever alcoholic cider and i really like it. Very smooth on the palate and gong down. Nice faint apple aroma, flavor was sweet and something else accenting the taste, maybe oak? Very nice, i would definitely like to try this again, but they do not sell it in my area (MA/RI).

Bottle, 35 cl. Clear yellow with a green touch, no head but some fizzy bubbles. Fresh aroma of red apples, with some faint wooden notes. Lively carbonation which is perfect for this kind of drink. Very refreshing, dry with rich fruit acids and a little mild sweetness.
Light and fizzy and I�m wasted and this cheese is just super tasty - delish
Pours a nice medium golden yellow color. Smooth apple aromas. Flavor starts out sweet and finishes with a tart ending.

Disappointingly flat...(just my bottle?) Nice rich ripe apply aroma. Good sweet golden delicious flavors...with a clean crisp finish. But this needed a LOT more spritziness to be considered really refreshing.
Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 05/06/2001 Light on the palate with a pale aroma. Hoppy.

Cask. Cloudy, dark copper colour. Nice creamy head. Flowery aroma, fresh fruit. Grassy hoppiness in flavour. Aftertaste is OK bitter, slightly astringent and with some aromatic hoppiness also. Nice, semi-creamy mouthfeel.
[Cask conditioned] Deep amber coloured. Very fruity and hoppy aroma. Fruity flavour with a nice bitter finish. Smooth mouthfeel. Really tasty.
Cask Conditioned at The Swan, Bicester. Gold coloured beer with bubbly head. Crisp dry clean beer, alcohol nose and sharp crystal mouthfeel. Dry fruity finish, but somewhat powdery / perfumed.
Unusually strong for a hot weather summer ale, perhaps Brakspear know what a British summer is really like. It tastes simular to their old ale and bitter.

11th September 2002 - Cask-Conditioned - . Tea colour. Hoppy aroma. Flavour is predominantly malty, slightly hoppy and a little spicy, dry bitter finish. RERATE- Cask-Conditioned, served on gravity into a 4 pint container and taken home. Brilliantly smooth, malty ale. Possibly the last pint of Henley brewed Brakspear's that shall pass my lips. Wycombe Wines, High Wycombe, Buckinghamshire.
Cask Stillage at the Old Broken Cross, Rudheath 11/07/2002 Amber golden coloured and slightly creamy on the palate. Pale aroma. Some bitterness in a lasting finish.

[Cask at Volunteers Arms, GBBF 2005] A hazy plale amber beer with a nice light orange head. The aroma is sweet malty and lightly hoppy, while the flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel, honey, and bees wax.
Cask conditioned GBBF 2005: Reddish appearance with off-white head. Malty slightly roasted. Bitter finish. Quite refreshing.
Cask Conditioned at The Rose & Crown, Charlbury, Oxon. Red brown beer with no head. Wishy washy flavours, a richness in malt perhaps but nothing that distinguishes it. Astringent finish.

slightly disappointing compared to the other brakspears. kind of like a dunkelweizen raping a bitter. clear copper colourwise. light texture, and dry finish, with a strong (for a wheat) fruity hop flavour.
Good bitter, perhaps a bit full bodied for the season.......................
Cask Conditioned, GBBF 2005: Some honet in the aroma. Very refreshing, no head. Cider appearance. Not as bitter as you would expect.

Cask Conditioned at The Falkland Arms, Gt. Tew, Oxon. Pale gold with thin head. Dry bitterness pervades through this beer with a heady peppery overnote. Obviously a play on hops but the flavour could have been fuller. Fair try though.
Sampled cask conditioned. Chestnut brown, slightly hazy. Citric aromatic hop aroma. Light bodied, sparkling mouthfeel. Slightly buttery, a little roaty, dry. Bitter, clean finish.

Thin head atop a deep almost reddish copper pint. Sweet apples and some faint spices in the nose, almost like baked apples. Little to no detectable carbonation and a perfect blend of malts with a tiny bit of hop end make this very easy to drink. It felt very light (if that makes sense) in my mouth, and the pint disappeared very quickly.
Cask conditioned. Very sweet, almost syrup like, but very pleasant. Nice fruit notes. Virtually no hops whatsoever.
NERAX '02: Bubblegum/apple aroma, orange/red color, long sweet aftertaste. Didn't notice the high ABV. Sweet, but not overwhelming.
Absolutely Delicious, Incredibly sweet, a little bit of fruit mixed in strong full flavors. Dark, and a slight bitterness on the finish. Excellent beer.

355ml bottle. Pale yellow colour, foamy white head. Aroma is grain malt, a little bit of lager funk and actually some hops. Taste was much the same. Impressed they actually put some hops in a light beer. Palate was a little watery, as is expected, but no more than anything else in the style. Lots of carbo. Overall, pretty good for a light. Stacks up well against other low cal beers like the 67 and even holds up the the non-light version.

341 ml bottle from the brewery. AP clear golden, overcarbed, quick white head AR almost nothing, some sweet grainy 2 row FL touch of powdery malt, touch of peanut shell, finishes anoyingly dry PA over carbed and super dry, might be the dryest light lager ive ever had OV much better options in light lager catagory

Bottle- Thanks Dave! A sparkling golden pour unleashes a foamy but short lived white head. Nose of grains, grassy hops, some biscuit, slightly fruity. Taste is sweet grainy malts, a bit of grass/floral hops, lemon. Quick, fizzy finish leaves no aftertaste whatsoever. Not all that memorable.

[2476-20090829] Bottle sample. Petrol sweet straw yeast aroma. Clear, pale yellow body with a quick bubbly white head. Sweet hay grain malt flavour has an odd sweet burnt aftertaste. Light body is very fizzy. Not refreshing, fair. &#40Golden Taps �09 @ beerbistro; Toronto, ON&#41
essentially a light version of the blonde. the blonde is fine and so is this i guess. taste is subdued. yellow. yawn.

Draught @ The Brewery: Chalk a higher score up to lower expectations. I wasn�t a fan of the blonde so I wasn�t expecting much from a lighter version of it. The head stuck around longer this time, with a very pale yellow colour on the pour. Flavour was more subtle, and thus to me, more enjoyable. A touch more sweetness, which offered more going on than the blonde. I feel the same way here as I do in the Corona vs Corona Light battle - go with the light, it offers less to be disappointed about.

Bottle (341ml). Poured bright pale slightly bubbly gold with a minimal white head. Not surprisingly, smells just like the "Natural Blonde" only lighter - corn, dry grain, a little harsh. Taste is probably nicer than the blonde - similar, sweeter, but less harsh - very watery mouthfeel, still has that unpleasant aftertaste - acceptable lawnmower/fishing trip beer only.

. Fizzy initial pour. Their regular blond may be better, but the taste is OK for a 4% beer. Thin mouthfeel, some hops and a bit of malt. I would have this before a Molson or Labatt, but it is pretty plain. Thanks for the sample Pootz/Pootzboy.
Much like the non-light version, except thinner. Even more pale in colour and bland in taste. A step up from a macro light, but nothing else.

2009-08-29. Crisp pale yellow body with a small white head. Aroma of grass and straw, pale malts are light, touch of grainy oddness. &#40 6+&#41 Flavour is thin, straw, grainy pale malts, touch of cardboard. Average to light palate. Meh. 6/3/4/3/10 Bottle at Beer Bistro 2003. Wasn�t impressed with it at first, but it finished nicely. A mediocre beer, but an exceptional light beer 4/3/4/2/9 - 2.2

column1: Big Rock Session IPA (India Pale Ale)
column5: Can as gift from Canada. Deep golden colour with a white head. Aroma malty and citrus. Taste light to mid bitter. Medium body.

column1: Big Rock Session IPA (India Pale Ale)
column5: Light grains if anything. Clear gold with a decent white head. Crystal malts and a touch of hop bitterness.

column1: Big Rock Session IPA (India Pale Ale)
column5: Aroma is honey, clove and citrus. Taste is light sweet malts, honey and a mild earthiness. Sessionable, yes.

column1: Big Rock Session IPA (India Pale Ale)
column5: Color �mbar y aromas maltosos con ligeras notas de caramelo. Adem�s, se perciben los aromas c�tricos y pin�ceos de los l�pulos. En boca, es muy fresca con notas c�tricas de toronja y un final seco que facilita tomarla una y otra vez.

column1: Big Rock Session IPA (India Pale Ale)
column5: 473ml can. Pours a clear medium amber-copper with a medium, creamy, long lasting, off-white head that leaves curtains of lace. Sweet, mild aroma of caramel malt, grain and light orange peel. Sweet flavour of caramel malt, bread, orange peel and a hint of grapefruit with a mildly bitter finish. Light body with a thin, watery texture and soft carbonation. Disappointing. Very under hopped and lacking bitterness. Much more like an amber ale, not terrible just boring.

column1: Big Rock Session IPA (India Pale Ale)
column5: Tasty, refreshing. Clean finish. Ok, like but not love. Color is pleasant. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Big Rock Session IPA (India Pale Ale)
column5: I just can�t seem to find a big rock beer that I like. The highest abv session IPA I�ve had with the least amount of flavour. Bit of citrus aromas and taste but mostly watery and boring

column1: Big Rock Session IPA (India Pale Ale)
column5: Upon opening this beer is very aromatically hoppy, more wild sage scent than citrus; it reminds me of summer in the prairies. Taste wise its quite average though, though it isn't the horrible flavour of orange rinds that so many hopped beers posses these days, so it has that going for it. It's an ok drink, but if you can get something better, I would suggest that.

column1: Big Rock Session IPA (India Pale Ale)
column5: On holiday in Canada a 473ml can amber coloured body with a off white head and a spicy malt hops aroma a spicy sweet hops dry bitter taste with a bitter finish

column1: Big Rock Session IPA (India Pale Ale)
column5: Can. Intense yellow-orange, small white head with poor retention, no lacing. Aroma of sugar, hard candies, honey and a touch of spices. Taste of sugary malts, cough syrup and herbs. Total miss for the style.
1L glass bottle pours a golden color with a fast dissipating white head. All I will say about this one is that it is one of the worst beers I have ever tried.

Obligatory malt likra purchase for the long weekend at the lake. Actually looks quite decent-- deep golden with a dense, creamy, lasting white head that captures the gently falling ashes from the stirred-up fire pit, like grey cinnamon dusting a beer latte. Aroma is corn syrup and bananas, no alcohol that I can smell (but I�m fighting campfire smoke, and I�m basically shitcanned at this point anyway). Smooth, sweetly malty, warming. Would I buy this again? Fuck no. Was it a decent malt liquor? Sure. But that�s like saying "That�s the best gas station burrito I�ve ever had".
Golden and clear with minimal head. Corny grassy aroma. Lots of malt, a touch of grain and a little alcohol. Decent for a malt liquor.

Corn, banana, alcohol and grain in the nose. Clear golden body is topped by a decent white head that lasts and laces well. Very sweet flavour shows off plenty of corn, some wacky fruity esters and some alcohol. Grainy in the aftertaste. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Sure it`s well made. Still don`t really care for it though. Bottle sampled with BeerPrince, CapFlu and Oakes.

Slow carbo, gold colour, thin head. Big alcohol on the nose, with some slight crystal malt chewiness and plenty of creamed corn. Full body. Noticeable hop crispness. More chewy maltiness. Everything in balance, and it still retains that kick-you-in-the-nuts character a malt liquor needs to have. A rating to style would be in the high 4s. As it is, this is a remarkably high quality forty.

Dark gold. Starts with a good head and maintains a nice white film. Aroma starts out like high alcohol fuel and then indeed a banana scent comes out. As it sits more of a dirty fuel scent is common with hints of the banana. Relatively full bodied and at least when cool drinkable. Tastes like high alcohol, grain and banana traces. Alcohol burns the ears. Even as it warms it is drinkable. Not a great beer but a great malt liquor, easily my highest rated.

Insanely good malt liquor, im a black bull man but i have to admit that this 40 blows black bull out of the water, you cannot even taste the 9% and its very cheap even compared to other malt liquors, pound for pound this is about as good as beer can get, im proud to say that this is brewed in my home town

1.18Liter bottle = 40OZ. Looks exactly as illustrated in the picture. First of all this is lowest priced alcohol of any kind I�ve seen in Alberta. Chilled in -20C/0F weather, opened bottle, aroma isn�t offensive. Took a sip, this is suprisingly drinkable. I can�t believe this has 9% alcohol init. Zero head, fruity taste(not honey), moderate carbonation, almost no aftertaste. This is cheapest beer in the market at $3.20 per bottle of 40oz. I need to drink few more to find any adverse effect.
Thanks to my future sister-in-law for the one. 1.18 liter bottle. Pretty good. Smooth malt flavor that I wasn�t expecting. Wasn�t harsh. Alcohol was good also at 9%.

Golden beer with a small white head. Pleasant bananas in aroma, almost like a wheat beer, or a hefe. Light fruity taste with pleasant malt. Nice bodied. Actually a very decent malt liquor, aka, Saskahootch. Thanks to the capflu. (Sept. 2004)
Una delle migliori birre analcoliche che ho provato , dal odore e persistenza della schiuma non si distingue molto della classica birra lager , veramente un buon compromesso per un 0,5% di alcol

Zlatnozute boje, tanka bijela pjena, kratkotrajna. Bez izrazene arome, blago trava i neugodno vlazan karton. Blage gorcine, bljutavo, kratkog gorkog finisa. Vodene teksture, blage prema srednjoj karbonizaciji.
0.5l bottle. Light yellow color with white head. Aroma is malty and straw. Taste is sweet with light bitterness. Overall it's drinkable non-alcoholic beer.
Bottle at a restaurant in Umag. Looks just like a typical lager, though smells and tastes very weird, something like a malt+butter+sugar combination, pretty bad.
Clear yellow color with small foam. Some strange sweet taste. Bad, just bad.
50 cl. bottle. A clear golden coloured beer with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, grain, fruit and a bitter hoppy finish.

Enjoyed: Poured from a bottle into shaker glass. Appearance: Clear golden colour, with small / medium head. Aroma: Malt and grains. Palate: Watery, light body, light carbonation. Taste: Malt, wet bread, corn, soury-sweet. Overall impression: Quite good for non-alcoholic beer, and also considering where it is brewed.
0,5 l. bottle. Golden color with big white head, sweet, corn, sugar. like corn juice
koja �alost, tuga, strava i kukuruzni u�as,jednostavno jadno...................H�V
[backlog] 06-04-16 // bottle in Medulin, Croatia. Refreshing after cycling. But more like water.

Bottle from an "Auchan", Bp. Golden colour with a nice, fine poredand slowly collapseing head on its top. Grainy, yeasty, bit watery nose. Flavour�s malty/bready, the aroma has mainly a malty character with some grassy and yeasty undertones. The finish is herbal and light dry. Texture�s unfortunately kinda thin, but apart of this it was better than expected...
Bottle, 4.8%, Hungarian version. OK fruity aroma. Clear golden colour. Very small white head. Mild malty flavour. Medium bitterness, slightly rough. Not bad.

Bottle brewed by Ilzer S�rgyar, purchased at a Kaisers (Spar) store in Budapest, on Rakoczi ut I reckon. Poured a yellow body with a small head that disappeared fast. Light grassy nose, slightly acidic and sweet. A note of sweet maltiness, a bit eggy, covered with an unimpressive bitterish light hop presence. In the end passes as refreshing because of the light bite and bitterness, but I was a bit underwhelmed in the end.

Bottled (BB 12/2008) Brewed by Ilzer S�rgyar, Hungary. Pale yellow color, small white head. A bit skunky, grassy nose. Crisp carbonation. Sweet malty flavor with skunky grassy hops. Expected more from Ilzer.
Bottle. Medium head with short duration. Color is slightly hazy and golden. Aroma and taste are malt and hops. Slight bitterand acidic finish.
Bottle. Golden colour with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of malt and hops.

(Bottle 50 cl) This version brewed by "Ilzer S�rgyar" in Monor. Nice golden colour with a fine, creamy head. Malty nose, medium body with a fine balance between hops and malts. Quite dry and quenching.

Bottled, brewed by Ilzer S�rgyar, Hungary. Pale yellow, small head. A rounded, fairly malty beer with restrained sweetness. The hop rate is fairly low, and the mouthfeel is suffering from slight overcarbonation. Overall a decent helles.
beautiful golden body with a fluffy head. deep wieser scent. smooth leaves traces of flavour in mouth after swallow.
Bottled(500ml). -below average german beer..................................
Pale golden color, weak white head. Corny, malty nose. Taste is corn, some malts, and slightly hoppy. Medium body, light carb. Average hungarian mass lager. Could be better.
Aroma 3. Appearance 3. Taste 3. Palate 2. Overall 8. Grain aroma. Grain and corn syrup taste.
Clean golden color, foam doesn't last long. Maize grits and hops made this an average sweet beer. Watery and malty beer. It's pretty good and drinkable until you reach the bottom.
Exactly what you'd expect a Hungarian lager mass produced by Heineken to be like. Sweat socks, slightly skunky, overly soft palate, fuzzy afterfeel. Can "courtesy" of and shared with Zoltan.

22oz bottle. Admittedly, my family said this was likely a year or two old. Gushes then pours a murky sepia with tons of off white head. Nose isn't great, raisins and caramel. Flavor is caramel and butterscotch, lots of sweetness. Finishes cloying. Woof.

This review is for the bottled 22 oz. As a great restaurant with great values, I want to love People's Pint's bottled beer, but all their bottles taste uneven and uninspired. Their selection might have been new and interesting at one point, but the competition is fierce. It's time to step up their production methods to make a beer that travels well. I suppose the poor taste could have come from an issue in bottling / distribution, but seeing as the point of purchase is about 15 miles away, I doubt it.
Taster at brewpub. Pours light brown with a white head. Leaves some lacing in the glass. Fairly malty and fruity on the nose and tongue. Finished clean. Quaffable.
Enjoyed from a pint glass. Poured a dark, cloudy amber color with a minimal head... Expected a bit more of a hoppy flavor, but was sweet and malty instead. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This draft brew from a beer festival poured a medium sized head of foamy fine to medium sized bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a uncarbonated transparent red brown colored body. The mild aroma was hoppy and caramel malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of caramel hops and malt. A decent one that I would consider drinking again.

Slightly hazy burnt copper and brownish body with a very thin tan head that fades very fast - almost no head/carbonation at all. Very nutty, earthy, caramel and a slight hoppiness, but a very strong scent - nice. Medium-bodied; Flat taste, almost no carbonation; Strong nutty and caramel flavours dominate with a light hoppy touch of pine and herbs and a mellow earthiness at the end. Aftertaste shows some burnt caramel and a little hop bitterness. Overall, an okay beer, but the lack of carbonation and sheer complexity make this hard to say it�s a good beer. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Colonial Spirits in Acton, Massachusetts on 23-September-2010, sampled at home in Washington on 11-October-2010.

07/2007: From a 22 oz bottle. Pours a deep orangish-red color. Brownish head that goes away rather quickly. It�s hazy and deep. Dark and more thick than a regular ESB. Has a roasted pale ale scent. Like a pale, but burnt. There is also a hint of deep berry smell. There is some minor mustiness but I�ll chalk that up to storage rather than the craft of the beer. Does smell a bit like a basement, though, I have to admit. Pale malt taste with a toasted/dry ending. Slight taste of bitter hops. Much more burnt roasted taste that I would have expected. Also some dark berry which balances some of the roasted and bitter flavors. The finish is dry and actually a little ashy. A bite comes at the end, and one that�s not altogether welcome. Overall it�s not a bad brew. It�s a bit stiff and somewhat dry. Surely a darker ESB.

Very deep amber coloured beer. Thin white head. Aroma is quite sweet and malty. A touch of caramel and some soft light cocoa. A touch of soft earthy hops as well. Flavour is pretty pretty solid as well. Sweet and toffeeish but there aren�t any off-flavours. A lingering sweet caramelly finish with a little bit of light stickiness. A decent, if slightly too sweet, sessionable beer.

My Bottom Line: Toasted and caramelized malts benefit from sturdy, spicy hopping and firm leafy bitterness, building a resolute pint of Extra Special Bitter. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam sits atop the nearly clear copper. -Even though the flavor profile is much hoppier than their Pale Ale�s (which is not usually the case in the USA), I found it to be still balanced. -The mouthfeel is healthily lean and softly carbonated. -The hop bitterness is both leafy and earthy. On tap at the brewpub.
on tap-pours an off white head and copper color. Aroma is medium malt-peat, herbal hops. Taste is medium malt-peat, herbal hops. Semi-dry finish. Some Irish red character.
A very basic light beer. Not much nose or flavour but easy to drink. Why breweries insist on these beers I will never know, perhaps cheaper to make then a good porter or IPA?
Tap: Not a lot of nose or flavor, but is clean and crisp and easy to drink.

column1: Granville Island English Bay Pale Ale
column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: The initial strength proves superficial towards the end. Like the structural integrity of any product sold by an infomercial, any adult male in a �stringlet�, or me leaving the house within a month after a breakup.

355ml can @ Kelly's Cabin. Pours a clear golden colour with a medium white head. Nose is lightly grassy, touch herbal, and a biscuity malt. Flavour is pretty much the same. Light bodied, nice carbonation, and a mild sweetness with soft bitterness.

On tap at Oscar's Pub in east Vancouver. A pale amber beer with a modest pale head and a faint hop and malt nose. A 16 ounce pour in a tall cylindrical glass. Lightly hopped and the malt is light and slightly sweet. It's listed as a Dortmunder/Helles, but truth be told, it's not noticeably different from a pale lager. Refreshing if it's very cold, and one's very thirsty, else not so much. 2.7
Draught at the Museum Tavern, Bloor Steer, Toronto. An easy drinking lager. Not too sweet and some bitterness. Drinkable but not great.
Round-tasting lager with long afterglow on the tongue. Could session on this.

Draught: This one pours a clear golden color. There was a thin white head that left minimal lacing. Very light nose. Faint malts. The taste is OK. No real bitterness or sweetness. Some malts. A basic industrial lager, but better than most of its American brothers.

Pours a thin white cap and has a pale straw coloured appearance. Weak lacing. Light aromas of citrus hops, wheats, very grassy. Flavours are mildly sweet, mostly malts, crisp, and herbal hops. Light mouthfeel, prickly sensation. Excessive carbonation. Not bad just nothing special really.
Draft. Clear yellow body, big white head. The aroma is funky and the taste is horrible. There are thousands of beers like this around the world. Why even sell it?

Faint hazy dark straw color with lots of activity. Slightly frothy white 2 finger head, lasting around 5 minutes, but producing very good amounts of lacing. Flavors of fresh barley, caramel, buttery floral and herbal hops. Highly sugary, a little syrupy, with roasted spiciness. Smooth medium body with crispy carbonation. Light finish, lingering caramel sweetness and grassy hoppy notes. Overall good quality craft. Inviting smell, decent flavors, nicely balanced and accessible. Feels like a quality malty pilsner. Although a little thin, flat, and lacking some freshness.

On tap. Pours a clear golden with a small white head that laces. Sweet aroma of bready malt and grain. Sweet flavour of biscuity malt, corn and a light grassy bitterness in a crisp finish. Light body with a watery texture and average carbonation.
Very strong character full of grass and biscuits. Slightly corny aftertaste. Sweet finish.
Cask Handpump at the Vernon Arms, Liverpool 08/04/2004 Golden and hoppy beer which is slightly creamy on the palate. Bitter finish that lasts.
Cask-conditioned @ Black Boy, Winchester. Grassy citric hops. Some malt character. Refreshing with growing bitterness.

Cask, Royal Oak, Sevenoaks. Nice pub with interesting carved figures of historical characters around the bar. Beer is a light amber. Lovely lemon and tangerine flavour. White wine with a touch of vinegar aroma. Soft fruity finish lingering briefly before ending on a softly astringent note. Decently refreshing with enough complexity to keep interest but not to overwhelm.

Perhaps my mood was still in the winter season, but this light-colored "spring ale" was far too plain. I couldn't pick up an appreciable aroma, and while not offensive, the beer failed to make any impression.
Not a cains beer!!!!! ill think youll find this was brewed by wapping............... cains under their current ownership couldnt do a beer as good as this........

Interesting but not especially rewarding beer. No head, with a watery palate. Lightly hoppy, with a flavor late in the finish that I couldn't place--clover, perhaps? (Had on tap at Bookbinder's Arms, Oxford)

On tap at BAR in a pint glass. Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma of toasted and pale malts, some floral hops, and some dough/bread. Flavor the same with a decent blend. Average texture. Not bad for the style.

Tap. Pours clear dark yellow with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with spare lacing. Aroma is toasted Pils malt and light vanilla notes. Flavor is malt dominant with a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.
Draft at the source. Clear golden color. Aroma of subtle white pepper. Taste is black pepper, light straw. Light body.
Easy to put down a couple pitchers of this one. On draft at brewery. Paired well with pizza.
On the light side, but fairly clean. Has markings of a session beer if you�re looking for something refreshing. Finishes off a little sour.
Pours a bubbly clear yellow with white lacing. Aroma is diacytl, butter and almond. Mouthfeel is slippery.

Pours pale golden with small fizzy head. Grainy with a strong caramel sweetness. Malty flavor, but kind of skunky. Not very crisp and sort of muttled. Hoped for a blonde to be a little more refreshing.
(Draught) Pours a clear pale yellow with a small off-white head. Aroma of honeycomb, toasted grain, and nuts. Flavor of toasted grain, cereal, grass, subtle honey, and delicate florals.

My Bottom Line: Toasted and caramelized cereals overcome the herbal hops and their bitterness in this easygoing Blonde Ale. Further Personal Perceptions: -A ring of foam circles the nearly clear gold. -While the first half of the sip is pretty sweet, the second half can be said to be well dried out. -Once again, the nose is very timid and not enticing. -All of their beers had a level of sweetness that is not necessary in session ales of the sort they brew. On tap at the brewpub.
On tap at the BruRoom Brew Pub. Poured a lighter golden color with a smaller sized white head. Aromas and tastes of grains, citrus and a matly sweetness. LIght lacing left on the glass.
On draft at brewery. Regular pale ale. Piney hops. Laura didn�t like it :(.

Taster on tap. Pours a clear medium amber color with thin head. Aroma light hops. Flavor has a nice hoppy bite on the front, mellowing to a medium bodied balanced salt finish. Good beer for eating pizza. Just enough character to stay afloat. Overall, a well-behaved and balanced ale without a lot to distinguish itself.

On tap at BAR. Pours copper with a lacy head. Aroma of caramel and pale malts plus a little bit of floral and piney hops. Flavor the same. Average texture. A decent pale ale. Edit: Dec 2014. Better this time. Hoppier. Moved from 3.3 to 3.5.

Pours a heavily filtered dark orange, with no lacing. Aroma has hints of metal, but predominantly pince, resin and grapefruit. A somewhat biscuit malt component balances the hops out. Hints of diacytel.
Pours a slight dark yellow with a very thin light white head. If I inhale really really deeply I might get a slight hop every once in a while. Some hop character on the tongue but it doesnt linger.

My favorite and least flawed beer from the BAR. This is overall a pretty well balanced pale ale with solid hop/malt blend. This was the only beer I had from the night that had a pleasant aftertaste of bitter hop zing. This was a little bit on the watery side, but overall not bad.

In short: A basic refreshing brewpub pale ale. Uninspired but well brewed, I can�t complain. How: Tap at brewpub The look: Clear golden blonde body topped by a small off-white head with good lacing In long: Nose of standard pale ale (light C-hops kind of nose). Taste has some citrus fruits, soft caramel, light grapefruits notes. Mild bitterness with a light tartness. I�ve had a pale ale like that 100 times before. I cannot fault it for anything. It was a hot day and I drank my pint in 10 minutes. I liked it. Inoffensively drinkable. It is what it is. The BruRm brewpub is right next to the prestigious Yale University. It was kind of weird for me to see all these high class kids sitting in a pub at 4pm working on their laptops. I sat in front of one, opened my laptop, looked at him and said �I sank your battleship". Good times.

On tap at the BruRoom Brew Pub. Serviceable cascade lke pale. Golden yellow body with lace sheets down the glass. The aroma is hoppy, but also malts. The carbonation is right there. Good orange citrus flavour, good drinkability.

My Bottom Line: Fruity yeast and hops scent this thin Pale Ale�s mild caramel malts, leading to light wooden hop bitterness. Further Personal Perceptions: -A ring of foam still laces atop the golden clarity. -The nose is not appealing at all. Very low on hops, and there was some window cleaner (chemical) aspect as well. -Carbonation was smooth and the body well rounded. On tap at the brewpub.
On tap at the BruRoom Brew Pub. Poured a deeper golden color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, citurs, and a little earthy. Tastes follow suit. Light lacing left on the glass.
Pours dark brown with some off white bubbles. Smells of licorice, roasted malt, ash, chocolate. Tastes semi sweet with a nice bitterness that results in a dry, chocolatey finish.

Deep dark plummy brown. Thin edge head. Little if any carbonation. Vinous aroma laced with burnt caramel and coffee. Thickish body for a Baltic Porter loaded with bittersweet prune notes and light caramel and dried coffee beans. So quaffable despite it's size. Finishes drier and slightly more intense in the vinous fruit quality. A true to form Baltic Porter here in Connecticut. Well done.

Bottle: Deep brown ....see-throu when backlit, small tan head. Aroma of melted chocolate and cocoa. Taste is slightly lactic, roasty dark chocolate malt. A bit of earthy bittering. Pretty nice, overall.
Bottle. Sour milk, chocolate malt, and dry hay aroma. Dark chestnut brown with small tan head. Mildly sweet chocolate malt and mildly bitter hay flavor. Good body. Pretty good.
12oz bottle included in a craft beer club shipment. Pours dark brown with a tan head. An OK porter though maybe a tad on the sweet side.
Bottle in Seattle. Thin foam, modest brown body. Clear edge. Cool cola body, mild bitter. Good flavor in a lighter body. A touch sweet, fairly thin. Not fantastic.
On tap at Dick�s, pours a deep dark reddish brown with a small tan head. Aroma and flavour of toasted malt and a touch of cocoa powder. Not very interesting. Decent.
Draft - Toasted malts. Deep dark brown with a light brown head. Toasted malts, light bitterness and a roasty malt finish. Nice.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown color with a moderate tan head that quickly disappears. Nose actually seems a little sour to me, with just a hint of roasty and chocolate flavors in there. Taste is also a bit sour, which was surprising to me. Fairly smooth, but not all that tasty.

Reviewed 06/23/10 poured from bottle to new belgium tulip A: deep brown on pour. obvious yeast cake in bottle. low carbonation avg for bottle conditioned beer. deep brown, the beer is difficult to assess given the depth of color. Light, velvety head translucent. Ongoing ribbon presumed on cap at center of ale top. S: I could smell the chocolate, coffee, roastiness of ale while pouring into glass. full bodied and rich, slight hop pine scent in background. T: Thick, rich. lacks normal astringency i taste in many porters. Slightly burnt aftertaste. M: rolls over tongue and foams slightly. Leaves creamy, slick coating on tongue. D: good beer. one of my favorite porters. Always recommend when asked about micro porters. Serving type: bottle 12-20-2010
Very tasty. Smokey up front but sweet malty finish. Slight coffee twinge in the midst of it all. Really a great beer to have in the fall. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This Porter is a dark brown, nearly black color with a medium beige head that dissipates steadily. Short strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of malt and coffee. Medium body with flavors of chocolate, malt and slight hops. The finish is roasty with a sweet chocolate malt aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

330ml bottle from Blenheim New World. Nice copper colour faint head but does linger. Aroma quite malty. Nice toffee / butterscotch. Good body, sweetness thru the middle and a real maltbiscuit flick at the finish. Well crafted beer.

Amber in colour with big white creamy head. Typical English bitter style, mild hop bitternes. (Perhaps too may Belgian beers this week and change of palate brought marks down) Orginal 3 3 5 2 8 2.1 Rerate Dark amber in colour, small white head. malty hop aroma, estery/apple like flavour.

Copper coloured beer with a thick creamy white head. Aroma is quite malty, caramel, toffee, and a touch of vanilla. Light spicy hops. Flavour is semi-sweet, with vanilla, toffee, and a creamy toasted malt character. Light apricot fruitiness as well.
Copper color, slight haze, cream colored head. Fruity malt and hops go well together, orangy along with some bready flavors. Medium bodied. Pretty nice.

Thanks to Sammy for this rare beer. Sampled with Tim and Rudy. Vinous, alcoholic, fruity aroma. Kind of smells like fermented cow corn ethanols. Moderately hazy copper color with a whitish head. Very tea-like flavor to start, turning sweeter and caramelly.
Thanks to Sammy. Nose has tea and orange, sweetish malt. Flavor has orange, bread, malt, tea-like. A solid English Pale - I�d like to try this one fresh.
Hoppy nose with notes of malt, spice and maple. The body is warm and malty with peppery undertones and sweet hints of brown sugar and male syrup. Pours a deep bronze with a fluffy off-white head.
pure enjoyment from this brewery. Well hopped, malt, great with a multi-course supper. Quite drinkable and complex. Sadly the last of 5 great beers from this region brought back by Douglas D

I found this beer to be very similar to the Mammoth, with just a litle less of everything - less alcohol, a bit less hop and malt taste, and not quite such a funky aroma. Would make an excellent session beer.
some pretty damn good yeast they've got going there. sweet stonefruit aroma. hint of butterscotch schnapps and then some pepperiness and a slow bitter finish with some self raising flour

14-Jan-12 (330-ml bottle: Gift purchased at Pembroke Wine & Spirits in Wanaka, New Zealand and received 23-Dec-11, thanks Melissa!) This beer pours very hazy and amber-brown in color, with half an inch of creamy, pale-tan head that settles to a thin, nearly unbroken layer, leaving plenty of spotty lace on the glass. In general, it's not especially aromatic, but the nose is dominated by somewhat sweet, very toasty malts that smell like bread crust and a bit of earth and mushroom. The earthy, toasty malts are the focus in the flavor as well, as lightly sweet, toasted, cereal malts have a distinct flavor of bread crust and honey, while the grassy hops are gently bitter and just a complementary, background flavor. For me, that's good news because it's very malty and very delicious. The weight is medium, carbonation is light-medium, and though a bit sweet to the taste, there is enough toasty dryness on the palate that the sweetness is held at bay. As such, it's a very drinkable beer, one that makes you think it's a session beer, but the 7% ABV will sneak up on you. I know it's "only" a brown ale, an oft-maligned style, but I'm really enjoying this!
From notes. Bottle. Hazy orange brown color, medium tan head. Aroma of raw bread and licorice. Taste has light spice, burnt caramel and toast. Interesting.

Bottled. New Zealand holiday 2011-12. Old notes. The aroma has raisin, some spice. Clear, red-brown coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is sweet, has caramel, raisins, plum and some clove. Good.

(Bottle) above average beer. Nice brow to dark amber colour, thick white-brown head. Caramel, malt and brown sugar with little bit of syrup in the aroma. Caramel and sweet background. Bitter with earthy undertone and warming alcohol finish. Full body, medium carbonation.
For me, a swing and a miss. I�ve avoided this for a while but it�s been in the fridge and demanding attention. All the flavour via the caramel and that�s not good enough,
very sticky fruits in here, which is nice, but the hop bitterness in this one seems a bit off. but otherwise the deep caramels are quite nice, along with that stickiness.
Flavoursome & full with just enough bite to make a statement without overpowering. Almond notes with a lemon undercurrent. Very enjoyable. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aromas of sweet malt and roasted nuts/chestnut. Loads of sweet thick caramel malt character. Very rich, one for the armchair
Big beer from Mr Pink. Good deep colour and this shows through in the beer. Little raisony in the palate

Definitely not my style. Shocking taste, too bitter and floral, a seemingly unnecessary abuse of hops. The beer seems to have its legion of admirers though, by the scores below. I was actually eager to love it, but I must say that I found it disappointing, to say the least.
Country tick #92, Light pale colour, small head, aroma sweet, malt, grain, corn, taste is the same, sweet, light bitter, not bad.

I have purchased this beer, at one small cr�ole shop, place de l'Aligre, Paris. Drinking and judging it, at Pr�laz, Lausanne, october 2018. The body is yellow/gold and clear, average carbonation, thin and white foam. It is aa common and rather poor lager for mass people that you could find from all over the world. There is nothing to see with a pils, it sounds more a poor lager with corn giving a poor taste at the palate, metalic and dry, poor quality of hop.
Golden and clear with a small head.Slightly hoppy but nothing really distinctive about it apart from being country number 98.
Bottle at a tasting. Sweetish corny syrupy, devoid of anythin else really, maybe light warmth. Clean, eh, okay.
Bottle, kindly shared by Rubin77, many thanks. Golden color with head. Aroma of malt, corn, bitter hops. Taste, the same.
Bottle at tasting, thanks Rubin. Malty aroma and taste, cardboard, light sour notes, light to medium bitter. Medium body, malty bitter finish. Not good.
Country #123. Bottle at Slovak tasting 08/2019. Pours golden color, white head. Aroma of malt. Taste is medium sweet, malty, caramel.

33cl bottle as "THB Pilsener" from Le Kaloupil� creol restaurant in Nice, France. Big, white head, not long lasting. Pale gold, clear colour. Nose is weak malty, watery, bit bready, bit papery. Malty, bit caramel, grassy bitterness, bit papery oxidized, medium body and medium carbonation, not for the style at all but ok for country tick.

330ml bottle from Bien Manger. Yellow gold colour, white foam head leaving some lacing and aroma of corn, malt, grass. Taste is sweet corn grainy, malty, with cardboard, hay, grassy, metallic bitterness. Medium bodied, high carbonation, dry grassy bitter finish. Standard pale lager.
33cl Bottle. Gift from a friend. Golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma is malt, straw. Taste is malt, sweet, grain, cardboard. Light body, average carbonation.

Yellow gold, bright, watery and almost still with no head. Not exactly screaming at me right now. Weedy and grassy nose with a hint of salty brine and cardboard. Hmm.... Gassy, carbonic, watery thin and lagered of all life. Really close to soda water. It could be the first beer I�d admit a lemon wedge would actually enhance. Very little here at all. (33cL, BB 28/10/15, Luckies Liquor, East Vic Park)

Keg - Edison�s, Mona Vale. Poured a clear, lively golden yellow with a small, slowly fading white head. Aromas of grain, corn, grass and lemony hops . Light to medium body, medium to full carbonation, firm mouthfeel and a short, soft intensity bitterness in the finish. Crisp and refreshing with some malt sweetness to balance.

OLD NOTES JAN 17, 2004 Has a corny malt aroma. A few hop notes, as well as a few light sweet caramel malty kind of flavours came through. Nothing special, but not bad for your average lager. Easy and decent price.
Not a bad beer but nothing spectacular. Good with a juicy hamburger or pizza. --- Beer in my belly makes me hoppy.

I was expecting something pretty ordinary, but got something pretty decent. A hearty pour gave me a beer with an orange body and a medium sized head that didn�t last or lace much. An initial aroma of lychees (!) was followed by some pineapple and caramel malt. The flavour is quite inert however, with not much bitterness and a bit of sweetness smoothing it out. A medium body, with a good carbonation level. A pleasant surprise, especially considering it�s 10 months past it�s best by date!

Bottle-Poured a nice thick white head which left some minimal head and lacing. Nice golden colour with a malty hay aroma. Initial taste was sweet & fizzy on the palate but a bit dry in finish I had tasted this beer a couple of years ago and was not impressed but having revisited it today i have changed my opinion. Not a bad effort certainly a different taste to some other aussie lagers. Would have again.

Bottle: Sigh..... Sometimes things can be so predictable. Here we go then: Pale gold with a thick white head - looks good, there�s no doubt about that. Add to this the initial aroma of freshly mown grass that greets me as the cap is popped and things are beginning to look good. Unfortunately the lawn mower had been trimming the verge above a mid-sized cliff. Let us just say that things go decidedly down hill - the aroma fades to a mettalic passionfruit and pineapple salad. OK, nothing particularly wrong so far, but as it warmed this aroma profile morphed into an unmistakable �urine-from-a-dehydrated-person� smell. Urghh! Right, so forget the aroma let�s see what this tastes like (hopes are dim now): Crisp, cool lemony hops notes lift in the beginning (so far so good). Some very faint malt notes too (not much... did they actually use any?). Crumpff!! We hit the valley floor - any pleasantness in the flavour spectrum gives way to a spicy, rough bitterness with (again) that overbearing mettalic presence. Ah, the vicissitudes of Pale Lager. Where would we be without them.

Pale golden, clear, medium head. Above average for the Aussie premium lager market, but still pretty boring. Is it worth paying the extra over, say, VB or Castlemaine XXXX Gold? It sepends on how discriminating you are, but I�m not sure that it�s a big enough difference. I�d probably just spend the extra and buy a solid european lager.

Botled. Golden colour, clear, brief head. Grassy aroma with a whiff of grapefruity hops. Sweet and firmly malty with clean mouthfeel and a fair amount of hops, resulting in an orangey flavour and a pleasantly bitter finish. Nothing spectacular, but a solid, well made lager.

Above-average Aussie "premium" lager - but the average is depressingly poor. Straw colour, moderate head. Plenty of malt in the aroma. Fruity taste - apples probably - crisp and refreshing. Some bitterness but no real finish, unfortunately. (Bottle)
Typical Belgian tripel-style ale with a bit of spiciness and a lot of zestiness. Big white head.

Blonde taken over from the Biertoren brewery, like several others. Hazy golden blonde with thick, frothy, off-white head; grainy, somewhat toasted flavour, yeasty, a bit phenolic with a thin mouthfeel, dryish and feeling a bit �empty�. Bland.

31/X/14 - 33cl bottle from De Bierloods/Zytholoog (Adegem) @ home - BB: VI/2015 (2014-1276) Clear gold beer, small creamy white irregular head over lots and lots of brown slimy chunks. Head is little stable, non adhesive. Aroma: very sweet, sugary, some banana, spicy touch, almonds. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: very spicy, orange peel, almonds, marzipan, bit sweet.
