Malty, slightly eggy aroma. Some sweetness in the flavour and minor bitterness. Actually the taste isn�t too bad; it�s just on a very small scale. Afterwards you wonder why you bothered.
A standard (rubbiish) every day dirty northern bitter in the mould of John Smith�s and Tetley�s. Shit!
It just wasn't worth the effort to write notes on this swill................
good clean, crisp lager. won't fill you up, light coloured lager, thin head, weak aroma

Shaftebury Brewing Company--Summer Solstice Ale--2000 12 oz. Bottle. 4.50% ABV. (2.75 / 5.0) Pilsner Ale. Very clear light golden color. Light lager like Saaz hop front. Very similar to domestic lager in taste with light fruit ale hints. Light bodied, tasty, nice hops. Clean light hop balanced finish. Sampled 7/5/2000.

I don�t ordinarily like Shaftebury, but this was okay. Pale golden colour with a faint chill-hazed appearance and a disappearing white head. Pale malty aroma, light floral hoppiness and some bready yeastiness. Flavour is actually pretty good, decent amount of malt and a clean finish. A fairly quaffable summer beer.
Yellow with hints of honey, wow, please don�t amaze me. I guess it would be Ok in the summer, but I can think of a few more hefes I would rather drink.
Not bad...poured a golden yellow, but the head went south quickly. I agree with Tipsy McStager on this one...very weak palate. Mind you, it IS wet, it IS beer, and it ISN'T American!

stinky, foul aroma. Pours a golden yellow, carbonation high, head mid range. This kind of tastes like a fruit beer, except all the fruit is rotten. Very weak palate and unusual aftertaste. Shaftebury is a brewery you want to avoid except for their cream ale.
Golden amber body with a small off white head. Aroma was lightly malty and little else. Taste was sweet but thin. Finish was spicy and not really enjoyable.
Sparkling golden amber. Fast fading off white head. Nutty nose with light malt taste, but cigar butt off taste

Pleasant aroma as I poured the glass. The aroma died out quickly. Light but lasting head of white bubbles. For a light summer ale it has an intriguing spice flavour that I cannot place. ALmost a ginger taste that lingers. This weird taste takes it out of the summer guzzler category but not sure where it takes it to. As it warms the aftertaste is almost soapy. Very interesting and worth a sample but can't say I see a fit as a regular beer. SECOND BEER AND I CANT GET PAST THE SPICE AFTERTASTE!
I haven't had this one since last summer actually, but i'm going to go out and grab some (it comes with a free pint glass)
A really basic pilsener. Really rather sweet taste. Texture is fairly thin and watery. Not a whole lot going on here.

Vancouver 25/7 2018. 47,3 cl can from BC Liquor Store in Valemount. Yellow can with a fence positioned on top of a landscape with a Lake in British Columbia. The person who designed this Can seems to be quite confused. Pours clear yellow with medium-sized white head. Settles as 1 cm thick layer of foam completely obscuring the surface of the beer. Substantial Lacing. Aroma is not especially intense. Sweet malts, butter. Moderate hoppiness. Grassy. Medium carbonation. Thin, lively and prickly texture. Flavor has medium sweetness. Followed by stronger bitterness. Aftertaste is bitter. Lingers shortly. Simple pilsner-style beer. A tad sweet but nicely balanced by a notable bitterness.

Golden clear lager with sudsy medium head. The head persists. Purely malt aroma profile with bread, cereal, and some hay. Lightly sweet with just the barest hint of hop bitterness. The body is medium and the finish short.

Can 0,50L. Courtesy of my cousin Tony. Crystal clear, golden color with small, creamy, white head. Aroma of grain, hay, toasted malts. Light sweet flavor with some crispness and light bitter finish. Medium body, dry texture and slick carbonation. Decent pilsner, good as a thirst quencher.
Deep golden frothy white head. Virtually no nose with a bit of cereal. Very malty and lackluster

This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a nice looking semi-hazy yellow color with a decent transparency about it. Light carbonation was seen rising to fill a slim fingered white foamy head. Light ringy lacing clings and then slides into the beer. The smell had some sweet corn and cereal / graininess to it. The taste was mainly sweet through the corn with a long sweet aftertaste leading to a wet finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light on the body with a good sessionability about it. The carbonation was pretty smooth as it seemed barely there. Overall, not bad, definitely do-able, but I think it may have been a little old as the carbonation seemed just a bit too smooth.
Pretty well balanced and flavourful for a Pilsner. A nice crispness to it with bread, hops, floral flavours. A nice bitterness at the end.

Can @ AirBNB Arts Colony. Pours a slightly hazed golden color with a finger of white foam. Aromas of butterscotch, bread dough, and popcorn. A lot of grain husk and flowers, too. An interesting fruity ester component...apricot? Flavor is sweet and bready. A lot of butterscotch as well. Hints of cracker and caramel popcorn. Some light floral and earthy hops. Mild bitterness. Not bad.

Tree brewing�s kelowna Pilsner. 4.8% drunk from the can. �2.60$ for a 500ml can. Pale gold pour, thick head. Light malts, crackery aroma. The taste is light grains, crackers, bread crust, sharply bitter finish. Meh it is ok, though it has an odd earthy nutty character to it. It is a pilsner made without pilsner malt - not to style.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Not exactly what I was expecting in a Pale Ale. However, when in Canada order the poutine and Nat Bailey Pale Ale.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Not much of an APA but really not bad. Deep amber pour. Caramel malt. Better than the White Spot food I�ve had.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Caramel flashes, some malt backbone. Heavily carbonated, and too watered down. Meh..

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Nose is very bready with some hops, flavour is dirty bread, dry. Metallic. Not good. Tastes like an EPA.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Just a normal pale ale. Nothing special. Very transparent color and unfortunatelly bad head...

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Fairly bland in both nose and palate. Has some caramel and malty flavours but not much else.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: On tap at white spot in Richmond. Copper colour. Missing the maltiness and hopiness that I expected. Not so great ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Draught Served in a frosted glass, uh. Hazy amber color; small creamy head. Remarkable for its absence of aroma and flavor, and bitterness; a new achievement.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Deep amber, thin off white head. Aroma is malty caramel, light yeast. Taste is lightly malted, caramel, mild hoppiness.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Decent level of head and an amber body, vague aroma of malts Very drinkable, but very simple. A reasonably good choice if you�re at a White Spot restaurant and need something with a burger.

column1: Phillips Hop Circle IPA (formerly Phillips IPA)
column5: Can. Just hazy amber with an inch of white head. Aroma of grapefruit, bread crust, gentle fresh cut pine. Medium bodied. Resin, some citrus, bread crust - guess I would have preferred just a little cleaner but it's characterful and engaging. Brief, decisive bitter end.

column1: Phillips Hop Circle IPA (formerly Phillips IPA)
column5: Pint draft at Taps Beer Bar in Kuala Lumpur. Appearance is a hazy orange gold, topped with a finger of white froth which does not persist for long before retreating to a thin ring. Aroma is floral and piney hops, followed by a distinct caramel malt note. Taste is similar, lightly sweet, piney, but above all a sweet caramel flavour which persists for a long finish. Mildly bitter only, light to medium bodied. Distinct taste, nice brew!

column1: Phillips Hop Circle IPA (formerly Phillips IPA)
column5: Orange pour, small off-white head. Orange, pine, and caramel, sweet. Not bad!

column1: Phillips Hop Circle IPA (formerly Phillips IPA)
column5: 6.5%ABV. IPA. Tapped out deep gold. 12�SRM. Nose has aromas of pine, citrus peel, and spruce. There is also a good full malty funk. As it warms, the spicy, fresh herb aromas start to emerge suggesting cilantro and parsley. Mouthfeel is juicy and round. Full and pleasing. Palate has flavors of barley toast, fresh biscuits. Hop flavors are aggressive featuring resin, sap, and alkaloid type flavors that suggest poisonous plant extracts. Finish is lingering with a deep resinous, ponderous sappy bitter that is almost oily. Overall, a really nicely balanced IPA that has a kick-in-the-groin deeply resinous bitter finish, which is likely to be the enduring impression of this beer. For me, it was the grain bill that was the unsung hero on this allowing the ponderous hop profile to be slowly and continuously tasted.

column1: Phillips Hop Circle IPA (formerly Phillips IPA)
column5: 35,5 cl Can @ Bier Kraft, Seville, Spain. Hazy amber colour with a medium size white. Aroma is hops, citrus, pine. Taste is hops, citrus, grass, malt. Medium body, average carbonation.

column1: Phillips Hop Circle IPA (formerly Phillips IPA)
column5: Tap at Beer Republic, Bangkok. Poured a hazy light amber with a frothy white head and some clingy lace. The aroma is grassy, light pine needle, citrus hop. The flavour is moderate bitter with a dry malt, light fruity, woody hop bitter palate and a long bitter. Medium bodied with average to soft carbonation.

column1: Phillips Hop Circle IPA (formerly Phillips IPA)
column5: 355 ml can. Pours clear copper color with a large white head. Resinous hoppy aroma, malts, pine needles, orange and some grapefruits. Flavor is bitter malty, resinous hoppy, some caramel notes, slightly oily feel from the hops too. A solid resinous IPA. 4515

column1: Phillips Hop Circle IPA (formerly Phillips IPA)
column5: 355ml can. Cloudy, orangey golden colour with small to average, frothy, moderately lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Citrusy hoppy and caramel malty aroma, notes of lemon, orange, hints of grapefruit. Taste is citrusy hoppy, notes of lemon, a touch of lime, hints of grapefruit and orange, slightly too weak caramel malty backbone. Flawless yet unspectacular West Coast IPA.

column1: Phillips Hop Circle IPA (formerly Phillips IPA)
column5: 355ml can Coppery color, off-white head with some lasting and nice lacework. Aroma with a high presence of grapefruit, resin hops and light caramel. Flavor with a decent bitterness, good maltiness, peach andgrapefruit notes. Bittery final with astringent mouthfeel.

column1: Phillips Hop Circle IPA (formerly Phillips IPA)
column5: Pours a large frothy, foamy head that gives off good dirty lacing. Aromas of hops, lemony, and oranges. Flavours are very citrus oriented. Oranges, grapefruit, mild lemon with mild floral hops and very mild malts. Nice warming sensation. Hoppy bitterness found in an IPA, this one�s much more apparent. Really nice taste ant not too bitter. Good balance.
Crystal clear yellow color with steady carbonation that allows the rentention of a nice white head. The aroma is hay and grain with a sweet corn note. Ok pils.
Can't put my finger on it as I had a Pil tonite. You have to slam it back. If you nurse it and go around the 15 minute mark with it, it starts to go flat. Plus colder the better.

For a cheaper Pilsner in bottles or tall boys I find this beer really good for it's price range compared to other major Pilsners around it's price range. The bottle logo is awesome, the beer is refreshing. For a cheap beer it's not bad at all.

I'm also rating this in terms of it's "cheap beer" status. Is it actually a 5 out of 5? Nope, maybe a 3.5, but as far as affordable lagers go, this is by far my favourite and in my opinion deserves a higher score.
This beer is great. Im trying to boost the rating. You guys are rating it all wrong. Its a damn good $2 tallboy when compared to others.
Can. Pours clear pale golden with small white head. Average carbonation. Sweetish malt and light hops. Bitter finish. Average pils.

A super can from 8th St. Liquor store in New Westminster. A very pale beer with generous white head and a faintly sweet malty nose. Very lightly hopped and malted, but not overly sweet. It calls itself a pilsner, but RB lists it as a pale lager, which really it is. It does not have the bright crispness of a Czech pils. I give it 2.3
Goes great with palm bays (palm breezys) keg stands, douchy pool parties and dumping your girlfriend over txt because she's taking time away from "da boiz"
Pale yellow pour, fairly large head that disappeared fast. Grassy and grainy aroma and taste, corn, light hopping detected. Easy drinking, if nothing else.

Pours a huge foamy, bubbly white head which gives off thick patchy lacing. Has a straw coloured appearance. Mainly grainy and wheaty aromas. Very light roasted malts. Some hints of corn adjunct used in this one. Flavours are pretty much same as aromas. Just lots of corn, grains and wheats. Very mild sweetness. But something about it makes it real easy to drink and has just enough flavour. Sort of a mild, flat, prickly mouthfeel. Light and smooth, not much else. Awesome old school/retro label on cans from the old Lethbridge, Alberta brewed beer.
Clear red gold some foam. Aroma stale honey malts, paste. Tastes generic cereal. corn pops maybe? astringent grain. ugh. sorry snipes, I usually like your stuff but this one... nope

Thx tot Joris (from de Plukker), taste yesterday 09/09/�14 from bottle 50 cl. @ William�s Place. Bit hazy amber color, with a offwhite head. Aroma: sweet, malts, hops, light fruit. Medium body. Taste: lightsweet, hopsbitter, malts, fruit.

Bomber thanks to my friends Erin & John. Pours opaque amber with thin white head. Aroma is malty & hoppy; caramel, citrus, and bread. Flavor is grassy, earthy, bitter with a thin body. I also detect some malty chemical sugary-ness that throws the whole experience off for me.
Bottle... Poured an amber/orange-ish with a medium, white head. A nice, mild ale with noticeable esters a low to medium hop bitterness. Quite sessionable and an earthy, creamy, sugary, malt profile.
Clear amber, small white head. Aroma of leather and dry leaves. Sweet caramel, smoky ham, light on the hops. Balanced to the point that the hops never really come out until beyond the finish.

Draught @ WABF 2008. Pours a slightly hazy orange color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty slightly piney hoppy aroma. Fruity malty hoppy flavor with some piney hints. Sweetish malty finish with some light bitter hoppy aftertaste.

Had at brewery and in my opinion this was the worst beer they had. Pours hazy bright orange with slightly bubbly white head. Smells literally like nothing. Flavor very light and watery with slight piney hop presence. Has the taste of a beer that maybe at one time was good until grain and hop prices went up. I think they cheaped on this beer to cut costs.

12 ounce bottle from By The Bottle in Vancouver, WA--Poured a dull golden-copper body with a medium white head. Nose of floral citrus hops and biscuit malts. Hops linger as beer gets drunk. Very nice and sessionable.

6/14/08 On draught at the Washington Brewers Festival. Aroma is hoppy. Appearance is hazy gold with a low white head. Flavor is balanced but starchy and resiny, more so in flavor than texture. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a low carb texture. Overall, well balanced but too much towards the IPA side.

Taster � Brewery � Sunnyside, WA Aroma � Medium malt aroma with a light hop. Appearance � Amber color really??? Nice head and clear. Flavor � Easy Pale Ale flavors, good malts. Had some hop flavor I was impressed. Palate � Nice Mouthfeel, good texture with a dry finish. Overall � Easy to drink Pale ale this was a good beer. Color was dark for a Pale ale.

12 ounce bottle I am always open to new porters. This one had some hallmarks of a West Coast style release but still was fairly unique. A couple of flaws mar a better experience. Even so I�d think I would not turn down another bottle if it came in a trade. Aroma / Appearance - The creamy black pour clings to the sides of the glass. The dirty head was the color of wet sand with slow legs. Almonds, black coffee, and plummy undertones drive an oily and sweet presence. Flavor / Palate - Dry coffee, prunes, and teases of smoke rub against the tongue. There is a brief sour tang before the sweetness takes over. I wasn�t excited about the beer to the point where I wish I had another but I�ve had worse porters.

Location: Bottle at Max and Andy�s Fantasy Tasting, 5/1/10 Aroma: The nose on this one is roasted malts, some coffee, licorice, and toasted grains Appearance: Clear brownish-black color with a beige head Flavor: The taste is fairly simple, light taste, roasted malts, some sweetness Palate: This porter is fairly thin, even a little on the watery side, with a light-medium body Overall Impression: My first rating from this brewery, heck, I�d never even heard of it before I tried this beer at the tasting. Anyway, I wasn�t particularly impressed. I don�t know if this was a bad bottle, but I didn�t get as positive an impression as many of the previous raters did.
Bottle at Andy and Max�s fantasy tasting - molasses and sulfuric. Brown sugar, some roast. medium bodied, dry pruney finish. Carbonic tart, blech. Boozey finish.

Bottle at Andy and Max�s fantasy tasting. Pours a rich oily black with a fizzling head. Aroma is intense with sharp dark acrid burnt malts, oil, solvent and licorice with hints of smoke, nuts, toffee and anise- a bit off and too sharp/harsh. Flavor is pretty flat, nothing lively going on- oil, tar, and licorice with ink and harsh astringent and bitter burnt malts. Hard to drink.

Bottle at Andy and Max�s fantasy tasting. Pours a clear dark brown with a thin beige head. Light caramel and coffee, a hint of roast. Medium bodied, big roast. Dry roast finish with a touch of sweet malt.

Bottle from Malt & Vine. Pours dark brown/black with a few tan bubbles. Aromas of dark burnt malt, mild sour/smoke and a touch of coffee. Medium plus body with rather smooth carbonation. Chocolate and coffee attack the tongue. A bit chalky. Finishes with coffee bitter, and a touch of smoke and/or sour. Really exceptional porter.

Bottle. Poured brown black with frothy beige head. Much lacing. Aroma of smoke and roast malt. Very smoky flavour, a little chocolate, a little roast, but mostly smoke. Tangy smoky finish, with more roast.

Pours a deep black, brown body with a thin whitish head. Spicy, carbonic nutty and hoppy nose. Tingles the nostrils. Mildly metallic and malty with a big hop spiciness. Very nice NW Porter style. Crisp, clean, and refreshing.

V - black with a tan head
A - slight coffee aroma
T - nice strong coffee taste
P - odd aftertaste
One of the better beers at the brewery. Poured jet black with some bubbly froathy tan head. Aroma strong coffee and roasted malts. Flavor very creamy with dominant bitter coffee flavor. Dry finish.

Renegade Brewing Company--Siletz Brewing Company--Spruce Ale--Ale Brewed With Spruce Tips. 2007 22 oz. Bottle. 5.29% ABV--35 IBU�s. (2.0 / 5.0) Amber Ale--Spruce. 2 @ $3.99 Each. Fizzy off white mild lace thin head. Clear bright thin dark amber red color. Citrus mild spruce hop front. Fizzy tangy sour sweet fruity spruce caramel malt body. Clean dry citrus mild hop end. Another Siletz Sour. Tight dark sour sediment. Bad to begin with and aged poorly. Sampled 3/27/2010.
Bottle. Pours an amber body with a tan head. Lots of malt caramel and some light earth y tones. Spruce, dirt and some lighter bark. Lemon sappy tart finish. Decent brew.

Bottled. An amber beer with sediment floating around under a thick off-white head. The aroma is acidic malty with notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet with hints of acidity and notes of malt, citrus, and spruce, leading to a dry lemony finish. The body is thin.

Bottled. Amber coluored. Unclear. Dense light brown head. Light apple, light citrus and some sourness in the aroma. Flavour of caramel, some sweetness and herbs. Again a light sourness. A bit thin bodied. Sourish grape in the end.

Bomber poured a clear reddish amber with a small lingering ring of ivory foam. Aromas of cabbage, light spruce and light carmel. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of spruce and carmel with a crisp dry lingering bitter finish.

Bottle at Madsberg 2008 Tasting. Pours orange with a small, lightly creamy, off-white head. Aroma has lots of oranges, some wax-like notes. High carbonation, weak and watery mouthfeel. Flavour is sour, citric and definitely infected. Poor.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of Ungstrup. Clear amber golden with a very tall and lively rough head. Strange aroma of wax. Medium body with an almost violent carbonation and citrusy accents dominating. Dry and astringent finish. 291208
Cloudy amber with large off white head. Aroma had spruce and citric notes. Highly carbonated flavour with spruce, caramel and malty notes. Finished somewhat sour.
Bottle. Clear amber coloured with a huge white head. Fruity aroma of honey and pine needles with notes of caramel. Light acidic flavour of hops and pine needles with notes of caramel. Tart finish.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a huge bubbly off-white head. Mild citrusy and slight herbal aroma. Light milky touch. Acidic and citric flavoured, solid bitterness and spiced. Ends sour and citric. Quite fizzy carbonation mouthfeel.

Renegade Brewing Company--Siletz Brewing Company--Lovin Lager Premium Pilsner--Give someone you love some Lovin�--2007 Release. 22 oz. Bottle. 5.13% ABV--34 IBU�s. (2.25 / 5.0) Overall. Terrible as a Pilsner? (1.0 / 5.0) $3.99 each. Thin foamy lacy white head. Clear thin bright amber gold color. Mild floral Saaz fruit ester front. Big dark sediment hazes brown orange. Slightly sour crisp zesty mild sweet fruity caramel Pilsner hint body. Dry puckery mild hop clean citrus end.Weird! Sampled 1/9/2010. Siletz Brews seem sour whether fresh or not.

22oz Bomber - Siletz Brewing Company - Siletz, OR Aroma � Nice malty lager aroma very little hops. Appearance � Amber in Color, Thick head and clear. Flavor � A nice easy to drink Lager beer with a good malt build and a slight use of hops. Palate � OK Mouthfeel, Nice texture with a Good finish. Overall � This was much better for Siletz a nice easy to drink average lager.
On tap in Siletz, Oregon--Poured a shiny golden-copper hue with a decent/moderate white head. Sticky lager flavor with a thin acidic bittter finish. Clean, subtle finish.

Nose of grain & cereal, some pine resin. Pours a sparkling solid golden. The mostly diminishing white sticky head leaves light lace. Pretty robust for a pils, this brew is well balanced with decent malt depth and heavy acidity with a corresponding bite. The bready finish is somewhat tart. The light creamy body is lively and the finish feels crisp and snappy.

Sampled on draught at the brewpub in Siletz, Oregon during the ABA 07 Beer Tour. Pours a semi- cloudy pale golden blonde brew with a thin white head that quickly dissolves toa fine film. Aroma of light multi-grain malt, bubblegum, some vegetable margarine and lemon peel. Taste is light bodied, slightly carbonated, with flavors of flowery lemon peel, and corn flakes. Finish is slightly acidic with a citrus peel aftertaste. Siletz�s lightest beer on tap.

22oz bottle pours cloudy golden with a short white head. Aromas of spice and slight grassy hops with crisp grains. Flavor is fruity at first with notes of apple, then grains and bready malts before the slight german hops at the finish. Palate is crisp and pretty clean and not a bad lager on the whole..
Pours light copper with a soft white head. Spicy and grassy hops in the nose. Very creamy on the palate with a smooth fruity malt start and balanced crisp hop finish. Nice beer on tap.
On Tap at Siletz Roadhouse, Siletz OR. Pours out a hazy gold topped with a small white head. A nice little hop to this one.

A deep reddish gold color (nowhere near ruby, but far deeper than a bud tone). Mouthfeel. Hops. This is a pilsner? It drinks like a light ale (little fruit, though). As ever, there is that hint of Siletz acidity. Where do they get that? It�s about 1/3 of the way from Bud to Sam�s Imperial Pilsner. I�m a hophead, and I cheerfully drank 22 ounces. Trust me. It�s ok. More than.
I was not loving this lager. Kind of corny and malty, some grassiness and earthiness. Just overly light and boring.
Cask, Sweet Green, Bolton. Burnt Amber colour. Sweet, floral ,orangey taste. Some lingering hops. Nothing to shake the foundations but not without charm.

Cask at the Bon Accord. Aroma is eppery spicey hops, with caramel coming off the malts and i hint of butter. Taste is upfront far maltier and again you can tell thier is butter but hints of tarter fruit over the peppery floural hop.
A Mes rate: Cask at the Olde Market Tavern in Altrincham. Amber colour. Sweet and citric at the same time. Chewy toffee in the flavour with some sweet malt and a hoppy finish.
Cask Stillage at King George�s Hall, Blackburn 06/09/2001 Amber coloured beer with plenty of fruity and a lasting full hop finish.

[Cask at GBBF 2004] An amber beer with no head. The aroma is sweet with notes of oranges as well as hints of diacethyl. The flavor is sweet notes of caramel and a little alcohol, which gives it a nice body.
Straight from the Cask at the Chesterfield Beer Festival on 04/02/05. Mid amber / straw brown bolour. A very fresh feel to the aroma & taste. Quite hoppy, nice lingering aftertaste.

Copper colour. Some floral hop in the aroma, but a touch of sulphur too. Fruit and a bit of hop in the flavour, but the overall feel is rather soft. Not bad, but somewhat lacking in gravitas for a 5% beer. Cask, GBBF 2004.

GBBF, London, gravity. Sampled with chris_o, ungstrup and maybe rauchbier (I was losing track by this point). Plain aroma, no head. Very sweet, fruity and smooth, with some orange. No gradiation or development. Alright, but not brilliant.
[Cask conditioned] Very pleasant aroma of flowers and sweet German white wine. The flavour is also very flowery.
Straw color and no head. Weak malt body. Not at all strong - don't know why this was listed with the porters, stouts and strong ales. Pretty poor showing.
on cask-pours a light brown head and mahogany color. Aroma is dark malt-some chocolate, secondary resin hops. Taste is dark malt-some chocolate, secondary sharp resin, astringent-earthy hops.
Cask sample at the brewpub. Pours brown with a nice light brown head. Smells of chocolate and roasted malt. Tastes of roasted malt, some spicy hints, roasty, lightly bitter on the finish.
On cask at the brewpub. Pours deep dark brown with off-white head. Roasty and malty aroma. Good balance of hops. Chocolate and caramel notes. Roasty. Finish is chocolatety. Very nice.

sampled at the brewpub. When I was first looking at my sampler, I thought this was going to be a brown ale or something of the sort, then my friend points out it�s the porter. It�s clear amber in color with reddish hues. Aroma was caramel with a touch of chocolate and toasted malt. Taste was pretty much the same, with some light notes of butter and vanilla. Thin bodied.
Dark brown ale, clear, with reddish hues. Strong diacetyl aroma. Rather bland porter with no body, no character. On tap at brewery , Feb. 10, 2006.
On Cask at the pub......... Aroma:Mixe of caramel and rosted malt....... Appearance:Dark with a beige head... Flavor:Caramel,buter(diacetyl),watery.....
(cask) Red-black body with no head. Aroma is medium sweet, coffee, roast, molasses, light cherry. Taste is medium sweet, mocha, molasses. Light-medium body, no carbonation.

On cask at the brewpub. Deep dark brown in color with a nice tan head. Roasty and malty hoppy aroma. Roasty and malty hoppy flavor. Chocolate and caramel notes. Roasty. Chewey. Finish is chocolatety. Very nice. Drinkable.

Cask at the brepub. dark brown, tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate and hops. Flavor is big dark chocolate and hops, and resembles a baltic porter in flavor. Chewey American hops. Unsweetened chocolate finish. Best thing they had...

On cask. Big chocolate flavor. Like, it seems, most of the People�s Pint beers this beer is extremely smooth and well-made. It had a nice, almost sweet, malty undertone to the decent hop underbelly. Tasty.
Cask at the Royal Standard, Wooburn Common. A pale amber pour with a loose white head; floral aroma; floral taste with a light biscuity body; then a fry finish. Moreish, but rather thin.

Gravity Cask Half Pint at Battersea Beer Festival, London in Feb 2011 - Pale Yellowy Gold in colour. Malty ; toasty malts, caramel. Fruity; citrus grapefruit. Hoppy; grassy hops. Nice malt/fruit/hop balance. Sweet malty with nice citrus fruity edge. Good Beer! (2011-02-09)

Cask at The Hop Inn, Newcastle-Under-Lyme. A clear golden colour with q medium white head. Aroma of lemon, some apple, slight ginger, pale malts and subtle floral hops. Taste of lemon, maybe orange, some apple, slight ginger, pale malts and spicy, floral hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A dry, malty, spicy hop bitterness in the finish. Not a fan of the finish, too astrigent and spicy. Not my kind of hoppy pale ale I�m afraid. Average
Great session ale easy drinking and interesting without being in your face on cask at the baum
Cask at Hop Inn, Newcastle under Lyme. Pours golden. Quite a malty golden session ale. Pretty pedestrian.
Cask. Kelham Island Tavern, Sheffield. Clear gold. Bubbly, lasting, white head. Soft, grainy, sweetish malts. Light lemon hop. Taste follows on from that. Light body, with some lingering bitterness.
Cask at the Ale Emporium. Pours pale gold with a thin white head. Aromas of lemon barley water Taste is thin, finishes thin too.
Pours a pale colour, a well balanced beer and quite sessionable, but ultimately unexciting
Clear yellow appearance. Not much of an aroma to this one. Flavour has a tart apple acidity and some sweeter fruity tones too. Finish is dry.
Cask @ Crown, Bacup. Yellow golden with a frothy head. It has a dry hopped character with a fruity aroma.
These other reviews have no idea what they're talking about. Its actually a smooth beer

Cheap, cheap beer. Now I know all the micro/craft brew loving, IPA drinking, "what pumpkin beers do you have on tap?" hipsters have and will savage this beer because it's soooooo lowbrow, but here's the truth- it's beer. You know- grainy stuff, water, yeast, hops, cook it, put in can, chill, drink. Beer has never been (until recently) broken down in agonizing detail by self-styled gourmands of the art of the craft brew.. It's beer. Beer. BEER. Find some drinkable beers, buy the cheapest and enjoy. This is drinkable beer. I would wager that if it was $13 for a six-pack, had a presumptuous name, and was brewed using an old world fermented yeast strain that was discovered in a 400 year old Scottish pit toilet, millennials would be frothing over it wherever they congregate to froth over things. But it's not. It's just a good cheap beer.
355ml can. This is inoffensive and at 18 bucks for 3 cases of this stuff you get way more bang for you buck than you would with natural light. This is better and cheaper than natural light.

Oh it�s bad, so so bad. so so so so bad. They just can�t seem to get anything descent out of that brewery. I was offered a second one on the house and TURNED IT DOWN! It is so bad. Looks good though :}

Picked up a single 12-oz bottle at Festival Foods in LaCrosse, Wisconsin. Pours a clear straw blonde brew with a fast dissolving white head that dissipates nearly clean with a thin film top. Aroma of corn grits, grassy hops and some burnt charcoal. Taste is light bodied, well-carbonated with flavors of watery corn grits and some front lawn grass and dandelions. Finish is watery and quite metallic. It�s getting into the drain pour category.
Has no taste. Well, ok, it does but it sucks. I remember when beer like this was great because it was so cheap. I have learned the ways since then.
About as bad as it gets for beer, agree with prosqtor, it will get you drunk and if it�s cold it tastes decent. makes for a good shower beer i.e. getting a little more water into it doesn�t matter.
Terrible. But cheap, and either cools you down (lawnmower) or gets you drunk (eventually).

This stuff is rotten! We drank this in college at the Kul Duel. It is a competition to see if you can drink more Kul or Kul Light held in La Crosse, WI where they brew this swill. I have nothing nice to say about this abomination.

I just found this in the database. This is one of the beers that got me into real beer back when I was living in Vail. At the time it was called the Hubcap Brewery (same address), probably around 1991 or 1992. As i remember it, it was thick and chewy. With a chocolate maltiness but then I was drinking MGD back then so what did I know. It a shame Hubcap never made a go of it. If you ever climb Mount Everest look around on the summit for a Hubcap hat, there used to be one there.

Little head atop a murky brown liquid. Some sugared apple notes in the nose. Some hop bitterness, little aroma/flavor. Overall, the beer seemed either undone or out-of-date. Had an astringent, alcohol laden finish with sharp esters.

Head is initially small, fizzy, off-white, fully diminishing. Body is hazy medium brown, moderate density of tiny particles. Aroma is lightly malty (caramel), lightly hoppy (citrus - orange). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation. Sweet and not much else.

Can. Great packaging. The can has neat graphics and the resealble blob top makes this a nice item to put on your shelf. The beer itself was pretty average at best. Yellow, overcarbonated, with a moderate white head. Buy this for the can, not for the beer.

Clear yellowy appearance, heavily carbonated, moderate head formation. Funky fruity, herbal aroma. Sweet fruity aniseed/mint candy like flavor, sugar prevalent throughout. Spritzy carboantion provides some cut thrugh along with a graininess from the malt, but the bitterness is very light. The can says "imported German ale" and although that could be for legal/import reasons I wouldn�t call this a pilsner. Really I�m not sure where it fits in but it�s definitely better than what I thought it was going to be. I bought it for the can which is original for sure.
I was surprised with this beer. the depth of flavor was more than I expected, the aroma was malty with some woody undertones. Not a bad beer at all.

Head is initially large, fizzy, white, fully diminishing. Body is hazy light yellow, dense tiny and small particles. Aroma is moderately malty (grain, light bread), moderately yeasty (dough), moderately hoppy (herbs). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately bitter, lightly acidic. Finish is moderately bitter, lightly acidic. Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation. Quite a shock...I've been passing up this kitschy can with the ridiculous name for years now, embarassed to be seen buying such a silly thing. But lo and behold, we have here a clean, very well-balanced, bitter yeasty Bavarian-style pils with a decent body. Despite all the yeast, not much acidity exists, much to my delight.

Standard longneck, functional label. Clear, dark ruby brown. Light, filmy head. Some fruitiness, light creosote, buffered/chalky acidity in the aroma. Sweet, a little pruney, acidic, light roast. Low carbonation, body is a little on the flaccid side. New World, Albany, Auckland.
Apperance: clear, jet black, no head Aroma: roasted malts, not burnt Palate: medium light mouthfeel, low carbonation Taste: roast malts, not tart, slight sweetness that balances the flavours well
Light malt aroma. Clear red dark brown colour good head and lacing. Roast malt flavour. Smooth palate.
Kolor czarny wpadaj�cy w br�zowy pod �wiat�o, klarowne. Piana do�� szybko opada zostawiaj�c lekkie �lady na szkle, ma�e nagazowanie w smaku wytrawna czekolda i troch� karmelu, przyjemne w piciu.

50cl bottle from a Countdown supermarket in Christchurch. A cola coloured pour with a ring of cream head; aroma of roasted malts and some burnt sugar; rather thin in the mouth, with burnt sugar and chocolate malts; and a bitter roasted grain finish with a touch of licorice. Lacking depth.

500ml bottle. Pours dark brown with hint of red. Dark roasted malt with hints of chocolate but a bit thin and lacking in body. A bargain priced (NZ$5) Porter that probably reflects fair value for money. Worth getting when you are on a budget.

Bottled. A deep red beer with a thin tan head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel as well as lighter notes of wood and fruit. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel as well as lighter notes of butter, diacethyl, and dusty hops, leading to a dry finish.
Red brown with a medium off white head. Sweet aroma with butter, roasted malt and caramel notes. Flavour was sweet with hard roasted malt, rye, bread and butter notes. Finished sweet.

Bottle 33 cl. Clear dark brown with a warm, reddish hue and a small, off-white head. Roasted malty aroma with a whiff of butter. Light body with hard roasted malts, vanilla and again a touch of butter. Finishes dry with a light malt bitterness. 010209

From bottle, blindtasting #5. Pours clear and deep brown with a reddish golden glare with a diminished off-white head. Dry hardroasted malty aroma, mild butterish note. Dry and hardroasted malt flavoured. Bitter, breadish and slight spiced flavoured with a subdued hops note. Ends medium dry and roasted.

Looks great. Near black in colour with a thin but dense mocca coloured head. Mild roast nose with coffee, malts and a faint metallic note. Fairly similar again to taste althoug the roast component was fractionally sweeter. Pretty good weight for a 5%er.

500ml bottle. Pours ink black with a rich coffee coloured head. Light aroma of toast. Lightly carbonated and smooth flavours of milk chocolate with a touch nutty. A touch thin towards the end and no real char or burt notes that you would expect but a nice enough drop all the same esp when it warms a little

Tasted 15/05/2006. 330ml bottle from Miramar Liquorland. Pours just short of black, with the slightest ruby hints in the light. A thick tan head rides atop, and laces all the way down the glass. Milk and bittersweet chocolate, on the first nose, are followed up with roasted grain and very light plummy esters. More milky chocolate notes, up front in the mouth, with some caramel; a bitter middle with background esters, and a lingering astringency in the roasty finish. Woody aftertaste that makes me think of twigs. Medium weight, just the slightest touch over-carbonated and lots of lingering flavour. A very nice stout, easily drinkable and quite complex.
Sweet and strong, with much coffee-burnt flavor. Very dark, just a little bit of hops to offset the sweetness.
Pours a very shiny dark brown with a rich tan head. Smelled sweet and malty with a good burnt scent. Very burnt taste-- sweet and lightly hoppy.
Ink black colour, bitter coffee flavour. Similar to their porter, yet darker and bolder.
Fles 33cl thuis.Verrassend hoppig, maltig, kruidig. (8-2015).-------------.

Six-pack from Netto in Germany - they don't sell it as singles - pours dark-gold with a white foam, nose is lemony and grassy noble hops, sweet golden malt, palate is similar - sticky caramel balanced (mostly) by dry bitterness and spritzy hops. Worryingly quaffable....
33 cL bottle. Pours hazy brown with a fizzy tan head. Dense dried fruity and mild spiced aroma. Dense caramel malty and slight dark breadish. Mild spiced too. Dry lingering roasted malt and breadish.

Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a thick light tan head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of dusty hops and over ripe fruits. The flavor is sweet malty again with notes of over ripe fruits and dusty hops. Thanks yespr for sharing.
Bottle, thx to thewolf. Dark golden colour with a beige head. Aroma is fruit, hop, caramel. Flavor is fruit, sweet, malt, caramel, hop. OK beer.

Bottle, thx to thewolf. Pours a hazy, orange-brown with lots of floaties of all sizes, from the tinyest small to big chunks. Beige head leaving nice lacings. Malty-sweet flavor with fruityness and some pale malt. Fruity, caramel flavor with some hoppy bitterness and a little spiced touch. Quite dry. Fruity and slightly caramel-sweet finish. Decent beer, but far from impressing. (080301)
(on bottle, thanks thewolf) Sunflower and canesugar in the aromas. Waterish and thin body; but the finish gets all vanilla and sweet tobacco + peat andnutmeg; nice catch.
Bottle. Hazy amber-orange. Sweet yeasty ripe fruity aroma. Good mouthfeel. The flavour is sweet with dark fruits, malt and...dust. Sweet fruity finish.

Bottled (by Duwac, BBE 09/04...), bought from BelgianShop.com in Jan 2008. Hazy brown colour with big beige fluffy head. Leaves some lace. Aroma is yeast, raisins, some toffee and some notes of mild oxidation (probably due to being this old). Flavour is caramel malts, toffee, yeast and some mild dark dry fruits. No notes of oxidation in the flavour. Dry palate.

(Bottle, best before 09/04) Pours a murky yellowish brown body with an average creamy yellowish off-white head. Aroma of yeast, banana, and raisins. Flavor of yeast, malt, caramel, and some dark fruits.

Hazy light brown with a modest but well sustained fizzy tan head, this ale has an aroma of toffee malt, brown sugar, yeast, and a healthy dose of aniseed. Soft and well carbonated in the mouth. The flavor is a sweet caramel/toffee with a hint of chocolate, yeast, licorice, pepper, and other spices. It finishes on an oddly sweet yet dry note, then leaves a touch of bitterness in the mouth. Nice. The Belgian Shop, Verviers, Belgium

Dark coppery color, medium yellow head. Chocolate, sweetness, mild alcohol and licorice in aroma. Medium bodied. Chocolate, toffee and mild coffee in flavor, also mild spices. Aftertaste lasts with mild alcohol and spices. Nice complex brew.
500ml bottle in 2012. Hazy mid golden with a white head. Aroma of tropical fruit, bready malt and straw. Fairy malty flavour and mid sweet.

Bottled (backlog). Slightly hazy golden colour with a small bubbly head. Aroma is fruity, caramelly, wooden and some mild notes of honey. Flavour isfruity, nectary, some bready and mild fudgelike sweet notes.
Bona cervesa, bastant equilibrada i gustosa. Buena cerveza, bastante equilibrada y sabrosa.
500ml Bottle. The aroma is hoppy and slightly floral. The rich amber colour pours well but the head is quickly disapating. Tastewise there is the merest hint of citrus (lemon).

500 mL bottle from the Vale Brewery shop. Slightly cloudy and very fizzy golden/orange beer with a fair head on. Fairly nice yeast and hops aroma, a hint of fruit. A nice hop blend, bitter and quite complex. A nice drop but not going to set the world on fire.

Sampled this golden bitter in Esquires, Glasgow (JDW)in February 2009. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear pale straw in colour with a thin white open head. Faint dry dusty hops in the thin aroma with a hint of fresh green apples. Pale malt base gives refreshing almost weiss stle flavours with sweet fruit notes of overipe gooseberry and kiwi fruit to the fore. Could not detect any lemon and grapefruit flavours though? Distinct wheat/maize notes as the metallic tang of hop resins seep into the aftertaste. A dry bitter finish. An ok golden ale but lacking the complexity of similar strengthed golden ales like Harviestoun Schiehallion of Houstons St Peter�s Well.

1)Bottle from The Wine Cellars, Lutterworth. Brassy gold with a low, patchy white head. Rustic and strange with drab woodland hop, boiled sweet and almond notes. Good creamy aftertaste equal parts Honey Nut Loops, sponge cake and apple turnover. Aroma of beeswax, dandelion, dank English woods. I sense the presence of honey. Just a beer. 536312. 2) Cask handpull, The Shoes, Nuneaton, 05/10/12. Thick-lacing gold freckling with lace. Pepper, orange and aniseed nose with good green sappy notes; maybe geranium. Aniseed and orange tang rounded with vanilla and biscuit. Pretty good. 747414.

[Cask at the William Robert Loosley (JDW), High Wycombe] Rich gold colour with a decent white head. Honey dominates with a hint of flowers. It�s a nice flavour, but by the end I found it rather sweet and syrup-y. Needs to bang in some bitter floral hops for balance.
Cask @ The Bon Accord. Creamy biscuit aroma. Golden colour with a good head. Resin cereal biscuit flavour. Bitter & dry aftertaste. Reasonable golden ale.
50cl bottle. Slightly hazy amber with a thin white head; the aroma has dusty hops and citrus; light, fruity flavour; with some toffee to finish.
A creamy white head on top of a light golden brown beer. A full hop nose with a hint of spice. A hoppy flavour with spice, citrus and a floral undertone. A light finish.
Bottled. Golden body with large fine white head. Lacy and attractive. Hoppy and fresh. Citrus and pineapple flavours.

Bottle conditioned. Amber gold, good white head and moderate condition, big dry hopped aromas, spicy and peppery with a hint of grapefruit . In the mouth there is a brief suggestion of caramel but then its back to the grapefruit and peppery hops before turning dry and hop bitter in the finish
Sampled cask conditioned. Deep golden coloured. Big, tempting spicy hop aroma. Medium bodied, sweet, fruity and dlowery. Bitter spicy finish. A tasty and flavourful pint.
0,33l bottle. Long time I didn`t bought lager style beer in Scandinavian wintertime but this lager is good and purpose to buy was that I am in the J�mtland district at the moment :)

Aroma; herbs, sour grass, malt, fruit, hops. Look; low off white head, golden near clear body. Taste; herbs, sour grass, sweet malt, caramel, fruit, hops, and finishes alright and with lemon. Feel; ok body n co2. Overall; normal beer. [btl T@Bod�-in-Lulea] 5363'11

Bottle from hotel in �stersund. Aroma is grass, citrus, lager. Used to be one of my favourite lagers, it is still definitely a good bet in my opinion. Taste moves from occasional delightfulness to a bit soapy. Overall, decent :) Retried. Maybe I have become meaner, rating taken down overall by 0.1. Agree with above comments that it is almost a delicious lager but something not spot on. Appearance an almost bright yellow. Incredibly smooth beer however, strong bitterness coming through this time. Bottle from same place. Re-rated, bottle at Plaza bar �stersund. Smooth. 2.9 to 3. Bottle. Aroma of roast lamb this time mixed with lager. Appely finish. Its a decent pilsner. 2.9

Backlog. Bottle from 2001, enjoyed in 2008. Aroma�s: sweet, port/sherry, fruit, old, little roasted. Flavor: moderate sweet, somewhat roasted, old-ish. Body: light to medium. Finishes with some roast, sweet, just lightly bitter. Nicely evolved.
Butterscotch aroma. Dark brown, light brown rocky head that diminishes fast. Light sweet, light roasted, nice coffee, sparkling, could be a bit fuller. Coffee and cola in the finish.
Good stout from Cambridge brewer, coffee dark and just what u need on a cold night

Name: Espresso Milk Stout Date: 04/26/2000 Mode: Firkin Source: Roswell, GA black, frothy tan head, toffee coffee aroma, lots of espresso flavor, creamy texture, low carbination - even for a cask Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Espresso Porter Date: 03/23/2002 Mode: Bottle Source: DC Black, whispy head, sweet toffee aroma, thin body, roasted flavor, harsh bitterness, overdone with the espresso Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 3/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 4/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.6/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

On tap at the Wayne location. The beer menu had this listed as their �Organic Coffee Stout�. Poured a dark black, with red edges and a smaller sized tan head. Aromas of coffee, roast, and light chocolate. Tastes of coffee, roast, light vanilla and chocolate. Nice bitter coffee finish. I�m a sucker for coffee beers.

[Wayne, PA] Poured an opaque black color that had a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of straight coffee bean. That�s about it, same with the taste with a bit of roasted malt, and chocolate, but with a dry, bitter, somewhat astringent finish.

I have had this one several times at the Monroeville PA location. Draft only it pours a thick dark black color with almost no head. The aroma is light coffee and chocolate. The mouthfeel is thick and rich. The flavor is bitter but less so than I would expect from this style as this is surprisingly sweet. The coffee is noticeable but not overwhelming. The beer drinks easily and pleasurably begging for a refill.

Tap - DC. Deep dark browns and blacks, small creamy brown head. As it warmed, I got notes of roasted black coffee, chocolate, cream, with some light vinous notes as well. Flavors of dark coffee and chocolate dominate, but some citric hops shine thru to keep a nice balance. Medium to full-bodied, pillow soft carbonation, silky, semi-bitter, coffeeish finish. ABV around 6.7%. Very good stout.

(DC) Creamy brown head atop black body, lovely lacing. Aroma is medium sweet, coffee, chocolate. Taste is medium sweet, strong roasty coffee, light chcolate. Medium body. A good beer, but the coffee elements are a bit too strong for it to achieve excellence.

I had this with lunch, and I would like to try it again when I am just having a stout for a stout. Very dark appearance and roasted aroma, but the flavor it this and creamy, with the frothy head it is almost like drinking an espresso drink. I await the next time I am near a John Harvard's, so I can try it again.
a solid sweet stout. The expresso was barely tastable, but the stout was light and creamy.

WOW...I think this was the best beer I had on my trip to Boston. This stout from the Famous John Harvard''s Brew House was excellent. It was a dark rich brown in color, had a coffee like smell mixed with the drak small of a stout. The rich creamy foam made this brew look ever so appiteasing. When you taste it is like a smooth rich cool black coffee but not as harsh as that would be. it has the taste of coffee and hops and malts. Like Cambells Soup Umm Umm Good!
can bb 7/19 chiara limpida non molta schiuma poco persistenza cereale mais niente aroma poco amara

Goudblond bier met lichte oranje gloed en witte schuimkraag. Geur: gistkarakter, mout, licht kruidig. Smaak: Gistkarakter, licht hopbitter, licht kruidig, ietwat peperig. Goede koolzuurprikkel. Afdronk: gistkarakter, licht hopbitter.
Sample, yellow beer, small head. Aroma is stale, taste is the same, wheat, maybe some tartness... no i do not want another one.

F: big, creamy, white, average retention. C: yellow blonde, hazy. A: sweet malt, floral, grassy, spicy, bit of orange peels. T: malty, grassy, sweet floral, light peppery, orange peels, actually not bad, may be more sweet paradoxically for low carb beer but enjoyed, medium body, high carbonation a little disturbing, 6,4% is on the bottle, 33cl bottle from BIO-PLANET JAMBES supermarket in Namur.

Bottle 33cl bought at Het Confituurpotje in Tervuren. Pours hazy golden with a big white head. Nose: some hops, hay, malt, sugary. Taste: medium carbonation. Pretty malty and dry with a bitter touch and a feeling of hay that sticks around for a while. A warm alcoholic feeling. Hints of sweetness too.

31/X/15 - 33cl bottle from... no clue, totally forgot @ home - BB: 10/XII/17 (2015-1527) Little hazy blond to orange beer, big aery off-white head, pretty stable, adhesive, leaving a nice lacing in the glass. Aroma: fruity, orange peel, bit spicy, oxidized touch. MF: lots of carbon, medium body. Taste: quite some coriander, bit sweet, orange peel. Aftertaste: bit soapy, some citrus, lots of coriander, bitter touch, bit sweet, metallic touch, bit spicy.
Helder bier met mooie schuimkraag. Biologisch bier met suikervervangende Stevia, resulteert in weinig smaak maar toch droge afdronk met bitterige mondgevoel.

Organic beer low in sugar and calories, made for a company which promoted the sweet but very low calory Stevia plant as a replacement for sugar - we�re clearly in the health beer atmosphere here. Very far fermentation resulted in an indeed utterly dry beer with very low residual sugars, but unfortunately there is not much taste left either. Too thin and too barren for my taste, with not very stable head either.

Bottle from Delhaize supermarket Pours clear blonde, huge white head that fades fast. Smell is bit... sour ??? Some twisted maltyness . Quite weird, and I cannot put my finger on it ... sweaty ??? Taste is sweet . The funk that I could not place in the smell , def comes from the grains . Not sure what they used, but it tastes weird . Horsestables come to mind, as well as metallicness, and sweetness . Really funky, but not at all like brett . Sourness ? Not quite, but almost .. very weird and unique . Other tastes are bitterness ( a bit ) , sugar , maltsweetness . Overcarbonated , as in most Belgian beers . The name means �another one � , I don�t easy will say that after drinking this . The name is quite fun ( being in a bar , many people will accidently order this ! ) , too bad that is the only reason people will ask it - cause they don�t know what it is ....
Pours slightly cloudy golden colour with small head. Sweet aroma, fairly hoppy flavour for a tripel. Nice one.
Clear golden blond, well-carbonated. Bread malts. Relatively bland in aroma and palate for a tripel.
Cask Handpump at the Bar Fringe, Manchester 24/08/2002 A golden bitter which poured very lively. Plenty of hops and a bitter finish that lasts.

NERAX '02 Laughing my ass off at reading Volgon's comment,because I have the exact same sentiments about this beer.In fact I was one of only two people in a group of about seven,that would even take a sip of this,everyone else couldn't get past the aroma.

On cask NERAX '02: The talk of NERAX '02, well at least the beer that everyone was saying to stay away from. It had some weird almost skunky taste to it. Most of the people I talked to said 'It's skunked, stay away'. I talked to one of the people working there who assured me it wasn't skunked and was supposed to taste that way. Hmm. With a flavor that makes most people think that a fresh beer is skunked, this could pose some serious competition to Heineken. Interbrew better buy these guys out and put them out of business before the green bottle drinkers of the world find out about this one.
MIBG Fest: Lighter in color than expected. Saazy and sweet - good malt - good body - I thought it was a fair attempt at a Classic German Pils.

They claim this as a cross between a pils and a helles, but it really is an attempt to reach a wider audience. Nonetheless, it could be a good transition brew - it does have some hop action, however faint, and a fine soft mouth to its fair body. Otherwise, the malt just slips away into banal American Standard blandness.
330ml (thx, Alex M.!). Appearance: dark brown with a tan head. Aroma: nice vinous and dark sugars, some raisins and plums. Taste: along the same lines, some booziness. Overall: good Belgian Strong.

Surprised I never rated this one. This one is in a regular sized bottle from a six mix pack, rather than the standard 750 that this usually comes in. Even with a careful pour this one went 90% thick tan head. When it finally settled down, you get taste sweeter molasses, cloves, a little nutmeg, a little dried stone fruit. It the type of beer you have to be in a mood for, but it's a nice one.
Bottle shared. Dark brown color, full sized mocha colored head. Aroma and flavor malts, sweet, lightly raisins, some light sourness in there. Hmm not a fan. 6-3-6-3-11.

bottle. Poured dark brown with a thin beige head. Dark fruity alcohol aroma. Medium bodied, low-tight carbonation, lightly dry finish. Flavour of roasted malts, dark fruits, notes of dates and treacle, a touch of tartness. Alcohol nicely hidden.
From backlog. Bottle at Extended Stay America, Cypress,Ca. Dark brown with big offwhite head. Malts, hops, Caramel, Chocolate and yeast.

750ml corked and caged bottle. Pours an opaque dark mahogany with red hue and a large, creamy, long lasting, beige head that leaves curtains of lace. Sweet aroma of caramel malt, toffee, plum, fig, raisin, Belgian yeast and light spice. Sweet, complex flavour of caramel malt, plum, raisin, cherry, brown sugar, molasses, chocolate, red wine and spicy yeast with a dry, warming finish. Medium body with a creamy, smooth, oily texture and soft carbonation. Very nice. Lots of complexity. The ABV is well hidden.
750 ml bottle pours a dark brown color with a tan head. Aromas of Belgian yeast, sweet roasted malt, dried fruit. Full bodied, delicious. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A strong beer, drank 750ml bottle poured in a celebrator glass. Pours a dark black amber with a medium head. Initial taste is mildly smokey, with an aftertaste or burning that fades to a sour coffee sensation with a hint of bitterness. Lovely beer, drinks like a 5% abv.

750 ml cork and crowned bottle. Nearly opaque dark brown color. Firm creamy beige head. First sip yields notes of dark dried fruits and sweet roasted malts. Midtaste brings hints of plum, fig and calvados. Finish is pure plum sauce and church chatter. Button up, it's gonna be cold out tonight. Exponentially delicious without being pretentious. You be the judge.

Pours nearly black with a thick, foamy head that recedes quickly. Aroma is dried fruit and spice (cinnamon, plus something else - maybe clove). Taste is at once plum and brown sugar, warming to various spices, especially clove, as well as some light roast. Finish is where the Belgian yeast shows up. A really tasty beer.

First impression is a beer with a unfiltered fluid, and nice air foam. The aroma is nice hoppy and a perfect fruity aroma. The taste is fruity in a hoppy way. It starts with a strong bite of alcohol and bitternes, and then the sweet fruits in the aftertaste, which makes the beer in a good balance.

Pours a huge bubbly head but quickly dissipates and leaves a very thin layer. Ok lacing. Has a cloudy amber appearance with sediments clearly visible. Aromas are of citrus hops, some yeasty notes with mild spices and mild malts. Has a strong bitter citrus flavour, notes of coriander and orange peel. Some spices, mildly sour. Has a bit of tartiness. Bready malts. Full bodied mouthfeel with a slight tingling, nice warming feeling. Lively carbonation. Sort of a thick yeasty feeling on the palate. The 10%abv is not really noticeable at first. Goes down fairly easy. Pretty good stuff.

First impression is a very sparkling beer with a foam that is almost too perfect! Beads of carbonation rising from the bottom of the glass and foam build up at all times below the crown. Before I lift the glass to your nose, I can already sense a fruity aroma spread. It has a good and promising aromas of ripe fruit and citrus, coriander and other gentle spice. The taste is sweet as light syrup, but mixes fairly quickly with a tart flavor of green apples. Hop bitterness is not much, but instead have the aftertaste very pleasant and as a stop-filled basket of fruit: apples, lemon and light summer berries. Palate is top notch and the mouth feeling is sparkling so it�s a completely delight.

Pours a hazy golden topped by a finger or so of bright frothy head showing moderate retention and lacing properties. The is sweet, malty, corny and yeasty. Mid-full body with moderate carbonation, the taste is somewhat sweet and corny with the yeasts getting through. Pretty good tripel with a bolder yeast feature than the Don de Dieu. Cheers!
Bottle. Vintage 2002. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty aroma. Fruity malty spicy yeasty flavor. Has a sweetish malty spicy yeasty finish.

Single bottle, sold separately from the mixer pack. Hazy amber with an off white head. Happy to try this again - typical Unibroue yeast aroma with some light spice, bit of orange zest, citrus and a bit of applewood. High carbonation and moderate body, easy to drink and slightly sweet.

Clear coppery amber. Thick, creamy light tan head. Dense carbonation. Sugary, caramel sweetness and a thick hop base. Pine, mint and citric peels. Well balanced despite the long hoppy aftertaste. Medium body. Juicy sweet hop flavor gets thicker as it warms. Finishes thick and pasty with hop flavors.
Excelent red IPA. Very hoppy, smooth finish................................

This beer has been made by various breweries throughout the years, but know it's Munkbo's turn. Pale golden colour. Grassy aroma with a hint of mashed apples. Medium bodied and dry. Salty finish with medium bitterness.

Draught @ the brewery. Pours an almost clear amber colour with a white head. Nose is honey and bread. Flavour is caramel with a bready aspect that finishes with a noticeable alcohol despite the low abv.
Draft - Caramel and some honey. Clear gold with a decent white head. Sweet caramel notes.
Amber pour, tan head. Nose is malt. Leans little sweet. Middle is caramel, medium mouth feel, toasted malt. Finish has a brief hop hire, surrounded by more malt.
Classic copper colored amber. Sampled at brewery and not at all murky as others have reported.
Draught at brewpub, 4.2% ABV Hazy amber color with compact head. It has light caramel aroma and flavor, correct bitterness, extremely light fruity esters. Correctly brewed but somehow boring.
Draft at the source. A,ber color (logical I guess). Sweet caramel aroma, bittersweet taste. OK.

It�s a perfectly GOOD amber...but I would not go as far as to say "great" and here�s why...on tap at the brewery, pours a murky brown amber in color, minimal head, absolutely no clarity in the glass...African mudwater. Aroma hints at light roast nuts and slight citrus. Tastes like a fairly tame and well-mannered amber ale, nutty malt, light citrus hops with notes of hay and grapefruit. Suspended yeast definitely adds to a fuller mouthfeel yet an ugly looking pint. Fruity esthers carry it through the finish. A very casual american amber ale, not extremely hopped or high gravity like some.
Pint @ The Traveler. Inoffensive though ultimately unmemorable amber. Pours a pretty copper color. Taste vaguely malty, but mostly just watery. Should have ordered Loco Red instead.
Bottle sampled at Bottleworks. Aroma and flavour of pale malts and mild hops. Quite weak.

Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--PGA--Perfectly Good Amber--2002 22 oz. Bottle. 4.00% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Amber Ale--Nice lacy head. Clear thin bright amber color. Mild malt hop front. Crisp tasty mild amber body with light sweet caramel fruit and toasted biscuit flavor. Lingering malt mild balanced clean hop end. Tangy. Sampled 9/26/2002. Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--SNOQUALMIE PGA--Perfectly Great Amber. 2005 22 oz. Bottle. 4.00% ABV--25 IBU�s. (4.0 / 5.0) Amber Ale--Bottle Conditioned Sediment. Mild lacy head. Clear bright thin amber color. Mild hop front. Smooth quenching mild earthy dry sweet mild caramel fruit body. Slightly tangy clean hop spice mild citrus end. Light tasty Brew. Sampled 11/8/2005. Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--PGA--Perfectly Great Amber Ale--A medium-bodied. easy drinking beer. 2009 22 oz. Bottle. 4.00% ABV--23 IBU�s. (3.75 / 5.0) Amber Ale--Dense very foamy lacy off white head. Light sediment. Clear thin bright amber color. Mild fruit ester hop front. Mild sweet medium bodied delicate soft caramel fruit light amber flavor. Herbal hop cloying weird sediment spice end. Nice except for end. Sampled 8/15/2009. 2 @ $4.99 Each.

A very short lasting light brown/tan coloured head sat atop of this dark ruby coloured bock beer. Initial aroma that I picked up was liquorice then changing to a meaty broth. Sweetish coffee taste with plenty of fruit thrown in for good measure. Medium body with a slightly creamy texture.

I dunno about plax ecz, but this one sure had some nice beer flavours, aromas, palates and overall impressions. Perhaps Vegemite I reckonz. I like the weird old pissed fart on the label. In conclusion a nice beer for the festive season. Bottoms up!
Dark brown in colour, small spritzy head. hot spicey coffe flavours. Can smell the chillies and this hides it bitter after taste.

Almost opaque brown with a medium size short lasting mid-tan head. Passion fruit, roasted malt and coffee aroma - no chocolate anywhere on this one for me. As it warms the ester/actone ratio increases somewhat. Medium crisp body. Medium sweetish fruity, coffee and lighter bitter-sweet roasted malt flavours. Not really very bock like - but not like anything else either. Sweet black coffee finish and slightly fruitier aftertaste. It left me feeling a little like the guy on the label - confused!

Eczematic says it best "mixed up tinned fruit salad" and "no frills cooking chocolate", well said, and all this points to the fact that it is quite artificial tasting, dryish finish, slightly burnt malt flavour.
Deep amber-brown colour. Toffee-butterscotch aroma. Thinnish palate. Pretty fruity flavour (strawberry, cherry). I'd prefer more malt and hop flavour. The yeasty esters seem to dominate this beer.
says on the label that it tastes of chocolate and fruit salad and indeed it does. can respect it as it tastes like no other aussie beer
Very weird. mix up tinned fruit salad, no frills cooking chocolate, fried banana, and wash it down with plax.
Coppery amber colour with a very little head. Caramel raisins and honey aroma, very little bitterness but overall I quite like it.
Pours dark amber-brown with basically no head. Aromas of roasted grains, caramel, and fruitcake(??).. Very sweet taste, thin body with a little tingle of bitter afterwoods.
Medium amber coloured, not much head. Sweet almost caramel aroma and flavour, too sweet, sticky palate. Not refreshing at all.

Medium dark amber cola like clear with a medium small size short lasting head, Amusing roasted caramel honey fruity (watermelon and passionfruit) aroma. My first observation on tasting is where is the bitter? Flat dry ginger ale softdrink like body and palate. Light fruity/floral nectar sweet and faint bitter flavours. Soft sweet soda-pop finish. Disappointing.
a nice bitter finish with a full hop palate, tastes better than it looks, and the aroma leaves a lot to be desired, but the flavour makes up for it
Kind of strange tasting ale, slightly fruity and dry hop finish, and a tad bitter, its drinkable, but it kind of missed the spot with me.
Bottle. Pours bright golden color, clear, with a medium rocky white head. Aroma is lemon, malt, straw. Flavor is some lemon, malt, honey, grain. Good for the style.

Tap. Pours to a clean golden body with a white head. The aroma is silage and not very good. The flavor is icky. Grains galore and nasty lager yeast flavors. Man, I can do without this one. Thank God I only had a sample. Had I decided on a glass, I�d have wanted my money back. Unappealing palate. Was not that good.

Tart lemon earth aroma, spritzy with aged hops and grain husks. Percolatingly hazy golden, with a rocky cream of white. Flavor a very plain and longingly sweet sugary malt over a light body of lemon dust. Malt is clean, but very plain and subdued, however tending a few distant esters and some background yeast notes. Bright and refreshing. Not much depth or character, which I find unfortunate in the this example. It�s almost too americanized for me. But, cleaniness appreciated and light euro hop parch provides welcome balance to the finish.

It�s a great example of a Munich Helles. I�m not sure if I like it better than Hacker Pschorr�s fine Edel-Hell, but they are close. one of my favorite styles of beer. not a "light beer" at all but a specialty lager with lawnmower malt flavors and nice fresh tettanger hop flavors. Superb summer lager.

12 oz bottle: Rated a while ago! Crystal clear deep golden body w/ a lasting white head. Aroma is of clean grainy and toasty malt, a light DMS, also a bit of malty sweetness in the aroma. Clean flavor, well balanced throughout w/ a sweet, malty finish. Toasty malt dominates w/ no hop presence. Lighter medium body, medium carbonation, smooth m/f. Overall a good beer, I�m actually a bit surprised they are discontinuing this one! Not their best, but this would appeal to the non "good beer" drinkers in Cleveland!

I don�t usually enjoy these soapy german style lagers. But this one is very good. The color is nice and golden, witha decent head. The aroma is strong of hops. And the flavor is full and ends witha very good bitterness. A very good lager.

One of the very best dortmunder�s I have experienced, which is saying a lot because I don�t particularly enjoy these types of beers. I didn�t pour this one, so I can�t speak of its color, however, the aroma was pure and clean, as was the finish. The taste was very smooth, flowed like honey, although not as sweet as honey. So that really isn�t an apt comparison.
I don�t think this is a lager at all. It�s more of a hefe-weizen. It�s very citrusy, with a small head. It�s tasty, but I don�t see how it�s labeld a lager.
I dont know if I have any more to say, Great Lakes is simply a great brewery and I enjoy all of it, great job!

Figured I�d better try this one last time before it was too far past freshness date on the bottle. Blonde pour with a foamy white head. Not much retention or lace. Mildy malty aroma, with grassy noble hops. Bready malt profile with slight spice and a hint of fruit from the hops. Clean finish with the slightest hint of yeast. I liked drinking this at Jacobs Field. Too bad this didn�t sell better, or it would probably still be in the bottling rotation. Now, where�s the Barrel Select Pils bottles?
Great chocolatey, nutty, textured aroma. The falvour, however, is one-dimensional being heavily nutty and a tad dry.
Sparkling deep amber,thin head. Roasted carmel malt nose. Burnt carmel flavor
Brick amber; peaty, assertive, roasty nose. Firm maltiness, quaffable though, slight toffee note, more smoke lingering, dry finish. Good flavour, needs a shade more body and malt to back it up.
A dark ale with a kind of roasty taste to it. No over whelming hop content and not very strong.
Sparkling gold,thin white head. Malt nose. Medium bodied clean malt flavor.

Light copper; light earthy hops, bread crusts on the nose. Interplay of warm biscuity malts and crisp, earthy hop notes. Light on the IBUs (between 16 & 18). Almost lemony finish - mix of US and English hops, which I usually do not recommend.
A very nice Ale to enjoy while trying some of their dishes. Great spot too.

341ml bottle sampled many years ago poured a dark brown color with a finger of off-white head that left some sporadic lacing on the glass. Aroma was caramel and light chocolate with some roasted grains. Taste was malty sweet with a surprising hop bitterness in the finish. Light to medium body with adequate carbonation. A refreshing and flavorful brown ale that was thoroughly enjoyed.

Body is medium brown with a nice tan head that laced pretty nicely. Aroma was sweet and quite hoppy. Flavour is quite sweet with a caramel flaour to it. Finish is sort of dry but the feeling in the mouth is quite acidic.
Brown colour. Thick head. Sweet aroma out of the bottle. Stronger hops than expected. Body is a little thin. Decent but unspectacular beer from thes small brewer.
Slightly hoppy aroma with a fruity tinge. Pours amber brown with a thin head. Palate is a bit thin. The finish is also a bit light. An ok beer for casual quaffing but not a standout.
Along the spectrum of brown ales, from Rogue's flavorfulness to Newcastle's mildness, this falls about midspectrum. It's sweeter than most and yet has a mildness that could make it a session brown.
I''m not a fan of brown ales, but I didn''t mind this one. Light carmel malt nose. Malt flavor throughout, no noticeable hops
Really liked this. I swear I'm getting a hint of caramel in it. Much better than a Newcastle. Crisper and better flavor. Excellent!!!

Brewers never admit it, but I think this and their lager have been dumbed down over the years. At first, this was a fine, hoppy "American Brown", kind of like what Pete's Wicked used to be. Now it's not as hoppy, and the malt is lacking that hint of smoke I used to enjoy. It's ok, but a simplistic beer and not as good as when these guys first came out and people were actually excited about them.

I'm not sure how old this is, but since the last review was in 2016, I'm guessing I've had it awhile. Purchased at Albertson's in Bakersfield. Clear orange/amber color with a fluffy and persistent white head. Not much in the aroma other than nice toasted malt. Taste is also toasted malt and a clean, dry grain flavor. Earthy, slightly spicy, dry leaf bitterness follows this and balances the maltiness really well. Finishes with a light caramel sweetness and lasting dry bitterness. There's nothing extreme or intense about this beer, but it's a very well constructed and balanced traditional IPA that's flavorful and tasty. I'll try to drink it a little fresher next time!

Bomber courtesy of IrishBoy (Thanks Richard!) poured a clear golden amber with a lasting creamy ivory head. Aromas of biscuit, pine, dankness, light earthiness and light grapefruit. Palate was light bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of biscuit, dankness, pine and a hint of grapefruit with a smooth dry bitter lingering dank piney finish.
Great nose that showcases the hop well, as does the flavor. Avg body but as expected. Solid.
Draft. Big Centennial hop aroma of flowers, also of honey. Flavors are orangey honey with some nutty bittering at the finish. Solid.
Very unique IPA - Intense malt profile combined with great Hops! One of my all-time favorites! At 6.5 ABV, the Bomber is a nice solo drink to enjoy while food-prepping!

I like Centennial hops, so I think well of this beer. Good citrus and tropical fruit nose from a healthy foam. Amber color with medium body. Flavors are a little too sweet but hops are still noticeable. Finish is also slightly sweet.

Amber pour with a white head. Nice citrus hop nose. Some grapefruit, a bit of orange, and a light peach note. Plenty of pine, a mild malt sweetness, and a hint of floral hops. There is a bit of a grassy note to the flavor. Some pie bitterness, grapefruit, and orange peel. Moderate malt sweetness on the palate as well.
On tap at the brewpub. Unclear amber, tiny head. Aroma-grains, citrusy hops. Taste- sweet malt, spicy and floral hops. Light-medium body, dusty aftertaste.
Growler. Deep orange pour. Citrus aroma. Very nice hop aroma. Flavor is sweet malt. Some cotton candy. All followed up by a calming American C-hop bitterness.

On tap @ the brewpub. Clear medium orange with a 1/2 finger yellowish white head, good retention. Big grassy citrus hops and light pine hops behind, with a solid lightly sweet clean caramel malt backbone. The flavor has the caramel turning a little honeyish, with the hops otherwise staying the same. Dry finish with bitterness at a 4. Light carbonation with a medium body. Very good IPA--more of a regular IPA than a West Coast. . .

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Appearance - golden amber with a nice fluffy head. Nose - sulphur, and perhaps something funky. Taste - more of the same. Palate - well, I�ve implied it all above. Overall - I�m not sure this is how the brewer intended.
Bottle at appellation. Pours golden orange, nose is eggs, biscuity, light fruit, taste is harsh toffee, sweet.

500ml bottle shared with Ashton McCobb and Stuu666. Pours clear amber with a thin white head. Aromas of toffee and a sulphur farty note. Eggy. Taste is light sweet, cooked vegetables. Grainy. Not great.
Bottle. Amber in colour. Fruity; citrus lemon. Hoppy; grassy hops. Malty; grainy malts, some toffee. Sweet fruity throughout; quite dry. Long dry bitter finish. Drinkable. Sessionable. (2011-01-20)
Bottle Ambrata velata buona schiuma piuttosto persistente floreale leggero malto biscotto secchezza media siscreta luppolatura lieve nota tostata

Bottle from Alesbymail. Light hazy golden with a big white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity and light hoppy. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. Carbonation is a bit high for an English bitter. 310314
Bottle at yespr. Hazy golden coloured with a small white head. Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel and spices. Fruity flavour of caramel and spices with notes of hops. Spicy finish.

Sample from 50 cl. bottle. Slightly hazy golden colour with an amber tint. Thin, bubbly white head. Fruity aroma with caramel malts, grass, some toasted bread. Taste is sweet. Light to medium body. Finishes dry with fruits. Okay bitter.
Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and fruits. The flavor is sweet with notes of straw, malt, and a bit of caramel, leading to a lightly bitter finish.
bottled. golden colored. unclear. dense off white head. aroma. sweetness, caramel, herbs. flavour. sweetness, caramel. medium bodied. ends light bitter.
Cloudy golden beer with frothy head. Full aroma dominated by bubblegum, apple and smoke. Fruity full taste with smokey bitter finish. Dry and crisp on the palate. Nice beer.

Bottle. Reddish-Brown in colour. Malty; sweet malts, caramel, chocolate. Fruity; orange citrus, plums. Hoppy; grassy hops. Nice malt/fruit/hop balance. Sweet malty fruity chocolatey throughout. Interesting beer. Liked this. Very Drinkable. (2011-08-26)

Bottle from the much lamented Memorable Cheese and More, Ipswich. Pours a cloudy copper brown colour with a big off white head. Aroma of caramel malt and hops. Medium sweetness, light bitterness and slight sourness. Medium body, texture has a slightly chalky feel to it. Average carbonation. Malty bitter finish.

Bottle: Burnt toast, from a dark gold body. light sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, thick feel, thick feel, average carbonation, im a bit confused by this beer! i cant get any flavour from it! it doesnt taste of anything in particular, even the aroma is hard to pin down, im not sure what to make of it! i didnt dislike it....
Light amber coloured and hazy. Has a white head, lasting. Aroma is hoppy and herbal. Flavor starts sweet,more herbal notes. BItter finish. Creamy, dry texture.
November bottle;light grass aroma,amber, hazy, off white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, light fizzi, nice harmonic light hoppy finish.
Bottle. Creamy white good fully lasting head. Amber cloudy colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter nice flavor. Average moderate bitter fnish. Nice balance. Oily palate.

Bottle. Dark golden, cloudy, average and mostly diminishing head. Moderate, malty and lightly sweetish aroma, light caramel and light bread, light barnyard, light herbal hoppyness. Body is medium, malty and lightly sweetish flavor, light caramel and light roasted malt, light herbal hoppyness.
