Part of sampler at brewpub. Pours clear copper with small white head. Aroma is hops, pine, citrus and caramel malts. Flavor is light hops, caramel malts and some citrus and very light pine. Not the most hoppy IPA I have had. Good amount of malt. Nothing special.

Poured from firken. Nice citrus hop aroma. Nice hoppy flavor (grapefruit) with an average malt backbone with some sweetness. I enjoyed this thorougly. I was pleasantly surprised considering the 33 percentile it falls into here. Maybe they changed thier recipe or maybe the firken is the way to serve it. I for one recommend as an excellent example of style and american hop showcase.

A copper / amber appearance, some lacing that sticks and a lasting head. Tons of hops which are a little overpowering. Smells of citrus and pine from the hops, but still has some sweet/malt smell as well. The flavor is a little more balanced than the smell. Not too heavy, good mouthfeel and an enjoyable hoppy-bitter finish/aftertaste.

Aroma is grapefruit. Taste is of very citric hops with a fair amount of malt sweetness to balance it out a bit. Palate is thicker than many IPAs. This is on the bitter side, even for the style, but I enjoyed i very much. Nice example of a West-coast style IPA.

Strong citrus/pine hop aroma. Pours a clear orange/amber with a quickly fading white head. Nice grapefruit hop punch at the beginning of the beer, fading into a touch of caramel. Long bitter finish. A very drinkable IPA.

Now here?s the funny thing... yes, this beer was like a Flander?s red, and I loved it. Nice sourness. Well... the brewer changed. It?s good, but not the hidden sour gem. Deep red, balanced malt now. No discernible anything else.

Growler shared by bvc. This is in no way shape or form an alt. There is no way in hell. Nose of cherry balsamic, wood, some funky off notes - it literally smells like a flanders red or something. Tangy off aromas, some dark fruit I guess. Pours brownish, no head or lace, minimal carbonation, flabby, kind of bad looking. Flavors of cherry balsamic, funky off notes, a little wood, a little medicinial, tangy lingering notes. Still I feel this is mislabeled or something happened and the wrong beer was filled but this is in no way a fucking alt. Almost uncarbonated, flabby, slick mouth feel. Undrinkable. Fuck what the hell happened here?

Growler from in recent growler swap. Now this growler came with a �CC Alt� on the cap. Sender told me that is was Copper Canyon Alt, but that the bartender told him that is was the Alt with Brett in it. I contacted them to ask if they had another beer listed with Brett in it, and they told me they do not use Brett. So shame on the bartender for trying to pass this off for something it isn�t and shame on the brewery for putting an infected beer on for sale. Pours a clear walnut amber tinted brown with very flabby white head that is minimal with a very aggressive pour from the growler. Very tart nose (not in an intentional or good way), fake cherry, apple, bubblegum, tannins, chalk dust, some medium roasted malt undertones. Thin body, little carb and what is there is loose. Cherry, tart, slight balsamic, hints of wood, crushed aspirin in the finish. Nothing alt about this beer, it is infected and undrinkable.

Their Copper Canyon Alt is one of their signature offerings, as one could surmise by the name. A perfect brown in color, this has a thinner body than a typical brown ale, more in the direction of a traditional northern German Altbier it�s supposed to be. There�s a lovely roasted caramel nose, and lingering glass cling that measured the sips down the edge of the pint. The balance was exceptional with a clean, sweet barley finish as this was definitely one of their better offerings and a solid above average brew. Serving type: on-tap

Draft sample. Poured clear dark brown color with an average frothy white head that mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate balanced toasted aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

Part of sampler at brewpub. Pours dark amber with small white head. Aroma is caramel malts and some nuts. Flavor is caramel malt, toffee and some nuts. Average body and mouthfeel. Middle of the pack of the beers I had tonight.

Maybe they have improved this since the last reviews, but I really enjoyed this. It had a nice amber-red look to it with just a ring of head around the glass. Aroma and taste was of caramel malt, possibly Vienna as well, and noble hops. Very well balanced and perfectly carbonated.
Not one of their better beers, mild hop flavor with little to no malt, to thick and almost syrup like consistency, nothing special.

On tap: The aroma consists of moderate caramel and nuts. Transparent amber with a small off-white head. The flavor is pretty simple with moderate caramel and roasted nuts with a mild grassy hopped finish. Easy drinking, but nothing special.

Deep amber in color with a small white head, as served. Rich toasted and caramel malt aroma with a hint of roasted corn nuts in the finish. The flavor is malty with some upfront bitterness and a lingering toffee-like sweetness. The body is okay, nothing noticably exciting or disappointing. This beer is okay to drink, but not one I�d order regularly.
Excellent lacing and long lasting head. Rich dark gold. Slight hop presence... almost like a pale, pale ale. New brewer, so I�m wondering if the recipe for this changed from earlier.

Their Northwest Gold is really a pretty standard training wheels light ale. It has a very light body, accompanied with a mild noble hoppy bite. It�s very clean and very high in carbonation. With its light blonde, straw color, it was every bit the imitation "macro" offering for people who don�t like beer. With that in mind, it�s clean, crisp and surprisingly not a bad effort. Serving type: on-tap

Draft sample. Poured clear amber color with an average white fizzy head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate hop and malt aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture and soft carbonation. Medium bitter flavor with a medium bitter finish of moderate duration. Drinkable soft brew.
Part of sampler at brewpub. Pours light golden with white head. Aroma is sweet corn and grains. Flavor is grainy with some light corn and malt. Rather boring and your average macro substitute.

On tap: The aroma is lightly sweet with moderate grassiness. Transparent gold with a minimal white head that leaves behind sporadic lacing. The flavor has some light lager sweetness with a touch of citrus. The finish is moderately grassy. It is boring, but about as good as you can expect from a house golden lager.

Clear light gold color. Maybe a tiny bit of barley or wheat on the aroma. Little head. Has a medium light body with a tinge of sour hops, and a fluffy, doughy finish. Aftertaste is decent though, it tasted like I was chewing on some wheat, which was about the only flavor I could really find. Again, not a bad flavor, just not much of any flavor.

Golden and highly carbonated with a faint nose of wheat fields and leaves. Grainy first sip, lively mouthfeel and quite a thick body for a presumably thin selection. Taste really went nowhere, staying grainy and bland. Hints of dryness at the end. Not offensive or too harsh, or too thin for that matter.
Good head and nice lace. Golden Color with a clean smooth taste. .........
This one is their microbrew for the masses and it manages to capture rather well the typical beery standard lager taste in its fuller ale body. Cardboard malt, some hops at close.
A refreshing golden ale. Nice hop taste on the finish although rather unspectacular. A thirst quencher rather than a taste to be savored.
Good head with a nice lace. Expected color and typical flavor, but a strong fruity aftertaste that sneaks up on you.

This is the second straight brewpub where the best beer I've tried was the wheat. It may be the season, or it may be that I'm finally being won over, because I used to despise wheat brews. Anyway, this comes on with a rush of citrus and finishes pleasantly spicy, with a decent body in between. A strong effort.
Bottle. Poured an amber color with a thin sized head. Dark fruits, caramel, lighter alcohol and a bit thinner in the body.

5th November 2016 High Wycombe House Warming. Thanks to Paul for this antique. Lightly hazy amber beer no real head. Palate is smooth and dry, modest carbonation. Oxidised caramel. Ripe fruits. Smooth finish. Shows it�s age but doesn�t lack for flavour.

November 2016 - Bottle share at Casa de Cloine. Thanks to Paul for another perspex pour Gales beer. As �Gales Jubilee Ale�, 2002 vintage, 12%. Orange brown with no head. Aroma is sherry, rum, papery oxidation. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is sugary, meaty dense sweetness, sherry. OK � a bit meaty and old but interesting and drinkable. (2.7)

Bottle at The High WyCum tasting, Chez Bois, thanks to Paulo 05/11/16 Mahogany brown with a moderate tan covering. Nose is soy sauce, toffee, spice, charr, cocoa rub, toffee. Taste comprises light oxidised notes, dark fruits, spice, biscuit, gravy, oxidised. Medium + body, fine carbonation, drying close. Ok for age.

Bottle shared at the hi wy cum. Tasting, 5/11/2016. Many thanks to Paul for this one. Aroma is soy, umami, salty, toffee, musty. Flavour is composed of salty toffee, tangy berry, red fruits, toffee, . Palaate is sweet. Sticky, lowish carbonation, flat. Salty.

Bottle shared at Colin�s. It pours mohaganny brown with minimal head. The aroma is rich, umami, plummy, port wine, musty, malt loaf and bisto. The taste is rich, musty, meaty, plum wine, juicy, earthy, tannins, drying, vinous and a touch of alcohol with a drying finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Not bad for the age.

Bottle shared in High Wycombe - thanks to Paul. Pours clear copper with a slim head. The nose has light caramel, oxidation, ripe fruits, dates. Medium sweet flavour with more gooey caramel, ripened fruits, dates, old leather, light tang. Medium to full bodied with fine carbonation. Lightly warming in the finish with more toffee, caramel, dried fruits, berries, some oxidation. Pretty good stuff.
Bottle at Travlr�s DC Departure RateBeer Tasting. Dark amber with no head. Aromas of dark fruit, spice, caramel. Tastes of salt, dark fruit, woody notes. Light body with a dry finish.
From a bottle at the RateBeer gathering 9/9/16. Vintage 2002.it is a cloudy Amber color with a scant head. The Aroma is sweet toffee. The taste has hints of molasses in it rather thin
Bottle courtesy of maniac, thanks! Cloudy reddish color. Aroma of tannic plums. Aroma of boozy heavy spice, tons of tannins. Weird.
Cask Conditioned at The White Lion, Fewcott, Oxon. Light Amber colour with fluffy head. Sweet malty beer with apple hints, fresh, heavily hopped at the end some alcohol notes.
Tried from cask. Cloudy amber color - no head. Hop aroma and refreshing acidic taste - nice.

From Dec 2007 I got this bottle also as an extra in a trade with JDV. Thanks again, Deniz! This pours from 12oz bottle a cloudy rusty brown with a small but stubborn head of foam. The smell is of apricots, caramel malt, and a touch of hops in the background. Smells nice. The taste is well, tasty. Apricots are the first thing I noticed followed by some caramel malt and a nice big heaping helping of hops. Wow. I didn't think the different flavours would work all that well together but hey, they do! The mouthfeel is medium, the carbonation is fairly low, and it finishes with a good mix of bitter hops and apricot tartness. Very nice indeed! Thanks again, Deniz, for throwing this one in. DFH has again defied the odds. ;^)
Medium amber color. Apricots, apples and caramel. Modestly bitter palate, but a bit more restrained in the finish.

Found in cellar from last year (2016) and drank it today while working in garage. Pours a clear gold with a very very creamy long lasting head. Subtle apricot under more traditional pale ale aromas. Taste is more pale ale than apricot and it has a very long lasting finish of a melange of apricot, hop, and malt - almost lasts like it�s sticky going down, but it�s not. Very nice on this warm, but not hot, day.

Vtg Blackberry backlog, Many bottles over the years, This review was from Spring 2010. Pours amber golden with one finger head. Smell and flavor are old hops, caramel, pine, and candy apricot. Too sweet.

12fl oz bottle poured into a Dogfish Head IPA glass. Very effervescent, dark amber with a couple fingers of lingering off-white head. Aroma and flavor are both heavy on hops and apricot. Lasting bitter finish. Delicious. My 500th rate! :D
Pours a light amber color. Aromas of hop, apricot with hints of grass and malts. Flavor has a nice piney juniper bite to it, with a mellow apricot flavor with a nice dry finish.
just a slight hint of apricot, the apricot really gets overwhelmed by the hops (a good thing) much tastier that I expected; not your average fruit beer

Bottle 0,33l. Pours an amber colour with a white head. Aroma is fruity malt, apricot, and pine. Taste is sweet caramel malt with some fruit notes and slight apricot flavors. Finishes with earthy, pine hops. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I was stoked for this beer. What a cool concept, apricots and Dogfish Head, right? Eh. I didn�t enjoy it like I thought I would. It wasn�t a bad beer, but it didn�t keep me drinking. It was a little bitter and not really smooth, and tasted more reminiscent of grapefruit than any other fruit flavor I can associate with a beer. Just okay.
Bottled. Has a darker brown. Has a hoppy taste. Has a light body with a medium taste of apricots. Pretty good IPA!!

Wow! What a balancing act. The maple syrup flavor is right up front, backed by a lightly chocolaty malt character. The hop bitterness is present but unobtrusive. Full bodied, rich and strong. This beer should not be served in pints! Of course, it is on the sweet side and one pint is enough. More of an after dinner drink.

Too sweet!! This dark brown colored brown ale just had way too much of a brown sugar taste and it wiped my olefactory senses and tastebuds in the blink of an eye. I hope this was just a bad batch and not indicitive the this beer.
Big foam ( at the castle in Salzburg) mild bead flavor with a soft wheat finish. Location adds to the rating.
Easily one of the best weissbiers I have tasted. Malt and wheat in perfect balance with just the right amount of sweetness.
Draft at moldau Sthlm Decent weizen with a bit thin body and to sweet finish to be great. Refreshing. Heavier than most hefeweizen i have tried
Bottle 50cl. Huge white foamy white head. Hazy yellow color. Aroma is hay, grass, banana. Taste is sweet and foamy with banana.

Carolina Beer Company--Charleston Brown Ale--2002 12 oz. Bottle. 5.70% ABV. 25 IBU�s. (4.25 / 5.0) Malt of the Earth Beer of the Month Club Selection. Creamy head and lace. Clear thin amber brown color. Malty tangy mild floral chocolate hop front. Creamy smooth light sweet toasted cocoa body. Dark wheat bread notes. Mild tangy end. Sampled 3/24/2003.

Draft. Pours deep brown with a tan head. Aroma was biscuity and yeasty, not very pleasant. Smooth roasty taste which made up a little on the aroma. I didn�t find this to be anything I would want to drink again.

Draught at Charlotte International Airport. Pours brown with an average, frothy, off-white, lasting head with good lacing. Aroma is average malt (cookie, caramel, nutty), light hops (herbs), average yeast (leather) with notes of toffee. Light bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation, and a metallic finish. Average duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.
I tell you this... I have drank a few other brown ales. Sam adams, petes, cotton wood low down brown(good), & new castle. I rate charleston above all the above.

draught at Murphy�s Law Pub. Pours brown (duh), small white head. The nose is heavily nutty with smoked almonds up front.There�s a bit of caramel and coffee in there too. The beer is not so dense and the sweetness is not over bearing. Yeah, it sounds good, even as I type it, but the balance is off and some salty, veggie notes come out. Okay, I guess.

Enjoyed at the �Pirate�s House� in Savannah GA on draught. Fantastic malty, nutty, roasted initial flavor, then flavor disappears. Would have been one of my favorites if the flavor could have hung on a little longer.
Dark with a big off white head. Tasted of toasted malts. Not much hops. Had some slight stout like qualities. Dark for a brown ale. Not bad.

Poured a translucent brown color with an ok head and lacingg that was ok. Aroma on this one was hard to pick up, maybe some toasted malts. The fflavor was an odd liquor type flavor in the front of everything (sorry, I don�t know my liquors, nor can I say this was high abv, but boy, it was liquor sweet and sharp). Bitter nuts picked up mid-glass and as it warmed some sweet type candy came out. Too strong of an odd liquor type flavor in this one to be great.
a great beer out of the draught. rich dark color with an off white head. rich carmel and toasty, almost taste like beef gravy, which is a plus for me.

12 oz bottle. Clear dark mahogany color with bubbly khaki head. Heavy molasses nose that competes for aromatic supremecy with the strong raisin smell. Flavor is roasty and chocolatey with a delicate sweetness. Medium bodied with a flat finish.
At the great place in the neighborhood. Decent euro lager, good and unchalleging cold, suffers as it warms, malty and biscuity Serving: Bottle
from notes taken 9/21/10 -- golden color, almost no head, light streaks of lace. Taste is some malt supported by lots of sweet corn. Flavor thins as it moves to light hops. Not recommended.

Served from bottle in pint glass. Appearance: light golden color, a bit of lacing, mild carbonation streaming. Aroma: grassy hops, sweet fresh bread dough and a bit of metallic Mouthfeel: light and dry, almost champagne like Flavor: echoes the aroma with grain sweetness and bread crust along with grassy hops. The slight lingering metallic is a distraction. Overall: an average beer that paired well with my Greek pasta dish.
Rated based on notes taken 25 June 2012 -- A very refreshing lager. Went well with my spicy burrito.
Clear golden with s white head. Aroma of metal, grass, and grain. Taste is sweet and grainy with a slight bitterness. Light bodied and dry.

1st June 2015: 330ml green bottle sat outside �A Taste of Greece� in Laguna Niguel while waiting for a take away. Golden and bright pour, weak un-lasting white head. Corn aroma and taste: poor and basic. Just a boring lager/pilsner based beer that lacks interest or character.

Location: 12 oz bottle at a Greek restaurant, 7/30/14 Aroma: The nose is fairly typical pale lager, grainy, some lemon notes, grass, and a little bread Appearance: This one pour a clear golden-yellow color with a fizzy head on top of it Flavor: The flavor is much the same, clean, with a little sweetness, and a mild bitterness Palate: The body is light, but not as watery as some of the style, with a lively-to-fizzy carbonation Overall Impression: This one was pretty much what I expected, while at the same time being a little better. Maybe I just really was in the mood for a light, easy drinking beer, but this one hit the spot.
Bottle at olympic flame downtown dm.. pale clear yellow pour with super thin off white head... taste is malty and skunky.. decent overall

33cl bottle pours with a clear deep gold yet watery body and almost no head. The aroma puts off sweet creamed corn and some mild floral hop notes. The taste is similar as you�re greeted by a big dose of sweet creamed corn. It then slides into sugary malt sweetened subtle floral hops. Behind those notes are sweet fruity esters like honey covered apples wedges and pears. A bit less sweet and this might not be too hateful.
Bottle->session. Light gold with big frothy white head. A: strong corn and lager grains, wet hay. T: watery sweet corn and grains, grass. Crisp but unpleasant.

column1: Golden City Mad Molly's Brown Ale
column5: Sample at the taproom. Clear mahogany-brown color with a thin light beige head that recedes quickly to an outer ring. Spotty lacing. Roast malt, caramel and fruit aroma. Light body with flavors of roast malt, caramel and fruit. The finish is sweet with a short malty aftertaste. Average overall.

column1: Golden City Mad Molly's Brown Ale
column5: Tap@ GCB.Clear dark amber color with ivory head. Nutty, mild chocolate, dirt aromas. Medium body. Same nutty, light roast, mild chocolate flavors with a dirt finish----decent

column1: Golden City Mad Molly's Brown Ale
column5: On tap at GCB. Brown with a light tan head. Toasted malts, caramel, nuts, roast, light hops, light pine. Similar flavor, bittersweet with a medium body. Pretty easy to drink, I was thirsty. Tastes nice and fresh.

column1: Golden City Mad Molly's Brown Ale
column5: On tap at brewery. Very good brown. Leather aroma with a sweet finish. One of the better beers here.

column1: Golden City Mad Molly's Brown Ale
column5: Clear dark nutty amber with an aroma of nutty toffee and a fair whiff of tobacco and vanilla. Taste is much too light for my liking, with a mild flavor of light brown malts and some light earthy caramel. Meh.

column1: Golden City Mad Molly's Brown Ale
column5: Tap @ Golden City Brewery. Dark reddish brown appearance with an off white head. Toasty, caramel, a bit roasty, dark malty, lightly nutty, earthy aroma. Somewhat soapy, bitter, floral, caramel flavor. Too much soap.

column1: Golden City Mad Molly's Brown Ale
column5: Cask at GBBF 2011. Dark chestnut brown color. Aromas of leather, chocolate, nuts and soya sauce. Sweet taste of caramel, nuts, milk chocolate and some strawberry like fruitiness. Low bitternss. Very rounded and mellow.

column1: Golden City Mad Molly's Brown Ale
column5: Cask gravity @ GBBF 2011. Pours a hazy amber brown color with a small off.-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma with hoppy hints. Fruity malty caramel and chocolate flavor with hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

column1: Golden City Mad Molly's Brown Ale
column5: Cask at GBBF 2011. Brown with a small off-white head. Malty toffee aroma with hints of choclolate and fruit. Dry and malty flavour with spice and pineapple notes.

column1: Golden City Mad Molly's Brown Ale
column5: Cask (gravity) @ GBBF 2011, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Unclear medium to dark amber colour with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, sour berry, wood, moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet, light acidic and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20110803]

Tap at the brewpub. Pours black with tan head. Burnt malt aroma. Fullish body/creamy carb. Flavor is smooth burnt malt - and I think I get the oatmeal aspect. Plus it is nicely hopped. Very, very good.

A very beautiful pour nets a slightly carbonated, jet black beer, with streaks of brown slipping through around the edges. Unfortunately the promise of its appearance disapates with a hugely burnt smelling nose, with some type of liquid smoke aroma dominating. Better on the palate, with nicely roasted coffee flavors up front and some nice hops on the finish. Seems too young, and the roasty character makes it hard to drink too much of this one.

Bomber thanks to footbalm, bought on our amazing journey in Colorado. Pours a dark black color with a small white head. The aroma is quite nice; oats and roasted malts, some sweet coffee also. The flavor was similar; coffee, roasted malts, cocoa. The only downside was that the body was very thin and watery.

22 oz bottle. Pours a dark brown with a big creamy dark brown head that retains fairly well and laces the glass. The aroma is roasted malts and chocolate with some off plasticy/vegetal notes. The flavor is bitter roasted malts and sweet chocolate and some lactose. As it warms some off-notes come out - burnt plastic. The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with full but smooth carbonation. Overall, pretty simplistic but enjoyable when cold. As it warmed, it became less so as some off-notes started dominating.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a thick rapidly disappearing head of a nice mocha color, some mild lacing over a very black opaque body.....nose has nice coffee, chocolate tones....taste is light watery with a bit of bitter finish.....mouthfeel has none of the creaminess an oatmeal (listed on the bottle as one) should have. After the initial appearance and nose a total bomb.
bottle. pretty bad. poured black without head. tasted kinda sour and lactic acid-ish. i guess otherwise it was pretty normal and uninspiring.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a rim of brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of cocoa, but also a siight off-note of dust. The flavor is sweet with notes of vegetables, cardboard, and roasted malt as well as a light note of acidity, leading to a dry bitter cocoa finish.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours black with a fully gone head. Hardroasted malt and liqourice aroma, vague oaties note - pleasant aroma. Flavour is roasted, liqourice and dark malty. Light butterish on the back of the tongue. A bit unrefined. Dark acidic finish.

Bottle. Pours black without much head. Strongly roasty nose with a dark chocolate note. Very thin. Acidic roast and cardboard. Definitely an oxidized bottle. I�ll try to find another bottle sometime to see if this is an aberration. Tastes like coffee watered down with iced tea. I�m surprised how bland this is compared to the aroma. 3 7 3 2 7

22oz bottle. Pours black with a very small tan head. Sweet aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, and some coffee. Roasted malt flavour with chocolate and coffee, with a burnt malt flavour following quickly. I could do without the burnt malt flavour as well as the plastic and metal tastes that show up. The finish is of burnt malt with some bitterness. With every sip it becomes more unpleasant. Under-carbonated with a thin mouthfeel. The best part of this beer are the appearance and aroma, it�s all downhill from there. It�s going to be a challenge finishing this bomber.

tap at Mad Anthony Oktoberfest - Pours clear dark amber with a thin head. It has a very mild malt aroma. The flavor is caramel malt with just a touch of hops. It has a good light hops and caramel finish. The overall result is a decent session brew.

Date: 07/20/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear dark red, fine dirty white head, lots of spidery lace, light toasted and chocolate aroma, rich chocolate malt flavor, hint of roasted, nice nutty character, earthy hops keep it mostly dry with just a bit of sweetness coming through, light lingering bitter finish keeps some of the nutty character, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4

Very clingy, thin beige head, watery cola colored. Yeasty, milky aroma. Tangy, amateurish, overbrewed hops, out of balance. No nuts, no fruit. Like water that�s been run through an old coffee filter. Their red actually came off as a better brown.
Tried this in the sampler tray on the patio at thier Anaheim location. Not as malty as most. Good head on it. Rather enjoyed it.
Draft at Indy location. Rediish brown with medium off-white head. Well balanced aroma and medium flavor of malt, coffee and small hops. Medium texture with short finish.
Clouded dark brown apearance, craemy head (nitrogen). Chocolaty coffee aroma. Sweet chocolate nutty flavor, slight bitterness and fruitiness in the finish.

This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of medium sized mostly lasting off-white colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing. The body was transparent softly carbonated and dark ruby red brown in color. It had a medium strength malt hop aroma with a mild brown note. The mouth feel was smooth and somewhat flat with a mild lingering malt finish that was mildly tingly. The flavor contained notes of malt and hops.

Utterly delicious! Rather sweet and mild with probably not much alcohol. I could drink gallons of this stuff. Not a hop in sight. Fantastic! Quite malty. Looking forward to more during 2005's annual Indy pilgrimage.
Nitro. Dark brown. Nitro head makes it somewhat interesting, but not enough. Smooth clocolate taste with subtle nuts, malt and caramel. It did have a gritty finish. Way too light at 4.4%

From a sampler: This beer is a dark brown color with a medium thick beige head. Thin, sticky lacing. The aroma is very nutty with a touch of brown sugar. Very smooth body with a tasty roasted coffee, nut and malt blend. The only downside is the flavor is not very lasting. The finish is nutty and has a lightly bitter aspect to it. This is a pretty good Brown.
Bottle from bottle shop near Callandar. Deep amber brown colour with a tan head. Aroma malty light chocolate sweet. Taste light sweet. Full body.
Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.

Flasche 0,5l: Dunkel, kastanienbraun, tr�b, deutlicher mittelporiger Schaum; w�rzige Nase, R�stmalz, Karamell, kr�ftige R�staromen, Kaffee; w�rziger K�rper, R�stmalz, Karamell, kr�ftige R�staromen, Kaffee, cremig, kr�ftige Kohlens�ure, leichte S�ure; recht s�uerlicher Nachgang
Just getting to know Scottish beers. This is a nice middle between their light pub ales to their dark offerings. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
500ml bottle. Clear, dark, reddish brown with an off white head. Sweet, fruity malt aroma, matched in the flavour which also has some bitterness. Not bad

Deep nutty color with a big off white head. Looks nice and gives a fine lacing down the glass. Fruity, malty and toffee. Medium body and a fine carbonation. Tad sweet and a moderate bitterness. Decent fine bitter. [Bottle at The Brewery]
-at the local pub, lochranza- brown with small white head. Toffee, chocolate and sweet malt. Sweet, nutty, floral and watery finish. Overall: enjoyable. A little watery.

Bottle on the Calmac ferry from Brodick to Ardrossan. Appearance - dark amber with a decent head. Nose - sweet malt and toffee. Taste -more light toffee intermingled with sweet malt and oats. Palate - close to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a long dry finish. Overall - classic 80 shilling.

Brown-orange with beige head. Fruity nose with notes of honey, some acid, spices, plastic and roasted malt. Fruity flavour with notes of roasted malt, petroleum, berries, spices, hops, honey and wormwood. Aromatic green bitterness.

* Bottle. Pours chestnut brown, clear, with an off-white head. * Aroma is roasted malts, milk, chocolate & toast. * Palate is medium, medium carbonation, fine bubbles, medium dry. * Taste is sweet roasted malts & dried fruit. * Finish is short, bittersweet, fruity & smokey. * Overall sweet roasted malts, dried fruit & smokey.
A nice change of pace from the usual, somewhat ham-handed Cascades hop approach at Buckhead. This was nutty and dry with a decent but not overly-done hopping. Woody amber brown. Good aroma.

Tasted more like a Porter - noticed the caramel and toast as the description states - littel bit of coffee/chocolate as well. Not as sweet as Marzens tend to be and should be. Nice orange/copper color - pleasant aroma. Another solid effort from Buckhead.
Nice amber color. Balanced flavor that finishes on the hoppy side. Smooth and refreshing.
Cask Handpump at the Pot Of Beer, Manchester 26/03/2004 Golden coloured fruity and malty. Some bitterness in a lasting finish.
Sampled cask conditioned. Slight apple aroma. Medium bodied, rather sweet, fruity. The finish is slightly salty with medium bitterness.

I have known this beer,but I could not drink it,because,I am young and now beer is not making.I was a young,seen this bottle,logo in local store.My review is not correct,just I take out my respect to local beer

Sampled from bottle. Pours hazy gold with a scattered white head. Aroma is unpleasantly sour. Flavor is balanced and dominated by pils malt. Metallic finish brings a grimace to my face. Light-bodied, moderately carbonated. Typical industrial lager.

Interesting head. Starts out tall & bubbly, becomes slender but creamy, then turns to pond scum, all in about a minute�s time. The aroma is grainy and sweet, covered by an herbal bitterness and pencil erasers. The flavor contains a toasty malt coupled with a corny sweetness that turns somewhat metallic towards the finish, which is an oddly bitter, sticky event. I wish these folk brewed a mocne. DiCarlo Fine Wine and Spirits, Mundelein, IL

Chill-hazed golden with a trickle of carbonation and a large but fast white head that settles scummy. Aroma finds stale pink bubblegum to start before powdery grains with a light floral quality that gets harsh and herbal as it warms. A thick, malty palate with syrupy-sweetness greeted me in the flavor, fully covering the alcohol assault I had expected. DMS quickly follows turning the sweetness to corn syrup with alcohol creeping in later. A sour finish hangs in the throat. Not too great, but better than the Gold. Purchased from Di Carlo Fine Wines and Spirits, Mundelein, IL 60060

Pours a clear amber with a feeble white head. Nose was bearly perceptible but held a hint of sweetness and alcohol. Slightly fizzy but still watery and thin. The flavor was almost imperceptible notes of bubblegum and alcohol.

22oz bottle. A clear gold color, well-carbonated and sporting a white head. Early perfumy aroma before a sweet malty flavor matched with early mellow hops. Overall, a nice pale malt sweetness. Drinkable.

This has kind of an interesting taste going on. Malt very present, sweet. Hops not so much. Eastern European brews are running my life! So many 16 oz bottles and cans for cheap. I�m poor and can�t resist

For some reason, I have a bizarre fascination with the beers of Eastern Europe even though they�re seldom memorable. This is another typical pale lager for the region. It does pour quite a nice glowing golden. The head is initially white and fluffy but diminishes a tad to quickly for my taste. Nose is very bready with a strange sort of tang to it. Sweet and sluggish on the palate with a bit of chemical bitterness in the finish. I just can�t get into this. Sorry.

Color�s a clear yellow, head a full billowy white. Aroma is soft, dry, notes of flowers, straw, little else. Mouthfeel is smooth, texture and body are light. An underlying sweetness pervades the palate, leaving a pleasant, unobtrusive finish. Indistinct hop presence, just enough malt, turning out tasty, nicely balanced, easily consumed beer. And by far the best Ukrainian pilsener this old suds-snoot�s ever had.

(Bottle) Pours a clear yellow with a large white head. Aroma of grain and straw, reminds me of growing up on the farm. Not a bad flavor for a pale lager. I could even drink this one warm without making faces. I couldn�t say that for most pale lagers.

Cask. Pours golden with a white lace head. Aroma pale malts and floral hops. Taste is medium sweet with some lemon bitterness before a malt finish. Carbonation average to strong. A forgettable beer whose rumoured retirement is challenged by this rating.

Cask (Elm Tree, Cambridge) Tiny hint of honey, a bit vegetal. Black tea and tobacco. Some nettles, some green apple. Pretty crazy combination sometimes. Watery palate. Spicy and fruity hops in the taste, some gentle bitterness. Sweet. Weird. Kinda fun I guess, despite the oddness.

500ml bottle. Clear yellow golden colour, foamy white head that quickly dissipates away and aroma of malt, citrus. Taste is sweetish malt with some citrus, fruity & straw notes and a light bitterness. Watery mouth feel, light to medium bodied, medium carbonation, dry bitter on the finish. OK.

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium yellow colour with many large body particles, a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, grain, citrus, soured milk. Flavour is moderate sweet and light acidic with a average duration, sour, citrus. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120810]
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is sweet malt, hops, fruits, grass and straw.

Bottled@chriso. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is fruity, floral, yeasty and a bit tart wooden. Flavour is citrus, some yeast and mild parfumeish sweet notes as well. Mild tartness in it. Lots of particles floating around, foams a lot.
A - floral with light citrus A - light with thin head T - light sour with citrus bitter P - thin O - ehhhh....
Old Rating. Bottle. Golden coloured. Medium body, strong malt body with a touch of sourness and a slightly bitter finish. An average bottled bitter which makes it a slightly below average beer.

Bottle. Fine skimmed straw. Nose of regurgitated vanilla, farmyard and...wait for it....Picked Onion Monster Munch. No two ways about it. As wayward as that suggests on the palate where there�s TCP, oak, green apple, mealy corn snack notes and a dab of vinegar to be had. Soda emptiness, accidental gueuze. And yet I�m drinking it. Which probably says more about me than the beer.

Bottle. Vibrant cloudy golden beer with a strong head. The aroma is mildly sour and fruity, and the flavour is fruity and dry with an element of sourness and yeast. Overall a very nice and drinkable bitter beer.
Sampled cask conditioned. Amber coloured. Grassy hop aroma. Medium bodied, clean with short fruitiness and an immensly bitter finish.

Name: Single Track Nut Brown Date: 10/26/2001 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub dark brown, thin head, slightly sweet malt aroma, rich malt flavor, hints of toasted and chocolate malts, -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Single Track Nut Brown Date: 11/13/2002 Words: Draft Words: Brewpub Dark ruby, whispy tan head, toasted malt aroma, medium body, dry malt flavor, touch of roasted malt, hint of malt based bitterness, malt flavor gets richer as it warms Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Dark cola brown, light tan head. Very faint cherry-fruit aroma. Tastes a little like a lighter version of their Winter (Scotch) Ale. Moderately sweet, fruity (currants, plums), cola and a bit of cocoa flavoring. Mildly tart/sweet finish that fades to a very slight astringency. Pithy palate. A little sulphur in the finish. Commendable.
Nice malty aroma - deep copper color - thick head with good lacing. Flavor is initailly nutty with a bit of caramel detected. Turns metallic and artificial as it winds down however.
Good hoppy ale with a lot of character - not too hoppy that it deadened the tastebuds though. Good quencher for the wings that accompanied it. On the upper echelon of Buckhead's offerings.
Has a lot of the Buckhead house character. Hoppy, citrusy, crackery-dry. Good palate, good kick. Medium rust colored, with smallish head.
Moderately hoppy with a floral aroma. Nice copper color but no head retention. This is the first Buckhead beer I tried and it was very enjoyable.
A pretty solid APA with the strong, grapefruity hops dominating the malt. On the dark side for an APA. It's a solid beer, but not outstanding. A bigger hophead might disagree with me however.

Date: 08/31/1996 Source: Brewpub clear amber, thin head and very nice lace, pleasant faint hop aroma, lots of hop flavor leading to a bitter aftertaste -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 11/10/2000 Score: ii+ to iii Words: Draft Words: Brewpub hazy amber, lots of fresh hop aroma, solid malt base with lots of hop flavor, even bitter finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.5/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Poured a clear ruby color (I wish my homebrew barley wines were this red) with a thin off white head. Big citrus and floral hoppy aroma with sweet caramel underneath. Sweet flavor of caramel mixed with a light hop flavor and finishing with a big hop bitterness. Light to medium bodied.

This is probably closer to a british bitter or pale ale than the American variety. The same bronze color and faint head. Wondeful, flowery aroma and aggresive hops. A macho version of their Red Hills Amber. Great for lovers of assertive ales.

This made up for the weak Pioneer Pilsener. Ruby brown body topped with a whiff of a head, but that�s not a big deal. The aroma is sappy hops and caramel malt. The flavor has a nice grapefruit rind bitterness supported by a sweet caramel malt that makes this a pleasure to drink. A very tasty APA.

This was a really solid example of this style. Lots of cascade and centennial hops come through in the flavor and aroma. Nicely hoppy, with a sloid malt backbone, to keep it all balanced. Lots of zesty fruity flavors as well. Very good.
A very hoppy APA. Copper color with a decent head. Orange and grapefruit citrus flavor. A bitter and refreshing aftertaste. A west coast style hopfest and an excellent beer all around.

Overall a decent offering by Buckhead. No real discernible difference between this and their IPAs - therein lies the rub. A little too hoppy for the style in my humble opinion. Not a bad beer - they are just starting to all taste the same. Nice copper color and hoppy flavor stays strong throughout.
Looks like copper jello with khaki foam head. Hops to make you weep. Lingering hop and orange bitters on the palate. More an APA than an IPA

Name: Eagle�s Eye Oatmeal Stout Date: 06/15/2001 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub black, thin head, thick lace, roasted malt aroma, creamy smooth body, a bit light, lots of rich malt and coffee flavor, a touch of oily oatmeal character Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.5/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
Best of Buckhead to date. Hoppy presentation of a Pilsener - hint of a sweetness underlying it all. Bit of a bite to it as well.
What a pilsener! Very hoppy. Warming C2H5OH content. Excellent mouthfeel and trailing bittering. One of my favorites from this brewery.

This was introduced to me as the seasonal at the Alpharetta location and this is the only maibock I see, so I assume this is it. This was a very typical example of this style. It was light and refreshing and easy to drink, with a modest aroma and subtle flavors. Slightly buttery in the aftertaste.

Date: 06/15/2001 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clean clear yellow, whispy head, light fresh floral hop aroma, soft creamy character, slightly sweet flavor, light bitter finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

If they�d added some more hops to this, it wouldn�t be a bad pilsner. The body is a gold with limited streaming bubbles and a decent head. The Aroma isn�t much. The flavor has a nice pilsner malt profile, although sweeter than most in the style, but it�s definitely lacking the appropriate hoppiness. A bit of peppery hops tease the nose here and there and towards the end you catch a little bitterness, but basically, it�s an extremely drinkable beer, but boring.
A drinkable pilsener but way below average. Cloudy off-yellow color without any real taste of anything. A perfectly good waste of water.

Lager flute. Sweet, dark, boring. Looks like practically ever other beer on the premises. Medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation. The bottom line is: an uneventful way to cap off a night of drinking.

This is a REALLY good dunkel. Nice crystal clear ruby brown body that's dark to the point where you have to look to notice that it is in fact crystal clear. The head is large but not overly so and a creamy off-white. The aroma is nicely malty, chocolate and an earthy caramel. The flavor is smooth, lightly sweet and extremely drinkable. A bit of wood is mixed in with the stuff that carries over from the aroma. This is something you'd down four pints of before you realized it and still not be bored with the beer.

Grassy, coffee nose with notes of 'green' fruit. Deep cola brown. Floavor is coffee, plum and somewhat tannic or acidic. The palate finishes well, because the tannic notes in the flavor suggest that a twang is coming at the end, but it dampens out well. Medium body.
Nice and tranquil, but with a highly sweet palate. Like a beautiful moonlit night, in mosquito season
Herb�cea, ligeramente c�trica y manzana verde fresca. Ligera y refrescante con final lupulado vivo y de amargor suave.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ The Shnoodlepip, London. [ As New Holland Full Circle ]. Clear medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, fruity malt, vegetables, cardboard, light hoppy. Flavor is light moderate sweet with a average duration, pale malt, cardboard. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20160809] 5-3-5-3-9
Straw color with very little head. Flavors of bread and spice. Moderately bitter.

If you are already drunk, this beer tastes fine. However, if this is your first beer of the night, it may taste and smell like vomit. That�s how I have felt about this beer the times that I have had it. Personally not a fan.

Draft to pint glass. Yellow in color and fair amount of head on the pour, which then recedes to a thin layer. Aroma and taste is of lighten sweetened grains, where the body is light and carbonation is light-medium. It�s a good drinker when reasonably priced.

On tap at First Draft Taproom & Kitchen. Clear golden to yellow in appearance with a white head. Aroma of bread, grains and light floral/herbal hops. Similar flavor, light and crisp with a mild bittersweet finish. A solid K�lsch overall.
Bottle, Ann Arbor, MI. Hazy pale yellow. Herbal apple aroma sharp citrus. Muted flavor. Bright citrus. Yeasty finish.

Aroma is fruity, apple, grassy, some wheat. Appearance is pale golden, clear, white head. Taste is wheat, corn, metallic, earthy hops, slightly fruity, dry. Mouthfeel is light body, light crisp carbonation, metallic wheat and slight fruit aftertaste. Overall, not especially kolschy but better than expected.

On tap @ Mudville 9. This is a crystal clear looking, golden colored one - only a little slowly islandy white head in the top. Smells like your average sweetish fruity pilsner really. Green apples and a little bit of peach if I have to say anything. Tastes absolutely drinkable. Could of course be the fact that I�m really thirsty though. It�s thin oily on the mouthfeel and it�s just about average on the small bubbled carbonation. A bit more fruity peaches at first, then it turns really grainy and cerealish toward the finish. I�m sure it wouldn�t taste as good as this if I wasn�t as thirsty as I am right now. 22.06.2015

355ml bottle pours amber in color with a finger of white head that leaves some thin spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma is caramel and light roasted malts with some mild hops. Taste is light caramel malty sweetness with hints of chocolate and some earthy hop bitterness. A decent amber ale that I somewhat enjoyed, but may have been an old bottle.
Had this ber on 9/14/1999. Aroma is a highly sweet malt and honey scent. Color is an amber/orange. Taste is malty rich, with a sweet honey flavor.
One of the best beers I have had in months. I ussually don't like honey beers, but this one has just a slight taste of honey and is a very balanced red beer. Very very good! A+

2010 - 06 - 25 11.5 fl. oz. botlle (app. 330 ml... ??) dark golden colour. no head. stale taste. I don�t understand why nobody rated this since 2003, when I saw a lot of sixpacks at �t drankurgel (a liquor-store in Eindhoven, Netherlands...) taste is like an alcoholfree beer.

Has a golden brown color some carbonation and a sweet malt smell. Taste was light malt and finished with a little watery bitterness. Overall for a $3 6-pack, this stuff is great. I bought it in the 6-pack box so no light was able to spoil the beer.

Eh. Clear bottle, which isn't a good sign. Pours a nice clear golden brown, with a thick whitish head. Aroma smells like it's in the preliminary stages of skunking, but still alright. Just starting to. A little sourness. It actually smells like a golden ale, and tastes like one too. Slightly estery and sweet, more like an ale. Light bodied, effervescent. I guess it's ok, but I won't get it again. Boring.
Nauseating. Smelled like a stagnant pond. I Drank half the bottle. It's all i could take.
No head, no aroma,light blond color.Clear.Tastes corny,pastey.Oh well.......
transparent golden colour, aroma of a danish strong lager (translation: bad), flavor of an ice-beer (same translation as before) - avoid this stuff even if you're very thirsty

A dark golden color, with a medium head. Slight lace. Minimal aroma - faint paper. Some body, but no flavor. Maybe my "buds" have been numbed by the Trois Pistoles. No really nothing there. Where's the Malt? Sure it's balanced, but so is water.

pale blond colour, few creamy head, nice lace, malty, medium hop aroma, smooth and fresh, low carbonation, robust with a late bitter kick, long dry malty finish - looks like a mix between an ale and a pilsner - pleasant
Blond ale, misty. Some nice hop aroma. Light carbonation, good mouth, good malt taste, nice hop balance, lightly sweet. Good hop palate. Beers of Switzerland
cloudy red-amber colour, few head, subtle aroma of caramel and peaches, sweet and quite light-bodied, dry vegetable and floral finish - some qualities but somehow they does not fit very well together
Amber ale, cloudy, thick head. Light hop aroma. Similar to the Blonde, with quite strong caramel taste. Palate more aromatic than the average red beers. Beers of Switzerland
Gold lager, thick head, persistent; no perlage. Very nice hop aroma. Simple body and taste, ordinary palate. Dry. Too cold. Beers of Switzerland
Blond lager, with corn. Strange aroma, indefinable, honeyish and malty. Body not too strong, lightly sweet, poor malt. Ordinary palate. Beers of Switzerland
Gold, cloudy wheat beer. Classic spicy aroma; apple and banana aroma. Nice body, some sweetness, lightly malty; smooth. Ordinary palate. Beers of Switzerland

Drought at Brasseur des Grotes, Geneva. Murky whitish yellow with small white foamy head, strong citric acid aroma, low carbonation, sweetish citrus taste, medium finish with lemon peel aftertaste. Drinkable, but barely.

Pale white, hazy. Definitely a wit. Coriander, citrus. Even some camomile. Soft on the palate. Light and easy. Does have a noticable bitterness, so i wouldnt count it as a coriander lemonade, even though easy to swallow. A bit thin. -- rated with �lankku� (N9)

From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy yellow with a small, dense and white head. Mild farmhouse yeasty dry aroma with a mild wheaty note. Dry spiced and herbal flavoured, vague wheaty sweetness. Mild citrusy finish with a lingering wheaty touch. Ends smooth and medium dry.
hazy pale orange colour, no foam, notes of diacetyl, corn and banana, grapefruit, thin body, sweet and desperately flat
Wheat ale, nice head. Nice malt aroma, yeast, spices. Ordinary taste, some malt, some hop, almonds; dry. Ordinary palate, dry, lightly aromatic, almonds. Beers of Switzerland

Drought at Brasseur des Grotes, Geneva. Clear amber color with creamy off-white head, doughy aroma, low carbonation, caramel-toasted malt taste, abrupt finish. Not better or worse than the other two types available.

Butterscotch, butter. Heavily caramel, a bit like a scottish ale, but just a lot more. Quite drinkable though. Probably the best of what geneva�s craft scene has to offer. Smells like toffee candy, dr �tkers. A nice bitterness to balance. Finish is a bit dry and fading. -- rated with �lankku� (N9)

From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy darkorangeto amber brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is citric fruity, same line infection again. Dry and wooden flavoured,metallic and with a hint of roasted malt. Light bitter and slight acidic finish. Off.
hazy red-amber colour with few foam, discreet aroma of caramel and dark fruits, sweeties-like, sweet and medium-bodied with a moderate malty and slightly fruity finish

Amber ale, misty, nice head. Light malt aroma, but somehow rancid. Some malt (rancid), alcohol, lightly sweet; the hop remains in the background, but it's pleasant. The palate is ordinary, with some hop. Beers of Switzerland

Drought at Brasseur des Grottes. Pale yellow with large creamy off-white head, very little honey aroma, sweetish taste laced with honey, high carbonation, abrupt finish with slight bitterness at the end. Not very remarkable..

Tap. Bright, clear yellow color with a thin white head. Light graininess and some faint grassy hops in the aroma. Touch of maltiness about it in the body, grassy hop (very light) finish. Thinner body and dry finish. Just bland overall, and didn�t care for some of the graininess.
Clear golden with a medium white head. Sweet aroma with malty, caramel and mild hoppy notes. Flavour was malty with grassy hops and hints of caramel. Finished dry and bitter.
On tap at the brewpub. Clear golden, creamy white head. Malty all the way, semi-dry finish. The beer lacks any class, and so does the brewpub that serves it.
Bottle. Very grainy with big clumps of yeast in amber colour and fine head. Fine spicey beer some sweetness.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and highly carbonated yellow with a dense and white head. Aroma is mild acidic and fruity. Flavour has the same fruity and acidic off note. Quite dominant but not unpleasant. Vague smoke infection touch into the finish. Lasting fruity impression.
hazy blond colour, fine head and nice lacing, blood, metallic aroma, medium-bodied, dry unpleasant finish - definitely not at maturation, bad work !

Gold ale, misty, nice head. Light malt and hop aroma, lightly fruity. Full mouth, some malt, dryish, correctly balanced, some hop, the bitterness reminds the abricot almond; the same particular flavour outstands in the palate, enough aromatic and quite long. Beers of Switzerland
20cl from tap. Heineken wasn�t the best pilsener (to say the least) but this one is really rediculous! No added anything at all. Just marketing...
horrible like drinking fizzy water, would nt even drink this if it was free.
Light pale yellow with no head. Sparse aroma...some wheat but not much. Smooth taste...like a light beer. Nothing special about this. Very uninteresting, as Aubry puts it.

Sweet and sugary smelling nose. Entirely headless. Looked like a glass of apple cider. Sticky malt with an under-fermented flavor to it (seemed to contain unfermented fermentables). Easy to swallow, but I suppose that doesn�t necessarily mean anything � good or bad. Didn�t have a whole lot of flavor, or much of a mouthfeel for that matter. No interesting yeast flavors to talk about either. Overall, an uninteresting wheat beer, which would most likely fall under the diverse and vague category, American Wheat.

column1: Fish Tale River Run Organic Rye Ale
column5: Fish Brewing Company--Fish Tale River Run Seasonal Ale--Organic--2002 12 oz. Bottle. 4.50% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Rye Ale--Clear bright light golden color. Light lacy head. Mild rye spice floral hop front. Crisp tangy tart smooth creamy light sweet Pilsner Rye buttery body. Balanced mild hop spice citrus rye end. Tasty Rye. Sampled 5/16/2003. Fish Brewing Company--Fish Tale River Run Seasonal Organic Rye Ale--2001 12 oz. Bottle. 5.00% ABV. (4.5 / 5.0) Rye Ale--Clean bright golden color. Rye spice hints in mild hop front. Light creamy texture. Malty lacy white head. Malty Pale Malt and light Rye body. Crisp sweetness. Mild tang. Dry clean end. Balanced citrus hops. Sampled 6/19/2001.

column1: Fish Tale River Run Organic Rye Ale
column5: Clear pale yellow color with a white head. Initially a cheap pilsner aroma, but developed more honey and spice aromas as it warmed. Spicy hops flavor, with a smokey aftertaste. Fairly thin, bubbly feel.

column1: Fish Tale River Run Organic Rye Ale
column5: Pale yellow color with a small white head. The aroma was, at first, that of a cheap lager. Later, it became more malty sweet with a nice spicy hops character. The flavor was an interesting mix of malty sweetness and spicy hops...with a distinct smoky aftertaste. Soft feel...medium thin consistency.

column1: Fish Tale River Run Organic Rye Ale
column5: I can't say this is a favorite of mine but it isn't to bad a brew.Nice reddish amber color,Aroma was malty and little else to this untrained nose.The taste was pretty decent with a malty start,an almost spicy flavor some hops thrown in there as well.I got kind of a sweet,hoppy,earthy after taste from this one still it was pretty good and my first organic brew to boot.I don't know if it will be a brew that i will frequent but if it's around i won't turn it down.

column1: Fish Tale River Run Organic Rye Ale
column5: The beer pours a hazy �Organic� yellow orange color, the head portly in size, creamy in texture and the color a very light tan, with the lace a thick covering sheet to seal off the glass. Malt aromas weigh heavy in the nose, earthy, with a certain mustiness that is common in organic beers, crisp and fresh, and a real treat for the schnozzle. Begins malt and lightly sweet, the mouth feel is middling, the finish has a light hop spicy bite, the carbonation tolerable and the aftertaste quite dry and long lasting. A fine drinking beer, one that would set well in any location, but with summer coming faster than I�d like a good Arizona Summer Beer.

column1: Fish Tale River Run Organic Rye Ale
column5: My first impression was that this was a horrible pilsner. As the beer warmed, I could taste a fuller malty presence and I noticed yeast floating around in the beer. No huge rye taste present. A n ok beer, but not something I''ll drink again.

column1: Fish Tale River Run Organic Rye Ale
Fish Tale River Run Organic Rye Ale
column5: cloudy with more body than most organics but it tastes like that's all they went for

column1: Fish Tale River Run Organic Rye Ale
column5: really nice pale rye ale. medium body, moderately hopped with some nice spiciness. the rye adds a dry finish and slight tang. well balanced.

column1: Fish Tale River Run Organic Rye Ale
column5: A perfect summer beer, crisp rye flavor with sweet maltiness and nice hop bitterness. light copper color and medium light body, finally a good rye beer!
golden colour, decent hoppiness, clean and full-bodied......................

Disgusting brew, cheaply made beer sold to bums and low income people in dodgy liquor stores. The beer itself is only found in cans and has a stale musky taste that is potent. Not reccommended at all. Stay away from this beer in New Zealand
clear amber colour, light and modest........................................
Really good beer when you have had a few of another style and you get to the point where you don�t even think about the taste. Cheap

do us a favour Independent Breweries, stop making and selling beer that tastes like its been made in a swimming pool then laced with metallic slag. brought an 18 pack of this crap for $25 at pak n save, drank only 6 cans and biffed the rest, disgusting ended up buying some panheads instead which is far better tasting albeit more expensive.
Can from Waiheke Wine Centre on 20 November 2018. Not as bad as I was expecting.

Enormous thanks to Kre�o for lugging this all the way from New Zealand! The can got battered in transport and half of it was spilled through a tiny puncture. It still retained some carbonation when it was opened, so yay there. Will rerate if possible at some point. Anyway, poured a deep amber body, quite nice, traces of a white head. Mild sweetish plum jam and rubber notes in the aroma mingling with a dry graininess. Doesn�t smell bad, only a bit industrial. The taste... ah.. yeah, the same vague mild fruity sweetness, light rubber, over a more or less characterless body, a mild touch of tartness. Vague herbal notes, absolutely no bitterness. Certainly slightly more character than expected from a 4% macro lager, but it�s still very much an industrial 4% lager, with, perhaps, a touch more complex grain bill than normally.
after an earlier lovely porter this was as expected not that good 440ml can smells bit grainy malty taste is mostly caramel malt & water

440ml can of beer for macho men, it appears. Pours amber with a large foamy off-white head. Plenty of sticky lacing is left on the glass. Aroma: light mix of bready malts and herbal hops; a bit floral. Flavor: Mild; good balance although it is sweet up front and mildly bitter by the finish. The hops dominate eventually in the mildly bitter and hoppy aftertaste. Feel: medium-light body; very smooth; good, very soft medium-high carbonation. O: a decent but unremarkable NZ beer.
Cheap beer, poor taste not much can be said about it, try it to see what you think don�t expect a lot from it...
Can. A dark golden beer with a fluffy off-white head. The aroma has notes of metal, malt, and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, metal, and straw. The body is light.
Clear golden with a small short lasting head. Somewhat fruity hops in the nose along with hints of malt. Flavor was somewhat rotten with yeast flaws and caramel.
44 cL bottle, courtesy of Ungstrup. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white and quickly gone head. Aroma is cornish and slight metallic. Cornish and bitter. Slight metallic and dry finish.
I used to like it years ago but I'm not sure if I would rate it so high today ... Anyway, if you love malt liquors, go for it.
Dark brown color. Fudgey, light chocolate in the nose with evident alcohol. The body is sweet and smooth, but not in a good way. Much too much alcohol evident.

Muddy brown. Aroma of pear brandy and other fruits. Lots of alcohol. Fat alcohol tang on the tongue, light plastic notes. I'd like a more developed malt/hop interplay to distract me from the alcohol assault, but worth trying.
Colour of dark tea with few foam. It has an aroma of peat, syrah and honey. The flavour is a mix of acidity and sweetness. The finish is strong and smokey. A complex and very pleasant beer.
Nut brown, pours thick with almost no head. Big unusual marzipan aroma. Malty and sweet, vinuous, almond flavours. Dry finish. A superb, rich, balanced and complex beer.

re-rate 05/18/02: (one year old bottle) The sweetness is now balanced by a nice bitterness. It shows a powerfull alcohol presence. 03/17/02: dark brown colour, few head, nice lace, impressive aroma: dark fruits and hoppy with notes of licorice and a touch of caramel; the flavour does not live up to its aroma and lacks of balance (this beer is probably too young), very sweet; the finish is dry and long with notes of alcohol - warming and showing a great potentiel (I really would like to try it in 3-5 years) but lacks of balance right now.

This beer has a beautiful clear brown colour with few foam. Its aroma is superb, thick with nutty notes. It is robust, full-bodied, powerful with maybe too much alcohol presence. The aftertaste is very long, strong and full of alcohol.

Aged 18 months. Dark ale; the head is not persistent. Light aroma, fruity. Full body, full malt, not too sweet, well balanced by the bitterness and some carbonation acidity; even the high alcohol content is not too strong in the taste. Good palate, enough aromatic. Beers of Switzerland

Dark ale, creamy head (not persistent). Poor aroma. Really balanced mix of malt, sweetness, roasted malt, bitterness; strong body, yet easy to drink. Strong palate, sweet first, then firmly bitter; persistent. Beers of Switzerland

very dark colour, nice head and beautiful lace, nutty aroma with notes of plum, coffee and of course the traditional floral touch "made in B�re-Br�u", full bodied and well-structured with a dry, bitter coffee aftertaste

Cloudy orangeish amber with a large white frothy head. Decent retention. Aroma: wheat bread, banana, light phenols. Light plus body. Fine lively carbonation. Taste: light sweet, fruity, bready, spicy. Low plus bitterness. Highly drinkable especially after a two hours long alpine hike.
Tap, nose is lots of banana, dried banana chips, bubblegum. Palate is slightly flowery, banana, clove. Good weizen.
Tap. Hazy deep golden color with a thick foamy head. Aroma of banana and yeast. A typical, decent Hefeweizen.
Sampled draft at the local pub in Lustenau (Austria). Hazy orange, creamy white. Nose is weird plastic, DE yeast, fish guts, fizzy,� Taste is plastic, wheat, banana, basic but fair fizzy wheat.
Bardzo przyzwoite piwo pszeniczne ze wszystkimi klasycznymi cechami. Jest dro�d�owa chlebowo��, banan, go�dzik. Piwo jest aksamitne i bardzo pijalne. Goryczy brak, delikatna kwa�no��.
Decent Weizen. Quite savory, has grainy flavors, wheat and bread. Just the right think to quench your thirst after skiing for example.
Dark. Ripe fruit, molasses, booze, a bit of earth. Aroma is inviting but the flavor is lagging a bit. Full bodied. Mad decent.

On tap at Hood Canal, pours a cloudy dark amber orangey brown with a small beige head. Aroma brings out caramel and bready malt. Flavour is dry and chemically, with bready malt, some sort of chemically mess, and caramel. This is a total mess. Off-flavours abound. Drain pour.

Draft - Caramel and light raisin, very subdued. Clear copper with a decent beige head. Light sweet caramel, raisin and some bitterness. So much like their ESB on steroids. Not a great interpretation of the style.

Draft at the Collection. How the f do you say that name? Dark clear copper. Cheap raisin and cleaning product aroma. Astringent raisin and lots of cleaning product in flavor. A perfect example of something that is not hop-centric, not malt-centric but just cheap and alcohol rich. Poorly made barleywine, imo.

12 oz bottle courtesy of brewolf. Thanks. Pours a dark amber-brown color with a small beige head that quickly dissipates to a fine film. The aroma is dark fruits, hot sherry and a bit of toffee. The flavor was more toffee, roasted walnuts, dates and some more of that hot sweet sherry. The palate was full and smooth with soft carbonation. Finished long and sticky sweet. Overall: A rather complex little beast of a barley wine and not a bad one at all.

12 oz bottle, cellared about a year and a half. Deep clear brown with a pocked head and lacy rings. Nose is caramel, overripe peach, butter and earth. Medium body, slick and oily, trace carb. Taste initially sweet plum, prune and butterscotch. A citric tang then bitter, dry and vegetal. Maybe infected but enjoyable as a curiosity.

on tap at brouwer�s cafe for hard liver 2010. very dark reddish tint that was gorgeous. dark fruits on the nose, alcohol noticeable, a bit too cloying but had intriguing notes that kept me coming back.

On tap at Brouwer�s Hard Liver 2010. Deep, dark ruby amber with a dense, foamy head. Fruit and caramel malts on the nose � definitely on the sweeter side � with some booze and a mild hop contingent to counter. Smokey meats follow overripe, fermented fruits in the flavor � this stuff would be killer with a plate of fresh beef jerky, and that note doesn�t come through at all in the aroma. Thick, full mouthfeel. Slightly boozy, slightly sticky� with some acetyl on the finish. Nice.

2009. On draft at Hard Liver. Deep, dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma of candied fruits and caramel. Likewise with the taste: very sweet dried fruit and a heavy, heavy dose of malt sweetness. The only flavors here are cloying malt and sweet candied fruit. Maybe ideal for some, but not for me.

draft at the brewery. pours a deep ebony with coppery edges. dense, creamy tan head that fades quickly away. loose stringy lace. rich datey, figgy nose with tangy molasses and brown sugar undertones. creamy medium body. rich fruity sugary mid palate...dates, figs, shortbread, black bread. lingering sweet finish. tasty. does not seem bugged. yay!

column1: Fish Tale Old Woody English Old Ale
column5: Pours a deep amber with off-white hea. Chewy-like malty sweet aroma. Syrupy sweet with a toch of smoke character. Notes: on tap GABF week '16

column1: Fish Tale Old Woody English Old Ale
column5: Backlog rating of 2-3 year old 2005 bottle. Cloudy red, low creamy head. Wooden herbal Honeyish nose. Wooden dry, vanilla, cigars. Medium body, sparkly mouthfeel. Honeyish retronasal.

column1: Fish Tale Old Woody English Old Ale
column5: Winter Beer Fest 2016, Seattle. Brown-tan, small foam. Rich leathery brown. Lovely sweet, rich, barleywine-like. Good smoky malt note. Fairly fresh, bright carb and green hop. Really quite nice.

column1: Fish Tale Old Woody English Old Ale
column5: Pours hazy, barely translucent copper with a thin buff head. Aroma features bourbon, woody, toasted malt, and subtle caramel notes. Flavor offers malty, pomme fruit, bourbon and woody tones. Mouthfeel delivers firm body and good fizz. No fish tale this!

column1: Fish Tale Old Woody English Old Ale
column5: Pours a dark reddish brown color. Aromas of wood, dark fruit, and some sweetness. Flavors of whiskey?, caramel, and some faint hops.

column1: Fish Tale Old Woody English Old Ale
column5: Bottle shared by mcbackus!!!! Nose is slightly oxidized in a sherry way. Pours an amber brown, completely flat. Taste is a chewy raisin and sugary sweet. Very good for bring 8 years old or however.

column1: Fish Tale Old Woody English Old Ale
column5: Roughly 2006 vintage, give or take. Fairly clear, amber color, minimal head. Big caramel, malty, boozy, sweet, more caramel. Very sweet, boozy, sweet, caramel, toasty melanoidans, maple syrup flavor.

column1: Fish Tale Old Woody English Old Ale
column5: Bottle �08 vintage. Clear amber pour with no head. Caramel malt aromas. Lots of caramel. Uber thin body. Watery and bland with no soul. What a disappointment.

column1: Fish Tale Old Woody English Old Ale
column5: 355ml bottle pours a pale orangey amber color with a small white head that leaves virtually no lacing on the glass. Aroma is oak with some dark fruits and sweet malts. Taste is dominated by sweet malts and dark fruits with a mild hop presence. Heavy bodied with some mild carbonation leaving the palate with a full balance of flavors. Has many qualities of an English barley wine and is quite satisfactory.

column1: Fish Tale Old Woody English Old Ale
column5: 2008 bottle from brewolf...thanks Micheal! - Pours hazy rosy amber with only a tiny ring of white head. Herbal hops still there on the nose with a sweet boozy breadiness. Taste is big nutty bread malt and light bourbon/caramel sweetness. A decent amount of oakiness in the finish. Very little carbonation with lots of slickness. Still pretty soft, but full-bodied. Pretty good, even though I�m not into big beers right now.
Bottle (as Beltza). Black colour with small tan head. Roasted, chocolate and coffee aroma. Chocolate, roasted taste, slightly sweet. Medium body.

Dark but not quite dark color wit a small, white head. ,Chocolate nose. Too watery, with some carbon and thick texture, Taste is sweet and bitter. Palate is some coffee or chicory, without clear impressions. B@H

Botella verde de 330ml. Vaso Nonic. Brota con color marr�n muy oscuro y coronada por una capa bronceada que se disipa con rapidez. Aromas torrefactos y de caf� con trazos agrios. Sabores de levadura y algo avinados. Cuerpo ligero y carbonataci�n moderada/alta. La textura cremosa se torna aguada. En el intermedio, amargor floral bastante contundente, matices de regaliz, leve toque tart�rico y notas de bac�n quemado. Final amargo y seco. Retrogusto reseco con recuerdos de grano de caf�. 330ml green bottle. Nonic glass. Pours very dark brown in color, headed by quickly dissipated & tan crown. Roasted, coffee aromas & sour hues. Yeasty, vinious-like flavors. Light body. Moderate to high carbonation. Creamy to watery texture. Quite sharp floral bitterness, hints of licorice, slight sour touch & roasted bacon notes in the middle. Dry bitter finish. Dried aftertaste with coffee grain memories.
Bottle @ Porterhouse Dublin. This is a very dry stout but it has a nice flavor complexity.

Bottle. Dark brown liquid with a small beige head. Roasted malts in the aroma. Light body, little bit watery. Roasted malts, milk chocolate, lactose sweetness in mouth. Some years ago it was a better beer but still the best stout in every Basque supermarket.
Bottle at Pension Ondarra, San Sebastian. Clear dark dark brown - light brown head. Sweet malty, fruity, cocoa, chocolate, roasted malts, light bitterness. Simple and a bit thin.

Bottle at restaurant in Brussels. Pours a dark brown to black colour with a small beige head. Pretty sweet aroma of chocolate, leather, and some licorice and lactose. Flavours of roasted malt, coffee, leather and dark wood. Has a slick but surprisingly thin mouthfeel, and a very light bitterness. The aroma is good but disappoints from the first sip. Way too thin on the palate.
Bottle. Black pour, thin off-white head. Aroma is buttery cream, slightly roasty, caramel. Flavor is slightly sweet caramel roasted and smooth. Quite soft and a bit of diacetyl.

330ml bottle. Pours a dark brown, with a brown head. Spicy, roasted aroma, malt, chocolate, coffee, licorice. Dry, medium body and bitterness, balanced CO2. Roasted, malty taste, ashes, coffee, licorice, caramel, fudge. Dry, astringent finish. Not bad. (2012-06-07)
Bottle in Bilbao bar Dark colored, some foam Medium body & complexity AN ok beer
Pours hazy amber with two finger, white head. Aroma is dried fruit, caramel and lacto. Taste is plum and light caramel, moving to tartness, clove and wheat. Finish is tart plum. A good hefe
Geruch recht fruchtig, leicht s��lich. Geschmacklich auch (vergoren) fruchtig, s��lich, getreidig. Etwas zu s�urebetont. Nicht so ganz harmonisch, aber durchaus interessant und gut trinkbar.

Pours hazy orange gold with a thick white head. Aroma of bananas and cloves. Taste has orange, banana, nutmeg. Palate contains much of the same with an extended citrus element, unusual for the style but good in that it accents the spice notes. Fantastic Hef.
Tap at Arcotel, Vienna, 13th March 19. Pours cloudy and yellow. Aroma is wheaty, citrus, light banana. Taste is light spice, wheat, citrus. I liked this.
One pint bottle. Pours a cloudy gold with a big white head. Nice big lemon and wit banana scents. Good flavors of wheat and light sours and a broad malty finish. Mild carbonation and a dry finish.
Bottle from supermarket in Italy. Hazy yellow color, white head. Wheat, banana, yeast,. Not bad
Sehr Cremig Mild und zart im Mund, geschmacklich ein Traum �ber Banane und leicht Fruchtig
Draft. Hazy golden body with white large lasting head. Aroma is fruity mostly ripe fruits and bananas. Taste is nearly the same but with some herbs and yeast. Aftertaste is sweet malty. Nice weizen.
Bottle pour cloudy yellow and near perfect milk white head. Clove, cream, banana, floral, spiced malt and yeast. Creamy and smooth. Refreshing AF. A good hefe.
Originally rated using the RateBeer application on my phone. For some reason errors erased my notes and made it a tick. I no longer have the reference notes.

clear blond colour, almost transparent, fine creamy head which quickly disappears, nice lace, deep perfumy aroma, touch of spices (ginger ?) and orange, very smooth, low carbonation, sweet with a short fruity finish (apricot?) - easy and lacking of character
Pale gold. Very good malts. Fairly well-balanced, decent hoppiness. Has some caramel.

column1: Jacks Mountain Black Jack Oatmeal Stout
column5: Pours dark with small tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and hops. Flavor was too hoppy for my liking, coffee, and roast, good body, good brew.

column1: Jacks Mountain Black Jack Oatmeal Stout
column5: A good oatmeal stout, went great with my delicious ribs, but I'd take a Sammy Smith any day over this.

It's always a pleasure to discover a new brewery, especially one with some good beers. Jacks Winter Warmer was quite good, a nice strong, spiced yet refreshing weizen bock. Great aroma of bananas and spices such as nutmeg, and a nice purplish color. Taste was quite impressive, although it is not nearly as good as the Moonglow Weizenbock from Victory. Tasted very much like a wheat beer with a hint of spice. Overall very good and quite worth the half hour drive to get there.

As far as I know, the only place you can get this beer is the Sidetrack bar in Ypsilanti, Michigan. The bar is remarkable - solid beer selection, outstanding food, great atmosphere, but the beer is a little humdrum, not much more than the nice red color, really.
